('27', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. INTERVIEW TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('27', 0, 2, 3, 81) [SASSOON HOSPITAL, POONA, January 12, 1924]
('27', 0, 3, 4, 125) Dr. V. B. Gokhale came to me about 8 45 p.m.
('27', 0, 3, 5, 170) just as I was finishing my dinner; he told me how the Yeravda authorities had removed Mr. Gandhi to the Sassoon Hospital, where he was in charge.
('27', 0, 3, 6, 316) He was about to be operated for appendicitis.
('27', 0, 4, 7, 362) On my entering the room, we greeted each other and I enquired how he felt as to the operation.
('27', 0, 4, 8, 457) He answered firmly that the doctors had come to a definite conclusion and he was content to abide by it, and in reply to further inquiry, he said that he had full confidence in the medical men about him and that they had been very kind and very careful.
('27', 0, 4, 9, 711) Should there arise any public agitation, he added that it should be made known that he had no complaint whatever to make against the authorities and that so far as the care of his body went, their treatment left nothing to be desired.
('27', 0, 4, 10, 946) Then I enquired if Mrs. Gandhi had been informed of his condition.
('27', 0, 4, 11, 1013) He said that she did not know the latest development, but she knew that for sometime he had not been well and he expected to hear from her.
('27', 0, 4, 12, 1153) He then made inquiries of my wife and of my colleagues in the Servants of India Society, viz., Messrs Devadhar, Joshi, Patwardhan and Kunzru.
('27', 0, 4, 13, 1295) He asked: Have your frequent journeys out of India benefited your health?
('27', 0, 5, 14, 1369) Doctor Phatak then read a draft statement to be signed by Mr. Gandhi conveying his consent to the operation.
('27', 0, 5, 15, 1478) After hearing it once, Mr. Gandhi put on his spectacles and read it himself.
('27', 0, 5, 16, 1555) Then he said he would like the wording to be changed and asked Col.
('27', 0, 5, 17, 1623) Maddock who was in the room what he thought.
('27', 0, 5, 18, 1668) The Colonel said Mr. Gandhi knew best how to put it in appropriate language.
('27', 0, 5, 19, 1745) His own suggestion would [not] be of much value.
('27', 0, 6, 20, 1794) Then he dictated a lengthy statement 1 which I took down in pencil.
('27', 0, 7, 21, 1862) When it was finished, I read it out to him once.
('27', 0, 7, 22, 1911) Then he called Col.
('27', 0, 7, 23, 1931) Maddock to his side and I read it again at his desire.
('27', 0, 7, 24, 1986) Maddock was quite satisfied and remarked: “Of course you know best how to put in proper language.” He then drew up his proper posture for signing the paper, which he did in pencil.
('27', 0, 7, 25, 2167) His hand shook very much and I noticed that he did not dot the “i”.
('27', 0, 7, 26, 2235) At the end he remarked to the doctor: See how my hand trembles.
('27', 0, 7, 27, 2299) You will have to put this right.
('27', 0, 8, 28, 2332) Maddock answered: “Oh !
('27', 0, 8, 29, 2356) We will put tons and tons of strength into you.”
('27', 0, 9, 30, 2405) As the operation room was being got ready, the doctors went out and I found myself nearly alone with the Mahatma.
('27', 0, 9, 31, 2519) After a remark or two of a purely personal nature, I asked him whether he had anything particular to say.
('27', 0, 9, 32, 2625) I noticed a touch of eagerness as he replied as though he was waiting for an opportunity to say something.
('27', 0, 10, 33, 2732) 1 The following item
('27', 1, 0, 1, 2753) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 2
('27', 1, 1, 2, 2793) If there is an agitation for my release after the operation, which I do not wish, let it be on proper lines.
('27', 1, 1, 3, 2902) My quarrel with the Govern ment is there and will continue so long as the originating causes exist.
('27', 1, 1, 4, 3002) Of course, there cannot be any conditions.
('27', 1, 1, 5, 3045) If the Government think they have kept me long enough, they may let me go, that would be honorable if they think I am an innocent man and that my motives have been good.
('27', 1, 1, 6, 3215) While I have a deep quarrel with the Government, I love the Englishmen and have many friends amongst them.
('27', 1, 1, 7, 3322) They may release me.
('27', 1, 1, 8, 3343) But it must not be on false issues.
('27', 1, 1, 9, 3379) Any agitation must be kept on proper, non violent lines.
('27', 1, 1, 10, 3436) Perhaps, I have not expressed myself quite well, but you had better put it in your own inimitable style.
('27', 1, 2, 11, 3541) I then pressed him again for a message to his people, his followers or the country.
('27', 1, 2, 12, 3625) He was surprisingly firm on this subject.
('27', 1, 2, 13, 3667) He said he was a prisoner of Government and he must observe the prisoner’s code of honour scrupulously.
('27', 1, 2, 14, 3771) He was supposed to be civilly dead.
('27', 1, 2, 15, 3807) He had no knowledge of outside events and he could not have anything to do with the public.
('27', 1, 2, 16, 3899) He had no message.
('27', 1, 3, 17, 3918) “How is it then that Mr. Mahomed Ali communicated a message as from you the other day?” The words were scarcely out of my mouth when I regretted them, but recall was impossible.
('27', 1, 4, 18, 4096) He was obviously astonished at my question, and exclaimed.: Mr. Mahomed Ali !
('27', 1, 4, 19, 4174) A message from me !
('27', 1, 5, 20, 4194) Briskly, at this point, the nurse came in with some articles of apparel for him, and signalled to me to depart.
('27', 1, 5, 21, 4306) In a few minutes, he was shifted to the operation room.
('27', 1, 5, 22, 4362) I sat outside marvelling at the exhibition I had witnessed of high mindedness, forgiveness, chivalry and love transcending ordinary human nature, and what a mercy it was that the non co operation movement should have had a leader of such serene vision and sensitiveness to honour.
('27', 1, 6, 23, 4643) I have read out this statement to Dr. Phatak who approves of it and adds that his inquiry as to a message elicited the same sort of answers.
('27', 1, 7, 24, 4784) The Hindu, 14 1 1924
('27', 1, 8, 25, 4805) 1 Vide however, “Message to Mahomed Ali”, 10 9 1923.

('27', 2, 1, 2, 4900) 2. LETTER TO COL.
('27', 2, 1, 3, 4918) MADDOCK 1
('27', 2, 2, 4, 4928) SASSOON HOSPITAL, Poona, 9.45 p.
('27', 2, 2, 5, 4961) m., January 12,1924 2
('27', 2, 3, 6, 4983) DEAR COL.
('27', 2, 3, 7, 4993) MADDOCK, I know that you know the history of my illness during the past 6 months.
('27', 2, 3, 8, 5075) You have been extraordinarily kind to me.
('27', 2, 3, 9, 5117) You, the Surgeon General and other medical gentlemen have come to the conclusion that any delay in performing the operation described by you to me involves considerable risk.
('27', 2, 3, 10, 5292) You were kind enough to tell me that Government had authorized you to send for any of my special medical friends.
('27', 2, 3, 11, 5406) I therefore suggested the names of Dr. Dalal and Dr. Jivraj Mehta.
('27', 2, 3, 12, 5473) You have tried your utmost to secure their presence.
('27', 2, 3, 13, 5526) But then you have not been able to get at either of them.
('27', 2, 3, 14, 5584) I have the fullest confidence in you and regard being had to the serious nature of the case I would ask you please to go on with the operation without delay.
('27', 2, 5, 15, 5742) Yours sincerely
('27', 2, 6, 16, 5758) From a photostat: S.N. 8121
('27', 2, 7, 17, 5786) MESSAGE TO THE COUNTRY 3
('27', 2, 8, 18, 5811) January 14, 1924 I am deeply touched by manifestation of deep affection shown to me by my countrymen during the critical period of my health.
('27', 2, 8, 19, 5953) They need have no anxiety because every possible attention is being given me by medical authorities here.
('27', 2, 8, 20, 6059) Young India, 17 1 1924
('27', 2, 9, 21, 6082) 1 This was also published in The Hindu, 20 1 1924 and The Searchlight, 25 1 1924. 2 The message, given to Dr. Phatak in response to anxious inquiries from all over the country, was first published in The Bombay Chronicle, 15 1 1924. Young India reproduced it with a short editorial note under the caption, “The Nation in Agony”.
('27', 2, 9, 22, 6411) 3 The source gives the date as January 19, obviously a slip.
('27', 2, 9, 23, 6472) Gandhiji was operated upon for appendicitis on January 12.
('27', 3, 0, 1, 6531) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 4
('27', 3, 1, 2, 6571) 4. INTERVIEW TO “ THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('27', 3, 2, 3, 6611) POONA, January 19, 1924 The jail authorities cannot be blamed.
('27', 3, 2, 4, 6674) Our fight must be clean.
('27', 3, 2, 5, 6699) Appendicitis is a difficult disease to diagnose.
('27', 3, 2, 6, 6748) Murray is one of the best men I have met.
('27', 3, 2, 7, 6790) He has been very kind to me.
('27', 3, 2, 8, 6819) He is conscientious, considerate and kind.
('27', 3, 2, 9, 6862) I hold the highest opinion about him.
('27', 3, 2, 10, 6900) The Searchlight, 27 1 1924
('27', 3, 3, 11, 6927) 5. INTERVIEW TO DILIP KUMAR ROY 1
('27', 3, 4, 12, 6961) February 2, 1924
('27', 3, 5, 13, 6978) Our conversation having that morning centered round music, Mahatmaji told me in passing how fond he really was of music even though he could not boast of the power of any expert for analytic appreciation.
('27', 3, 5, 14, 7183) He had said: I am so found of music that once, while I was in a South African Hospital and ailing from a bruise on my upper lip, I felt greatly soothed as the daughter of a friend of mine sang the song ‘Lead, Kindly Light’ at my request.
('27', 3, 6, 15, 7421) On my asking him if he knew any of the beautiful songs of Mirabai, he said: Yes, I have heard a good many of them.
('27', 3, 6, 16, 7536) They are so beautiful.
('27', 3, 6, 17, 7559) It’s because they come from the heart and not from any desire to compose or to please a public.
('27', 3, 7, 18, 7655) I called the same evening at his request.
('27', 3, 7, 19, 7697) After the music, I saw that it had affected him visibly.
('27', 3, 7, 20, 7754) For I thought I saw his eyes glisten even in that none too bright light of the hospital.
('27', 3, 8, 21, 7843) “I feel” said I after a short pause, “that our beautiful music has been sadly neglected in the schools and colleges.” Mahatmaji replied: Yes, it has, I have always said so.
('27', 3, 9, 22, 8016) Srijut Mahadeo Desai who was present throughout our conversation
('27', 3, 10, 23, 8081) 1 The interview between Gandhiji and Roy, an exponent of Indian music and inmate of the Aurobindo Ashram, Pondicherry, took place at the Sassoon Hosptial.
('27', 3, 10, 24, 8236) The extract given here is from a report which was also reproduced in The Hindu, 7 2 1924, and later, featured in Roy’s book Among the Great, Jaico Publishing House, Bombay.
('27', 3, 10, 25, 8409) According to the author, Gandhiji had revised the reports of the talks and authorized him to publish them in the book.
('27', 4, 0, 1, 8528) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 5
('27', 4, 1, 2, 8570) corroborated this.
('27', 4, 1, 3, 8589) “I am glad to hear you say so.
('27', 4, 1, 4, 8620) Because I have been all along under the impression that you would be against all arts such as music.” I !
('27', 4, 1, 5, 8726) Against music!
('27', 4, 1, 6, 8741) Well, I know, I know.
('27', 4, 1, 7, 8763) There are so many superstitions rife about me that it has become now almost impossible for me to overtake those who have set them afloat.
('27', 4, 1, 8, 8901) As a result, my friends only smile at me when I try to lay any claim to being an artist myself.
('27', 4, 2, 9, 8997) “I am glad to hear this; because I have been given to understand that in your philosophy of life, which is one of unqualified asceticism, arts like music can hardly aspire to any place.” Mahatmaji emphatically said: But I maintain that asceticism is the greatest art in life.
('27', 4, 3, 10, 9273) “What I however meant by art just now is a somewhat different activity such as music or painting or sculpture for the matter of that.
('27', 4, 3, 11, 9407) And I had thought that you would be rather opposed to them than otherwise.” Mahatma said: I, opposed to arts like music!
('27', 4, 3, 12, 9528) Why, I cannot even conceive of an evolution of the religious life of India without music.
('27', 4, 3, 13, 9618) I do say I am a lover of music as well as the other arts.
('27', 4, 3, 14, 9676) Only, my values may be different from the accepted ones, that’s all.
('27', 4, 3, 15, 9745) I am doubtless against much that passes for art in these days.
('27', 4, 3, 16, 9808) I do not for instance call that art which demands an intimate knowledge of its technique for its appreciation.
('27', 4, 3, 17, 9919) If you go to the Satyagraha Ashram, you will find the walls bare.
('27', 4, 3, 18, 9985) And my friends object to this.
('27', 4, 3, 19, 10016) I admit I don’t have paintings on the walls of my Ashram.
('27', 4, 3, 20, 10074) But that is because I think that the walls are meant for sheltering us, and not because I am opposed to art as such.
('27', 4, 3, 21, 10191) For have I not gazed and gazed at the wonderful vault of the starry skyhardly ever tiring of the same?
('27', 4, 3, 22, 10295) And I do say that I can never conceive of any painting superior to the star studded sky in its satisfying effect on the mind.
('27', 4, 3, 23, 10421) It has bewildered me, mystified me sent me into the most wonderful ecstatic thrills imaginable.
('27', 4, 3, 24, 10518) Side by side with this wondrous mystery of God’s artistic handiwork, does not that of man appear to be the merest tinsel?
('27', 4, 4, 25, 10640) I said: “ I agree with you when you say that Nature is a great artist, as also when you inveigh against the regrettable prostitution of art, which unhappily so often passes for art.
('27', 4, 4, 26, 10822) I differ also from those artists who have acquired the habit of saying that art is even greater than life.” Exactly.
('27', 4, 4, 27, 10939) Life is and must always be greater than all the arts put together.
('27', 4, 4, 28, 11006) I go still further.
('27', 4, 4, 29, 11026) For I say that he is the greatest artist who leads the best life.
('27', 4, 4, 30, 11092) For what is art without the background and setting of a worthy life?
('27', 4, 4, 31, 11161) An art is to be valued only when it ennobles life.
('27', 4, 4, 32, 11212) I object emphatically only when people say that art is everything, that it does
('27', 5, 0, 1, 11292) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 6
('27', 5, 1, 2, 11332) not matter even if life has to be held subservient to its (i.e., art’s ) fulfilment.
('27', 5, 1, 3, 11417) I have then to say that my values are different, that is all.
('27', 5, 1, 4, 11479) But fancy people saying that I am opposed to all arts on that account !
('27', 5, 1, 5, 11551) The Bombay Chronicle, 5 2 1924
('27', 5, 2, 6, 11582) 6. INTERVIEW TO “ YUGA DHARMA” 1
('27', 5, 3, 7, 11615) [Before February 5, 1924]
('27', 5, 4, 8, 11641) Dr. Sumant enquired of Mahatmaji how it was that such a disease could attack a man like him who was self restricted sanyams.
('27', 5, 4, 9, 11766) Mahatmaji replied that though he was moderate in food for many year, he had not yet been abstemious as he ought to have been.
('27', 5, 4, 10, 11892) Mahatmaji said: I am sure that my body does not need much food.
('27', 5, 4, 11, 11956) In fact, very little food is required when one has to undergo mental work and a good deal of concentration.
('27', 5, 4, 12, 12064) Perhaps my weight might have been decreased by being abstemious.
('27', 5, 4, 13, 12129) But my body would have been surely improved.
('27', 5, 5, 14, 12174) Mahatmaji was of opinion that there was no necessity of pulse as food for those who were used to brain work.
('27', 5, 5, 15, 12283) As regards the amelioration of the depressed classes, Mahatmaji expressed the necessity of working in the villages by encamping there.
('27', 5, 5, 16, 12418) He did not at all believe the rumour that there was a depression in the workers of Gujarat.
('27', 5, 5, 17, 12510) In a further conversation Mahatmaji said: I have plunged into politics simply in search of Truth.
('27', 5, 5, 18, 12608) When I went to jail, I had fixed my programme for full six years.
('27', 5, 5, 19, 12674) I have dictated a little about South Africa to Indulal, but my thoughts about the Gita are still to be dictated and I want to show how to epitomize the Mahabharata.
('27', 5, 5, 20, 12839) I also think of writing my autobiography.
('27', 5, 5, 21, 12881) Still I have to do much.
('27', 5, 6, 22, 12906) On Dr. Sumant commenting on the new Labour Government in England by saying that there were still people who hoped to get sweets from the Labour Government, Mahatmaji answered with a rather grave voice: People do not leave off the hope of getting help from outside.
('27', 5, 6, 23, 13171) Who can give swaraj?
('27', 5, 6, 24, 13192) We have to take it.
('27', 5, 6, 25, 13212) What about the depressed classes and what about solving the problem of Hindu Muslim unity?
('27', 5, 6, 26, 13303) What help can the Labour Government give you as regards these questions?
('27', 5, 6, 27, 13376) Your future lies in your own hands.
('27', 5, 6, 28, 13412) If you get sweet balls, they will be made of stones.
('27', 5, 6, 29, 13465) The Hindu, 18 2 1924
('27', 5, 7, 30, 13486) 1 Dr. Sumant Mehta, editor of the Gujarati magazine published from Ahmedabad, called on Gandhiji at the Sassoon Hospital before release.
('27', 6, 0, 1, 13623) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 7
('27', 6, 1, 2, 13665) 7. ANSWERS TO DREW PEARSON’S QUESTIONS 1
('27', 6, 2, 3, 13706) [After February 5, 1924] 2
('27', 6, 3, 4, 13733) Mr. Gandhi is recuperating in the mountain air of Poona, just a few miles from
('27', 6, 4, 5, 13812) Yeravda prison in which two years of confinement so broke his health that
('27', 6, 5, 6, 13886) unconditional release by the British Government was necessary.
('27', 6, 6, 7, 13949) His first statement, when interviewed, was: I shall resume my activities for the attainment of swaraj just as soon as I am restored to complete health.
('27', 6, 7, 8, 14101) What course would he take?
('27', 6, 7, 9, 14128) He answered quietly: I still believe it possible for India to remain within the British Empire.
('27', 6, 7, 10, 14224) I still put implicit faith in non violence, which, if strictly followed by India, will invoke the best in the British people.
('27', 6, 7, 11, 14350) My hope for the attainment of swaraj by non violence is based upon an immutable belief in the goodness which exists deep down in all human nature.
('27', 6, 7, 12, 14497) I have always maintained that India had no quarrel with the
('27', 6, 8, 13, 14557) 1 In a letter of March 26, 1924 from New York, to Devdas Gandhi, Drew Pearson threw light on the manner in which the script of the “interview” was prepared for release.
('27', 6, 8, 14, 14726) Enclosing “the copy of the interview with father which you so kindly cabled me recently,” Pearson went on to write, “You will note that the editor has taken certain privileges with the interview by dating it as cabled from India.
('27', 6, 8, 15, 14956) My original article explains that the interview was cabled by you.
('27', 6, 8, 16, 15023) The interview appeared in about 50 papers in the United States, the list of which I enclose, together with 8 papers in Australia and New Zealand, 3 in Japan and China, 4 in Canada and was sent to other papers in Brazil, Argentine, Chile, Mexico, Cuba, South Africa and Hawaii.
('27', 6, 8, 17, 15300) You will note that I have enlarged a little bit on your skeletonized cable.
('27', 6, 8, 18, 15376) In such places where you referred to the fact that your father’s views do not change, I looked up his views as recorded in speeches and clippings from Young India and used such as a basis for enlarging the interview.
('27', 6, 8, 19, 15593) I did this rather in a hurry and there was not time for your approval, but I trust it will be satisfactory for you.” Acknowledging Devdas Gandhi’s letter of March 7, Pearson wrote again on April 15, thanking him for his “trouble and thoughtfulness in telegraphing the message from your father.
('27', 6, 8, 20, 15887) As I told you in an earlier letter, it was published widely all over the United States.
('27', 6, 8, 21, 15975) I trust your father did not object to my quoting from his past speeches and writings.
('27', 6, 8, 22, 16061) The telegram arrived in its original form without censorship.” Earlier, Drew Pearson had sought Sir George Lloyd’s permission to visit Gandhiji in jail, which was refused.
('27', 6, 8, 23, 16233) For an account of his interview with the Gover nor, vide Appendix “Drew Pearson’s Interview with Sir George Lloyd”, 22 11 1923. 2 The answers were obviously given after Gandhiji’s release on this date.
('27', 7, 0, 1, 16435) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 8
('27', 7, 1, 2, 16475) English.
('27', 7, 1, 3, 16484) Jesus denounced the wickedness of the Scribes and Pharisees, but he did not hate them.
('27', 7, 1, 4, 16571) So we need not hate Englishmen, though we hate the system they have established.
('27', 7, 1, 5, 16652) They have given India a system based upon force, by which they can feel secure only in the shadow of their forts and guns.
('27', 7, 1, 6, 16775) We Indians, in turn, hope by our conduct to demonstrate to every Englishman that he is as safe in the remotest corner of India as he professes to feel behind the machine gun.
('27', 7, 2, 7, 16950) What do yon mean by swaraj?
('27', 7, 2, 8, 16978) A full partnership for India with other parts of the Empire, just the same as Canada, South Africa and Australia enjoy.
('27', 7, 2, 9, 17098) Nor shall we be satisfied until we obtain full citizens’ rights throughout the British Dominions for all the King’s subjects, irrespective of caste, colour or creed.
('27', 7, 3, 10, 17264) I asked Mr. Gandhi if he still believed in boycotting the Councils.
('27', 7, 3, 11, 17332) Yes, I still believe that we should not participate in the Councils until Britain suffers a change of heart and acts squarely with us.
('27', 7, 3, 12, 17467) However, I do not wish to express any opinion on the action of the Nationalist party in participating in the Councils, until I have talked with the leaders.
('27', 7, 3, 13, 17624) This I have already started to do.
('27', 7, 4, 14, 17659) When asked if imprisonment had changed his views on politics and religion, Mr. Gandhi replied: They have undergone no change, but have been confirmed by two years of solitude and introspection.
('27', 7, 4, 15, 17853) I have been experimenting with myself and friends by introducing religion into politics, and now I believe they cannot be divorced.
('27', 7, 4, 16, 17985) Let me explain what I mean by religion.
('27', 7, 4, 17, 18025) It is not Hinduism, which I prize most highly, but the religion which transcends Hinduismthe basic truth which underlies all the religions of the world.
('27', 7, 4, 18, 18179) It is the struggle for truthfor self expression.
('27', 7, 4, 19, 18229) I call it the truthforce the permanent element in human nature, constantly struggling to find itself, to know its Maker.
('27', 7, 4, 20, 18351) This is religion.
('27', 7, 4, 21, 18369) I believe that politics cannot be divorced from religion.
('27', 7, 4, 22, 18427) My politics can be summed up in two wordsnon violent non co operation.
('27', 7, 4, 23, 18499) And the roots of non co operation are buried in the religions of the world.
('27', 7, 4, 24, 18575) Christ refused to co operate with the Scribes and Pharisees.
('27', 7, 4, 25, 18636) Buddha fearlessly refused to co operate with the arrogant priesthood of his day.
('27', 7, 4, 26, 18717) Mahomed, Confucius, most of our great prophets have been non co operators.
('27', 7, 4, 27, 18792) I simply and humbly follow in their footsteps.
('27', 7, 4, 28, 18839) Non co operation means nothing less than training in self
('27', 8, 0, 1, 18897) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 9
('27', 8, 1, 2, 18939) sacrifice.
('27', 8, 1, 3, 18950) And this again was practiced by the great teachers of the world.
('27', 8, 1, 4, 19015) Strength does not come from physical capacity.
('27', 8, 1, 5, 19062) It comes from indomitable will.
('27', 8, 1, 6, 19094) I have ventured to place before India the ancient law of self sacrifice the obedience to the strength of the spirit.
('27', 8, 1, 7, 19211) By non violence I do not mean cowardice.
('27', 8, 1, 8, 19252) I do believe that, where there is only a choice between cowardice and violence, I would advise violence.
('27', 8, 1, 9, 19357) But I believe that forgiveness adorns a soldier.
('27', 8, 1, 10, 19406) And so I am not pleading for India to practise non violence because she is weak, but because she is conscious of her power and strength.
('27', 8, 1, 11, 19543) The rishis, who discovered the law of non violence, were greater geniuses than Newton.
('27', 8, 1, 12, 19630) Having themselves known the use of arms, they realized their uselessness and taught a weary world that its salvation lay not through violence, but through non violence.
('27', 8, 1, 13, 19799) Therefore, I respectfully invite Americans to study carefully the Indian National Movement and they will therein find an effective substitute for war.
('27', 8, 2, 14, 19950) Before his imprisonment Mr. Gandhi was a most severe critic of modern civilization and I asked if his views had suffered any change.
('27', 8, 2, 15, 20083) They remain unchanged.
('27', 8, 2, 16, 20106) My opinion of modern civilization is that it is a worship of materialism, resulting in the exploitation of the weak by the strong.
('27', 8, 2, 17, 20237) American wealth has become the standard.
('27', 8, 2, 18, 20278) The United States is the envy of all other nations.
('27', 8, 2, 19, 20330) Meanwhile, moral growth has become stunted and progress measured in pounds, shillings and pence.
('27', 8, 2, 20, 20427) This land of ours, we are told, was once the abode of the gods.
('27', 8, 2, 21, 20491) But it is not possible to conceive of gods inhabiting a land which is made hideous by the smoke and din of mill chimneys and factories, and whose roadways are traversed by rushing engines, dragging cars crowded with men who know not for the most part what they are after, do not care, and whose tempers do not improve by being uncom fortably packed together like sardines in boxes.
('27', 8, 2, 22, 20873) Factories have risen on the corpses of men, women and children to create what we call civilization.
('27', 8, 3, 23, 20973) When asked for his opinion on the action of the Supreme Court in barring Indians from United States citizenship, Mr. Gandhi replied that he deplored the decision, and considered it due to American ignorance of India’s civilization and its possibilities.
('27', 8, 4, 24, 21227) Finally, when reminded of the fact that all India worshipped him as a “saint”, that thousands of children were being named “Gandhidas”, that wreaths were daily
('27', 9, 0, 1, 21387) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 10
('27', 9, 1, 2, 21428) freshened over his pictures in millions of homes throughout India, Mr. Gandhi replied simply: I think that word “saint” should be ruled out of present life.
('27', 9, 1, 3, 21585) It is too sacred a word to be lightly applied to anybody, much less to one like myself, who claims only to be a humble searcher after Truth.

('27', 10, 3, 9, 24179) 11. LETTER TO MAHOMED ALI 1
('27', 10, 4, 10, 24207) SASSOON HOSPITAL, POONA, February 7, 1924
('27', 10, 5, 11, 24249) MY DEAR FRIEND AND BROTHER, I send you as President of the Congress a few words which I know our countrymen expect from me on my sudden release.
('27', 10, 5, 12, 24394) I am sorry that the Government have prematurely released me on account of my illness.
('27', 10, 5, 13, 24480) Such a release can bring me no joy, for I hold that the illness of a prisoner affords no ground for his release.
('27', 10, 5, 14, 24593) I would be guilty of ungratefulness if I did not tell you, and through you the whole public, that both the jail and the hospital authorities have been all attention during my illness.
('27', 10, 5, 15, 24777) Murray, the Superintendent of the Yeravda Prison, as soon as he suspected that my illness was at all serious, invited Col.
('27', 10, 5, 16, 24900) Maddock to assist him and I am sure that the promptest measures were taken by him to secure for me the best treatment possible.
('27', 10, 5, 17, 25028) I could not have been removed to the David and Sassoon Hospitals a moment earlier.
('27', 10, 5, 18, 25111) Maddock and his staff have treated me with the utmost attention and kindness.
('27', 10, 5, 19, 25189) I may not omit the nurses who have surrounded me with sisterly care.
('27', 10, 5, 20, 25258) Though it is now open to me to leave this hospital, knowing that I can get no better treatment anywhere else, with Col.
('27', 10, 5, 21, 25378) Maddock’s kind permission I have decided to remain under his care till the wound is healed and no

('27', 11, 0, 1, 25551) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 12
('27', 11, 1, 2, 25592) further medical treatment is necessary.
('27', 11, 1, 3, 25632) The public will easily understand that for some time to come I shall be quite unfit for active work, and those who are interested in my speedy return to active life will hasten it by postponing their natural desire to see me.
('27', 11, 1, 4, 25858) I am unfit and shall be so for some weeks perhaps to see a number of visitors.
('27', 11, 1, 5, 25937) I shall better appreciate the affection of friends if they will devote greater time and attention to such national work as they may be engaged in and especially to hand spinning.
('27', 11, 1, 6, 26116) My release has brought me no relief.
('27', 11, 1, 7, 26153) Whereas before release I was free from responsibility save that of conforming to jail discipline and trying to qualify myself for more efficient service, I am now overwhelmed with a sense of responsibility I am ill fitted to discharge.
('27', 11, 1, 8, 26389) Telegrams of congratulations have been pouring in upon me.
('27', 11, 1, 9, 26448) They have but added to the many proofs I have received of the affection of our countrymen for me.
('27', 11, 1, 10, 26546) It naturally pleases and comforts me.
('27', 11, 1, 11, 26584) Many telegrams, however, betray hopes of results from my service which stagger me.
('27', 11, 1, 12, 26667) The thought of my utter incapacity to cope with the work before me humbles my pride.
('27', 11, 1, 13, 26752) Though I know very little of the present situation in the country, I know sufficient to enable me to see that, perplexing as the national problems were at the time of the Bardoli resolutions, they are far more perplexing today.
('27', 11, 1, 14, 26980) It is clear that, without unity between Hindus, Mahomadans, Sikhs, Parsis and Christians and other Indians, all talk of swaraj is idle.
('27', 11, 1, 15, 27116) This unity which I fondly believed, in 1922, had been nearly achieved has, so far as Hindus and Mussalmans are concerned, I observe, suffered a severe check.
('27', 11, 1, 16, 27274) Mutual trust has given place to distrust.
('27', 11, 1, 17, 27316) An indissoluble bond between the various com munities must be established if we are to win freedom.
('27', 11, 1, 18, 27416) Will the thanks giving of the nation over my release be turned into a solid unity between the communities?
('27', 11, 1, 19, 27523) That will restore me to health far quicker than any medical treatment or rest cure.
('27', 11, 1, 20, 27607) When I heard in the jail of the tension between Hindus and Mussalmans in certain places, my heart sank within me.
('27', 11, 1, 21, 27721) The rest I am advised to have will be no rest with the burden of disunion preying upon me.
('27', 11, 1, 22, 27812) I ask all those who cherish love towards me to utilize it in furtherance of the union we all desire.
('27', 11, 1, 23, 27913) I know that the task is difficult.
('27', 11, 1, 24, 27948) But nothing is difficult if we have a living faith in God.
('27', 11, 1, 25, 28007) Let us realize out own weakness and approach Him and He will surely help.
('27', 11, 1, 26, 28081) It is weakness which breeds fear and fear breeds distrust Let us both shed our fear, but I know that, even if one of us will cease
('27', 12, 0, 1, 28212) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 13
('27', 12, 1, 2, 28255) to fear, we shall cease to quarrel.
('27', 12, 1, 3, 28291) Nay, I say that your tenure of office will be judged solely by what you can do in the cause of union.
('27', 12, 1, 4, 28393) I know that we love each other as brothers.
('27', 12, 1, 5, 28437) I ask you, therefore, to share my anxiety and help me to go through the period of illness with a lighter heart.
('27', 12, 1, 6, 28549) If we could but visualize the growing pauperism of the land and realize that the spinning wheel is the only remedy for the disease, the wheel will leave us little leisure for fighting.
('27', 12, 1, 7, 28734) I had during the last two years ample time and solitude for hard thinking.
('27', 12, 1, 8, 28809) It made me a firmer believer than ever in the efficacy of the Bardoli programme and, therefore, in the unity between the races, the charkha, the removal of untouchability and the application of non violence in thought, word and deed to out methods as indispensable for swaraj.
('27', 12, 1, 9, 29086) If we faithfully and fully carry out this programme, we need never resort to civil disobedience and I should hope that it will never be necessary.
('27', 12, 1, 10, 29233) But I must state that my thinking prayerfully and in solitude has not weak ened my belief in the efficiency and righteousness of civil disobe dience.
('27', 12, 1, 11, 29383) I hold it, as never before, to be a man’s or a nation’s right and duty when its vital being is in jeopardy.
('27', 12, 1, 12, 29491) I am convinced that it is attended with less danger than war and, whilst the former, when suc cessful, benefits both the resister and the wrongdoer, the latter harms both the victor and the vanquished.
('27', 12, 1, 13, 29693) You will not expect me to express any opinion on the vexed question of return by Congressmen to the Legislative Councils and Assembly.
('27', 12, 1, 14, 29828) Though I have not in any way altered my opinion about the boycott of Councils, Law Courts and Government Schools, I have no data for coming to a judgment upon the alterations made at Delhi, and I do not propose to express any opinion until I have had the opportunity of discussing the question with our illustrious country men who have felt called upon, in the interest of the country, to advise removal of the boycott of legislative bodies.
('27', 12, 1, 15, 30270) In conclusion, may I, through you thank all the very numerous senders of congratulatory messages.
('27', 12, 1, 16, 30368) It is not possible for me personally to acknowledge each message.
('27', 12, 1, 17, 30434) It has gladdened my heart to see among the messages many from our Moderate friends.
('27', 12, 1, 18, 30518) I have, and non co operators can have, no quarrel with them.
('27', 12, 1, 19, 30579) They too are well wishers of their country and serve to the best of their lights.
('27', 12, 1, 20, 30661) If we consider them to be in the wrong, we can hope to win them over only by friendliness and patient reasoning, never by abusing.
('27', 12, 1, 21, 30792) Indeed, we want to regard
('27', 13, 0, 1, 30818) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 14
('27', 13, 1, 2, 30859) Englishmen too as our friends and not misunderstand them by treating them as our enemies.
('27', 13, 1, 3, 30949) And if we are today engaged in a struggle against the British Government, it is against the system for which it stands and not against Englishmen who are administering the system.
('27', 13, 1, 4, 31129) I know that many of us have failed to understand and always bear in mind the distinction and, in so far as we have failed, we have harmed our cause.
('27', 13, 2, 5, 31278) I am, Your sincere friend and brother,

('27', 16, 7, 13, 36049) 17. ANTI INDIAN CAMPAIGN IN SOUTH AFRICA 3
('27', 16, 8, 14, 36092) February 14, 1924] As one expected to understand the situation created in South Africa by the anti Asiatic movement now going on there, and especially the Class Areas Bill now under consideration by the Union Parliament, I deem it my duty to place my opinion on the situation before the public.
('27', 16, 8, 15, 36387) The anti Asiatic agitation on the part of Europeans in South Africa is no new thing.
('27', 16, 8, 16, 36472) It is almost as old as the first settlement of unindentured Indians in South Africa, and is principally due to trade jealousy on the part of white retail traders.
('27', 16, 8, 17, 36635) As in other parts of the world so in South Africa, interested men, if they sufficiently persist, find no difficulty in gathering the support round them of those who are not so interested, but who do not think for themselves.
('27', 16, 8, 18, 36860) The present agitation, I remember, was begun as early as 1921 4, and the Class
('27', 16, 9, 19, 36939) 1 The Wednesday following the commencement of addressee’s fast to which the letter alludes fell on this date.
('27', 16, 9, 20, 37049) 2 Addressee’s wife 3 This statement was published generally in the Press.
('27', 16, 9, 21, 37123) 4 Vide “Notes”, 6 4 1921.
('27', 17, 0, 1, 37149) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 18
('27', 17, 1, 2, 37190) Areas Bill is, no doubt, one result of that agitation.
('27', 17, 1, 3, 37245) Before dealing with the nature and effect of the Bill, It is necessary to point out that it is in breach of the compromise of 1914 arrived at between the Union Government and the Indian community of South Africa.
('27', 17, 1, 4, 37458) 1 But it was a compromise to which both the Indian Government and the Imperial Government were as much party as the Union Government and the Indian community, because the comp romise was arrived at with the knowledge and concurrence of the Imperial the and Indian Governments.
('27', 17, 1, 5, 37735) The latter had even sent Sir Benjamin Robertson as a representative, technically to watch the course of the Commission that was appointed by the Union Govern ment to inquire into the Indian position, but in reality to negotiate a settlement.
('27', 17, 1, 6, 37977) The main terms of the compromise were settled before Sir Benjamin Robertson, who represented the Indian Government, returned to India.
('27', 17, 1, 7, 38112) In accordance with that compromise, no further anti Asiatic legislation was to be passed by the Union Government.
('27', 17, 1, 8, 38226) The under stannding at the time was that the legal position of the Indian would be gradually improved and that the then existing anti Asiatic legis lation would, in time to come, be repealed.
('27', 17, 1, 9, 38418) The contrary has, however, happened.
('27', 17, 1, 10, 38455) The public may remember that the first attempt to break the spirit of the compromise was made when, in the Transvaal, an attempt was made to enforce the existing legislation adversely to the Indians and contrary to the practice that prevailed at the time of the compromise.
('27', 17, 1, 11, 38729) The Class Areas bill, however, goes much further in restricting Indian liberty.
('27', 17, 1, 12, 38809) Whatever may be the other implications of the compromise, this much cannot be disputed by any party, that the settlement of 1914 pledged the Union Government not to put further restrictions upon the Indian liberty, and apart from the general powers of disallowance vested in His Majesty under the Letter of Instructions addressed to the Governor General of South Africa, the Imperial Government if they would be true to their trust are bound, at any cost, to insist upon the observance of the terms of the compromise referred to by me.
('27', 17, 1, 13, 39345) We in India may not ignore the difficulties of the Union Government which is dependent for its existence solely upon the will of the Europeans of South Africa expressed through their elected representatives to the exclusion of Indians and the natives of the soil.
('27', 17, 2, 14, 39609) 1 Vide “The End of the Struggle”, 8 7 1914.
('27', 18, 0, 1, 39653) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 19
('27', 18, 1, 2, 39696) This unwarranted exclusion is the original flaw in the South African constitution, as it is to be found in the constitution of most of the self governing Colonies which have their native populations and Indian populations.
('27', 18, 1, 3, 39919) As the Imperial Government permitted the flaw, it is in honour bound to prevent untoward results arising from it.
('27', 18, 1, 4, 40033) South Africa and Kenya will presently show what moral worth there is in the Imperial system.
('27', 18, 1, 5, 40126) Pressure of public opinion may, and probably will, bring about temporary relief in both the places; but it will be only temporary.
('27', 18, 1, 6, 40257) It can merely postpone the final act in the tragedy unless some unforeseen radical change, either in England or in India, takes place.
('27', 18, 1, 7, 40392) And now for the Bill itself.
('27', 18, 1, 8, 40421) Unlike the Natal Municipal Franchise Bill, which happily the Union Governor General has in effect vetoed and which applied only to Natal, the Class Areas Bill is designed to apply to all the four 1 provinces.
('27', 18, 1, 9, 40630) It enables the Govern ment to segregate all the domiciled Indians and other Asiatics alike for residence and trade.
('27', 18, 1, 10, 40746) It is, therefore, an extension, in a modified manner, of the location system 2 devised as early as 1885 by the late Transvaal Government.
('27', 18, 1, 11, 40884) Let me say in a few words what the segregation may mean.
('27', 18, 1, 12, 40941) The Indian Location in Pretoria, where, in spit of the Law of 1885, not a single Indian has been as yet compelled to remove, is situated far away from the town itself and entirely outside the beat of the buyer, whether English, Dutch or native.
('27', 18, 1, 13, 41186) The only trade possible in such Locations is trade among themselves.
('27', 18, 1, 14, 41255) Segregation, therefore, carried out to the full means nothing less than compulsory repatriation without any compensation.
('27', 18, 1, 15, 41377) It is true that the Bill appears to preserve to a certain extent the existing rights.
('27', 18, 1, 16, 41463) But that reservation is of little consequence to the Indian settlers.
('27', 18, 1, 17, 41533) I do not wish to burden this note by citing illustrations from my South African experience to show how such reservations have, in practice, proved almost useless.
('27', 18, 1, 18, 41696) Finally, let it be remembered that, when Indian emigration to South Africa was unrestricted, the fear of the Europeans was expressed to be that South Africa might be swamped by India’s millions.
('27', 18, 1, 19, 41891) All the South African statesmen then used to say that South Africa could easily digest a small Indian population and could even give it a liberal
('27', 18, 2, 20, 42037) 1 The source has “poor”, evidently a misprint.
('27', 18, 2, 21, 42084) 2 Indians and natives in South Africa were forced to reside in certain areas which were known as “Locations”.
('27', 19, 0, 1, 42194) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 20
('27', 19, 1, 2, 42235) treatment, but that the European settlers could never rest content so long as the possibility of swamping remained.
('27', 19, 1, 3, 42351) Now that the so calledmessage to gujarat vidyapith message to gujarat vidyapith fear of swamping has been removed, practically since 1897, the cry is raised for segregation; and, if that is accomplished, the next step will be compulsory repartiation.

('27', 21, 6, 7, 45663) 23. OPEN LETTER TO AKALIS 2
('27', 21, 7, 8, 45691) February 25, 1924
('27', 21, 8, 9, 45709) DEAR COUNTRYMEN, It was with great distress that I heard about the shooting of an Akali Jatha on the orders of the Adminstrator of the Nabha State, resulting in several members being killed and many more wounded.
('27', 21, 9, 10, 45922) In reply to telegrams, beyond sending a message of sympathy, I had no wish to say or do anything more.
('27', 21, 9, 11, 46025) It is contrary to the wish of Col.
('27', 21, 9, 12, 46060) Maddock, who has covered me with every form of kindness during my illness, that I am undertaking a moderate amount of activity in the shape of informing myself of the prevailing situation in the country.
('27', 21, 9, 13, 46264) The following telegram just received from Zira, “Come unminding health condition soon Akali Jatha”’compels me to say something in connection with the tragedy just mentioned.
('27', 21, 9, 14, 46439) I do not happen to know the sender of the telegram, but had it been at all possible for me, I would certainly have gone down in reply to the message.
('27', 21, 9, 15, 46589) The wound being yet unhealed, any such journey is a physical impossibility.
('27', 21, 9, 16, 46665) I am, therefore, doing the next best thing.
('27', 21, 9, 17, 46709) I need hardly assure the Akali Sikhs of my sympathy in the loss of so many brave men and many more being wounded.
('27', 21, 9, 18, 46823) Without full facts before me, I am unable to say whether the march of a large number of men in order to pay devotion to the shrine of Gangsar at Jaiton was or was not justified.
('27', 21, 9, 19, 47001) But I would
('27', 21, 10, 20, 47013) 1 This was in reply to Mahomed Ali’s telegram of February 24, 1924: “If you consider necessary please send messages with instructions regarding situation recently created to Delhi.
('27', 21, 10, 21, 47194) Working Committee meeting 26th.” S.N. 8371. 2 This was published generally in the Press
('27', 22, 0, 1, 47282) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 23
('27', 22, 1, 2, 47325) ask the Akali Sikhs not to send any more Jathas without further deliberation and consultation with those leaders outside the Sikh community who have hitherto been giving them advice.
('27', 22, 1, 3, 47508) It would be well to stop and watch developments arising out of the tragedy.
('27', 22, 1, 4, 47584) One of the telegrams received by me tells me that the Jatha was and remained throughout strictly non violent.
('27', 22, 1, 5, 47694) You have, from the very commencement, claimed that your movement is perfectly non violent and religious.
('27', 22, 1, 6, 47799) I would like every one of us to understand all the implications of non violence.
('27', 22, 1, 7, 47880) I am not unaware of the fact that non violence is not your final creed.
('27', 22, 1, 8, 47952) It is, therefore, doubly incumbent upon you to guard against any violence in thought or word creeping in the movement.
('27', 22, 1, 9, 48071) Over 25 years of the practice of non violence in the political field has shown me as clearly as daylight that, in every act of ours, we have to watch our thoughts and words in connection with the movement in which we may be engaged.
('27', 22, 1, 10, 48304) Non violence is impossible without deep humility and the strictest regard for truth and, if such non violence has been possible in connection with movements not termed religious, how much easier it should be with those like you who are conducting a strictly religious movement?
('27', 22, 1, 11, 48582) I have deemed it necessary to reiterate what I used to say about non violence before my imprisonment, because I have observed, during my brief study of the events of the past years, that we who claim to be engaged in a non violent movement have not fully in thought and speech conformed to out creed during the past two years, as we certainly did not during the previous years.
('27', 22, 1, 12, 48960) I am sorry to have to say that what I wrote about ourselves in the pages of Young India during the three months prior to my arrest holds truer today than it did then.
('27', 22, 1, 13, 49127) I have not the slightest doubt in my mind that.
('27', 22, 1, 14, 49175) had we practiced non violence in the sense I mean during all these five years, we would not only have achieved our common goal, but there would be today no differences and quarrels between Hindus and Mussal mans.
('27', 22, 1, 15, 49388) In drawing your attention, therefore, to the necessity of non violence in your special struggle about your Gurdwaras, I do not wish to be understood to mean that there has been greater disregard of the essentials of non violence amongst you than amongst the other communities.
('27', 22, 1, 16, 49665) But a word of caution is more necessary in your case, because
('27', 23, 0, 1, 49727) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 24
('27', 23, 1, 2, 49768) you have never flagged.
('27', 23, 1, 3, 49792) You have been incessantly active in the pursuit of your special goal.
('27', 23, 1, 4, 49862) I would, therefore, have you to search yourselves and, if you find that you have not been true to the standard you set before yourselves, to cease further demonstration for the time being and perform the necessary cleansing process before beginning anew; and I doubt not that your effort will be crowned with success.
('27', 23, 2, 5, 50180) I remain,
('27', 23, 3, 6, 50190) Yours friend and servant,
('27', 23, 4, 7, 50216) M. K. GANDHI

('27', 23, 11, 14, 50423) 25. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES 2
('27', 23, 12, 15, 50449) February 26, 1924 It was my intention to publish all the important correspondence I had with the authorities during my incarceration as part of my jail experiences, which I intend to write out if health and time permit.
('27', 23, 12, 16, 50669) But it is not possible for me to do so for some time to come.
('27', 23, 12, 17, 50731) Meanwhile, friends have urged me to publish the correspondence without delay.
('27', 23, 12, 18, 50809) I appreciate the force of their reasoning, and, therefore, present the readers of Young India with a portion of it this week.
('27', 23, 12, 19, 50935) The main part of the contention raised in the letter 3 to Hakimji stands good even in
('27', 23, 13, 20, 51021) 1 This was in reply to addressee’s telegram of February 25, 1924, from Zira which read: “Come unminding health condition soon.Akali Jatha” The identity of Das is not known.
('27', 23, 13, 21, 51195) Vide also “Statement on Open Letter to Akalis”, 28 2 1924.
('27', 23, 14, 22, 51254) 2 This was Gandhiji’s prefatory note to the correspondence which, as a prisoner, he had carried on with the Yeravda Jail authorities from April 1922 onwards.
('27', 23, 14, 23, 51412) 3 Vide “Letter to Hakim Ajmal Khan”, 14 4 1922.
('27', 24, 0, 1, 51460) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 25
('27', 24, 1, 2, 51503) the light of subsequent experience.
('27', 24, 1, 3, 51539) But, in justice to the Jail officials, I must add that, so far as my physical comfort was concerned, pro gressively better facilities were given to me.
('27', 24, 1, 4, 51691) Mr. Banker, much to my joy, was restored to me.
('27', 24, 1, 5, 51739) The marking line referred to in the first letter to Hakimji was done away with, and both of us had a run of the whole yard.
('27', 24, 1, 6, 51863) On Mr. Banker’s discharge, without any request on my part, the then Superintendent, Major Jones, obtained the Govern ment’s permission to send Mr. Manser Ali Sokta to me as a companion, a consideration which I very greatly esteemed.
('27', 24, 1, 7, 52096) For, Mr., Manser Ali Sokta was not only a valuable companion, but was also an ideal Urdu teacher for me.
('27', 24, 1, 8, 52201) Soon after, Mr. Indulal Yagnik came and added to our pleasure.
('27', 24, 1, 9, 52264) Major Jones the transferred us three to the European ward where we had superior accommodation and not a bad garden in front of us.
('27', 24, 1, 10, 52395) On Mr. Manser Ali Sokta’s discharge, Major Jones’s successor, Col.
('27', 24, 1, 11, 52462) Murray, obtained the Government’s permission to put Mr. Abdul Gani with me as a companion who, in addition to giving Mr. Yagnik and myself joy, replaced Mr, Manser Ali Sokta as my Urdu teacher and took great pains in order to improve my Urdu Calligraphy.
('27', 24, 1, 12, 52717) Had my sickness not interrupted the course, he would have made of me a passable Urdu scholar.
('27', 24, 1, 13, 52811) so far, therefore, as my physical comforts were concerned, both the Government and the Jail officials did all that could possibly be expected to make me happy.
('27', 24, 1, 14, 52971) And if I suffered from illness now and then, it is my firm belief that neither the Government nor the Jail authorities could in any way be blamed.
('27', 24, 1, 15, 53118) I was allowed to choose my own diet and both Major Jones and Col.
('27', 24, 1, 16, 53184) Murray, as also in this respect Col.
('27', 24, 1, 17, 53221) Dalziel, who preceded Major Jones, strictly respected all my scruples about diet.
('27', 24, 1, 18, 53303) The European jailers too were most attentive and courteous.
('27', 24, 1, 19, 53363) I cannot recall a single occasion when they can be said to have unduly interfered with me.
('27', 24, 1, 20, 53454) And even whilst I was subjected to ordinary jail inspection, to which I cheerfully submitted, they carried it out considerately and even apologetically I. I entertain high regard for both Major Jones and Col.
('27', 24, 1, 21, 53663) Murray as men.
('27', 24, 1, 22, 53678) They never let me feel that I was a prisoner.
('27', 24, 1, 23, 53724) Subject to what I have said about the kindness of officials, I am unable to revise the estimate I gave in Hakimji’s letter about the soulless policy of the Government regarding political prisoners.
('27', 24, 1, 24, 53922) All I have said in that letter was confirmed by later experience.
('27', 24, 1, 25, 53988) For proof of this statement the reader must wait till I am able to write out my experiences.
('27', 24, 1, 26, 54081) My purpose just now is to avoid any the least possibility of the correspondence being so interpreted as to cast any reflection
('27', 25, 0, 1, 54208) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 26
('27', 25, 1, 2, 54249) upon the Jail officials or, for that matter, even upon the Government, so far as my physical well being was concerned.
('27', 25, 1, 3, 54368) I must not close this note without expressing my deep gratitude to the convict warders who were placed in charge of us.
('27', 25, 1, 4, 54488) Instead of acting as supervisors, they rendered me and all my companions every assistance.
('27', 25, 1, 5, 54579) They would not allow us to do any labour in the shape of cleaning the cells, etc.
('27', 25, 1, 6, 54661) I shall have to say more about them in my experiences, but I cannot restrain myself against mentioning the name of Gangappa.
('27', 25, 1, 7, 54786) He became a most efficient nurse to me.
('27', 25, 1, 8, 54826) His scrupulous regard to every detail, his always anticipating every want of mine, his readiness to serve me at all hours of the night, his loving nature, his strict honesty and his general observance of the Jail rules and the Jail discipline commanded my admiration.
('27', 25, 1, 9, 55094) I wonder how society can punish a man capable of showing such lofty character and how a Government can keep such a man in prison.
('27', 25, 1, 10, 55224) Gangappa is unlettered.
('27', 25, 1, 11, 55248) He is not a political prisoner.
('27', 25, 1, 12, 55280) He was convicted of murder, or some such crime.
('27', 25, 1, 13, 55328) But I must not pursue this subject any further.
('27', 25, 1, 14, 55376) I must postpone its consideration to a future date.
('27', 25, 1, 15, 55428) I have mentioned Gangappa merely to pay my humble tribute to fellow prisoners like him.
('27', 25, 2, 16, 55516) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 28 2 1924
('27', 25, 3, 17, 55552) 26. STATEMENT ON OPEN LETTER TO AKALIS 1
('27', 25, 4, 18, 55593) February 28, 1924 I have just read a paragraph in the news column of The Bombay Chronicle of the 28th February about the Jaiton tragedy in which it is suggested that my open letter to the Akali Sikhs is based on wrong information supplied to me and that “in this respect people mostly suspect Lala Lajpat Rai”.
('27', 25, 4, 19, 55904) In justice to Lalaji, I wish to state that, before he saw me, I had read all I could about the tragedy and that, when the telegram inviting me to go to the Punjab was received, I had made up my mind, before Lalaji had seen that telegram, that I should make some such statement as ultimately I did make.
('27', 25, 4, 20, 56207) As the telegram asking me to come down and stop Akali Jathas was received from Zira and I did not know anybody there and as was anxious that the advice I
('27', 25, 5, 21, 56361) 1 Vide “Open Letter to Akalis”, 25 2 1924.
('27', 26, 0, 1, 56404) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 27
('27', 26, 1, 2, 56447) tendered should reach the Akali Sikhs as early as possible, I adopted the method of the open letter.
('27', 26, 1, 3, 56548) My letter was based purely on the information gleaned by me from the papers and the knowledge acquired by me after my release about the state of the spirit of non violence in thought, word and deed in the country.
('27', 26, 1, 4, 56762) Lalaji did see the letter and under his pressure I struck out a large number of passages which otherwise I would have retained and which were stronger than the final letter.
('27', 26, 1, 5, 56936) Lalaji further pressed me to end the letter at the clause advising the Akali Sikhs not to send another Jatha before deliberation with non Sikhs advisers, but as I felt that a general reference to the implications of non violence at this moment was of vital importance, I was obliged respectfully to differ from Lalaji’s advice and retained the passages regarding non violence.
('27', 26, 2, 6, 57313) M. K. GANDHI
('27', 26, 3, 7, 57326) From a photostat: G.N. 5212; also The Hindu, 29 2 1924
('27', 26, 4, 8, 57381) 27. INTERVIEW TO SIND DEPUTATION
('27', 26, 5, 9, 57414) POONA, February 28, 1924
('27', 26, 6, 10, 57439) A deputation consisting of Mr. Jairamdas Doulatram, Khazi Abdul Rehman, Seth Isserdas and Mr. R. K. Sidhwa waited upon Mahatma Gandhi this morning requesting him to come to Karachi to restore his health.
('27', 26, 6, 11, 57643) Mahatmaji was lying in bed and received the deputation cheerfully.
('27', 26, 7, 12, 57710) Mr. Sidhwa acted as spokesman and said: “Your health will be immensely improved on the sea beach of Karachi where the weather is excellent.” Mahatmaji replying said: I would wish I could come to Karachi to gain health because I know Clifton is an excellent place, but I wish to remain in a central place so that friends would not find it inconvenient to see me from places far off.
('27', 26, 7, 13, 58092) Hence I have decided to stay in Andheri 1 near the sea.
('27', 26, 8, 14, 58148) MR. SIDHWA: We look to your health first and those intending to see you could come even from thousands of miles.
('27', 26, 8, 15, 58261) So you should come to Karachi.
('27', 26, 8, 16, 58292) People are more anxious about you health.
('27', 26, 8, 17, 58334) It is true, friends could come to see me from any distance, but I don’t want to trouble them.
('27', 26, 8, 18, 58428) I had an invitation from Ceylon also and, although I have not seen Ceylon I am told that it is a beautiful and
('27', 26, 9, 19, 58540) 1 A suburb of Bombay

('27', 27, 1, 2, 58602) lovely place for the convenience of visitors with whom I have to consult often, I have decided to remain near Bombay.
('27', 27, 1, 3, 58720) I had once decided to live at Dadabhoy Naoroji’s house and I was glad that I would be staying in the house of persons under whom I had learnt politics.

('27', 28, 5, 12, 60473) 31. STATEMENT ON AKALI MOVEMENT
('27', 28, 6, 13, 60505) [POONA,] March 4, 1924 If I am entirely satisfied as to the nature and implications of the present Akali movement and the methods adopted to gain the end, I should have no hesitation in throwing myself heart and soul into it and even in burying myself in the Punjab, if it became necessary in order to guide the movement.
('27', 28, 6, 14, 60827) The satisfaction that I require is on the following: (1) The strength of the Akalis.
('27', 28, 6, 15, 60912) (2) (a) A clear manifesto publicly stating the minimum, which I understand to be the performance of the Akhand Path cere mony in Gangsar Gurdwara, the Sikhs openly and sincerely declaring that it has no political end and that they do not desire,
('27', 28, 7, 16, 61158) 1 This was a meeting of citizens held under the presidentship of prof.
('27', 28, 7, 17, 61229) R.P. Paranjpye to protest against the refusal of the British Government to issue B. G. Horniman a passport.
('27', 28, 7, 18, 61337) Horniman had been deported in 1919. Gandhiji’s message was read out by C. F. Andrews at the meeting which adopted a resolution holding Horniman’s deportation illegal and demanding facilities for his return.
('27', 29, 0, 1, 61544) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 30
('27', 29, 1, 2, 61585) through the Akhand Path movemnet, in any shape or form, to carry on an agitation, directly or indirectly, for the restoration of the Nabha Maharaj 1. The agitation which the Akalis intend to carry on in connection with such restoration will be on an independent footing and will be purely a separate movement.
('27', 29, 1, 3, 61895) (b) In connection with the movement for control of gurdwaras in every case of disputed control or possession, the matter should be referred to arbitration.
('27', 29, 1, 4, 62051) In the case of historical gurd waras, it will be assumed that all such gurdwaras must remain in the control of the S.G.P. Committee.
('27', 29, 1, 5, 62184) But the question of fact whether a particular gurdwara is or is not historical will be a subject matter of arbitration, and the burden of proving that it is so will lie on the shoulders of the S.G.P. Committee.
('27', 29, 1, 6, 62395) With reference to all other gurdwaras, all the facts in dispute should be a subject matter of arbitration.
('27', 29, 1, 7, 62502) In the event of the party in possession of such gurdwaras declining to surrender control to the S.G.P. Committee or to refer the matter in dispute to arbitration., the Akalis would be free to take such direct action as is consistent with non violence in the strictest sense of the term.
('27', 29, 1, 8, 62789) (3) Full assurance and, therefore, a document intended for publication signed by all the principal leaders or on behalf of the S.G.P.C., giving a description of the methods which will clearly set forth all the implications of non violence.
('27', 29, 1, 9, 63029) By the term I do not wish to convey that non violence is to be regarded in the document referred to above as the final creed of the Sikhs, which I know it is not.
('27', 29, 1, 10, 63192) but I do understand that their methods, so far as this Gurdwara movement is concerned, will be absolutely non violent, that is to say, the Akalis will be non violent in thought, word and deed in connection with all persons, whether Government officials, English and otherwise, or whether members of the public belonging to any denom ination whatsoever, who may be regarded as opponents of the
('27', 29, 2, 11, 63585) 1 The Maharaj of Nabha abdicated in early 1923 and the Government of India took over the administration of the State.
('27', 29, 2, 12, 63703) The reason apparently was the friction which had lately developed between Nabha and the neighbouring State of Patiala.
('27', 29, 2, 13, 63822) The Shiromani Gurdwara Prabhandhak Committee, a body in charge of Sikh religious affairs, contended that the abdication was not voluntary and demanded that the Maharaja be restored to his throne.
('27', 29, 2, 14, 64018) Vide India in 1923 24.
('27', 30, 0, 1, 64041) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 31
('27', 30, 1, 2, 64084) objects of the Akali movement.
('27', 30, 1, 3, 64115) Absolute adherence to truth I regard as an integral part of any scheme of non violence, whether it is temporary or permanent and whether it is restricted to persons or places.
('27', 30, 1, 4, 64291) It, therefore, admits of no diplomacy, as we understand the term, and it rejects altogether the prevailing normal idea that it is legitimate to have surreptitious methods with regard to opponents.
('27', 30, 1, 5, 64488) It follows that there is to be no secrecy.
('27', 30, 1, 6, 64531) (4) That the movement is neither anti Hindu nor anti any other race or creed.
('27', 30, 1, 7, 64609) (5) That the S.G.P.C. has no desire for the establishment of Sikh Raj and, as a matter of fact, the Committee is purely a religious body and, therefore, as such can have no secular object or intention.
('27', 30, 1, 8, 64811) As to the restoration of Nabha Maharaja: In my opinion, whatever the true facts may be, the Maharaj has by his writings made it practically impossible for his well wishers to carry on an effective agitation for his restoration.
('27', 30, 1, 9, 65039) If, however, he makes a public statement that all the writings were practically extorted from him and that he is quite willing and anxious that all the facts against him should be published and if he is prepared to face all the consequences of the agitation, viz., deprivation of titles, annuity, etc., and if all his allegations regarding duress can be proved, it is possible to carry on an effective and even successful agitation.
('27', 30, 1, 10, 65472) In any event, when the declaration of the kind mentioned is made by the Maharaja, the agitation should be an all India agitation.
('27', 30, 1, 11, 65602) The Akalis should merely assist in the observation of faith.
('27', 30, 2, 12, 65663) M. K. GANDHI

('27', 33, 1, 2, 69956) 35. NOTE ON CORRESPONDENCE 1
('27', 33, 2, 3, 69985) The result of the correspondence was that the Government at last gave their reason for prohibiting the visits referred to, viz, it was in the public interest that the said visits were prohibited, but that, if in future I wanted to see anybody in particular, the Superintendent was to send the name or names to the Government.
('27', 33, 2, 4, 70311) I may add that to the last moment the names of all who wanted to see me had to be submitted to the Government.
('27', 33, 2, 5, 70422) In spite of the Government statement, in my case and [in the case of] those who were in the same block with me, the Superintendent had no discretion to grant permission to visitors, which he had in the case of all the other prisoners.
('27', 33, 2, 6, 70657) Young India, 6 3 1924
('27', 33, 3, 7, 70679) 36. COMMENT ON PRISON CONDITIONS 2
('27', 33, 4, 8, 70714) For reason I do not wish to enter into at this stage, I am unable to publish further correspondence in this matter.
('27', 33, 4, 9, 70830) But I may state that I was permitted to see two of the leading hunger strikers in the presence of the Superintendent of the Jail and the Inspector General of Prisons.
('27', 33, 4, 10, 70997) The result was that Messrs Dastane and Dev, the two prisoners, appreciated the moral argument I advanced, and at once broke their long fast.
('27', 33, 4, 11, 71138) The Government, after investigating the cause of flogging and surrounding circumstances, issued instructions that no flogging was to be administered by the Jail Superintendent without previous sanction from the Government except in the case of assault by prisoners upon Jail officials, or like conduct.
('27', 33, 4, 12, 71441) I have observed that exaggerated reports were published about the conduct of Major Whitworth Jones, then Superintendent, and that he was described as an inhumane Superintendent, and his conduct as inhuman.
('27', 33, 4, 13, 71647) Whilst, in my opinion, the flogging in question was a grave error of judgment on the part of the Superintendent, it was nothing more.
('27', 33, 4, 14, 71781) Major Jones was often hasty but so far as I am aware never heartless.
('27', 33, 4, 15, 71851) On the contrary, [in] all I saw of him and heard about him from those prisoners with
('27', 33, 5, 16, 71936) 1 This was published under “Letter to Jail Superintendent, Yeravda” 16 4 1923. The other letters sent by Gandhiji to the Jail authorities are placed in their chronological order.
('27', 33, 5, 17, 72115) 2 This was published under “Letter to Jail Superintendent, Yeravda” 29 6 1923.
('27', 34, 0, 1, 72194) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 35
('27', 34, 1, 2, 72237) whom I came in contact, he was a most sympathetic Superintendent, ever willing to listen to the prisoners and to take severe notice of the subordinates who in any way ill treated them.
('27', 34, 1, 3, 72422) He was ever willing to admit his mistakesa rare quality in an official.
('27', 34, 1, 4, 72495) At the same time he was a disciplinarian, and a hasty disciplinarian is often likely to make mistakes.
('27', 34, 1, 5, 72598) The two floggings of satyagrahis were such mistakes.
('27', 34, 1, 6, 72651) They were of the head, not of the heart.
('27', 34, 1, 7, 72692) The fact is that the powers of indiscriminate flogging should never have been vested in the hands of Superintendents of Jails.
('27', 34, 1, 8, 72819) They were taken away none too soon.
('27', 34, 1, 9, 72855) A detailed examination of the prison administration and of these floggings must be reserved for a further occasion.

('27', 34, 2, 11, 72993) 37. COMMENT ON PRISON REGULATIONS 1
('27', 34, 3, 12, 73029) This letter was written as a result of His Excellency’s visit at which I discussed with him, when he pressed me as to whether I had anything to say, the question of Special Division.
('27', 34, 3, 13, 73212) I told him in effect that, in my opinion, the Special Division Regulations were an eyewash and were designed merely to deceive the public into thinking that something was done to accord to the political prisoners a treatment that their general upbringing rendered necessary.
('27', 34, 3, 14, 73487) But the Governor told me with the greatest assurance that he had no authority whatsoever in law to bring rigorous imprisonment prisoners within the Special Division.
('27', 34, 3, 15, 73653) And when I ventured to question the accuracy of his legal knowledge, he told me he ought to know inasmuch as he had framed the regulations himself.
('27', 34, 3, 16, 73801) I was amazed at the industry of a Governor who went so much into details as even to draw up regulationsa work that is generally left to legal officers.
('27', 34, 3, 17, 73954) Although my knowledge of law has become rusty for lack of use, in spite of the authoritative manner in which the Governor spoke, I could not reconcile myself to the fact that the law had given the Government powers to specially classify only simple imprisonmentand not hard labourprisoners, and that it gave no discretion to the Government to reduce sentences.
('27', 34, 3, 18, 74317) Hence the foregoing letter.
('27', 34, 3, 19, 74345) The reply received was that H.E. was mistaken about the law and that the Government had the necessary powers, but that in spite of that
('27', 34, 4, 20, 74481) 1 These observations were made by Gandhiji while publishing in Young India his “Letter to Governor of Bombay”, 15 8 1923.
('27', 35, 0, 1, 74603) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 36
('27', 35, 1, 2, 74644) discovery he could not see his way to revise the regulations so as to include all political prisoners, whether undergoing simple or rigorous imprisonment.
('27', 35, 1, 3, 74799) My suspicion, therefore, that the Special Division Reg ulations were a mere eyewash became, I am sorry to say, confirmed.
('27', 35, 1, 4, 74921) Young India, 6 3 1924
('27', 35, 2, 5, 74943) 38. COMMENT ON LETTER TO JAIL SUPERINTENDENT,
('27', 35, 3, 6, 74989) YERAVDA 1
('27', 35, 4, 7, 74999) The reader is warned not to read a meaning into the letter which it was never intended to bear.
('27', 35, 4, 8, 75095) The letter is only published in order to explain the incident referred to in the letter, as it has been the subject matter of much talk and speculation.
('27', 35, 4, 9, 75248) And as the renunciation of fruit is said to have hastened my collapse, it is necessary to make it clear that it was in no way a protest against the Superintendent’s refusal to grant Mr. Abdul Gani’s request.
('27', 35, 4, 10, 75456) Moreover, Mr. Abdul Gani had the right under the Special Division regulations to send for fruit and any other food that he wanted.
('27', 35, 4, 11, 75587) But he, Mr. Yagnik and I had come to the conclusion that it would not be proper for us to send for food from outside.
('27', 35, 4, 12, 75705) The authorities could, therefore, be in no way blamed for the consequence of my abstention.
('27', 35, 4, 13, 75797) The Superintendent as well as the Inspector General of Prisons pleaded with me to desist from enforcing my decision.
('27', 35, 4, 14, 75914) They warned me of the possible serious consequences of abstention, but for the peace of my mind, I had to take the risk.
('27', 35, 4, 15, 76035) And after all the serious illness I have gone through, I do not feel sorry that I took the step I did.
('27', 35, 4, 16, 76138) Nor should the reader in any way blame Mr. Abdul Gani for having asked for a change of his diet.
('27', 35, 4, 17, 76235) He asked for it after full consultation with me, and I approved of the change not knowing that the regulations would not allow the Superintendent to grant the changed diet.
('27', 35, 4, 18, 76408) I was misled into thinking so because, as stated in the letter, Mr. Yagnik and other fellow prisoners were allowed by the previous Superintendent to change their diet from time to time.
('27', 35, 4, 19, 76594) When I decided to renounce fruit after the refusal to Mr. Abdul Gani, he tried his utmost to dissuade me from the course, but it was not possible for me to forgo the experiment until it was absolutely clear to me that fruit was necessary for my constitution.
('27', 35, 4, 20, 76853) Young India, 6 3 1924
('27', 35, 5, 21, 76875) 1 This was published along with “Letter to Jail Superintendent, Yeravda”, 12 11 1923.

('27', 39, 1, 2, 82504) 43. ADVICE TO AKALIS 1
('27', 39, 2, 3, 82527) [March 9, 1924] 2
('27', 39, 3, 4, 82545) 1. In my opinion, in order to bring the whole of the Akali movement to successful issue, it is absolutely necessary that their minimum should be unmistakably stated.
('27', 39, 3, 5, 82711) This alone can evoke universal approval and sympathy, provided that the minimum is just and reasonable in the sense that it appeals to the reason of a common sense, godfearing man.
('27', 39, 3, 6, 82892) It will not, therefore, do to say that a particular claim is a religious claim.
('27', 39, 3, 7, 82972) All religious claims must necessarily appeal to reason.
('27', 39, 3, 8, 83028) In a movement of non violence, the minimum is also the maximum, just as the minimum is not capable of reduction even though the difficulties may be insurmountable, similarly under favourable weather, there can be no addition to the minimum.
('27', 39, 3, 9, 83269) This folows from the fact that non violence incccludes truth and truth admits of no expedients 2. It is, therefore, necessary for the S.G.P.C. to state the implications of the Gurdwara movement, i.e which gurdwaras are claimed by the Akalis to be historical or otherwise falling within the movement and without which an Akali, to be true to his faith, may not rest.
('27', 39, 3, 10, 83635) Second, what are the implications with reference to the present Akhand Path affair in the Gangsar Gurdwara.
('27', 39, 4, 11, 83743) Third, what is the movement in connection with the forced abdication or deposition of the Maharaja of Nabha.
('27', 39, 4, 12, 83852) 3. ('27', 40, 1, 2, 84911) remains strictly non violent throughout, it is not enough that there is absence of active violence, but it is necessary that there is not the slightest show of force.
('27', 40, 1, 3, 85078) It follows, therefore, that a large body of men cannot be deputed to assert the right of S.G.P.C.’s possession, but one or at the most two men of undoubted integrity, spiritual force and humility may be deputed to assert the right.
('27', 40, 1, 4, 85310) The result of this is likely to be the martyrdom of these pioneers.
('27', 40, 1, 5, 85378) My conviction is that from that moment the possession of the Committee is assured, but it may so happen that martyrdom is postponed and intermediate stages such as pinpricks, serious assault or imprisonment might have to be suffered.

('27', 40, 1, 7, 85809) It is hardly necessary for me to point out that, if the possessor for the time being may consent to submit to arbitration, the Committee should be ever ready to accept the offer when the asserting of the right by means of satyagraha ceases.
('27', 40, 1, 8, 86050) In such a case, it goes without saying that if there are any of the devotees who have been imprisoned in prosecution of the object of the Committee, they should be discharged simultaneously with the acceptance of the arbitration.
('27', 40, 2, 9, 86280) NABHA I understand the position regarding the Nabha State to be as follows and as explained by the Akali friends who have been kindly sent by the S.G.P.C. for the purpose: 1 The S.G.P.C. contends that the Maharaja has been forced to abdicate, that there is no sufficient warrant for the step and that the Committee is in a position to prove that the Maharaja has been forced to abdicate not because of the charges vaguely referred to by the Viceroy or of any other charges such as would justify the extreme punishment, but for his public spritedness exhibited on several occasions and for his known active sympathy for the Akali cause.
('27', 40, 2, 10, 86916) The Committee invites an open and impartial enquiry by a competent authority into the whole case before which the S.G.P.C. should have the right to give evidence and the Committee would be satisfied with the findings of such an enquiry.
('27', 40, 2, 11, 87153) It has been suggested that the Nabha Maharaja has voluntarily abdicated in consideration for the Govern ment suppressing certain charges which they hold are of an extremely damnatory character.
('27', 40, 2, 12, 87347) If the Maharaja’s own writing can be produced
('27', 41, 0, 1, 87393) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 42
('27', 41, 1, 2, 87434) in proof of the statement, the Committee will naturally have nothing further to say.
('27', 41, 1, 3, 87519) Such a writing should be given by the Maharaja without any veiled pressure from the Government and should be a fresh document.
('27', 41, 1, 4, 87646) The Committee have no desire at present for any direct action.
