('27', 41, 2, 8, 88316) SHAHIDI JATHA
('27', 41, 3, 9, 88330) Had it been possible for me to have met the Akali friends before the Jatha which is now on its way to Jaiton had started, I would, even after having heard all that the friends had to say, have adhered to my advice that it should not be sent before perfect stock taking and a review of the whole situation, but I wish to cast no blame on anyone for the delay in the friends meeting me or, if there is any blame to be attached to anybody, I must take it upon my own shoulders because I omitted to take the precaution of wiring the full text of my message to S.G.P.C. at the same time that I handed it to the representative of the Associated Press.
('27', 41, 3, 10, 88976) I was under the mistaken belief that Press messages having precedence of private messages the A.P. message would be earlier in the hands of the Committee.
('27', 41, 3, 11, 89131) I foolishly wanted to save public money.
('27', 41, 3, 12, 89172) Could I be present in the Punjab and see things face to face, I would not hesitate, even though the Jatha is nearing its destination, to tender my advice for its recall in order to enable us to review the situation, to take certain steps which I hold are necessary before taking further direct action, but I cannot undertake the res ponsibility, lying on a sick bed, of advising the recall.
('27', 41, 3, 13, 89563) I dare not place such as burden on the friends who have come to discuss the Gurdwara affair with me.
('27', 41, 3, 14, 89664) In the circumstances, therefore, I fear that Jatha must be allowed to proceed to its destination.
('27', 41, 3, 15, 89762) I understand that elaborate precautions have been taken to prevent admiring crowds or others from following or accompanying the Jatha.
('27', 41, 3, 16, 89897) I understand too that strictest instructions have been issued to the Jatha to adopt and con 
('27', 42, 0, 1, 89990) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 43
('27', 42, 1, 2, 90033) tinue a perfectly non violent attitude in spite of the gravest provo cation.
('27', 42, 1, 3, 90110) This is all to the good.
('27', 42, 1, 4, 90135) But I understand further that the Jatha has also been instructed, in the event of its receiving orders, to leave the State boundary to disobey and, arm in arm, the Jatha has been instructed to present a solid living wall to the State soldiery and to draw upon their devoted heads with unflinching courage the fire that can be poured upon them.
('27', 42, 1, 5, 90479) The idea is no longer to submit to pinpricks and prolongation of the agony by way of forcible deportation, but to end it by every member of the Jatha sitting at his post and dying there with calm resignation without any retaliation.
('27', 42, 1, 6, 90712) This plan is conceived in a most lofty and daring spirit.
('27', 42, 1, 7, 90770) The bravery of who conceived it and still greater bravery of those who are expected to carry it out in its entirety cannot be questioned and, if the Nabha authorities are so foolish as to fire upon the Jatha till everyone lies dead at his post, it will certainly stagger humanity, thrill the world and command universal applause for matchless heroism, but I am sorry to say it could not be recorded as an at of non violence.
('27', 42, 1, 8, 91195) This proposed action can be described as civil disobedience, but in reality it would not be civil disobedience, for civil disobedience [is] perfect submission to orders which are given as punishments for the breach of primary orders which a civil resister holds against conscience to obey.
('27', 42, 1, 9, 91485) But such disobedience to be civil requires perfect obedience to be sanctions small or great, and dis obedience of smaller sanctions in order to invite larger sanctions is not civil but is rowdy and therefore violent.
('27', 42, 1, 10, 91702) The faith of the civil resister must be a living faith in the ultimate success of the spirit of suffering and forbearance.
('27', 42, 1, 11, 91825) Infinite patience must, therefore, be our badge.
('27', 42, 1, 12, 91874) Let us now apply this principle to the proposed action: to sit tight in the face of an order of deportation or an imprisonment in order to invite shooting is to avoid the intermediate sanctions and the possibilities of prolongation of slow suffering and also the struggle.
('27', 42, 1, 13, 92147) Such avoidance is not permissible in civil disobedience; it is calculated to give an excuse to the opponent that they are not non violent.
('27', 42, 1, 14, 92286) The natural course would be to obey the order of deportation when it is accompanied by physical force, be it ever so slight.
('27', 42, 1, 15, 92411) Therefore, even if a youngster duly authorized came to enforce the order of deportation, 500 strong men would in honour be bound meekly and joyously to march out with a young deporting officer whom by the heroic forbearance the 500 are likely to convert into a friend.
('27', 42, 1, 16, 92680) Once put across the border, the right of marching back and be treated similarly
('27', 43, 0, 1, 92760) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 44
('27', 43, 1, 2, 92801) or worse accrues to the 500. The idea underlying meek suffering is that ultimately it is bound to melt the stoniest heart.
('27', 43, 1, 3, 92924) It further deprives disobedience of the slightest trace of violence either active or passive.
('27', 43, 1, 4, 93018) I wish to analyse the proposed action still further.
('27', 43, 1, 5, 93071) What is the locking up of arms of the whole Jatha, if it is not passive violence?
('27', 43, 1, 6, 93153) It is clear that such a solid wall cannot be broken by one man, whereas the creed of non violence presupposes that a move of violence by the opponent is enough for him to push back a crowd of 20,000 non violent men.
('27', 43, 1, 7, 93369) If, therefore, the Committee accept all the implication of non violence, I am firmly of opinion, instructions already given as to the action to be taken by the Jahta when it comes in conflict with authority should be revised in terms of what I have sketched above.
('27', 43, 1, 8, 93634) In that event, only one or the other thing can happen, either the 500 will be deported or imprisoned.
('27', 43, 1, 9, 93736) But, in both the cases, the act will have been performed with complete meekness on our side.
('27', 43, 1, 10, 93829) I know the difficulties of following the procedure.
('27', 43, 1, 11, 93881) The authorities may endlessly continue the seesaw business in order to tire us out.
('27', 43, 1, 12, 93965) But this difficulty vanishes if we, as a body, claim to be incapable of being tired out.
('27', 43, 1, 13, 94054) Non violence, depending as it does on an unquenchable faith in God and in the persistence only of that which is good, does not know what it is to be defeated or to be tired out.
('27', 43, 1, 14, 94232) If the plan suggested by me is adopted, any number of men may march in and at any time of the day.
('27', 43, 1, 15, 94331) It will be found in practice that no authority can possibly afford to play the game of seesaw with a people so determined.
('27', 43, 1, 16, 94454) So much regarding the Jatha now on the march.
('27', 43, 1, 17, 94500) When the present manoeuvre is finished, I would suggest a review of the whole situation.
('27', 43, 1, 18, 94589) So far as I know, the aim of the Akhand Path movement is to assert the right of the community to have Akhand Path in the place [of] that which was interrupted on the.
('27', 43, 1, 19, 94756) 1 and to vindicate the right to have the Akhand Path as often as the community considrs it necessary.

('27', 43, 1, 21, 95156) In order to meet this objection, I would advise the Committee to make a declaration in the clearest possible terms that the

('27', 49, 2, 6, 106230) “Mr. Gandhi.” I said, “I am going to ask you ten questions.

('27', 52, 6, 21, 114929) DEAR MRS.
('27', 52, 6, 22, 114939) MADDOCK 2, Here is a brief statement of my activities as per my promise: (1) Removal of the curse of untouchability among the Hindus.
('27', 52, 6, 23, 115073) (2) The spread of hand spinning and hand weaving and the advocacy of the use of hand spun and hand woven cloth to the exclusion of all foreign cloth and even cloth woven in Indian mills.
('27', 52, 6, 24, 115260) (3) Advocacy of simple life and, therefore, of the avoidance of intoxicating drinks and drugs.
('27', 52, 7, 25, 115355) 1 The report of the interview concludes “This subtle defence precluded any discussion on a controversial subject.
('27', 52, 7, 26, 115469) Gandhi was visibly tired.

('27', 52, 7, 29, 115658) C. Maddock
('27', 53, 0, 1, 115669) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 54
('27', 53, 1, 2, 115710) (4) The establishment of unaided national schools both for the purpose of weaning students from Government institutions as a part of the Non co operation struggle, and of introducing education, inclu ding industrial training, in keeping with the national problems.
('27', 53, 1, 3, 115975) (5) The promotion of unity amongst Hindus, Mussulmans, Christians, Parsees, Jews etc.
('27', 53, 1, 4, 116061) I carry on these activities through two institutions.
('27', 53, 1, 5, 116115) The first is an Ashram near Ahmedabad established in 1916 1 where all those who desire to work out these ideals are invited to join.
('27', 53, 1, 6, 116248) Its expenses are defrayed out of private contributions made by monied friends who are interested in the activities named.
('27', 53, 1, 7, 116370) It has at the present moment nearly 100 inmates, both male and female, who include several families from the so called untouchable class.
('27', 53, 1, 8, 116508) There is a carding, spinning and weaving school and an ordinary literary school attached to the Ashram.
('27', 53, 1, 9, 116612) Simple agricultural work also is done there, and an attempt is being made to grow our own cotton.
('27', 53, 1, 10, 116710) The second institution is the National Congress which is a vast political organization with a very simple but, in my opinion, perfect constitution.
('27', 53, 1, 11, 116858) This has adopted practically the whole of the foregoing programme.
('27', 53, 1, 12, 116925) It has branches in every part of India and has thousands of members who elect representatives annually.
('27', 53, 1, 13, 117029) Payment of 4 annas and acceptance of the Congress creed entitle an adult male or female to the membership of the Congress and to vote for the election of delegates.
('27', 53, 1, 14, 117194) The Congress naturally has a larger programme of work than the activities abovenamed, and being a representative body, has no permanent programme, but can change it from year to year.
('27', 53, 1, 15, 117378) Its aim is the attainment of swarajya, that is, self government, by peaceful and legitimate means.
('27', 53, 1, 16, 117477) For the last four years it has sought to attain its end by non violent non co operation with the Government.
('27', 53, 1, 17, 117586) My own motive is to put forth all my energy in an attempt to save Indian, that is, ancient culture, from impending destruction by modern, that is, Western culture being imposed upon India.
('27', 53, 1, 18, 117775) The essence of ancient culture is based upon the practice of the utmost non violence.
('27', 53, 1, 19, 117861) Its motto is the good of all including every living thing, whereas Western culture is frankly based upon violence.
('27', 53, 1, 20, 117976) it therefore, does not respect all life and, in its progress onward, it has not hesitated
('27', 53, 2, 21, 118066) 1 This is a slip.

('27', 54, 0, 1, 118241) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 55
('27', 54, 1, 2, 118284) to resort to wholesale destruction of even human life.
('27', 54, 1, 3, 118339) Its motto is: Might is Right, and it is essentially individualistic.
('27', 54, 1, 4, 118408) This does not mean that there is nothing for India to learn from the West, for in spite of the acceptance by the West of the Doctrine of Might is Right, the human touch has not altogether disappeared in the West.
('27', 54, 1, 5, 118621) The relentless pursuit of a false ideal conceived as truth has opened the eyes of numerous men in the West to the falsity of that ideal.
('27', 54, 1, 6, 118758) I would like India to copy that spirit of search for the truth in the place of being satisfied with tradition without question, but India can safely copy nothing before she has come to her own and realized that her culture has a very important place in universe and it must be defended at all costs.
('27', 54, 1, 7, 119058) The importation of Western culture by the British in Indian has meant exploitation of her resources for the supposed benefit of Great Britain.
('27', 54, 1, 8, 119201) It has brought millions of people to the verge of starvation, and it has almost emasculated whole nation.
('27', 54, 1, 9, 119307) The foregoing programme is an attempt to prevent the impending ruin not by Western methods but by Indian methods, namely, by internal reform and self purification from the very bottom.
('27', 54, 1, 10, 119492) To remove the curse of untouchability is to do penance for the sin committed by the Hindus of degrading a fifth of their own religionists.
('27', 54, 1, 11, 119631) To remove the curse of intoxicating drinks and drugs not only purifies the nation, but it also deprives an immoral system of Government of an immoral source of revenue to the extent of nearly 25 crores of rupees.
('27', 54, 1, 12, 119844) To revive hand spinning and hand weaving brings back to millions of cottages of India their supplementary industry, revives the old Indian art, removes the degrading pauperism and provides an automatic insurance against famine.
('27', 54, 1, 13, 120072) At the same time, it deprives Great Britain of the strongest incentive for Indian exploitation, for if India can clothe herself without importing foreign cloth and foreign machinery, the relations between Great Britain and India become natural and almost idealistic.
('27', 54, 1, 14, 120339) They take the form then of a voluntary partnership resulting in mutual benefit and, probably, benefit to mankind in general.
('27', 54, 1, 15, 120464) Unity between the different religionists of India prevents Great Britain from pursuing the immoral policy of Divide and Rule, and the practice of non violence in resisting exploitation and degradation, if it becomes successful, is likely to serve as an example for the whole world to copy.
('27', 54, 1, 16, 120754) In following out the programme, mistakes and miscalculations have undoubtedly been made.
('27', 54, 1, 17, 120843) Regrettable incidents have also taken place, but I make bold to say that no movement in which millions of
('27', 55, 0, 1, 120949) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 56
('27', 55, 1, 2, 120990) people have taken part has yet taken place with so little bloodshed or interruption of the ordinary activities of the people.

('27', 56, 1, 2, 122962) 52. STATEMENT ON POTTI SRIRAMULU’S FAST
('27', 56, 2, 3, 123002) BOMBAY, March 15, 1924 Shri Sriramulu is an unknown poor Congressman and servant of humanity working in Nellore.
('27', 56, 2, 4, 123115) He has been labouring singlehanded for the cause to the Harijans of that place.
('27', 56, 2, 5, 123195) There was a time when high hope was entertained about removal of untouchability and other social work in Nellore.
('27', 56, 2, 6, 123309) An ashram was built near Nellore, but for variety of causes the activity received a set back.
('27', 56, 2, 7, 123403) Desabhakta Konda Venkatap payya was, and still is, though very old, the moving spirit in con nection with these activities.
('27', 56, 2, 8, 123527) It is in this place that shri Sriramulu has been quietly and persistently working for the removal, root and branch, of untouchability.
('27', 56, 2, 9, 123662) He has been trying to have a temple opened to Harijans.
('27', 56, 2, 10, 123718) He asked me the other day whether, in order to awaken public conscience in favour of such opening, he could, if all others efforts failed, undertake a fast.
('27', 56, 2, 11, 123875) I sent him my approval.
('27', 56, 2, 12, 123899) Now the place is astir.
('27', 56, 2, 13, 123923) But some persons have asked me to adv ise Shri Sriramulu to suspend his fast for removing legal difficulties of which I have no knowledge.
('27', 56, 2, 14, 124062) I have been unable to give such advice.
('27', 56, 2, 15, 124102) As I am anxious that an unobtrusive servant of humanity my not die for want of public knowledge and support, I bespeak the interest of the journalists of the South, if not of all India, to find out for themselves the truth of the matter and, if what I say is borne out by facts, shame by public exposure the opposing parties into doing the right and save a precious life.

('27', 62, 6, 9, 132240) When I went to Prem Vidya laya, I believe Bhai Kotwal talked to me about you.
('27', 62, 6, 10, 132318) Whilst it is true that we seem to see in Nature both the benignant and the malignant forces in full activity, I am convinced that it is the prerogative of man to rise superior to the eternal duel and to attain equanimity, and the only way we can do so is by practising to the fullest extent the truth force, otherwise described as love force or soul force.
('27', 62, 6, 11, 132675) You will not expect me to argue out the point.
('27', 62, 6, 12, 132722) I can only place before you my conviction based upon prolonged experience during which I cannot recall a single occasion when this force has not completely answered.
('27', 62, 6, 13, 132888) No doubt it requires the cultivation of patience, humility and the like.

('27', 63, 2, 3, 133337) POST ANDHERI, March 15, 1924 MY DEAR FRIEND, “Cheer, boys, cheer, no more of idle sorrow.” Why worry about anything?
('27', 63, 2, 4, 133454) There is an under note 2 of sorrowful despair about your letter 3. Better that, however, than nothing.
('27', 63, 2, 5, 133557) You want me to whip you into cheerfulness and for my encouragement you cite the noble example of your cousin in Zanzibar.
('27', 63, 2, 6, 133679) Only, he had a black boy who was really a boy to deal with, whereas I have the very difficult task of correcting a grown up old boy with a hoary beard and a fair face.
('27', 63, 2, 7, 133847) It was a comparatively easy task to brave the operation for appendicitis.

('27', 63, 2, 18, 134721) I am not yet capable of much physical exertion.

('27', 64, 6, 11, 135951) POST ANDHERI, March 15, 1924 MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I have your letter, and I had your and Mahomed Ali’s telegrams regarding Panikkar.
('27', 64, 6, 12, 136083) 2 Your letter embarrasses me a little.
('27', 64, 6, 13, 136122) I have not intended, nor do I intend now to form any decided opinion about making appointments, fixing salaries, etc.
('27', 64, 6, 14, 136240) As I shared Joseph’s opinion that he should be by his wife’s side when she was so much troubled, and as the Sikh friends who came to see me seemed to be very anxious to have a substitute for Gidwani, a substitute who could also edit their paper Onward, I was on the look out for one.
('27', 64, 6, 15, 136524) They wanted Sundaram who used to be on the Independent and suggested
('27', 64, 7, 16, 136593) 1 Perhaps a slip for “and” 2 Gandhiji appears to have wired Jawaharlal Nehru on March 12. The telegram is not available.
('27', 64, 7, 17, 136714) Nehru replied to it on March 13. He had written: “I have known Panikkar by repute for several years and met him for a short time in Cocanada.
('27', 64, 7, 18, 136856) I am sure his presence will be very useful in Amritsar.
('27', 64, 7, 19, 136912) His ignorance of Hindustani will be a drawback, but this will be more than compensated by his other attainments.
('27', 64, 7, 20, 137025) He will be an excellent man for publicity work.
('27', 64, 7, 21, 137073) Perhaps, owing to his language difficulty, he might not be very helpful in bringing the Sikhs and Hindus nearer to each other.
('27', 64, 7, 22, 137200) But on the whole Panikkar will be an acquisition in Amritsar.
('27', 64, 7, 23, 137262) As regards terms, anything that you consider reasonable will surely be agreed to by all others.
('27', 64, 7, 24, 137358) Technically, the Working Committee will not meet till the 21st April.
('27', 64, 7, 25, 137428) The terms suggested in your telegram are rather complicated, but that is for you to decide.
('27', 64, 7, 26, 137520) I am glad that Panikkar contemplates a lengthy stay at Amritsar.
('27', 64, 7, 27, 137585) Personally, I doubt if it will be necessary for him to stay for many months.
('27', 64, 7, 28, 137662) There is just a possibility of Gidwani coming out sooner and an equal possibility of Gidwani’s successor going in.
('27', 64, 7, 29, 137777) Of course, Panikkar will not unnecessarily invite jail, but neither did Gidwani.”
('27', 65, 0, 1, 137859) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 66
('27', 65, 1, 2, 137900) that he could do both the thingspublicity and editing.
('27', 65, 1, 3, 137956) On my arrival at the retreat near Andheri, I saw Panikkar who had come to see Mr. Andrews in order to discuss the advisability of an offer that was made to him by the Indian Daily Mail.
('27', 65, 1, 4, 138142) He had hesitation in accepting the offer because the Mail politics were not his.

('27', 65, 1, 9, 138941) Panikkar was in the Swarajya office at Rs. 700/ per month, but as the paper is not, self supporting, it has not been able to pay him a few months’ salary.

('27', 65, 1, 16, 139478) At the end of 3 months’ service, therefore, he will be owing to the Congress Rs. 300. This may again be deducted from his salary at the rate of Rs. 100 per month.
('27', 65, 1, 17, 139641) That means that he has to serve for 6 months in order to discharge the loan he would be receiving.
('27', 65, 1, 18, 139740) I am now perturbed because I gather from your letter that he may not be wanted for that length of time.
('27', 65, 1, 19, 139844) I would not like to be the instrument of useless expense to the Congress.
('27', 65, 1, 20, 139918) I propose, therefore, to place the whole situation before Panikkar, and he will probably agree that if his services are dispensed with before 6 months, he should be liable for the unpaid balance of the loan.

('27', 66, 4, 18, 141733) 64. LETTER TO A. A. PAUL
('27', 66, 5, 19, 141758) POST ANDHERI, March 15, 1924
('27', 66, 6, 20, 141787) DEAR MR. PAUL, I have your letter of the 8th inst.
('27', 66, 6, 21, 141838) enclosing a copy of Mr. Aitken’s letter.
('27', 66, 6, 22, 141879) I believe he and I know each other.
('27', 66, 6, 23, 141915) If he is the Mr. Aitken I know, he knows my views very well.
('27', 66, 6, 24, 141976) However, I shall jot them down here for what they are worth.
('27', 66, 6, 25, 142037) The Indian community of South Africa includes people from all provinces and represents Hinduism, Islam, Christianity and Zoroastr ianism.
('27', 66, 6, 26, 142175) There are many South Africa born Indians who are Christians and are highly educated and therefore naturally very sensitive about self respect.
('27', 66, 6, 27, 142318) The restrictive legislation of South Africa applies to them although South Africa is their home and although the majority of them never expect to see India at all.
('27', 66, 6, 28, 142482) It is not known here that rightly
('27', 67, 0, 1, 142516) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 68
('27', 67, 1, 2, 142557) or wrongly these young men and women have adopted European customs, manners, dress, etc., but neither their Christianity nor their education nor their Europeanization has saved them from the bar sinister.
('27', 67, 1, 3, 142762) I mention this fact not to show that they should have a special or separate treatment (they would themselves object to any such distinction), but to emphasize the fact that the restrictive legislation in South Africa is predominantly racial in character.
('27', 67, 1, 4, 143017) The economic aspect occupies a subordinate position.
('27', 67, 1, 5, 143070) The Indian claim is exceedingly simple and reasonable.
('27', 67, 1, 6, 143125) They have voluntarily accepted administrative restriction of Indian immigration and, as a matter of fact, hardly any Indian who has not previously resided in South Africa and practically made it his home is admitted.
('27', 67, 1, 7, 143342) In exchange for this voluntary self denial, the domiciled community claims equality of treatment.
('27', 67, 1, 8, 143440) This position has been always regarded by the thoughtful Europeans of South Africa as eminently reasonable, and in 1914, an agreement was arrived at between the South African Government and the Indian community to which both the Imperial and the Indian Governments were party, whereby it was understood that no further restrictive legislation should be passed and that the position of the domiciled Indians would be steadily and progressively ameliorated.
('27', 67, 1, 9, 143896) 1 The local Indian community, therefore, has a double grievance in respect of the present anti Indian agitation in South Africa.
('27', 67, 1, 10, 144025) The vast majority of Europeans in South Africa are nominally Christian.
('27', 67, 1, 11, 144097) I have the privilege of claiming many of them, especially the missionaries, as my life long friends.
('27', 67, 1, 12, 144198) What is wanted is for the real Christians to dare to stand for truth and justice.
('27', 67, 1, 13, 144280) There is unfortunately too much of expedience even amongst some of the best of them.
('27', 67, 1, 14, 144365) They think that standing for truth in the face of prejudice will impair their usefulness for service.
('27', 67, 1, 15, 144467) I have always dissented from this view, and my humble opinion based upon extensive experience is that such an attitude is a concession, although totally unconscious, to Satan.
('27', 67, 1, 16, 144643) I need hardly assure you that Mr. Aitken’s letter will be regarded as strictly confidential and, on that account, I shall make no use of my letter to you either.
('27', 67, 2, 17, 144805) Yours truly, A. A. PAUL, ESQ.
('27', 67, 2, 18, 144835) GENERAL SECRETARY THE STUDENT CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION OF INDIA, BURMA & CEYLON 6, MILLER ROAD, KILPAUK MADRAS

('27', 70, 11, 18, 149848) 70. LETTER TO D. HANUMANTRAO
('27', 70, 12, 19, 149877) POST ANDHERI, March 16, 1924
('27', 70, 13, 20, 149906) MY DEAR HANUMANTRAO, I have your long but welcome letter.
('27', 70, 13, 21, 149964) You need not apologize henceforth for the length of your letter because you never write idly.
('27', 71, 0, 1, 150058) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 72
('27', 71, 1, 2, 150099) The only way for those of us who, living in isolated, unprotected places, rely for protection upon God’s grace and not upon force of arms, is to have as few valuables as possible whether in the shape of money or otherwise, and to cultivate fellowship even with the roughest element surrounding us.
('27', 71, 1, 3, 150397) That is what is being attempted at Sabarmati.
('27', 71, 1, 4, 150443) I appreciate your suggestion regarding the founding of an Ashram like the Sabarmati one in the different Provinces of India.
('27', 71, 1, 5, 150568) I would like to do so, but they cannot be founded for the mere wish.
('27', 71, 1, 6, 150637) We need the proper stamp of men and I have no knowledge of them.
('27', 71, 1, 7, 150702) You have established one and you realize the difficulty of carrying it on.
('27', 71, 1, 8, 150777) There is another at Wardha, as you know, conducted by Vinoba, whom you know.
('27', 71, 1, 9, 150854) It came into being because a Vinoba was found.
('27', 71, 1, 10, 150901) There is another near Andheri, because a Keshavrao Deshpande has been found.
('27', 71, 1, 11, 150978) All the four are struggling.
('27', 71, 1, 12, 151007) Such Ashrams are an organic growth and they will come into being in their own time, but I like the centre of your suggestion, namely that I should remain at the Sabarmati Ashram and endeavor to make it perfect.
('27', 71, 1, 13, 151218) I would love to do it.
('27', 71, 1, 14, 151241) The external political activity is not of my seeking.
('27', 71, 1, 15, 151295) I therefore cannot give it up of my will.
('27', 71, 1, 16, 151337) If God desires that I should develop the Ashram by being in it, He will make my way clear.
('27', 71, 1, 17, 151428) If it is a real organic growth, I know that it will continue to make progress whether I am in it our outside.
('27', 71, 1, 18, 151538) After all, if any such institution has to depend merely upon one man’s existence on earth, it has to perish with him, but if it is to be of a permanent character, it must depend for its existence upon its own independence and internal vitality.
('27', 71, 1, 19, 151783) Nor need we be impatient about their progress or success.
('27', 71, 1, 20, 151841) It is sufficient if we do the best according to our lights and leave the rest to Him who disposes of everything.
('27', 71, 1, 21, 151954) I think you have done well in not taking upon your shoulders the grave responsibility of taking young women in the Ashram so long as you have no woman worker who can stand on her own and who can become a wall of protection to such girls.
('27', 71, 1, 22, 152192) I shall hope that your own wife will be such in time.
('27', 71, 1, 23, 152246) Now about the Nature cure.
('27', 71, 1, 24, 152273) Every change at Sabarmati, so far as diet and medicinal aid are concerned, is, I know, a fall.
('27', 71, 1, 25, 152368) It commenced with my first serious illness.
('27', 71, 1, 26, 152412) It shook me and I lost confidence in myself, whereas at Kochrab I handled fearlessly and with confidence in Nature’s healing power two cases of confluent small pox in the face of medical opposition and serious enteric fever at the same time.
('27', 71, 1, 27, 152654) At Sabarmati, after my illness, I have not been able to handle even trivial cases.
('27', 71, 1, 28, 152737) My theory is that a man who himself becomes a prey to
('27', 72, 0, 1, 152791) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 73
('27', 72, 1, 2, 152834) illness is unfit to guide others.
('27', 72, 1, 3, 152868) I tried almost to the point of obstinacy to do without milk and ghee, but I failed.
('27', 72, 1, 4, 152952) Had the illness not overcome me, I would have continued my experiments, but I was nonplussed, and I must make the same sad confession about medicine.
('27', 72, 1, 5, 153102) A man who advises abstention from such things must be prepared with an effective substitute.
('27', 72, 1, 6, 153195) Having myself become a broken reed, I have allowed things to take their own course.
('27', 72, 1, 7, 153279) This breakdown in the application of Nature cure is a tragedy of my life.
('27', 72, 1, 8, 153353) Not that I have lost faith in it, but I have lost confidence in myself.
('27', 72, 1, 9, 153425) Help me to recover it.
('27', 72, 1, 10, 153448) You can see how Maganlal understands me through and through.
('27', 72, 1, 11, 153509) He has sent Shivabhai to you without any reference to me, because he realizes our tragic fate just as much as I do.
('27', 72, 1, 12, 153625) We shall all, therefore, be watching your progress with greatest sympathy and attention.
('27', 72, 1, 13, 153714) You will therefore not hesitate to write to me about this whenever you have anything new to tell me.
('27', 72, 2, 14, 153815) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('27', 72, 2, 15, 153837) D. HANUMANTRAO SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM PALLEPADU (NELLORE DIST.)

('27', 74, 0, 1, 156562) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 75
('27', 74, 1, 2, 156605) 73. THE ROOT OBJECTION
('27', 74, 2, 3, 156628) ANDHERI, March 17, 1924 A document dated the 1st of February 1920 and signed by me at Lahore and handed to Dr. (now sir) Joseph Nunan 1 has been reproduced in an elaborate paper (dated 22nd November, 1923) on the status of Indians abroad.
('27', 74, 2, 4, 156867) As it has been used in support of a scheme of Indian colonization in British Guiana and as it is stated in that paper “so far as is known, it still expresses Mahatma Gandhi’s attitude towards British Guiana,” it is necessary to make my position clear.
('27', 74, 2, 5, 157120) The statement made by me in the February of 1920 is as follows:
('27', 74, 3, 6, 157184) Lahore, 1st February, 1920
('27', 74, 4, 7, 157211) From the outset Mr. Gandhi made it perfectly clear that he was not prepared to take any step that could be construed as a personal encouragement by him to Indians to leave India.
('27', 74, 4, 8, 157390) He was not in favour of the emigration of Indians.
('27', 74, 4, 9, 157441) At the same time he realized that many held different views on this point and he was equally not in favour of using compulsion.
('27', 74, 4, 10, 157569) by legislative or executive action to compel Indians to stay at home.
('27', 74, 4, 11, 157639) They should be treated as free citizens at home and abroad.
('27', 74, 4, 12, 157699) They should certainly, however, be protected from misrepresentation.
('27', 74, 4, 13, 157768) He knew nothing to prevent people emigrating now except a Defence of the Realm Regulation which would expire six months after the War.
('27', 74, 4, 14, 157903) (This is the regulation preventing the emigration of unskilled labourers for work abroad, until six months after the War, unless under special or general licence.)
('27', 74, 5, 15, 158067) Once assured that equal rights for Indians existed in regard to political, municipal, legal, commercial and industrial matters in British Guiana, and that they were not alone receiving fair treatment from the administration and the general community, but would be guaranteed the continuance of such fair treatment, he would not oppose any scheme of free colonization by Indian agricultural families.
('27', 74, 6, 16, 158467) He was satisfied that the Colony had liberal constitution, and that Indians could be and were elected to membership of the Legislature and to municipal office.
('27', 74, 6, 17, 158627) He was satisfied that they had equality of rights with other races, and that there were opportunities of acquiring land for settlement.
('27', 74, 6, 18, 158763) He was in favour of allowing a test of the scheme subject to a report at the end of six months on its working by Mr. C. F. Andrews or some other representative
('27', 74, 7, 19, 158923) 1 Attorney General of British Guiana.
('27', 74, 7, 20, 158961) In 1920 he led a deputation to India to recruit emigrants for colonization in British Guiana.
('27', 75, 0, 1, 159055) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 76
('27', 75, 1, 2, 159096) of the Indian popular leaders.
('27', 75, 1, 3, 159127) The deputation accepted this proposal of a report by a popular representative independently of any supervising officer nomi nated by the Indian Government, and offered to pay all expenses.
('27', 75, 2, 4, 159316) Mr. Gandhi agreed that all necessary guarantees for the continuance of equal treatment could be furnished by the Colonial Office and British Guiana Government through the Government of India to the Indian people and its popular leaders.
('27', 75, 3, 5, 159553) It was hardly fair to use this statement in support of any scheme.
('27', 75, 3, 6, 159620) It could only be used for supporting a trial shipment under the supervision of Mr. C. F. Andrews or someone having the same status and having the same intimate knowledge of the position of British Indians abroad.
('27', 75, 3, 7, 159833) But I admit that if such a trial proved successful from the Indian standpoint, I should be bound, under the foregoing statement, not to oppose a scheme of colonization under proper safeguards.
('27', 75, 3, 8, 160026) My views, however, since the February of 1920, about the British system of Government have, as is well known, undergone a revolutionary change.
('27', 75, 3, 9, 160170) At the time I gave the statement, my faith in that system, in spite of bitter, hostile experiences, had not altogether disappeared.
('27', 75, 3, 10, 160302) But now I am able no longer to rely upon verbal or written promises made by persons working under that system and in their capacity as officials or supporters.
('27', 75, 3, 11, 160462) The history of Indian emigrants to South Africa, East Africa and Fiji is a history of broken promises and of ignominious surrender of their trust by the Imperial Government and the Indian Government, whenever it has been a question of conflicting interests of Europeans against Indians.
('27', 75, 3, 12, 160749) The handful of Europeans have almost succeeded in East Africa in bullying the Imperial Government into sacrificing the prior rights of Indian settlers there.
('27', 75, 3, 13, 160907) In South Africa, the Indian settlers’ fate is trembling in the balance.
('27', 75, 3, 14, 160979) In Fiji, the Indian is still the underdog.
('27', 75, 3, 15, 161022) There is no reason to suppose that British Guiana, if the test came, will be an exception.
('27', 75, 3, 16, 161113) The moment Indians become successful rivals of Europeans in that colony, that very moment all guarantees, written or verbal, will disappear.
('27', 75, 3, 17, 161254) Filled as I am with utter distrust of the British Imperial system, I am unable to countenance any scheme of emigration to British Guiana, no matter how promising it may appear on paper and no matter what guarantees may be given for due fulfillment of the pledges given.
('27', 75, 3, 18, 161524) The benefit that must accrue to the Indian emigrants under any such scheme will be illusory.
('27', 75, 4, 19, 161617) 1 For Gandhiji’s views on the question expressed in 1920, vide “Punjab Letter”, 2 2 1920 & “British Guiana and Fiji Deputation”, 4 2 1920.
('27', 76, 0, 1, 161756) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 77
('27', 76, 1, 2, 161799) therefore, unable to countenance the proposed scheme of Indian colonization in British Guiana.
('27', 76, 1, 3, 161894) I do not hesitate to give my opinion without consultation with the British Guiana deputations because of the root objection stated above.
('27', 76, 1, 4, 162032) If I had to express an opinion upon the merits of the scheme, the ordinary rule of courtesy would have bound me, before saying anything hostile to it, to meet the British Guiana deputation’s and understand their view points.
('27', 76, 1, 5, 162257) Not till India has come to her own and has a government fully responsible to her people and able effectively to protect Indian settlers abroad from injustice can any advantage accrue to Indian emigrants even under an ideal scheme.
('27', 76, 2, 6, 162488) M. K. GANDHI
('27', 76, 3, 7, 162501) Young India, 20 3 1924
('27', 76, 4, 8, 162524) 74. LETTER TO A. W. BAKER 1
('27', 76, 5, 9, 162552) POST ANDHERI, March 18, 1924
('27', 76, 6, 10, 162581) DEAR MR. BAKER,
('27', 76, 7, 11, 162597) I was delighted to receive your letter with The Key to Happiness.
('27', 76, 7, 12, 162663) Be Careful for Nothing has ever been with me, and did I not place all my worries at the feet of God, I should have gone mad by this time.
('27', 76, 7, 13, 162801) All I can say at present about the other part of your letter is that I am endeavouring to follow where God leads me.
('27', 76, 7, 14, 162918) Nothing can possibly keep me away from that light except my ignorance.
('27', 76, 7, 15, 162989) I have no axes to grind, no worldly ambition to serve.

('27', 76, 7, 17, 163356) But I do not wish to argue with you.
('27', 76, 7, 18, 163393) I have simply stated what has become a deep conviction with me.

('27', 83, 1, 2, 172927) 85. LETTER TO C. VIJAYARAGHAVACHARIAR 1
('27', 83, 2, 3, 172967) POST ANDHERI, March 19, 1924
('27', 83, 3, 4, 172996) MY DEAR FRIEND, I was able today to read your interview 2 from first to last.
('27', 83, 3, 5, 173074) You have touched upon topics on some of which I am pledged to silence till I have met the leaders who have warmly advocated Council entry.
('27', 83, 3, 6, 173213) Whether the last Congress 3 was a success or not is a question upon which I can say nothing because I was not an eye witness.
('27', 83, 3, 7, 173339) Your remarks on the question are most interesting.
('27', 83, 3, 8, 173390) You seem to think that the Congress has done very little in the matter of untouchability and general national education.
('27', 83, 3, 9, 173511) I venture to dissent from the view.
('27', 83, 3, 10, 173547) The removal of untouchability has been brought within the range of possibility in the near future because of the incessant propaganda by Congress Hindus.
('27', 83, 3, 11, 173701) No doubt a great deal still remains to be done.
('27', 83, 3, 12, 173749) It is not an easy feat to root out prejudices which have acquired an undeserved sanctity because of their age.
('27', 83, 3, 13, 173860) But the barrier is breaking down.
('27', 83, 3, 14, 173894) I heartily endorse your remark that it is the duty of the Hindus to move and win over all the minorities to the service of the country.
('27', 83, 3, 15, 174030) I wish that your pronouncement against untouchability was more precise and uncompromising.
('27', 83, 3, 16, 174121) I am not concerned with its origin.
('27', 83, 3, 17, 174157) I have no manner of doubt that the higher orders are entirely responsible for perpetuating the sin.
('27', 83, 3, 18, 174257) It is unfortunate, too, that you have likened the untouchability of women and others on certain occasions with the permanent untouchability under every circums tance of the suppressed classes and their descendants.
('27', 83, 3, 19, 174472) Nor am I enamoured of the method you have suggested for the amelioration of the condition of these classes.
('27', 83, 3, 20, 174580) You say that the boycott of law courts and Government schools should be removed.
('27', 83, 3, 21, 174661) I venture to doubt the soundness of the
('27', 83, 4, 22, 174701) 1 C. Vijayaraghavachariar (1852 1943); lawyer and Congressman; presided over the Nagpur session of the Indian National Congress, 1920 2 This had appeared in The Hindu and Voice of India.
('27', 83, 4, 23, 174888) Vijayaraghavachariar had sent a copy to Gandhiji which, however, is not available.
('27', 83, 4, 24, 174971) 3 The Cocanada session of 1923 over which Mahomed Ali presided
('27', 84, 0, 1, 175034) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 85
('27', 84, 1, 2, 175077) proposition.
('27', 84, 1, 3, 175090) Its value is at the present moment negative, but none the less great on that account.
('27', 84, 1, 4, 175176) Both these institutions have lost prestige.
('27', 84, 1, 5, 175220) What is wanted is removal of the slightest trace of bitterness against those who do not comply with the boycott, that is, lawyers who still practise law and boys who still make use of Government schools.
('27', 84, 1, 6, 175424) We shall win both over if we are not bitterly hostile, but concede to them the right of free judgment or sympathize with them for their weak ness.
('27', 84, 1, 7, 175571) I am convinced that, whenever we have not succeeded well or at all, the primary reason has been our inability or unwillingness to enforce non violence with all its implications in our personal conduct.
('27', 84, 1, 8, 175773) I do not wish to say anything about your suggestions as to the position after swaraj, if only because methods that ultimately bring about swaraj will largely decide our programme after swaraj.
('27', 84, 1, 9, 175966) You seem to think that “for years to come, perhaps for a century or for ever” we are bound to be partners with England not from choice, but because we must.
('27', 84, 1, 10, 176123) Therefore, for you evidently swaraj without the British connection is unthinkable.
('27', 84, 1, 11, 176206) In my opinion, if British connection is a necessity of our existence, whatever the measure of freedom we may enjoy under that connection, it cannot be described as full swaraj, for full swaraj means, in my humble opinion, our ability at any moment to sever the connection.
('27', 84, 1, 12, 176479) Partnership for me has no meaning if one party is too weak to dissolve it.
('27', 84, 1, 13, 176554) It will also follow from your reasoning that swaraj will only have to be a grant from the British Parliament.
('27', 84, 1, 14, 176664) You know my view.
('27', 84, 1, 15, 176682) The very definition that I give to swaraj is that we have to take it and, therefore, we have to grow to it.
('27', 84, 1, 16, 176790) It is an eternal condition, whether with an individual or with a nation.
('27', 84, 1, 17, 176863) Moreover, if swaraj has only to be received as a grant from the British Parliament, the whole of the argument against Council entry, in my humble opinion, falls to pieces.
('27', 84, 1, 18, 177035) I hope you are keeping well.
('27', 84, 1, 19, 177064) I am making slow but steady progress.
('27', 84, 2, 20, 177102) Yours sincerely,
('27', 84, 3, 21, 177119) C. VIJAYARAGHAVACHARIAR THE ARAMA SALEM

('27', 84, 5, 23, 177203) 1 Vijayaraghavachariar replied to this letter on March 23; vide “Letter to C. Vijayaraghavachariar”, 28 3 1924; also vide Appendix “Letter from C. Vijayaraghavachariar”, 23 3 1924.

('27', 85, 1, 2, 177425) 86. LETTER TO S. E. STOKES
('27', 85, 2, 3, 177452) POST ANDHERI, March 19, 1924
('27', 85, 3, 4, 177481) DEAR FRIEND, I got the registered packet 1 on Sunday, and yesterday being my first Monday of silence after admission to the Sassoon Hospital, I was able to read both the papers.
('27', 85, 3, 5, 177659) The written memorandum I am sending up as desired by you.
('27', 85, 3, 6, 177717) I found both to be useful and instructive as giving me the mentality of one of whose impartiality I am certain and whose opinions I value.
('27', 85, 3, 7, 177856) If I could but accept your premises and your view of non co operation, there is not much with which I should disagree.
('27', 85, 3, 8, 177975) I entirely endorse your opinion that, if there is any Council entry at all, it should not be for mere obstruction.
('27', 85, 3, 9, 178090) On the contrary, we should take advantage of everything good that may be offered by the Government measures and endeavour to do our best to correct the evil in them.
('27', 85, 3, 10, 178256) Accepting your reasoning, I would also endorse your view that the embargo upon lawyers and law courts should also be lifted.
('27', 85, 3, 11, 178381) But I think that, perhaps, there is a fundamental difference between us as to the interpretation and implications of non violent non co operation and, therefore, what appeared to you to be a dismal outlook on your coming out of prison would not have set me thinking of other means of getting rid of the paralysis which you felt and saw had overcome all Congress activities.
('27', 85, 3, 12, 178755) I would have regarded it as a necessary stage in the evolution of the public life of the country.
('27', 85, 3, 13, 178853) It would have been for me a rare opportunity and still rarer privilege for redoubling my efforts and testing my faith in the programme.
('27', 85, 3, 14, 178989) You have cited your own personal experiences and naturally conclu ded that there was something wrong about the programme in that the work that was patiently built by you and your co workers had been almost undone in a moment.
('27', 85, 3, 15, 179215) But there is a saying among lawyers that hard cases make bad law.
('27', 85, 3, 16, 179281) Properly applied, it is a sound truth.
('27', 85, 3, 17, 179320) Para phrased in religious terms, it means that because, under some exceptional circumstances, departure from religious truth may appear to be advantageous, it furnishes no ground for losing faith in the truth.
('27', 85, 3, 18, 179530) In your own case I would have reasoned to myself: This
('27', 85, 4, 19, 179585) 1 This contained “memorandums which put the case for Council entry more completely”.
('27', 86, 0, 1, 179670) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 87
('27', 86, 1, 2, 179713) undoing of the work must be regarded as the people’s sacrifice in order to get the real thing.
('27', 86, 1, 3, 179808) And what is that real thing?
('27', 86, 1, 4, 179837) For the common masses to rid themselves of the fetish of power.
('27', 86, 1, 5, 179901) For ages they have been taught to look to a Government to do everything for them, to protect them.
('27', 86, 1, 6, 180000) The Government, instead of being regarded as an instrument in their hands for their advantage, is looked up to as something beyond and apart from them which, like a deity, whether benignant or malignant, has got to be propitiated.
('27', 86, 1, 7, 180231) Non co operation as conceived by me is ceasing to co operate with that idea of Government and teaching the people to feel that the Government is their creation and not they creatures of the Government.
('27', 86, 1, 8, 180433) I should not therefore wonder that many of the so called advantages that we have hitherto enjoyed through the instrumentality of such a Government have to be sacrificed.
('27', 86, 1, 9, 180603) If the non co operation was not non violent, we would seek, as all nations in history have sought, to beat Governments with their own weapons, that is, force of arms.
('27', 86, 1, 10, 180770) In such a fight it would be folly not to make use of the whole of the Government machinery.
('27', 86, 1, 11, 180862) People in a violent struggle do not expect to sacrifice though they are prepared for it and, if they have at their disposal arms superior to those possessed by the Government, beat it down without any sacri fice.
('27', 86, 1, 12, 181075) But in a non violent struggle resort to arms is eschewed, and sacrifice for the moment is a necessity of the case.
('27', 86, 1, 13, 181190) In practice, too, in our own struggle, ever since the September of 1920, we have been sacrificing.
('27', 86, 1, 14, 181289) Lawyers, school masters, schoolboys, merchants, every class of people who have realized the implications of non violent non co operation, have sacrificed to the measure of their ability and understanding.
('27', 86, 1, 15, 181494) I know men who have lost money because they would not go to a court of law.
('27', 86, 1, 16, 181570) I know cases in which the Government officials have chuckled with pride and pleasure that men who before used to gain advantages through their instrumentality were losing, but those who lost with a full knowledge of the struggle counted their loss as gain.
('27', 86, 1, 17, 181827) It is my firm conviction that you cannot enter the Councils at the present moment with the present system and the administrators with their present mentality without participating in violence of an extremely bad type which is the basis of the Government of India.
('27', 86, 1, 18, 182091) Take again the history of the other Governments of the world.
('27', 86, 1, 19, 182153) By way of illustration I cite the Egyptian Government.
('27', 86, 1, 20, 182208) They are in a fair way to attaining to what they want.
('27', 86, 1, 21, 182263) They have resorted to ordinary means hitherto adopted.
('27', 86, 1, 22, 182318) The Egyptians are trained for the use of arms.
('27', 86, 1, 23, 182365) It was open to them to take part in the Councils and all administrative
('27', 87, 0, 1, 182437) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 88
('27', 87, 1, 2, 182478) machinery because they were able and willing to vindicate their position by force of arms.
('27', 87, 1, 3, 182569) In India we have a state of things, so far as I am aware, without a parallel in the world.
('27', 87, 1, 4, 182660) The people as a mass are neither willing nor able to take up arms.
('27', 87, 1, 5, 182727) If you go to the Councils and are defeated in your purpose by the Government, you must be prepared for raising a rebellion.
('27', 87, 1, 6, 182851) It cannot be successfully raised in India.
('27', 87, 1, 7, 182894) Nor are the present Councillors men who can give that training to the people.
('27', 87, 1, 8, 182972) My endeavour was and is to find a substitute for ordinary rebellion, and that is civil disobedience.
('27', 87, 1, 9, 183073) The Councils are no training ground even for the Councillors for civil disobedience.
('27', 87, 1, 10, 183158) They believe in the “tooth for tooth” law.
('27', 87, 1, 11, 183201) The sophistry, evasion and even fraud of the Government benches are returned in [their] coin.
('27', 87, 1, 12, 183295) Their manifest purpose is to embarrass the Government.
('27', 87, 1, 13, 183350) Their appeal is to fear.
('27', 87, 1, 14, 183375) The non co operator’s manifest purpose is never to embarrass, and his appeal must always be to the heart, therefore, to love and trust.
('27', 87, 1, 15, 183511) You evidently seem to think that mystical and religious non co operation can run side by side with the purely political non co operation of the Councils.
('27', 87, 1, 16, 183665) I hold that the two are mutually destructive, and my faith in religious non co operation is so immutable that, if I find that it would not answer the needs of India and that the masses would not respond to it, I should be content to be alone and rely upon its ultimate invincibility to convert even the masses.
('27', 87, 1, 17, 183976) Indeed, I see no escape for this world except through the acceptance of non violence as the predominant and ordinary rule of life.
('27', 87, 1, 18, 184107) The present society is ultimately based upon force.
('27', 87, 1, 19, 184159) That is violence.
('27', 87, 1, 20, 184177) My endeavour is no less than to get ride of this worship of force, and my conviction is that, if any country is ready, for assimilating the doctrine in its entirety in a large and workable measure, it is India.
('27', 87, 1, 21, 184388) And having that conviction, I have no other remedy for the needs of our country.
('27', 87, 1, 22, 184469) I think I have already said more than I wished to.
('27', 87, 1, 23, 184520) It is possible to amplify what I have said, but I have no doubt that you will yourself dot the i’s and cross the t’s.
('27', 87, 1, 24, 184638) I am almost impatient to express my opinion upon the Council entry and kindred matters, the more so after reading your memorandum, but I am under promise to Motilalji, Hakimji and other friends not to give public expression to my views till I have met them again and discussed the whole thing.
('27', 87, 1, 25, 184932) When I am free to say all that I have in view on this question and If you have time to spare from your writings, you will see the development of the
('27', 88, 0, 1, 185081) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 89
('27', 88, 1, 2, 185124) outline I have sketched above.
('27', 88, 2, 3, 185155) With love,
('27', 88, 3, 4, 185166) Yours sincerely, S.E. STOKES, ESQ.
('27', 88, 3, 5, 185201) KOTGARH SIMLA HILLS
('27', 88, 4, 6, 185221) From a photostat: S.N. 8527
('27', 88, 5, 7, 185249) 87. STATEMENT ON OPIUM POLICY
('27', 88, 6, 8, 185279) Mr. C. F. Andrews has shown me a paragraph in his writings in Young India regarding the opium policy of the Government of India.
('27', 88, 6, 9, 185408) In that paragraph he quotes Mr. Campbell, the Government represen tative at the Geneva Conference held in May 1923. 2 Mr. Campbell is reported to have stated that “from the beginning India had handled the opium question with perfect honesty of purpose, and not even its most ardent opponents including Mr. Gandhi had ever made any reproach in that respect”.
('27', 88, 6, 10, 185766) The statement Mr. Andrews has shown me was written whilst I was a prisoner in the Yeravda Jail.
('27', 88, 6, 11, 185862) Mr. Andrews tells me that, knowing my views in the matter of opium, he did not hesitate to contradict Mr. Campbell’s charge against me, but in view of the importance of the matter, he wants me to state my position clearly regarding the opium policy of the Government of India.

('27', 95, 1, 2, 197749) 95. INTERVIEW TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('27', 95, 2, 3, 197787) JUHU, March 20, 1924
('27', 95, 3, 4, 197808) In answer to questions, Mr. Gandhi very willingly gave a few details of his daily routine.
('27', 95, 3, 5, 197899) He gets up at four o’ clock, a practice which he invariably follows.
('27', 95, 3, 6, 197968) After family prayers in which the household join, he reads religious literature for a time and then goes off again in a short sleep.
('27', 95, 3, 7, 198101) At six he has his breakfast of milk Mr. Gandhi confessed with a twinkle in his eye that he was following scrupulously Colonel Maddock’s instructions regarding foodand afterwards still following his old medical advisers’ advice, he takes a walk on the verandah and treats his wound to a sun bath.
('27', 95, 3, 8, 198399) Immediately after this, he attends to his correspondence, both English and Gujarati.
('27', 95, 3, 9, 198484) In order to deal with the former he has been provided with shorthand typists who greatly facilitate his work.
('27', 95, 3, 10, 198594) His time until midday is occupied by correspondence, the study of political problems and the seeing of important political and other friends by appointment.
('27', 95, 3, 11, 198751) Early in the afternoon he has his bath and at four o’clock is ready to see the very large number of visitors who call on him.
('27', 95, 4, 12, 198877) In the evening, about six, Mr. Andrews takes him for a walk along the sea shore, and this walk has now been prolonged to about forty minutes.
('27', 95, 4, 13, 199019) The day’s work is over by about eight, at which hour Mr. Gandhi usually retires for the night.
('27', 95, 4, 14, 199114) He explained: Later on, I hope to take up spinning, once I am able to sit up without fatigue.
('27', 95, 5, 15, 199208) “What do you think of new Labour Government?” was one of the first political questions which our representative put to Mr. Gandhi.
('27', 95, 5, 16, 199339) Mr. Gandhi evidently did not think much of it.
('27', 95, 5, 17, 199386) It has a precarious existence.
('27', 95, 5, 18, 199417) It has to depend on the good will of the other parties, and if it isn’t to break in pieces, it has to conciliate its very exacting constituents and follow out its special domestic programme.
('27', 95, 5, 19, 199608) I have no doubt that in trying to acquire the support of the majority of the House in pushing through its domestic programme, it will not hesitate to sacrifice its principles regarding Imperial policy affecting India, or Indians in South Africa and Kenya.
('27', 95, 5, 20, 199864) In fact, I should not be surprised, seeing it is so weak, if the Labour Government does worse even than its predecessors so far as Indian policy is concerned.
('27', 95, 6, 21, 200023) Mr. Gandhi concluded by admitting that he was not much perturbed over the
('27', 95, 7, 22, 200097) Labour Government, because India had to rely upon her own strength and resources.
('27', 95, 7, 23, 200179) When she becomes irresistible, I have no manner of doubt that
('27', 96, 0, 1, 200241) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 97
('27', 96, 1, 2, 200284) any Government, whether Labour, Conservative or Liberal, will fall in with India’s demands.
('27', 96, 2, 3, 200376) On the subject of Council entry and recent events in the Central Provinces and in the Assembly, Mr. Gandhi frankly confessed he could say nothing.
('27', 96, 2, 4, 200523) The Swarajist leaders are coming down from Delhi to see him at the end of the month, and he cannot give any opinion on their actions until he has discussed the whole position with them.
('27', 96, 2, 5, 200709) After having done this, he will be in a position to formulate his policy.
('27', 96, 3, 6, 200783) Interrogated regarding the Colonies Committee, which has just sailed in connection with the Kenya question, Mr. Gandhi thought that the Committee could do a great deal if it was not fettered by too many restrictions.
('27', 96, 3, 7, 201000) He added: Whether the personality of the Committee is strong enough to assert itself is very difficult to say.
('27', 96, 3, 8, 201111) Speaking apart from my views as a non co operator, I cannot help noticing the absence of Mr. Sastri, Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Andrews from the Committee.
('27', 96, 3, 9, 201270) They are the men who had studied the question and know it in all its bearing, while Mr. Andrews is an expert.
('27', 96, 3, 10, 201380) I cannot help saying that these omissions are glaring and inspire me with distrust as to the Com mittee’s findings.
('27', 96, 4, 11, 201496) Mr. Gandhi gave an interesting explanation of the South African Govern ment’s decision to omit the Cape Province from the operation of the Class Areas Bill.
('27', 96, 4, 12, 201653) He said: This is merely an instance of selfishness on the part, principally, of the Dutch population.
('27', 96, 4, 13, 201755) Nearly all the house work in the Cape is done by Malay women, and if the Segregation Act came into force, these Malay women would be affected by it.
('27', 96, 4, 14, 201904) This would mean depriving a major part of the white population of its domestic help, which would give no end of inconvenience.
('27', 96, 4, 15, 202031) Consequently, as the Indian population of the Cape is smallabout 10,000 in allthe Cape people decided that they are not worth worrying about as far as segregation is concerned in view of the difficulties which segregation would bring in its train.
('27', 96, 5, 16, 202281) In the course of the conversation, Mr. Gandhi paid a tribute to Col.
('27', 96, 5, 17, 202350) Maddock “Who was more than my doctor; he is my friend” and to Mr. Andrewsor “Charlie Bhai” as he is familiarly knownwho is his right hand man at Juhu and who writes articles incessantly from morning till night.
('27', 96, 6, 18, 202565) “I hope when India gets swaraj, you will not pack us poor but honest European journalists back home,” laughingly remarked our representative.
('27', 96, 6, 19, 202707) Gandhiji replied with a bright smile as he shook hands: Nothing is farther from my mind.

('27', 97, 9, 21, 203878) DEAR MR. SHEVAKRAM, I have your letter.
('27', 97, 10, 22, 203918) In my opinion, God’s name and God’s work go hand in hand.
('27', 97, 10, 23, 203976) There is no question of preference because the two are indivisible.
('27', 97, 10, 24, 204044) A parrot like repetition of the name is worse than useless, and service or action without the consciousness that it is done in God’s name and for God’s sake is also valueless, and if we sometimes pass our time in

('27', 98, 1, 2, 204534) merely repeating the name of the deity as we have to, it is simply a course of preparation for self dedication, that is, service for the sake of and in the name of God, and when we are thoroughly attuned, continued service in that spirit is itself equal to the repetition of the name of the deity.
('27', 98, 1, 3, 204832) In the vast majority of cases, however, the setting apart a part of our time for prayer is a vital necessity.
('27', 98, 1, 4, 204942) So far as I am aware, all scriptures and, certainly, the Indian scriptures, hold a guru to be absolutely indispensable, but if we cannot get a real guru, a sham substitute is not only useless but injurious.
('27', 98, 1, 5, 205149) That is one of the reasons why I suppose the tenth guru established the Granth Sahib as the last Guru.
('27', 98, 1, 6, 205252) I have no spiritual guru, but believing in the institution, I have been in search of one for the last thirty years.
('27', 98, 1, 7, 205368) The very search is the greatest consolation to me.

('27', 101, 5, 10, 210364) 102. INTERVIEW TO “LIVERPOOL POST” AND
('27', 101, 6, 11, 210403) “MERCURY” [March 21, 1924]
('27', 101, 7, 12, 210430) Today I talked for over an hour with Gandhi.
('27', 101, 7, 13, 210475) Somewhere outside the verandah hovered his son, and C. F. Andrews, an Englishman who espoused the cause of the African Indian and whose long beard and native garments and bare feet proclaimed one voluntarily quitting his own caste.
('27', 101, 7, 14, 210707) Despite the countless visits which the Swarajist inflict upon Gandhi, I gained the impression that his gentle spirit is chastened through long imprisonment and illness.
('27', 101, 7, 15, 210876) Gandhi admitted repeatedly the breakdown of that strange creed of his by which he hoped to make India a nation such as this materialistic world never sawsimple and non violent, maintaining independence amidst opportunist Asia by the quality which he called “soul force”.
('27', 101, 8, 16, 211148) Now that they in the Legislative Assembly have voted down the Govern 
('27', 101, 9, 17, 211218) ment’s demand for money grants, they want Gandhi’s consent to a campaign of civil
('27', 101, 10, 18, 211300) disobedience throughout India which means an agitation against the payment of all
('27', 101, 11, 19, 211382) It is known that Gandhi originally opposed participation in these Government
('27', 101, 12, 20, 211459) Assemblies and cast no favorable eye on the Swarajist game of obstruction.
('27', 101, 12, 21, 211534) But the
('27', 101, 13, 22, 211542) Swarajist success has taken the country by storm, and the leader who made the swaraj
('27', 101, 14, 23, 211627) movement before other politicians were heard of must bow to the reputation formed
('27', 101, 15, 24, 211709) while he was in prison.
('27', 101, 15, 25, 211733) Civil disobedience is always an advisable weapon when governments are not based on the will of the people, but it is
('27', 101, 16, 26, 211850) 1 Gandhiji’s stenographer 2 Pyarelal Nayyar, Gandhiji’s secretary, since 1920, and biographer
('27', 102, 0, 1, 211944) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 103
('27', 102, 1, 2, 211988) practicable only when the masses are imbued with a spirit of non violence.
('27', 102, 2, 3, 212063) Gandhi remarked: India is now ready for swaraj if granted, but India is unable to seize swaraj, either by force, which I oppose, or by disciplined non violence.
('27', 102, 3, 4, 212224) Gandhi then defined swaraj: It means Parliamentary Government, but I hope not in the sense of Western nations where selfish interest reigns supreme.
('27', 102, 3, 5, 212373) It means also the return to India’s ancient life.
('27', 102, 3, 6, 212423) Despite years of sneering, I still believe that the home spinning wheel can oust the British factory.
('27', 102, 3, 7, 212525) If so, how can British capital, which is the sole reason for British dominion, expect compensation?
('27', 102, 3, 8, 212625) Myself, I do not believe in a tariff wall against foreign imports.
('27', 102, 4, 9, 212692) Concerning the famous triple boycott against British courts, schools and Councils, Gandhi was pessimistic.
('27', 102, 4, 10, 212799) He said he would now organize panchayats or courts of arbitration, resembling Sinn Fein tribunals, by which suits would be settled outside the King’s writ.
('27', 102, 4, 11, 212955) Concerning the schools, Gandhi hoped only to make the non Government institutions more attractive.
('27', 102, 4, 12, 213054) Asked what advantages the curriculum of swaraj schools had over Government schools, Gandhi said they teach freedom of thought, whereas the British schools inculcate only fixed rules which fit the natives for service under the present regime.
('27', 102, 4, 13, 213296) Gandhi declared that such schools as on the Western plan make of the natives automatons.
('27', 102, 4, 14, 213385) He added that complete boycott of British goods would drive the British from India; but he admitted that the time was not yet ripe.
('27', 102, 5, 15, 213517) Asked to state what hopes he had of early attainment of swaraj, Gandhi answered only in the negative.
('27', 102, 5, 16, 213619) From experience in England, when he was a student.
('27', 102, 5, 17, 213670) he declared that Labour would think first of British constituencies, last of all, [of] India.
('27', 102, 5, 18, 213764) But on hopes from the present Swarajist obstruction in the Assembly, Gandhi was ominously silent.
('27', 102, 5, 19, 213862) He thought the British, whom he did not regard as a bad people, would eventually hit upon an honourable agreement, and declared that he had good reason for this hope.
('27', 102, 6, 20, 214029) Passing to the matter of the army, he announced that he would reduce this to a
('27', 102, 7, 21, 214108) fourth of its present establishment, and would change the whole railway system,
('27', 102, 8, 22, 214188) which he thought followed too closely upon strategic lines.
('27', 102, 9, 23, 214248) “You have no enemies to fear?” Gandhi was asked.
('27', 102, 9, 24, 214297) He replied: We fear the Afghans.
('27', 102, 9, 25, 214330) Once the Hindu Muslim unity [is] established, the Amir of Afghanistan would not attack fellow Muslims.
('27', 103, 0, 1, 214433) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 104
('27', 103, 1, 2, 214475) If Russia attacks us, we expect the militaristic nations of Europe to come to our aid to prevent Russia becoming too strong, and we should welcome help.
('27', 103, 1, 3, 214628) What do I think of the present rulers of Russia?
('27', 103, 1, 4, 214677) I take them at their face value.
('27', 103, 1, 5, 214710) What builds on force ends by force.
('27', 103, 2, 6, 214746) Do the Indian masses understand your preachings on non violence when at the same time they are told the British have done wrong?” I asked him.
('27', 103, 2, 7, 214889) Gandhi replied: Yes, but nowhere outside India would this be possible.
('27', 103, 2, 8, 214960) You Westerners are unable to understand this, but it is the spirit of the Indian people.
('27', 103, 3, 9, 215049) Asked if his attitude was unchanged regarding the “evils” of Western civilization, Gandhi replied that he would not abolish the railways since they were already established; he approved of modern farm implements since Indian agricul turists needed help.
('27', 103, 3, 10, 215303) Concerning the British factories, he hoped the spinning wheel would prove their doom.

('27', 103, 6, 13, 215538) not so strong as formerly.

('27', 103, 7, 18, 215845) What I want to end is the Indian’s mortal fear of the white skin which was more prevalent when I was a boy than now.

('27', 108, 4, 7, 223605) 111. STATEMENT TO PRESS 1
('27', 108, 5, 8, 223631) BOMBAY, March 23, 1924 The following cablegram has been received from Cape Town signed by Mr. Pather, General Secretary, South African Indian Congress:
('27', 108, 6, 9, 223783) South African Indian community submits notwithstanding strongest protests Union Government determined carrying through Class Areas Bill violating pledges given.
('27', 108, 6, 10, 223944) Bill indefensible.
('27', 108, 6, 11, 223963) Foreigners, also Euro Africans, Malays and Natives being exempted.
('27', 108, 6, 12, 224030) Bill will apply only to Indians.
('27', 108, 6, 13, 224063) Euro Africans, Malays and Natives assembled in thousands Cape Town assured Mrs. Sarojini Naidu of support to Indians in opposition to Bill.
('27', 108, 6, 14, 224203) Indians will never submit segregation.
('27', 108, 6, 15, 224242) Inform India.
('27', 108, 6, 16, 224256) Please take such action as you think best.
('27', 108, 6, 17, 224299) Mrs. Sarojini Naidu has made deep impression and won many hearts.
('27', 108, 6, 18, 224365) Mrs. Naidu deferred leaving South Africa until 30th April owing great demand on her in interest of the cause.
('27', 108, 6, 19, 224475) This is startling news, almost too bad even for South Africa to be believed.
('27', 108, 6, 20, 224552) I have already endeavoured to show why the Cape was to be excluded from the operation of the measure.
('27', 108, 6, 21, 224654) If the information cabled by Reuter as to the exclusion of the Cape is correct, there is something wrong in the foregoing cable, or the information contained in it is applicable to the other three Provinces only, namely, Orangia, Transvaal and Natal.
('27', 108, 6, 22, 224905) The position will be that, so far as the Cape is concerned, the Cape Indians will still remain exempted from the operation of the measure, whereas, in the other provinces the meassure will apply only to Indians.
('27', 108, 6, 23, 225117) There is no difficulty about understanding the exemptions, because the idea of segregation of Natives and Malays in the extreme sense is new.

('27', 110, 5, 9, 227866) 113. LETTER TO D. R. MAJLI
('27', 110, 6, 10, 227893) POST ANDHERI, March 23, 1924
('27', 110, 7, 11, 227922) MY DEAR MAJLI, Early in the morning m 2 first thought went out to you, and I asked myself how I could help you to be yourself again.
('27', 110, 7, 12, 228055) Belgaum is to have the honour of holding the next Congress Session.
('27', 110, 7, 13, 228123) 3 I know you want to take your part in the preparations.
('27', 110, 7, 14, 228180) I know also that you are one of the best of workers.
('27', 110, 7, 15, 228233) All that you need do is to become perfectly calm and get rid of excitement.
('27', 110, 7, 16, 228309) I fear that you have been thinking too much, in the jail, of our country’s troubles; but it would not do for us merely to be thinking of the troubles.
('27', 110, 7, 17, 228460) What are we?
('27', 110, 7, 18, 228473) We should leave all the cares to God.
('27', 110, 7, 19, 228511) Ours is to do our level best in lightening the burdens of India.
('27', 110, 7, 20, 228576) Have you ever read Tulsidas’s Ramayana?
('27', 110, 7, 21, 228616) If you do not know Hindi fairly well, probably you have not read it.
('27', 110, 7, 22, 228685) The great saint wrote his Ramayana in my opinion, to glorify Rama’s name.
('27', 110, 7, 23, 228759) For me it has been a talisman.
('27', 110, 7, 24, 228790) My nurse, whom I used to love as my mother, and in whose company much more of my time was passed in childhood than in my mother’s, used to tell me that if I thought of evil spirits at night and dreaded them, I could ward them off by repeating the name of Rama.
('27', 110, 7, 25, 229051) Having faith in the nurse, I followed her prescription, and whenever at night vague fears seized hold of me, I used to recite the sacred name, and it answered the purpose.
('27', 110, 7, 26, 229223) As I grew old, the faith weakened.
('27', 110, 7, 27, 229258) My mentor, the nurse, was
('27', 110, 8, 28, 229284) 1 This paragraph constitutes the message which was read at a meeting of the Journalists’ Association at the Voice of India Office, Bombay, on March 25; K. Natarajan, editor of The Indian Social Reformer, presided.
('27', 110, 9, 29, 229498) 2 This was held in December 1924 under Gandhiji’s presidentship.
('27', 110, 9, 30, 229563) 3 Shankerlal Banker, who was his co prisoner in Yeravda
('27', 111, 0, 1, 229619) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 112
('27', 111, 1, 2, 229661) I ceased to take the name of Rama, and my fears revived.
('27', 111, 1, 3, 229718) In the jail I read the Ramayana with greater attention and still greater devotion than ever before, and whenever I felt lonely or felt the pride in me rising and telling me that I could do something for India, to give me due humility and to make me experience the presence of the Almighty, and thus to remove my loneliness, I used calmly to recite the name Rama with all the halo that Tulsidas has surrounded it with.
('27', 111, 1, 4, 230136) I cannot put in words the indescribable peace that then came on me.
('27', 111, 1, 5, 230204) As you know, Mr. Banker 1 was torn away from me for some time.
('27', 111, 1, 6, 230267) When he rejoined me, he related his own experiences to me.
('27', 111, 1, 7, 230326) He used to experience all kinds of dreadful things after the cell door was cruelly locked upon him.
('27', 111, 1, 8, 230426) But he related to me graphically how the recitation of the name calmed him and gave him strength also to shed all those unbecoming fears.
('27', 111, 1, 9, 230564) I, therefore, send you the much tried prescription.
('27', 111, 1, 10, 230616) Think, whenever you feel you are excited, of Rama and the peace giving nature of the recitation.
('27', 111, 1, 11, 230713) Continue to recite the name slowly, forgetting everything, and considering yourself as one of the tiniest atoms in the mighty universe, and God willing the excitement will subside, and you will experience a blissful peace.
('27', 111, 1, 12, 230936) The sages of old knew from experience what they were saying when they prescribed for troubled souls Ramanama, Dwadash Mantra 2 and such other things.
('27', 111, 1, 13, 231086) The more I think of them, the more true all those mantras appear to me today.
('27', 111, 1, 14, 231164) I wish you could have faith enough to repeat Ramanama or such mantra which memory might have hallowed for you, and I know that you will soon be yourself again.
('27', 111, 2, 15, 231324) Yours sincerely, [PS.] You know that you owe me a letter.
('27', 111, 2, 16, 231382) I wrote immediately in reply to your postcard.
('27', 111, 2, 17, 231429) I await your acknowledgment of my letter.
('27', 111, 3, 18, 231471) D. R. MAJLI

('27', 112, 6, 9, 232149) 115. LETTER TO MANIBEHN PATEL
('27', 112, 7, 10, 232179) Monday [On or before March 24, 1924] 2
('27', 112, 8, 11, 232218) MANI, Bhai Manilal told me today that you are now free from fever, but still very weak and are living at Dr. Kanuga’s.
('27', 112, 8, 12, 232337) I should like you to come over here, if father and the doctor permit.
('27', 112, 8, 13, 232407) Here you will have both rest and peace of mind, and will soon recover your strength.
('27', 112, 8, 14, 232492) And then, I shall be able to take work from you.
('27', 112, 8, 15, 232541) Neither you nor your father need fear that you will be a burden to me.
('27', 112, 8, 16, 232612) For you will be a burden only to the floor, and the floor is pretty strong and capable of bearing the weight of a hundred girls like you!
('27', 112, 8, 17, 232750) Another [person] on whom the burden will fall is the cook.
('27', 112, 8, 18, 232809) But Revashankerbhai has given us a stalwart cook as strong as the floor itself!
('27', 112, 8, 19, 232889) If you come here, I shall be free from anxiety on your account.
('27', 112, 8, 20, 232953) For every man or woman engaged in the service of the nation and falling ill away from me adds to my worry.
('27', 112, 8, 21, 233060) If they are under my observation, I would be free from worry to that extent.
('27', 112, 8, 22, 233137) I am sure Dahyabhai is giving more time to spinning to make up for your not spinning.
('27', 112, 8, 23, 233223) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati]
