('27', 113, 1, 2, 233528) 116. APPEAL TO THE PUBLIC 1
('27', 113, 2, 3, 233556) JUHU, March 24, 1924
('27', 113, 3, 4, 233577) DEAR BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I address this appeal to such of you as come to see me daily, or intend doing so.
('27', 113, 3, 5, 233686) I appealed to you sometime ago through the Press that those of you who must see me may do so between the hours of 4 and 5 in the evening.
('27', 113, 3, 6, 233824) You are either not aware of this or come before or after these hours just because you cannot help coming.
('27', 113, 3, 7, 233930) The result is sad for me.
('27', 113, 3, 8, 233956) The little service that it is given to me to render is disturbed.
('27', 113, 3, 9, 234022) The capital of energy at my disposal is very small, and I want to utilize it only in service.
('27', 113, 3, 10, 234116) I wish to resume editorship of Navajivan and Young India from next week.
('27', 113, 3, 11, 234189) And I need absolute quiet for that work.
('27', 113, 3, 12, 234230) If all my time and energy are taken up in seeing and entertaining you, it will not be possible from me to edit the weeklies in the way I desire.
('27', 113, 3, 13, 234375) Moreover, seeing me is not likely to be of any benefit to you.
('27', 113, 3, 14, 234438) It is an indication of your love for me, but it is an exaggerated indi cation.
('27', 113, 3, 15, 234517) The love itself is a great force, and I should have you apply that force not to seeing me, but to the service of the people.
('27', 113, 3, 16, 234642) I would have you send me on all the money that you have to expend on a visit to me for being spent on the production and propagation of khaddar.
('27', 113, 3, 17, 234787) I would have you devote all the time a visit to me would take up to all or any of the following objects: (1) Spinning or carding and making slivers; (2) Khaddar propaganda; (3) Teaching spinning or carding to your friends and neigh bours.
('27', 113, 3, 18, 235026) To such of those as are not prepared to do any of these things and still cannot restrain themselves from seeing me I would appeal to restrict their visits to the time between 5 and 6 on all evenings except Monday, my day of silencewhen I cannot possibly see any visitor.
('27', 113, 3, 19, 235298) It is evident that I cannot see them individually.
('27', 113, 3, 20, 235349) I shall have to ask them to be satisfied with seeing me all at a time.
('27', 113, 4, 21, 235420) 1 This open letter, the original of which was in Gujarati, was published generally in the Press.
('27', 114, 0, 1, 235517) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 115
('27', 114, 1, 2, 235561) I may also request intending visitors to bring with them yarn spun by them or money for khaddar work.
('27', 114, 1, 3, 235663) The yarn will be turned into khaddar and the money used for khaddar production.
('27', 114, 1, 4, 235743) I shall feel grateful if you will kindly accept my request and all the time thus saved will be saved for the service of the country.
('27', 114, 3, 5, 235876) Your faithful servant,
('27', 114, 4, 6, 235899) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 27 3 1924

('27', 115, 5, 9, 237037) 119. LETTER TO K. G. REKHADE
('27', 115, 6, 10, 237066) POST ANDHERI, March 25, 1924
('27', 115, 7, 11, 237095) DEAR MR. REKHADE, I have your letter.
('27', 115, 7, 12, 237133) I do not think you will be satisfied with the Ashram life in Sabarmati.
('27', 115, 7, 13, 237205) All attention there is today concentrated upon the development of hand spinning and hand weaving.
('27', 115, 7, 14, 237303) The literary side of the Ashram takes the background.
('27', 115, 7, 15, 237357) Though, therefore, there is a very good library attached to the Ashram, I cannot say that the atmosphere is favorable for philosophical studies.
('27', 115, 7, 16, 237502) One cannot be reading and thinking whilst all around one are away working for all that they are worth.
('27', 115, 7, 17, 237605) The Ashram has been given that turn because I am convinced that we have had an overdose of philosophical and political studies.
('27', 115, 7, 18, 237733) The faculty of working with our hands and feet is all but atrophied.
('27', 115, 7, 19, 237802) An attempt is being made at the Ashram to revive the taste for hand labour.
('27', 115, 7, 20, 237878) Nor is it possible at the Ashram to provide for your financial wants.
('27', 115, 7, 21, 237948) Have you met.
('27', 115, 7, 22, 237962) Jamnalalji?
('27', 115, 7, 23, 237974) He might be able to guide you.
('27', 115, 8, 24, 238005) Yours sincerely,
('27', 115, 9, 25, 238022) K. G. REKHADE WARDHA (C. P.)

('27', 116, 3, 4, 238305) MY DEAR FRIEND AND BROTHER, I have your letter 1. I am following your movement through the papers, and I see that you have borne the domestic affliction 2 with the courage and resignation worthy of you.

('27', 116, 3, 10, 238867) I could easily take care of you, that is to say, you will be left to take care of yourself and make yourself as comfortable as it is possible in a place that has been turned into an hospital.

('27', 116, 3, 13, 239214) Prabhudas though not bed ridden is also an invalid, and I have invited mad Majli too to come here.

('27', 116, 3, 17, 239483) You may know that I am a better nurse than a politician, if I am one at all, and what is more, I felt ashamed to be occupying a big bungalow like this all alone when there were patients, some of whom, brought up under me from infancy, requiring far greater care, attention and change than I did.
('27', 116, 3, 18, 239779) They are all here, therefore, not for my consolation but for their own good; but having turned the bungalow into an hospital, I have disabled myself for looking after guests, whom I would not have if I could not give them the attention they deserve.
('27', 116, 3, 19, 240029) And while I should be quite glad to leave you to your self, and feel that I have done enough, I could not feel likewise regar ding Begum Saheba.
('27', 116, 3, 20, 240174) Now you know all about me.
('27', 116, 3, 21, 240201) Tell me when you are coming.
('27', 116, 3, 22, 240230) I wish you were here to join the discussions with the leaders who are coming over in the course of the week.

('27', 118, 8, 19, 242953) SATYAPAL
('27', 118, 9, 20, 242962) POST ANDHERI, March 25, 1924
('27', 118, 10, 21, 242991) DEAR DR.
('27', 118, 10, 22, 243000) SATYAPAL, I was glad to receive your letter giving me so much information about tension between Hindus and Muslims.
('27', 118, 10, 23, 243116) I await the second instal 
('27', 119, 0, 1, 243143) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 120
('27', 119, 1, 2, 243185) ment regarding Sikhs and Hindus with interest.
('27', 119, 1, 3, 243232) I know that the prob lem before the country is very serious and very complex, and in our ability to solve it satisfactorily and permanently lies the road to swaraj.
('27', 119, 1, 4, 243397) I have been thinking over it day and night ever since my release, and as soon as I have seen the leaders, I shall begin to write upon it.
('27', 119, 1, 5, 243535) I thank you for your inquiry about my health.

('27', 119, 10, 18, 243959) JUHU, March 27, 1924
('27', 119, 11, 19, 243980) He said he was satisfied with the progress and, though he needed much rest, he had resumed his practice of getting up at four o’ clock in the morning.
('27', 119, 11, 20, 244131) To a further question he replied that he had already begun the indispensable work of spinning.
('27', 119, 11, 21, 244226) As for the books he had written in the Jail, he gave our representative to understand that the History of Satyagraha in South Africa would be soon published by the Navajivan Publishing House, while the text books for children were made over to the Gujarat Vidyapith authorities for publication.
('27', 119, 12, 22, 244521) 1 This was written on the reverse of the telegram received from Kitchlew, dated March 26, 1924.
('27', 120, 0, 1, 244617) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 121
('27', 120, 1, 2, 244661) Pointing out The Times of India’s leaderette on Mrs. Naidu entitled “Mrs.
('27', 120, 2, 3, 244735) Naidu’s Poetics”, our representative asked Mahatmaji what he thought of Mrs. Naidu’s mission.
('27', 120, 2, 4, 244829) I am sorry to see The Times of India’s leaderette.
('27', 120, 2, 5, 244880) All the charges levelled against Mrs. Naidu in the leaderette are really answered in the special cable to The Times of India published in the same issue.
('27', 120, 2, 6, 245034) All cable messages, being a summary of speeches or writings, have to be taken with the greatest caution.
('27', 120, 3, 7, 245139) Illustrating this from his own life, as rich in varied experiences as in suf fering, he said: I was myself lynched in Durban because Reuter had cabled in 1896 a summary in a few sentences of pamphlet 1 I wrote in India describing the position of Indians in Natal.
('27', 120, 3, 8, 245403) It was not a conscious misrepresentation; nevertheless the intensive condensation of a 30 page octavo size pamphlet gave a very inaccurate account of what I had written.
('27', 120, 3, 9, 245573) The Europeans of Natal, when they understood what I had already stated in India, repented of the wrong they had done me.
('27', 120, 4, 10, 245694) Referring to the “Message from Mr. Gandhi” facetiously alluded to by the Times, Mahatmaji observed: My message to Mrs. Naidu was published in the Times and other newspapers.
('27', 120, 4, 11, 245868) I am inclined to believe that Mrs. Naidu has undoubtedly made a forcible, but in no sense irritating, speech.
('27', 120, 4, 12, 245978) She is too shrewd not to understand the gravity of the situation in South Africa.
('27', 120, 4, 13, 246060) the special cable to the Times would almost go to show that, if anything, she is too conciliatory.
('27', 120, 4, 14, 246159) For instance, she is said to have admitted that there is some economic menace owing to the low standard of certain classes of Indians.
('27', 120, 4, 15, 246294) It can be proved that their mode of life is no worse than that of the retail traders of the same standing.
('27', 120, 4, 16, 246401) I am not giving my own testimony but that of Europeans.
('27', 120, 4, 17, 246457) Nor can it be a grievance against Indians that they sent money to India.
('27', 120, 4, 18, 246530) It can be proved from statistics that Europeans sent out of South Africa ever so much more than Indians.
('27', 120, 4, 19, 246635) I should not be at all surprised if the full statement made by Mrs. Naidu to the Times correspondent has clauses qualifying the statements.
('27', 120, 4, 20, 246775) Anyway, according to the Times view of things, if she has erred, she has erred on the right side.
('27', 120, 4, 21, 246873) I have no fear whatsoever of her presence in South Africa doing any harm to India by her unguarded language.
('27', 120, 5, 22, 246982) 1 This was written on the reverse of the telegram received from Kitchlew, dated March 26, 1924.
('27', 121, 0, 1, 247078) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 122
('27', 121, 1, 2, 247120) The interview which was gradually drifting to grave political problems was at this stage enlivened by the appearance of Mr. Andrews in khadi shirt and dhoti with a copy of the latest London Punch in his hand.
('27', 121, 1, 3, 247329) “You are now immortalized, Mahatmaji,
('27', 121, 2, 4, 247367) if you are not already so,” humorously remarked Mr. Andrews with a broad smile.
('27', 121, 3, 5, 247447) “Here is ‘Charivaria’ in Punch about you,” said he, handing over the number of Punch to Mahatmaji.
('27', 121, 4, 6, 247546) Gandhiji replied as he briskly noted the contents: I am indeed immortalized, all the more so for the reasons that the reference to me occurs on the very first page and just after the picture of Pussy.
('27', 121, 5, 7, 247747) And then followed a loud burst of laughter ringing in the gallery, attracting the attention of two patients resting at a small distance.
('27', 121, 6, 8, 247884) Asked as to what he thought of the non payment of the Poll tax organized by the Kenya Indians, Mahatmaji replied: As the Poll tax affected only 4, 000 Indians, its non payment is not calculated to develop into a sharp struggle.
('27', 121, 6, 9, 248112) It is, however, bound to result in securing discipline and order amongst the Indians, though it does not involve intense suffering.
('27', 121, 6, 10, 248244) Europeans must feel that Indians are determined and would no longer submit to injustice.
('27', 121, 7, 11, 248333) Pointing to Mr. Sastri’s attitude, he said that Indians here must continue to give their moral support even as Indians in Kenya must persevere in the struggle.
('27', 121, 8, 12, 248493) Further asked as to what he thought of the Congress proceedings of the past two years, Mahatmaji frankly confessed that he had not been able to study the Congress proceedings of the past years.
('27', 121, 8, 13, 248687) Current events so much occupy such time as my feeble health allows me to spare.
('27', 121, 8, 14, 248767) But even if I had leisure to study the Congress literature during the past two years, I should hesitate to judge or criticize the action of my co workers.
('27', 121, 8, 15, 248922) It is so easy to be wise after the event.
('27', 121, 8, 16, 248964) But it is not equally easy to come to a just decision.
('27', 121, 8, 17, 249019) But I have faith enough in the probity, single mindedness and devotion of the principal Congress workers whether they were for entering the Councils or against.
('27', 121, 8, 18, 249180) It was an honest difference of opinion.
('27', 121, 8, 19, 249220) Such honest differences will remain so long as we are what we are.
('27', 121, 8, 20, 249287) In my opinion, it is a healthy sign when people refuse to surrender their opinions for the sake of achieving a superficial unity.
('27', 121, 9, 21, 249417) Our representative further asked, “I have noticed your remarks about the Labour Government’s Indian policy in the Times.
('27', 121, 9, 22, 249538) Would you give the same opinion even if the Labour Government were in power with an over whelming majority?” I do not think I should much alter my view because, even with an overwhelming majority, unless a Labour Government places
('27', 122, 0, 1, 249769) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 123
('27', 122, 1, 2, 249813) principles before popularity, it will be difficult for it to shoulder a really liberal measure for India without risking its domestic policy.
('27', 122, 2, 3, 249955) As the talk drifted to the political events of the past two years, Mahatmaji expressed his profound satisfaction at the result of the Borsad satyagraha and remarked: The lesson that Borsad satyagraha teaches is of inestimable importance.
('27', 122, 2, 4, 250193) Whilst it is true that the Government of Bombay deserved to be complimented upon its reasonableness and sagacity in truly sizing up the situation, the Borsad satyagrahis by their utter non violence, determination and the justice of their cause, made themselves invincible.
('27', 122, 2, 5, 250466) And if it was possible to organize whole taluka for successful satyagraha in respect of a small and particular evil, it must be possible to organize satyagraha on a larger scale in respect of a general and deep seated evil.
('27', 122, 2, 6, 250690) The only thing required is sufficient workers with an unquenchable faith in their cause and their means.
('27', 122, 2, 7, 250795) Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel himself had that faith and he had workers who were infected with the same faith.
('27', 122, 3, 8, 250898) Asked as to what he thought of doing after he fully gained his health, Mahatmaji said that would depend upon the situation that might face the country at that time.
('27', 122, 3, 9, 251063) I have no settled programme of the work after the completion of my convalescence.
('27', 122, 3, 10, 251145) As I want to hold myself free for any emergencies that may arise, I am accepting no appointments in advance.
('27', 122, 3, 11, 251254) The Bombay Chronicle, 29 3 1924

('27', 127, 3, 4, 258142) DEAR SIR DINSHAW, Perhaps you have heard of the late Sorabji 1 of Adajan.
('27', 127, 3, 5, 258216) As you know, he was in South Africa for a long time.
('27', 127, 3, 6, 258269) He was one of the satyagrahis who suffered the longest term of imprisonment.
('27', 127, 3, 7, 258346) After he qualified as a barrister, he went to South Africa to do public work there.
('27', 127, 3, 8, 258430) His expenses were paid by a friend.
('27', 127, 3, 9, 258466) He has left a widow and a daughter.
('27', 127, 3, 10, 258502) Mr. Pallonjee is a near relative of the Sorabjee family.
('27', 127, 3, 11, 258559) The widow and her daughter are at present living in Bombay for the sake of the daughter’s education.
('27', 127, 3, 12, 258660) The mother has to pay a very high rent.

('27', 127, 3, 14, 258780) I do not know the terms under which these tenements are let.
('27', 127, 3, 15, 258841) There was very little left by Mr. Sorabjee.
('27', 127, 3, 16, 258885) I think it was under Rs. 1, 000. This was all paid to the widow before I went to prison.
('27', 127, 3, 17, 258974) If you can, consistently with the terms under which the tenements refer red to are let to poor people, give a lease of one of them to Mrs. Sorabji, you will confer a personal favour on me.
('27', 127, 3, 18, 259163) The late Sorabji was one of the dearest among my comrades.
('27', 127, 3, 19, 259222) Among my many Parsee friends he was one of the most selfless.
('27', 127, 3, 20, 259284) Mr. Gokhale himself was so much struck by the beauty of his character that he implored him to become a member of his Society, and had he lived and come back to India and had Mr. Gokhale also lived, it is highly likely that he would have joined the Society.
('27', 127, 3, 21, 259541) I relate this not to influence your decision, because that would have to be arrived at in terms of the conditions guiding the lease of these tenements, but I mention the fact to show why I am interested in everything connected with the deceased.
('27', 127, 3, 22, 259787) And, could I have persuaded the widow to throw in her lot with me at Sabarmati, I would not have troubled you; but I can well appreciate her desire to give her daughter a training such as is given to the general body of Parsee girls.
('27', 127, 3, 23, 260021) For this I have no provision in the Ashram where we only turn out spinners and weavers and endeavour

('27', 133, 1, 2, 267722) 143. LETTER TO SHIVDASANI
('27', 133, 2, 3, 267748) POST ANDHERI, March 28, 1924
('27', 133, 3, 4, 267777) DEAR MR. SHIVDASANI, I have your interesting letter.
('27', 133, 4, 5, 267830) With the views I hold you will not, I trust, expect me to do anything in connection with your scheme.
('27', 133, 4, 6, 267932) All the energy I have I must devote to the immediate work before me.
('27', 133, 4, 7, 268001) Your argument about machinery is not at all convincing.
('27', 133, 4, 8, 268057) There is a tremendous fallacy lying underneath your broad statement: “Machinery can only supplant machinery.” If you will visualize the whole process in detail, you will find that it is totally unnecessary to import machinery in order to supplant machine made cloth we receive from outside.
('27', 133, 4, 9, 268348) Do you not see that the whole of the energy and cost of sending cotton say from a village in the centre of India to Manchester, to have it converted into cloth there and re import it, is saved by the villages themselves converting their own cotton into cloth?
('27', 133, 4, 10, 268608) It should surely strike you that no machinery in the world can compete with these villagers who need no other machine than their own willing hands and feet, and a few simple wooden instruments which they can devise themselves.
('27', 133, 4, 11, 268835) I would like you again to consider it from your own standpoint.
('27', 133, 4, 12, 268899) Multiply the cost of installation in one village by 700,000 and then ask yourself who is to find the capital and to what end?
('27', 133, 4, 13, 269025) Would you impose all these complications on villagers who are well able, during their leisure hours, to turn their cotton into cloth?
('27', 133, 4, 14, 269159) I hope not.
('27', 133, 5, 15, 269171) Yours sincerely,
('27', 133, 6, 16, 269188) MR. SHIVDASANI, L.C.E., BAR AT LAW HIRABAD HYDERABAD (SIND)
('27', 133, 7, 17, 269248) From a photostat: S.N. 8617; also C.W. 5167

('27', 138, 4, 5, 276425) 150. LETTER TO MAHADEV PANDAY AND CARAMAT
('27', 138, 5, 6, 276467) ALLI MACDOOM
('27', 138, 6, 7, 276480) POST ANDHERI, March 28, 1924
('27', 138, 7, 8, 276509) DEAR FRIENDS, I have your letter of the 25th inst.
('27', 138, 7, 9, 276560) As my difficulty is fundamental, I fear I can do nothing to help you.
('27', 138, 7, 10, 276630) You state that the Negroes are clamouring for the conditions offered to our Indian colonists.
('27', 138, 7, 11, 276724) Personally I do not mind it, nor need our countrymen in British Guiana fear the proposed influx of the Negroes.
('27', 138, 7, 12, 276836) If the 1, 30,000 Indians give a good account of themselves, they will bless themselves and bless the Negroes and everyone else who goes there.
('27', 138, 7, 13, 276979) Surely out of that population you should be able to raise enough doctors, Pundits, Maulvis and all other professionals.
('27', 138, 7, 14, 277099) I cannot help observing, too, that even at the present moment there is nothing to prevent a single Indian from freely emigrating to British Guiana if he chose to.
('27', 138, 7, 15, 277262) What I dread and what I do not want in the present helpless condition of India is a stimulated or assisted emigration.
('27', 138, 7, 16, 277381) You may know that hundreds of free Indians go to the Straits, Mauritius, Madagascar, Zanzibar and several other parts of the world without let or hindrance.
('27', 138, 7, 17, 277538) What baffles me is this feverish agitation and great waste of money in connection with a scheme of colonization.
('27', 138, 7, 18, 277651) If you do not mind my telling you that, on that very account, apart from the fundamental difficulty, I thoroughly distrust it.
('27', 138, 8, 19, 277778) Yours sincerely, MESSRS MAHADEO PANDAY AND CARMAT ALLI MACDOOM MAIDEN’S HOTEL [DELHI]
('27', 138, 9, 20, 277864) From a copy: S.N. 8625; also C.W. 5168

('27', 141, 6, 10, 281698) [Before March 30, 1924] How can you account for cases of pneumonia and other diseases in this beautiful spot where there is no shortage of houses, where light and air are unlimited and where you seek escape from the squalor and congestion of Bombay?
('27', 141, 6, 11, 281948) I simply cannot understand this.
('27', 141, 6, 12, 281981) Rather than that I, an invalid myself, should reproach you for this, I think I should try to explain to you that it is we ourselves who are responsible for these conditions.
('27', 141, 6, 13, 282155) I look upon mosquitoes, fleas, flies and other agents which spread disease, as correctives provided for us by Nature.

('27', 142, 2, 11, 284781) Conditions are different now from what they were in those days.

('27', 144, 1, 2, 288451) 157. LETTER TO K. P. KESAVA MENON
('27', 144, 2, 3, 288485) ANDHERI, April 1, [1924]
('27', 144, 3, 4, 288510) MY DEAR KESHAV MENON, Messrs Shivram Iyer and Vancheswara Iyer have come here in connection with your satyagraha 1. They tell me that the roads in dispute are private property belonging to the temple to which they lead and that it is in exclusive possession of Brahmin trustees who, these gentlemen claim, have perfect right to regulate entry.
('27', 144, 3, 5, 288854) I then asked them if these roads were private property, exclusively belonging to the Brahmins, whether any non Brahmins had the use of them, and they admitted that they had.
('27', 144, 3, 6, 289028) I then told them that, so long as a single non Brahmin was allowed the use of the roads, the so called untouch ables and unapproachable must have the same right as other non Brahmins.
('27', 144, 3, 7, 289212) They agree, but they say that it will take some time before they can bring round to their view of thinking the trustees and other Brahmins who are interested in temple and roads.
('27', 144, 3, 8, 289391) I understand, too, that Malaviyaji is going to the South in two months’ time.
('27', 144, 3, 9, 289469) If the trustees of the temple agree, in the event of any dispute between you as representing untouchables and unapproa chables and themselves, to refer all such disputes to the sole arbitration of Malaviyaji, his award to be delivered within a fixed time, I would advise you to suspend satyagraha, publicly announcing the cause of suspension, namely, its reference to arbitration.
('27', 144, 3, 10, 289850) Naturally, this advice is tendered in the belief that the main facts stated by the Iyer brothers are correct.
('27', 144, 3, 11, 289960) They tell me that they are as anxious as we are to carry out this reform in its thoroughness and, if they are sincere in their professions, we should reciprocate and acco mmodate them in so far as it is consistent with our principles.
('27', 144, 4, 12, 290195) Yours sincerely,
('27', 144, 5, 13, 290212) M. K. GANDHI

('27', 146, 1, 2, 292096) 160. FOR THE READERS PAST AND PRESENT OF“YOUNG INDIA” 1
('27', 146, 2, 3, 292152) It is not without much hesitation that I resume the editorship of Young India.
('27', 146, 2, 4, 292231) I do not know whether my health can yet sustain the energy required for conducting the paper.
('27', 146, 2, 5, 292325) But I cannot foresee.
('27', 146, 2, 6, 292347) I can only dimly understand God’s purpose in bringing me out of my retirement in Yeravda.
('27', 146, 2, 7, 292437) In taking up the editorial control of Navajivan and Young India I am following the Light as far as I see it.
('27', 146, 2, 8, 292546) Nor have I any new message to deliver to the reader.
('27', 146, 2, 9, 292599) I had hoped for release by an act of a Swaraj Parliament and to be able to take my humble share in serving Free India.
('27', 146, 2, 10, 292718) That was not to be.
('27', 146, 2, 11, 292738) We have yet to attain freedom.
('27', 146, 2, 12, 292769) I have no new programme.
('27', 146, 2, 13, 292794) My faith in the old is just as bright as ever, if not brighter.
('27', 146, 2, 14, 292858) Indeed, one’s faith in one’s plans and methods is truly tested when the horizon before one is the blackest.
('27', 146, 2, 15, 292966) Though, therefore, so far as my mind can perceive, there will be no new method or policy developed in the pages of Young India, I hope they will not be stale.
('27', 146, 2, 16, 293125) Young India will be stale when Truth becomes stale.
('27', 146, 2, 17, 293177) I want to see God face to face.
('27', 146, 2, 18, 293209) God I know is Truth.
('27', 146, 2, 19, 293230) For me the only certain means of knowing God is non violence ahimsa love.
('27', 146, 2, 20, 293304) I live for India’s freedom and would die for it, because it is part of Truth.
('27', 146, 2, 21, 293382) Only a free India can worship the true God.
('27', 146, 2, 22, 293426) I work for India’s freedom because my swadeshi teaches me that, being born in it having inherited her culture, I am fittest to serve her and she has a prior claim to my service.
('27', 146, 2, 23, 293604) But my patriotism is not exclusive; it is calculated not only not to hurt any other nation, but to benefit all in the true sense of the word.
('27', 146, 2, 24, 293746) India’s freedom as conceived by me can never be a menace to the world.
('27', 146, 2, 25, 293817) But if it is not to be such a menace, the means adopted for gaining it must be strictly non violent.
('27', 146, 2, 26, 293918) My interest in India’s freedom will cease if she adopts violent means, for their fruit will be not freedom but slavery in disguise.
('27', 146, 2, 27, 294050) And if we have not yet attained our
('27', 146, 3, 28, 294086) 1 On April 2, 1924, about the same time as this article, Gandhiji prepared, at Juhu, Bombay, the preface to the “History of the satyagraha in South Africa”, which he had commenced writing in Gujarati on November 26, 1923 and thirty chapters of which he had completed in Yeravda Jail.

('27', 147, 0, 1, 294476) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 148
('27', 147, 1, 2, 294518) freedom, it is because we have not been non violent in thought, word and deed.
('27', 147, 1, 3, 294597) It is true that non violence has been adopted as a policy, i.e., because we are convinced that by no other means can India achieve her freedom.
('27', 147, 1, 4, 294741) Our policy is not, must not be, a camouflage.
('27', 147, 1, 5, 294787) We may not harbour violence under cover of non violence.
('27', 147, 1, 6, 294844) Whilst we claim to be non violent for a particular purpose and a particular period, our thought and word must accord with our practice for that purpose and that period.
('27', 147, 1, 7, 295013) Even so does an honest jailer act towards a condemned man.
('27', 147, 1, 8, 295072) He protects his life at the peril of his own till the date of the extreme penalty.
('27', 147, 1, 9, 295155) He thinks and speaks of his safety.
('27', 147, 1, 10, 295191) He is, for the time and the person, non violent in thought, word and deed.
('27', 147, 1, 11, 295266) We pledged ourselves to be non violent towards each other and our opponents, whether administrators or co operators.
('27', 147, 1, 12, 295383) We were to appeal to their hearts and evoke the best in them, not play upon their fear to gain our end.

('27', 147, 1, 22, 296266) A word as to the business side.
('27', 147, 1, 23, 296298) Some of the readers will recollect that I announced that, when at the instance of Mr. Shankerlal Banker and other friends, I took up the editing of Young India, I told the public that it was run at a loss and that I would be obliged to give it up if the loss continued.
('27', 147, 1, 24, 296568) I do not believe in publishing newspapers indefinitely at a loss or by means of advertisements.
('27', 147, 1, 25, 296664) If a paper supplies a felt want, it must pay its way.
('27', 147, 1, 26, 296718) The subscription list, however, ran up steadily week by week and it began to yield profits.
('27', 147, 1, 27, 296810) But, during the last two years, as the reader is aware, the list has fallen from 21, 500 to 3,000 and it is now being run at a loss.
('27', 147, 1, 28, 296943) Happily, Navajivan has made up for it.
('27', 147, 1, 29, 296982) But even that method is wrong.
('27', 147, 1, 30, 297013) Young India must
('27', 148, 0, 1, 297030) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 149
('27', 148, 1, 2, 297074) stand on its own bottom or fall.
('27', 148, 1, 3, 297107) It is likely that, if I still retain the personal affection of the old readers, Young India will soon pay its way.
('27', 148, 1, 4, 297222) But I have mentioned the loss not only to acquaint the public with the true state of affairs, but also as an introduction to an important announcement.
('27', 148, 1, 5, 297374) When Messrs Banker and Yagnik suggested that the Gujarati Navajivan, which was then a monthly, should be turned into a weekly and edited by me and when I undertook the responsibility, I announced that it would be given up if it proved a loss and that if there were profits, they would be utilized for some public purpose 1. Navajivan soon became profitable, but at the instance of Sheth Jamnalalji, Hindi Navajivan was commenced.
('27', 148, 1, 6, 297804) 2 It too had just begun to pay its way when my arrest took place and the circulation steadily fell.
('27', 148, 1, 7, 297904) It is now again being issued at a loss.
('27', 148, 1, 8, 297944) But, in spite of these losses, the large circulation of Navajivan and other publications enables the management to devote Rs. 50,000 to public work.
('27', 148, 1, 9, 298093) Swami Anandanand who is managing the Navajivan press has left it entirely to me to allocate the money and, as I know no other and better method of utilizing it, I propose to devote the sum through the agency of the Provincial Congress Committee to the spread of the spinning wheel and khadi in Gujarat, including Kathiawar.
('27', 148, 1, 10, 298417) Preference will be given to their spread among poor women and the suppressed classes.
('27', 148, 1, 11, 298503) It is due to my co workers that I should inform the public that with some of them the work is a labour of love.
('27', 148, 1, 12, 298615) Where they receive payment, it is just enough for their wants.
('27', 148, 1, 13, 298678) The result of such work is before the public, I know that, if from the sweeper upward I could secure selfless workers, with the efficient management I have the good fortune to have today, it would be possible to show a better surplus.
('27', 148, 1, 14, 298913) I should also like to add that, if Young India again shows profits, as it did before my imprisonment, they will be distributed for all India work.
('27', 148, 1, 15, 299060) If any profits are derived from Hindi Navajivan, they will be devoted to the spread of Hindi.

('27', 149, 1, 2, 299284) 161. NOTES
('27', 149, 2, 3, 299295) THANKS It would be ungrateful for me if I did not publicly tender my thanks to the editors who one after another took charge of Young India at a most critical period in its career.
('27', 149, 2, 4, 299476) Shuaib Qureshi, with his sledge hammer style, proved too strong for the Government and they hardly allowed him breathing time.
('27', 149, 2, 5, 299603) Then followed Rajagopalachari with his scholarly contribution, exhibiting a wonderful grasp of the deep truths of satyagraha.
('27', 149, 2, 6, 299729) George Joseph’s trenchant style is still fresh to the reader.
('27', 149, 2, 7, 299791) To all these friends my deepest thanks are due for coming to the rescue.

('27', 157, 3, 19, 320930) For this reason I do not consider myself fit to be its editor.
('27', 157, 3, 20, 320993) I accepted the post of editor out of my affection for Shri Jamnalal Bajaj.
('27', 157, 3, 21, 321068) I cannot be satisfied so long as the paper carries only translations from Gujarati and English.
('27', 157, 3, 22, 321164) I shall now try, when I have time, to write something for Hindi Navajivan.
('27', 157, 3, 23, 321239) But there is some other reason for my writing this article.
('27', 157, 3, 24, 321299) I see that Hindi Navajivan runs at a loss.
('27', 157, 3, 25, 321342) At one time it had 12,000
('27', 158, 0, 1, 321368) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 159
('27', 158, 1, 2, 321412) subscribers, but now their number is 1,400. For Hindi Navajivan to be self supporting, it needs 4,000 subscribers.
('27', 158, 1, 3, 321527) If this number of subscribers is not forthcoming soon, it is my intention to close down the paper.
('27', 158, 1, 4, 321626) I have always held the view which became strengthened while I was in jail that newspapers that are not self supporting and have to depend on advertisements should be closed down.
('27', 158, 1, 5, 321805) In keeping with this principle, it is desirable that Hindi Navajivan, if it cannot pay its way, should be discontinued.
('27', 158, 1, 6, 321925) If you feel the need for this paper, a very good way to increase the circulation is for you to try and enroll your friends as subscribers.
('27', 158, 1, 7, 322064) I may as well let you know that I have expressed a similar intention with regard to Young India.
('27', 158, 1, 8, 322161) It is only on moral or spiritual grounds that I base this decision of mine.
('27', 158, 1, 9, 322237) The Gujarati Navajivanalthough it has had to bear the brunt of the losses incurred by Young India and Hindi Navajivan has shown profits.
('27', 158, 1, 10, 322375) In the five years of its life it has saved Rs. 50,000. This amount will be spent on public work on the propagation of the charkha and khadi.
('27', 158, 1, 11, 322516) You shall find details of it in translations from the Gujarati.
('27', 158, 1, 12, 322580) If Hindi Navajivan shows a profit, the money will be used for spreading Hindi in the South.
('27', 158, 1, 13, 322672) I feel that there is a great need to propagate in the South a form of Hindi which is simple and easily understood by Hindus and Muslims alike.
('27', 158, 1, 14, 322815) If you approve of the idea, please do your best to push the sale of Hindi Navajivan.
('27', 158, 2, 15, 322900) Your servant,
('27', 158, 3, 16, 322914) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 6 4 1924

('27', 159, 11, 25, 324553) 167.INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('27', 159, 12, 26, 324593) [April 3, 1924]
('27', 159, 13, 27, 324609) In spite of the heavy burden of work Mahatma Gandhi has begun to shoulder even in his days of convalescence, he was pleased to accord an interview to our representative who called at his abode at Juhu yesterday morning.
('27', 159, 13, 28, 324829) The callers yesterday morning included Messrs Shuaib Qureshi, D. Chamanlal and Dr. Kitchlew.
('27', 159, 14, 29, 324922) “It is not my purpose to trouble you again so soon after last week’s long talk we had”, said our representative apologizing for trespassing on his quiet and rest, and
('27', 159, 15, 30, 325089) 1 A village near Andheri, suburb of Bombay
('27', 160, 0, 1, 325132) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 161
('27', 160, 1, 2, 325176) as he was reminded of Mahatmaji’s appeal in Gujarati in the course of which it was stated:
('27', 160, 2, 3, 325267) “The capital of energy at my disposal is very small, and I want to utilize it only in service.
('27', 160, 2, 4, 325362) I wish to resume editorship of Navajivan and Young India from next
('27', 160, 3, 5, 325429) And I need absolute quiet for that work.
('27', 160, 3, 6, 325470) If all my time and energy are taken up in seeing and entertaining you, it will not be possible for me to edit the weeklies in the way I desire..” 1
('27', 160, 4, 7, 325618) “Will you not, however , make just a short statement to me on the result of the conference you are holding these days with the Swarajist leaders and others?” our representative inquired.
('27', 160, 5, 8, 325805) Mahatmaji was in an exceedingly humorous disposition.
('27', 160, 5, 9, 325859) He remarked that he was still a patient and little could be expected of him on the present situation till he finished his study of the current events and had had a full talk with the leaders who were there.
('27', 160, 5, 10, 326066) However, he light heartedly suggested, as he laughed heartily, our representative could “pad” his interview with the descriptions of shady palm groves and the gently rolling ocean.
('27', 160, 6, 11, 326247) Hindu Muslim unity and untouchability both were questions of paramount importance and it was not decided whether one of them would be tackled first or both of them would be dealt with simultaneously, replied Gandhiji to the question whether he had definitely arrived at a decision, as a result of consultations, to handle one or both of these vital problems.

('27', 166, 7, 11, 335703) 178. LETTER TO H. WALTER HEEGSTRA

('27', 166, 9, 13, 335765) DEAR MR. HEEGSTRA, I thank you for your letter.
('27', 166, 9, 14, 335813) This is my reply to the first question: My platform is India.
('27', 166, 9, 15, 335875) My goal is to attain self government for India.
('27', 166, 9, 16, 335923) The means adopted to attain the end are Non violence and Truth.
('27', 166, 9, 17, 335987) Therefore, Indian self government not only means no menace to the world, but will be of the greatest benefit to humanity if she attains her end through those means and those means alone.
('27', 166, 9, 18, 336174) The spinning wheel is the external symbol of internal reform, and its universal re adoption in India
('27', 166, 10, 19, 336275) 1 It read: “.
('27', 166, 10, 20, 336289) if the Beraris decline to avail themselves of this .
('27', 166, 10, 21, 336342) autonomy now within their grasp, (which the Nizam has spontaneously offered to them on condition [that] they express to the British Government their desire to come back under the Hyderabad State), then the logical conclusion to be drawn from this would be that they must give up all calims to self government for which so much noise and agitation is now going on all over India.
('27', 166, 10, 22, 336721) .” 2 Vide “Letter to the Nizam of Hyderabad”, 5 3 1924.
('27', 167, 0, 1, 336777) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 168
('27', 167, 1, 2, 336819) ensures her economic salvation and frees millions of Indian peasants from growing pauperism.

('27', 167, 4, 10, 337524) 179. LETTER TO V. V. DASTANE
('27', 167, 5, 11, 337553) POST ANDHERI, April 5, 1924
('27', 167, 6, 12, 337581) MY DEAR DASTANE,
('27', 167, 7, 13, 337598) I have seen the Mulshi Peta papers.
('27', 167, 7, 14, 337634) I have not been able to go through the whole literature.
('27', 167, 7, 15, 337691) It appears to me that the movement 1 has got to be dropped for two reasons or rather for three: (1) I understand that the vast majority of the men affected have accepted compensation and that the few who have not cannot perhaps even be traced.
('27', 167, 7, 16, 337935) (2) The dam is nearly half finished and its progress cannot be permanently stopped.
('27', 167, 7, 17, 338019) There seems to me to be no ideal behind the movement.

('27', 173, 7, 8, 344147) 189. LETTER TO DR.
('27', 173, 7, 9, 344166) M. A. ANSARI
('27', 173, 8, 10, 344179) POST ANDHERI, April 5, 1924
('27', 173, 9, 11, 344207) DEAR DR.
('27', 173, 9, 12, 344216) ANSARI, I have read your pathetic letter to Devdas.
('27', 173, 9, 13, 344268) I have already sent my assurance to Mahomed Ali that I am going to issue no statement till I have met him.
('27', 173, 9, 14, 344375) You will see how I have met the growing demand for some statement from me.
('27', 173, 9, 15, 344450) I am myself eager to make my views known on the Hindu Moslem question, and I am now held back only by Mahomed Ali’s desire for postponement, as also Pandit Malaviyaji’s, with whom I had a fairly long chat yesterday on this very question.
('27', 173, 9, 16, 344688) But you do not want me to keep silent about the Tibbia College incident, for instance.
('27', 173, 9, 17, 344775) I want to deal with that as also the charge against Mahomed Ali.
('27', 173, 9, 18, 344840) I have not got his reply to Swami Shraddhanand.
('27', 173, 9, 19, 344888) Though I am trying to overtake the vernacular Press, it is very difficult to do the thing single handed.
('27', 173, 9, 20, 344993) If you could send me all the choice cuttings from both Hindu and Moslem newspapers, I would like to deal with them with all the firmness I can command.
('27', 173, 9, 21, 345145) So much for the general question.
('27', 173, 9, 22, 345179) Not a day passes when I do not think of the Brothers and their sorrows.
('27', 173, 9, 23, 345251) The Khilafat is dear to every Mussulman, but the Ali Brothers have made its prestige and honour their life work.
('27', 173, 9, 24, 345364) I can therefore understand how the decision of the Turkish Assembly must have shaken them.
('27', 173, 9, 25, 345455) Amina’s death and Shaukat Ali’s serious illness filled the cup of sorrows.
('27', 173, 9, 26, 345530) How I wish I was by your side to nurse Shaukat Ali back to his former health and vigour!
('27', 173, 9, 27, 345619) It is so difficult to think of him lying prostrate on a sick bed.
('27', 173, 9, 28, 345685) May God soon restore him to health!
('27', 173, 9, 29, 345721) I wish I could go to Bombay to meet him when you arrive.
('27', 173, 9, 30, 345778) But I must not make the attempt.
('27', 173, 9, 31, 345811) One such journey may mean nothing,
('27', 174, 0, 1, 345846) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 175
('27', 174, 1, 2, 345890) but you know my method.
('27', 174, 1, 3, 345914) If I break the self imposed restriction once, I shall have to do it many a time, and I should be nowhere.
('27', 174, 1, 4, 346020) Even in this retreat I have no rest.
('27', 174, 1, 5, 346057) Crowds of visitors would not leave me alone, and from today I am commencing some hours’ silence practically ever day so that I might have some quiet and I might also be able to overtake the correspondence which is daily growing in volume.
('27', 174, 1, 6, 346296) I have already added Wednesday as a day of silence to Monday so that I may be able to cope with the editing of Young India and Navajivan.
('27', 174, 1, 7, 346434) I should not dream of Shaukat Ali coming to Juhu in his present state of health.
('27', 174, 1, 8, 346515) You must therefore, take him to Matheran, and when you can spare a day yourself, I certainly want to see you.
('27', 174, 1, 9, 346625) Mahomed Ali will bring me all the messages from Shaukat Ali and that would be quite sufficient to go on with.
('27', 174, 1, 10, 346735) As far as I am concerned, there is not much really that I now want to know except the views of yourself and the Brothers and of a few others whose opinions I value.
('27', 174, 1, 11, 346900) My mind is practically made up, and I am becoming impatient to deliver my soul.
('27', 174, 1, 12, 346980) My love to you, the Brothers and all other friends, and please remember me to Begum Saheba.

('27', 175, 0, 1, 347635) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 176
('27', 175, 1, 2, 347677) noble qualities with it?
('27', 175, 1, 3, 347702) Surely, in that event no one is fit to wear khaddar garments.
('27', 175, 1, 4, 347764) The wearing of khaddar should be considered on its own merits, whether from the economic aspect or from the political.
('27', 175, 1, 5, 347883) As a matter of fact, the political is a corollary to the economic.
('27', 175, 1, 6, 347950) I would not hesitate to urge the most viciously minded person to use khaddar in preference to foreign cloth or even Indian mill made cloth, because thereby we put the money paid for carding, spinning and weaving into the pockets of our poor brothers and sisters.
('27', 175, 1, 7, 348213) Whilst, therefore, I would very much like you to separate the wearing of khaddar from acquisition of noble qualities, and I doubt not that the adoption of khaddar will enable you all the more to cultivate those qualities.

('27', 176, 3, 6, 349181) TALWALKAR, I thank you for your letter.
('27', 176, 3, 7, 349221) After I wrote to you, Dr. Dalal paid his weekly visit to examine my progress.
('27', 176, 3, 8, 349299) I had all the three patients examined by him also, and he suggested cod liver oil injection for both Kikiben and Radhaben , and prescribed some pills and mixture for Maniben.
('27', 176, 3, 9, 349474) The Poona physician came after him and he also examined the three patients.
('27', 176, 3, 10, 349550) He felt very confident of success, and all the three are at the present moment under his treatment.
('27', 176, 3, 11, 349650) They appear to me to be better than they were, but I ascribe all the little improvement there is to more cheerful surroundings and the bracing sea air.
('27', 176, 3, 12, 349802) It is too early yet to say anything about the physician’s treatment.
('27', 176, 3, 13, 349871) When Dr. Dalal comes again, I propose to discuss the Poona physician’s treatment of the patients.
('27', 176, 3, 14, 349969) My unfortunate position is that I have faith in the Ayurvedic drugs, but very little in the diagnosis of the physicians.
('27', 176, 3, 15, 350090) I therefore never feel sure about a patient under an Ayurvedic physician if his diagnosis is not checked by a trustworthy practitioner under the Western system.
('27', 176, 3, 16, 350251) I am keeping a chart of the temperatures of all the three patients, and I feel fairly safe so long as the temperature is not high and the patients keep cheerful.
('27', 176, 3, 17, 350413) Do please give me further guidance if you consider it necessary.

('27', 176, 5, 19, 350495) G. B. TALWALKAR AHMEDABAD

('27', 180, 6, 8, 356722) BOMBAY [On or before April 6, 1924] I have carefully read Mr. Duncan’s 1 speech delivered by him at the second reading of the Class Areas Bill in the Union Assembly.
('27', 180, 6, 9, 356888) I have not before me the letters exchanged between General Smuts and myself.
('27', 180, 6, 10, 356965) I have sent for the file of the Indian Opinion which I have at Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati.
('27', 180, 6, 11, 357058) It contains the text of the two letters, but for my purpose I do not really need them.
('27', 180, 6, 12, 357145) I am surprised at Mr. Duncan’s assertion.
('27', 180, 6, 13, 357187) The two letters do not form the whole of the agreement.
('27', 180, 6, 14, 357243) It is necessary to remember that the Indian struggle commenced with the Asiatic Registration Act of 1907, which was vetoed as an ordinance and passed, almost word for word, by the first responsible legislature of the Transvaal.
('27', 180, 6, 15, 357471) Finally, in 1914, the struggle reached its climax and embraced all the four provinces of the union.
('27', 180, 6, 16, 357571) ‘Vested rights’ has been a phrase requiring interpretation from time to time.
('27', 180, 6, 17, 357649) My contention is that the whole tenor of the agreement pledged the Union Government not only not to curtail vested rights, but gradually to remove the restrictions that existed in 1914. I have already cited Sir Benjamin Robertson and Mr. Andrews as my witnesses in support of my contention.
('27', 180, 6, 18, 357940) I have asked Mr. Andrews, who was present at the negotiations that were going on between General Smuts and myself, and he completely supports me.
('27', 180, 7, 19, 358086) The Indian struggle extending over a long period of eight years could not have been undertaken so that, after a full and honourable settlement, it was open to the Union Government to take away the rights already possessed by the Indians.
('27', 180, 7, 20, 358324) The whole of Mr. Duncan’s speech is a curious exhibition of

('27', 188, 2, 4, 375624) 202. SHRIMATI SAROJINI AND KHADI
('27', 188, 3, 5, 375657) I received a letter from East Africa when I was in the hospital in Poona.
('27', 188, 3, 6, 375731) It purported to give Shrimati Sarojini Naidu’s views on whether Indians in East Africa should wear khadi.
('27', 188, 3, 7, 375837) The letter has been lost, but the following is a summary of the views attributed to Shrimati Naidu in that letter : “It is Gandhi’s view that the vow of khadi applies only within India.
('27', 188, 3, 8, 376023) Not only is there no need to wear khadi outside India, but actually it should be avoided and one should dress like an English man.
('27', 188, 3, 9, 376154) If Gandhi himself went to East Africa, he would not wear a khadi loin cloth but, like Mr. Verma, put on English dress, and you also should do the same.” I doubt if Shrimati Naidu spoke in this vein.
('27', 188, 3, 10, 376353) The correspondent from East Africa has asked for my comments on these views.
('27', 188, 3, 11, 376430) He says that a number of Indians in East Africa dress in khadi and also wear khadi caps.
('27', 188, 3, 12, 376519) They have been confused by Shrimati Naidu’s speech.
('27', 188, 3, 13, 376571) I do believe that the vow of khadi is intended to be observed in foreign countries.
('27', 188, 3, 14, 376655) In some cases, it may be altogether impossible to keep it.
('27', 188, 3, 15, 376714) Moreover, the object of this vow is to secure economic freedom for India; it is, therefore, not necessary to observe it outside India.
('27', 188, 3, 16, 376849) But it has never been my view, nor is it today, that khadi should not be used outside India even if it can be used conveniently.
('27', 188, 3, 17, 376978) I feel, too, that Shrimati Naidu would never express such a view.
('27', 188, 3, 18, 377044) In countries like East Africa or a place like Aden, khadi can be used without any inconvenience.
('27', 188, 3, 19, 377141) In South Africa, too, it can be used in summer.
('27', 188, 3, 20, 377189) That is, there will be no difficulty in wearing it in hot countries.
('27', 188, 3, 21, 377258) Further, most of the articles for use in the home should be of khadi.
('27', 188, 3, 22, 377328) I would, however, take the view that, if we go to a country which grows cotton and which weaves its own khadi, we should wear the cloth produced locally.
('27', 188, 3, 23, 377482) We should follow in other countries the rule which we apply in our own.
('27', 188, 3, 24, 377554) When foreigners come to India, it is desirable that they should use goods produced here.
('27', 188, 3, 25, 377643) We should, therefore, act on the same principle in foreign countries.
('27', 188, 3, 26, 377713) In countries
('27', 189, 0, 1, 377726) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 190
('27', 189, 1, 2, 377768) like East Africa, all cloth is imported from outside.
('27', 189, 1, 3, 377822) I have never heard that they produce their own cloth.
('27', 189, 1, 4, 377876) Not only, therefore, do we have every right to wear khadi in those countries, but actually it is our duty, I believe, to do so to the greatest extent possible.
('27', 189, 1, 5, 378036) As my views developed with the progress of the satyagraha struggle [in South Africa] and the more I felt the need to embrace poverty, I increasingly adopted simplicity in my life.
('27', 189, 1, 6, 378216) Ultimately, I adopted a dress resembling the Indian labourer’s and made of cloth imported from India, the lungi 1 and shirt in the Madras style, and kept it up afterwards.
('27', 189, 1, 7, 378388) In winter, I wore two shirts which I would get stitched from coarse cloth.
('27', 189, 1, 8, 378463) I had discarded the cap there.
('27', 189, 1, 9, 378494) I used to meet all Government officials in this very dress.
('27', 189, 1, 10, 378554) I did not notice that my English friends or the officials took offence at it.
('27', 189, 1, 11, 378632) Many of my English friends even congratulated me when they saw that I was adopting the mode of life and dress of the labourers whose fight I was leading.
('27', 189, 1, 12, 378786) My only aim in telling this story here is to explain that it will suffice if we wear in foreign countries a dress which will cover our limbs adequately.
('27', 189, 1, 13, 378939) In that passage from Shrimati Naidu’s speech, there was one point which deserves notice.
('27', 189, 1, 14, 379028) Her speech dealt with our undesirable habits.
('27', 189, 1, 15, 379074) It described many of our shabby and untidy ways.
('27', 189, 1, 16, 379123) To some extent, this criticism is justified.
('27', 189, 1, 17, 379168) If a khadi dress, or for that matter any other dress, is soiled or shapeless, it does not please the eye.
('27', 189, 1, 18, 379274) Tidiness is necessary, not as adornment, but for the sake of cleanliness and decorum.
('27', 189, 1, 19, 379360) One person may wear a dress made from a particular material carelessly and appear untidy and another person may wear a dress made from the same material properly and appear tidy.
('27', 189, 1, 20, 379539) A proper dress keeps up decorum and shows our regard for others.
('27', 189, 1, 21, 379604) We should not fail in these.
('27', 189, 1, 22, 379633) The border line between a becoming tidiness and adornment is very thin, but it is essential that the distinction should be maintained.
('27', 189, 1, 23, 379768) It is not at all my intention to suggest that men and women must every now and then look into a mirror and arrange their dress.
('27', 189, 1, 24, 379896) I have, of course, no such fear about friends in East Africa.
('27', 189, 1, 25, 379958) The clothes we wear must not be the least dirty.
('27', 189, 1, 26, 380007) White khadi clothes should be regularly washed.
('27', 189, 1, 27, 380055) In India, it is considered decent enough to wear a short dhoti.
('27', 189, 1, 28, 380119) Indian civilization is so liberal that it is not considered the least indecent if anyone wears, as I do, a very short loin cloth.
('27', 189, 1, 29, 380249) In our country, we do not judge a man by his dress.

('27', 190, 4, 21, 381865) 203. UNTOUCHABILITY AND UNAPPROACHABILITY
('27', 190, 5, 22, 381907) The accumulated burden of Hindus’ sins is big enough.
('27', 190, 5, 23, 381961) We have used Shastras, which teach selflessness, as instruments of selfishness.
('27', 190, 5, 24, 382041) By casting aside the immutable principles enunciated in the Shastras and treating as of permanent application verses which prescribed rules of conduct of temporary utility, we have elevated wickedness to the place of dharma.
('27', 190, 5, 25, 382266) My conscience tells me ever more emphatically every day that one such wickedness is the practice of untouchability.
('27', 190, 5, 26, 382382) As if the sin of untouchability was not enough, we started another sinful practice, that of unapproachability, to add to the burden.
('27', 190, 5, 27, 382515) In the South, that is, in Madras Presidency, the people are familiar with this sinful practice.
('27', 190, 5, 28, 382611) But with a view to serving these people kept at a distance and atoning for their own sins, Hindu
('27', 191, 0, 1, 382708) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 192
('27', 191, 1, 2, 382750) members of the Congress in Travancore have started satyagraha.
('27', 191, 2, 3, 382813) Travancore is a Hindu State.
('27', 191, 2, 4, 382842) There this practice of forcibly keeping people at a distance exists in a cruel form.
('27', 191, 2, 5, 382927) Many Gujaratis may not be even aware of the meaning of doorata 2. The word is not found in the dictionary.
('27', 191, 2, 6, 383034) How can it ever be found in the Shastras?
('27', 191, 2, 7, 383076) Doorata means the untouchables keeping at a certain distance from other Hindus.
('27', 191, 2, 8, 383156) Owing to the belief that the other Hindus, and mainly Brahmins, are polluted even by the shadow cast by these untouchables, the latter are obliged to walk at some yards’ distance from the Brahmins and other Hindus.
('27', 191, 2, 9, 383371) When passing along the same road, if they fail to do so, abuses and even blows are showered on them.
('27', 191, 2, 10, 383472) There are some streets in Travancore which these poor brethren are forbidden even to enter.
('27', 191, 2, 11, 383564) Pained by this unbearable evil, Hindu members of the congress have started satyagraha, as I mentioned above.
('27', 191, 2, 12, 383673) In order to establish his right to walk along a particular street, an untouchable Hindu takes with him another Hindu and enters that street.
('27', 191, 2, 13, 383814) Three untouchables offer this kind of satyagraha every day and court arrest.
('27', 191, 2, 14, 383891) Three of them, arrested in this way, are serving a six month term of imprisonment.
('27', 191, 2, 15, 383974) There is not the slightest doubt that, if this satyagraha continues peacefully and steadily, people will win.
('27', 191, 2, 16, 384084) The Hindus working to eradicate the evil of untouchability in North India have gone much further than this with the help and under the leadership of Bharat Bhushan Malaviya: the Antyajas draw water from wells used by other Hindus.
('27', 191, 2, 17, 384315) The notion of being defiled by their touch seems to have died out in many places.
('27', 191, 2, 18, 384397) Now the classes regarded as untouchables are able to make use of common wells.
('27', 191, 2, 19, 384476) The Secretary of the Dohad Taluka Congress Committee reports to this effect.
('27', 191, 2, 20, 384553) 3 He writes to say that the Hindus did not permit the Antyajas to draw water from a well belonging to the local board.
('27', 191, 2, 21, 384672) A weaver who had passed the vernacular final examination made bold to use the well and persuaded other members of his community to follow him.
('27', 191, 2, 22, 384815) They agreed and went to fetch water from that well.
('27', 191, 2, 23, 384867) Other Hindus attempted to stop them from doing so, but the police sub inspector refused to help them and explained to them that, when a movement was going on in the country against such restrictions, they should not try to stop the Antyajas.
('27', 191, 2, 24, 385109) This calmed the caste Hindus.
('27', 191, 2, 25, 385139) This was a happy conclusion.
('27', 191, 3, 26, 385168) 1 In Vykom 2 Literally, ‘remoteness’ 3 This information was later found to be misleading; vide “A correction”, 27 4 1924.
('27', 192, 0, 1, 385290) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 193
('27', 192, 1, 2, 385334) The incident, however, shows that, even in Gujarat, the Antyajas are still prevented from drawing water from public wells.
('27', 192, 1, 3, 385457) I congratulate the Hindus of Dohad, but at the same time suggest to the Dohad Congress Committee members that they should visit the Antyaja locality and instruct the residents in sanitation and persuade them to keep their pitchers, etc., clean.

('27', 196, 1, 2, 392193) 209. LETTER TO HARIBHAU PATHAK
('27', 196, 2, 3, 392224) POST ANDHERI, April 6, 1924
('27', 196, 3, 4, 392252) DEAR HARIBHAU, Here is a reminiscence from Lokamanya’s conversation with me.
('27', 196, 3, 5, 392329) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SJT.
('27', 196, 3, 6, 392364) HARIBHAU PATHAK SECRETARY CITY CONGRESS COMMITTEE POONA
('27', 196, 4, 7, 392420) [ENCLOSURE]
('27', 196, 5, 8, 392432) I had the privilege of meeting the Lokamanya scores of times.
('27', 196, 5, 9, 392494) The first time I had the honour of making his acquaintance was in 1896, when I went to Poona to pay my respects to the leaders there, and to canvass their assistance in the cause of Indian settlers in South Africa, and the last was in Bombay when with Maulana Shaukat Ali I went to him at Sardar Griha before leaving Bombay with the Maulana for an Upper India tour.
('27', 196, 5, 10, 392860) When we returned from the tour, it was only to hear that the Lokamanya was lying dangerously ill.
('27', 196, 5, 11, 392958) I went in to pay my respects, but that was all.
('27', 196, 5, 12, 393006) We had no talk.
('27', 196, 5, 13, 393022) I propose to give only the last reminiscence as it is appropriate to the season.
('27', 196, 5, 14, 393103) About Hindus and Mussalmans he said, turning to the Maulana: “I will sign any thing that Gandhi suggests, because I have full faith in him on the question.” About Non co operation, he significantly repeated to me what he had said to me before, “I like the programme well enough, but I have my doubts as to the country being with us in the self denying ordinance which Non co operation presents to the people.
('27', 196, 5, 15, 393512) I will do nothing to hinder the progress of the movement.
('27', 196, 5, 16, 393570) I wish you every success, and if you gain the popular ear, you will find in me an enthusiastic supporter.”

('27', 201, 10, 10, 399498) 220. NOTES
('27', 201, 11, 11, 399509) THE SATYAGRAHA WEEK The reader does not need the reminder that this is the sacred Satyagraha Week.
('27', 201, 11, 12, 399608) It was on Sunday the 6th April, 1919, that the first all India hartal took place as a protest against the passing of the Rowlatt Act.
('27', 201, 11, 13, 399742) It was on that day that thousands of men and women all over India kept a twenty four hour fast.
('27', 201, 11, 14, 399838) It was on that sacred day that the nation recognized, with the strength it has never done before, the necessity of Hindu Muslim unity and that Hindus, Mussalmans, Sikhs, Parsis, Christians and others met in hearty co operation, and it was on that day that an all India swadeshi spirit, not in vengeance but as a vital necessity in the life of the nation, was born.
('27', 201, 11, 15, 400203) It was on the 13th that the Jallianwala massacre took place.
('27', 201, 11, 16, 400264) We have been observing both these days and the intervening days from year to year as special days for purification, searching of hearts, for cultivating better relations among all the different sections and for promoting swadeshi which has centered gradually round the spinning wheel.
('27', 201, 11, 17, 400549) I was grieved to learn from a friend that in Amritsar, the scene of the black tragedy, the Week was least observed last year.
('27', 201, 11, 18, 400675) I wonder how Amritsar and the rest of India will have observed the Week this year.
('27', 201, 12, 19, 400758) AM I UNFAIR ?
('27', 201, 12, 20, 400772) I have the good fortune to possess friends who keep me on the right path when I am inclined or likely to stray away from it.
('27', 201, 13, 21, 400897) 1 This was in reply to Panikkar’s telegram of April 8, received on April 9, stating: “Third Jatha surrendered peacefully.”
('27', 202, 0, 1, 401020) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 203
('27', 202, 1, 2, 401064) such friend thought that, in my letter 1 last week to the readers of Young India, I was less than fair to the Government of Bombay inasmuch as I declined to render thanks to them for having given me best medical assistance and made the path to recovery easy by freely permitting friends to visit me.
('27', 202, 1, 3, 401364) In my friend’s opinion, the treatment was a sign of change of heart due to the advent of the new Governor.
('27', 202, 1, 4, 401471) I have deeply thought over my friend’s argument and I am reluctantly obliged to adhere to the conclusion that I owe no thanks for the best medical assistance and the facilities given to friends to visit me, unless thanks are due to a Government every time it does its duty.
('27', 202, 1, 5, 401745) I have made ample acknowledgment of the fact that the Government did for me during my illness all that it could reasonably be expected to do in respect of a prisoner.
('27', 202, 1, 6, 401912) But I am unable to render thanks to the Government as such in the same sense that I have rendered them to Col.
('27', 202, 1, 7, 402023) Maddock, Col.
('27', 202, 1, 8, 402037) Murray and Major Jones.
('27', 202, 1, 9, 402061) They need not have been as kind as they were and I would still have acknowledged that they had done all they could be expected to do in their respective spheres.
('27', 202, 1, 10, 402223) The personal element was a factor in these gentlemen’s conduct towards me, and I was bound to give them my thanks.
('27', 202, 1, 11, 402338) To finish this part of the argument, if I may state it without indelicacy, I may say that my scrupulously correct conduct as a prisoner had not a little to do with the happy relations that subsisted between the officials and, indeed, also the Government and myself.
('27', 202, 1, 12, 402604) I state this merely to emphasize the truth tested by me on scores of trying occasions that uniformly correct conduct will disarm the fiercest opposition, prejudice and suspicion.
('27', 202, 1, 13, 402783) Now for the supposed change of heart.
('27', 202, 1, 14, 402821) I wish I could see it.
('27', 202, 1, 15, 402844) I am longing for it.
('27', 202, 1, 16, 402865) The reader may know that the slightest real change of heart will make me capitulate without delay.
('27', 202, 1, 17, 402964) But it will have to be very real.
('27', 202, 1, 18, 402998) The Government have failed even in so simple a test as the release of Maulana Hasrat Mohani, and the removal of the ban against Mr. Horniman.
('27', 202, 1, 19, 403140) I own that from a strong believer I have become an equally strong unbeliever in this Government.
('27', 202, 1, 20, 403237) I am, however, sane enough to be able to perceive a sincere change of heart.
('27', 202, 1, 21, 403314) It has been suggested that Sir George Lloyd would not have treated me during my illness as His Excellency Sir Leslie Wilson has done.
('27', 202, 1, 22, 403448) I do not believe it.
('27', 202, 1, 23, 403469) In spite of Sir George Lloyd’s utter dislike of me, he would have given me the same medical assistance and facility that were given
('27', 202, 2, 24, 403601) 1 Vide “For the Readers Past and Present of Young India” 3 4 1924
('27', 203, 0, 1, 403667) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 204
('27', 203, 1, 2, 403709) to me by the present Governor.
('27', 203, 1, 3, 403740) Indeed, it was he who sent Col.
('27', 203, 1, 4, 403772) Maddock to examine me when I first became at all seriously ill in the Yeravda Jail about eight months ago.
('27', 203, 1, 5, 403879) Maddock was asked to visit me weekly during convalescence and send the Governor weekly reports.
('27', 203, 1, 6, 403975) I have a higher opinion of the British officials than most people imagine.
('27', 203, 1, 7, 404050) They have a high sense of duty.
('27', 203, 1, 8, 404082) Only the honesty of an ordinary official does not travel beyond the line of policy.
('27', 203, 1, 9, 404166) It is no fault of his.
('27', 203, 1, 10, 404189) He is heir to a system handed down for generations a system which is based on exploitation of the weak by the strong.
('27', 203, 1, 11, 404307) The official breaks down when the system which sustains him is in jeopardy.
('27', 203, 1, 12, 404383) But it is my belief that no other human being will do better under that system.
('27', 203, 1, 13, 404463) The sooner, therefore, it is destroyed or radically altered the better for us all.
('27', 203, 2, 14, 404546) DECK PASSENGERS I invite the reader’s attention to Mr. Chaturvedi’s interesting and instructive experiences in East Africa.
('27', 203, 2, 15, 404670) 1 His bitter experiences as a deck passenger revive painful memories.
('27', 203, 2, 16, 404740) The picture he has given is not overdrawn.
('27', 203, 2, 17, 404783) Three parties can change the disgraceful state of things: (1) The British India Steam Navigation Company (2) The Government (3) The passengers.
('27', 203, 2, 18, 404927) The British India S.N. Company will not worry because its concern is to secure the largest profits.
('27', 203, 2, 19, 405027) We may expect nothing from the Government till we have the power to move it.
('27', 203, 2, 20, 405104) The passengers are the real parties affected.
('27', 203, 2, 21, 405150) Unfortunately, the majority of them are injured even to avoidable hardship.
('27', 203, 2, 22, 405226) The others secure relief by bribes.
('27', 203, 2, 23, 405262) It is only when a sensitive passenger travels as a deck passenger that he causes a stir.
('27', 203, 2, 24, 405351) He does not make reform in the treatment of deck passengers his life work and so nothing is achieved.
('27', 203, 2, 25, 405453) Only when self respecting persons like Mr. Banarasidas insist on proper sanitation and accommodation, not merely for themselves, but for all, may substantial change be expected.
('27', 203, 3, 26, 405631) CHARKHA ABROAD Mr. Chaturvedi’s remarks on the spinning wheel are the most instructive.
('27', 203, 3, 27, 405719) If Indians of East Africa can popularize the bow, the wheel and the loom among the natives of the soil, they will have rendered
('27', 203, 4, 28, 405847) 1 Published in Young India, 10 4 1924
('27', 204, 0, 1, 405885) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 205
('27', 204, 1, 2, 405929) them a signal service.
('27', 204, 1, 3, 405952) The possibilities of the wheel are as wide as the world itself because its spread requires little capital.
('27', 204, 1, 4, 406059) It merely needs fellow feeling, ordinary organizing ability and technical skill which can be easily acquired.
('27', 204, 2, 5, 406169) KHADDAR IN EAST AFRICA Should the Indians of East Africa wear khaddar?
('27', 204, 2, 6, 406240) Shrimati Sarojini Naidu is reported to have replied in the negative.
('27', 204, 2, 7, 406309) I can hardly believe it.
('27', 204, 2, 8, 406334) Be that as it may, East Africa should use khaddar as far as possible.
('27', 204, 2, 9, 406404) It is not necessary for them to take or be under the vow of khaddar, as we at home must be.
('27', 204, 2, 10, 406496) What the Shrimati must have laid stress upon is cleanliness and neatness.
('27', 204, 2, 11, 406570) Khaddar clothing must be kept spotlessly clean and worn neatly.
('27', 204, 2, 12, 406634) One often notices a tendency towards neglect of these necessary qualities.
('27', 204, 2, 13, 406709) If khaddar is to become popular with the upper classes, the wearers must be clean and neat.
('27', 204, 2, 14, 406801) The roughness and thickness of well washed khaddar are a recommendation rather than otherwise.
('27', 204, 2, 15, 406896) The absorbent property of rough khadar makes it hygienically sound.
('27', 204, 2, 16, 406964) Its loose texture gives it a softness that is pleasant to the wearer.
('27', 204, 3, 17, 407034) AS WE HAVE SOWN Mr. Andrews’s pathetic remarks 1 on untouchability deserve to be pondered over by every Hindu.
('27', 204, 3, 18, 407145) I knew nothing till Mr. Andrews told me that untouchability was practiced even by Syrian Christians of Malabar.
('27', 204, 3, 19, 407257) As a Hindu I hung my head in shame when I heard the news.
('27', 204, 3, 20, 407315) For I realized that the evil was copied by them from the Hindus.
('27', 204, 3, 21, 407380) The retort of his fellow passengers which Mr. Andrews received when he broached the subject of the disabilities of Indians in South Africa was well deserved.
('27', 204, 3, 22, 407538) Whilst it is true that the Europeans in South Africa need not treat us as we treat our own people at home, our mouths are shut when our own sins are flung in our faces.
('27', 204, 3, 23, 407707) We are reaping fruits of what we have sown.
('27', 204, 3, 24, 407751) MY OFFER Shrimati Sarojini’s splendid work in South Africa has told.
('27', 204, 3, 25, 407820) Letters received by me from South Africa show that her presence has brought fresh courage to the Indian settlers.
('27', 204, 3, 26, 407934) Mr. Duncan’s fruitless efforts to justify an unjustifiable measure show also that the Europeans of South Africa have felt the force of her wonderful work.
('27', 204, 4, 27, 408089) 1 Andrews’s article, “Untouchability”, was published in the same issue of Young India.
('27', 205, 0, 1, 408176) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 206
('27', 205, 1, 2, 408218) Mr. Duncan’s assertion that the agreement of 1914 did not bind the Union Government to take away vested rights, as the Class Areas Bill admittedly does, ought to carry with it the understanding that, if such an agreement can be proved, the Bill will not be proceeded with.
('27', 205, 1, 3, 408491) Even though a non co operator, I beg to make the proposal that, if the Government of India receive an undertaking from the union Government that, if the agreement can be proved to the satisfaction of an impartial tribunal, they will suspend the Bill pending such enquiry, I shall be prepared to appear before such a tribunal to prove the agreement.
('27', 205, 1, 4, 408840) Nor is precedent wanting for such a course.
('27', 205, 1, 5, 408884) When the interpretation of the Transvaal Law 3 of 1885 and the propriety of its enactment in spite of the London Convention 1 were in dispute, the matter was referred to arbitration by the Imperial and the Transvaal Governments.
('27', 205, 2, 6, 409113) TO CORRESPONDENTS I have before me a heap of correspondence and other docu ments for publication.
('27', 205, 2, 7, 409211) It is impossible for me to find space for it if Young India is to retain its present size.
('27', 205, 2, 8, 409302) The correspondents will please, therefore, forgive me if they miss their contributions in these columns.
('27', 205, 2, 9, 409407) The fact is that, as an esteemed friend remarked to me, Young India is not a newspaper.
('27', 205, 2, 10, 409495) It is a veiwspaper.
('27', 205, 2, 11, 409515) And then, too, it is being used today predominantly for distributing my views and in my own way.
('27', 205, 2, 12, 409612) Its scope being, therefore, circumscribed, correspondents will do well not to send contributions which have no special feature about them and which have no bearing on the message for which Young India stands.
('27', 205, 2, 13, 409821) Young India, 10 4 1924
('27', 205, 3, 14, 409844) 221. CAMPAIGN OF MISREPRESENTATION
('27', 205, 4, 15, 409879) At the present moment there seems to be a wilful attempt being made to widen the gulf between Hindus and Mussalmans.
('27', 205, 4, 16, 409996) Some newspapers, both Hindu and Muslim are leaving no stone unturned to inflame passions and, unfortunately, they do not hesitate to resort to exaggeration and even misrepresentation.
('27', 205, 4, 17, 410180) Where they are not them selves consciously guilty of such methods, they recklessly copy without verification everything in the nature of a sensation that appears in any other newspaper.
('27', 205, 5, 18, 410366) 1 This was signed in 1884.
('27', 206, 0, 1, 410393) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 207
('27', 206, 1, 2, 410437) One such statement was made with reference to Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('27', 206, 1, 3, 410504) He was reported to have said that an adulterous Mussalman was better than myself.
('27', 206, 1, 4, 410586) That there should have been found any person willing to believe such a thing of Maulana Mahomed Ali shows the degree of tension that exists between Hindus and Mussal mans.
('27', 206, 1, 5, 410758) The reader will find in another column a translation of the two letters written by the Maulana, one to Swami Shri Shraddhanandji 1 and the other to Tej 2. In my opinion, the letters dispose of, once for all, the calumny against the Maulana that has been going the round of the Press.
('27', 206, 1, 6, 411042) Enemies of India’s freedom have not hesitated to distort the Maulana’s statement and use it for the purpose of setting the Hindus against the Maulana Saheb.
('27', 206, 1, 7, 411199) I venture to commend his letters to the attention of every thoughtful Hindu.
('27', 206, 1, 8, 411276) The letters, in my humble opinion, demonstrate the transparent honesty of the Maulana.
('27', 206, 1, 9, 411363) What is the original statement which has been so cruelly distorted by some newspapers?
('27', 206, 1, 10, 411450) He says in effect that the creed of Islam is better than my creed.
('27', 206, 1, 11, 411517) Is there anything offensive in the state ment?
('27', 206, 1, 12, 411564) So long as there are different religions, is not the Maulana’s position the only logical and honest one?
('27', 206, 1, 13, 411669) I have very dear Christian friends in South Africa and in India.
('27', 206, 1, 14, 411734) They pray for light for me.
('27', 206, 1, 15, 411762) One of them, a retired solicitor of standing in South Africa, urges me to accept the Jesus Christ and his salvation.
('27', 206, 1, 16, 411879) He says that without that all my effort will be useless.
('27', 206, 1, 17, 411936) Thousands of Christians certainly hold that a righteous man without belief in Jesus Christ is less than an adulterous Christian.
('27', 206, 1, 18, 412065) Does an orthodox Hindu fare better?
('27', 206, 1, 19, 412101) If he does, why is there all this feverish agitation regarding Shuddhi?
('27', 206, 1, 20, 412173) In making the choice of a husband for his daughter, will he choose the best character irrespective of religion or the best man in his own sect?
('27', 206, 1, 21, 412317) And if he will restrict the choice to his own circle, does it not show that he, too, like the Maulana, believes that his creed is the best of all?

('27', 210, 2, 3, 420422) Mr. Weatherly has laid down a universal proposition that “non co operation is a way of violence”.

('27', 210, 2, 7, 420828) The fact is that all non co operation is not violent and non violent non co operation can never be an act of violence.
