('27', 211, 1, 2, 423006) From the imaginary heartless milk drivers and the heaps of dead bodies of New York babies, the writer in Unity takes us to Lancashire and pictures its ruin when Indian non co operation has succeeded.
('27', 211, 1, 3, 423206) In his haste to prove his main argument, the writer has hardly taken the trouble to study even simple facts.
('27', 211, 1, 4, 423315) Indian non co operation is not designed to injure Lancashire or any other part of the British Isles.
('27', 211, 1, 5, 423416) It has been undertaken to vindicate India’s right to administer her own affairs.
('27', 211, 1, 6, 423497) Lancashire’s trade with India was established at the point of the bayonet and it is sustained by similar means.
('27', 211, 1, 7, 423609) It has ruined the one vital cottage industry which supple mented the resources of millions of India’s peasants and kept starvation from their doors.
('27', 211, 1, 8, 423758) If India now strives to revive her cottage industry and hand spinning and refuses to buy any foreign cloth or even cloth manufactured by Indian mills, and Lancashire of Indian mills suffer thereby, non co operation cannot by any law of morals be held to be an act of violence.
('27', 211, 1, 9, 424035) India never bound herself to maintain Lancashire.
('27', 211, 1, 10, 424085) Visitors to taverns or houses of ill fame would be congra tulated on their self restraint and would be held even as benefactors of keepers of taverns or questionable houses, if they ceased to visit those places even without notice and even if their abstention resulted in the starvation of the keepers of those houses.
('27', 211, 1, 11, 424404) Similarly, if customers of money lenders ceased to borrow and the latter starved, the former cannot be regarded as violent by reason of their withdrawal.
('27', 211, 1, 12, 424558) But they might be so considered if they transferred their custom from one money lender to another through ill will or spite and without just cause.
('27', 211, 1, 13, 424706) Thus, it is clear that non co operation is not violence when the refusal of the restraint is a right and a duty, even though by reason of its performance some people may have to suffer.
('27', 211, 1, 14, 424892) It will be an act of love when non co operation is resorted to solely for the good of the wrongdoer.
('27', 211, 1, 15, 424993) Indian non co operation is a right and a duty, but cannot be regarded as an act of love because it has been undertaken by a weak people in self defence.

('27', 212, 3, 6, 425717) This is a hurried note.
('27', 212, 3, 7, 425741) I have barely two hours to catch the mail.
('27', 212, 4, 8, 425784) Mrs. Sarojini Naidu has been in our midst for the past twenty days.
('27', 212, 4, 9, 425852) Her work by now has produced a very good effect on the people of this country, particularly the Europeans.
('27', 212, 4, 10, 425959) Johanseburg was hostile when she came, but her eloquence has disarmed much of the opposition and the mischief makers have been shamed into silence.
('27', 212, 4, 11, 426107) Towards the end of her tour in the Transvaal, Europeans attended her lectures in their thousands.
('27', 212, 4, 12, 426205) I was not at Johannesburg myself.
('27', 212, 4, 13, 426239) But I managed to meet her at Volksrust, half way between Johannesburg and here.
('27', 212, 4, 14, 426319) She was received at every station by large and eager crowds, composed of both Europeans and Indians and her compartment presented the constant appearance of a flower garden.
('27', 212, 4, 15, 426493) She stopped for two days in Maritzburg.
('27', 212, 4, 16, 426533) The anti Asiatic spirit there is acute and the reactionary element holds full sway.
('27', 212, 4, 17, 426617) There had been a strong movement to disallow the use of the Town Hall to the Indians for Mrs. Naidu’s reception and serious consequences were threatened if it was allowed.
('27', 212, 4, 18, 426789) But the situation was saved at the last moment by the Maritzburg Times which, in a leading article, wisely
('27', 212, 5, 19, 426896) dissuaded the Europeans from any precipitate action.
('27', 212, 5, 20, 426949) In spite of the indications of trouble, every rich of the Town Hall was packed with Indians and quite a number of Europeans occupied the gallery.
('27', 212, 5, 21, 427095) The Mayour having refused to preside on the occasion, a European friend was proposed in the chair.
('27', 212, 5, 22, 427194) He was howled down by the occupants of the gallery as soon as he attempted to speak.
('27', 212, 5, 23, 427279) Mr. Bhagat, who tried to reason, too, was obliged to sit down.
('27', 212, 5, 24, 427342) Mrs Naidu at this stage took charge of the meeting She had hardly uttered three sentences when the gallery leaders were seen quitting the hall one after another and, in about twenty minutes’ time, the main element of rowdies had retired from the field.
('27', 212, 5, 25, 427595) When the meeting was over, a number of Europeans, unknown before, showed great eagerness to shake hands with Mrs. Naidu.
('27', 212, 6, 26, 427716) The next day, crowds of Indians and Europeans could be seen in front of Mrs. Naidu’s residence struggling to have a glimpse of her, the space outside being hardly sufficient to contain them.

('27', 215, 9, 16, 432848) DEAR READER, Attempts are being made in many newspapers in North India to create feelings of disaffection between Hindus and Muslims.
('27', 215, 9, 17, 432982) One notices manifestations of jealousy, exaggeration and lies in these

('27', 217, 5, 12, 435976) 230. THOUGHTS ON COUNCIL ENTRY 1
('27', 217, 6, 13, 436009) [Before April 11, 1924] Pandit Motilalji and I have had prolonged discussions about propriety of non co operators entering the Legislative bodies.
('27', 217, 6, 14, 436156) I had too the privilege of discussion with other Swarajist friends.
('27', 217, 6, 15, 436224) But in spite of all my effort I have not been able to discover a common meeting ground in terms of non co opertion.
('27', 217, 6, 16, 436340) I retain the opinion that Council entry is inconsistent with non co operation.
('27', 217, 6, 17, 436419) There is an honest and fundamental difference between the Swarajists and myself.
('27', 217, 6, 18, 436500) I have failed to convince them that to be out of the Legislative bodies is, to say the least, far more advantageous to the country than to be in them.
('27', 217, 6, 19, 436651) But I recognize that so long as they think otherwise, their place is undoubtedly in the Councils.
('27', 217, 6, 20, 436749) It is the best for us all.
('27', 217, 6, 21, 436776) If their work prospers and the country benefits, such an ocular demonstration cannot but convince honest sceptics like me of our error and I know the Swarajists to be patriotic enough to retrace their steps when experience disillusioned them.
('27', 217, 6, 22, 437019) I would therefore be no party to putting any obstacle in their way.
('27', 217, 6, 23, 437087) I cannot actively help in a project in which I do not believe.
('27', 217, 7, 24, 437150) 1 The document is in Gandhiji’s handwriting, with several corrections by him.
('27', 217, 7, 25, 437228) It carries what are evidently his first thoughts on the “vexed question of entry by Congressmen into the Legislative Councils and Assembly” After week long discussions, from March 29 to April 5, in Bombay, with Motilal Nehru, Lajpat Rai and other Swarajist leaders, Gandhiji formulated his stand on the question.
('27', 217, 7, 26, 437541) It is likely that Gandhiji put down these thoughts sometime prior to his “Draft Statement on Council entry”, dated April 11; vide the following item.
('27', 218, 0, 1, 437691) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 219
('27', 218, 1, 2, 437735) I differ too as to the method of work in the Councils.
('27', 218, 1, 3, 437790) I do not believe in obstruction within the Councils.
('27', 218, 1, 4, 437843) I should only enter a Legislative body, if I found I could at all use it to advantage.
('27', 218, 1, 5, 437930) If therefore I entered the Councils, I should endeavor to give strength to the constructive programme of the Congress.
('27', 218, 1, 6, 438049) I should therefore move resolutions requiring the Central and the Provincial Governments (1) to make all their cloth purchases in hand spun and hand woven khaddar, (2) to impose a prohibitive duty on foreign cloth, (3) abolish the drink and drug reserve and correspondingly reduce the army expenditure.
('27', 218, 1, 7, 438352) If the Government refuse to enforce resolutions carried in the legislature, I should invite them to dissolve them and take the vote of the electors on the specific points.
('27', 218, 1, 8, 438524) If the Government will not dissolove, I should resign and prepare the country for civil disobe dience.
('27', 218, 1, 9, 438627) When that stage is reached, the Swarajists will find me ready to work with and under them.
('27', 218, 1, 10, 438718) My test of fitness for civil disobedience remains the same as before.
('27', 218, 1, 11, 438788) During the state of probation I should advise the No changers to prove their faith without thinking of what the Swarajists are doing or saying, prosecute their programme with undivided energy and concentration.
('27', 218, 1, 12, 438999) The khaddar and the national schools are enough to occupy a large army of workers who believe in quiet, honest unde monstrative work.
('27', 218, 1, 13, 439133) The Hindu and Muslim problem too will tax the best energy and faith of the workers.
('27', 218, 1, 14, 439217) As Vaikom is showing, the Hindus have in untouchability a huge problem before them.
('27', 218, 1, 15, 439301) In all such work outside the Councils, No changers and pro changers can work in unison.

('27', 219, 0, 1, 439418) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 220
('27', 219, 1, 2, 439460) 231. DRAFT STATEMENT ON COUNCIL ENTRY 1
('27', 219, 2, 3, 439500) April 11, 1924 After having discussed with the Swarajist friends the vexed question of entry into the Legislative Assembly and the Councils by Congressmen, I am sorry to have to say that I have not been able to see eye to eye with the Swarajist Friends.
('27', 219, 2, 4, 439754) I assure the reader there has been no lack of willingness or effort on my part to accept the Swarajists’ position.
('27', 219, 2, 5, 439869) My task would be much simpler if I would identify myself with the Swarajists’ programme.
('27', 219, 2, 6, 439958) It can be no pleasure to me to oppose even in thought the most valued and tried leaders, some of whom have made great sacrifices in the cause of the country and who yield to no one in their love for the freedom of the Mother land.
('27', 219, 2, 7, 440189) But, in spite of my effort and willingness, I have failed to be convinced by their argument, nor is the difference between them and myself one of mere detail.
('27', 219, 2, 8, 440348) Unfortunately, it goes to the rock bottom of the principle.
('27', 219, 2, 9, 440408) Had it been one of detail only, I would immediately have sacrificed my conviction, however strong it might be, and, for the sake of agreement, would have joined the Swaraj Party and advised the No changers to heartily co operate with the Swaraj Party and make theirs the national programme.
('27', 219, 2, 10, 440699) such an attitude is, however, impos sible, the difference being, as I have said, fundamental.
('27', 219, 2, 11, 440793) It is my con viction and further thought and observation are making it daily stron ger that the entry into the Legislative bodies has retarded the progress towards Swaraj for the following reasons.
('27', 219, 2, 12, 440991) In my humble opinion.
('27', 219, 2, 13, 441013) (a) The entry into the Legislative bodies is tantamount to taking part, directly or indirectly, in the present system of government, for the Legislative bodies are a chief part of the machinery designed to sustain that system.
('27', 219, 2, 14, 441240) (b) The programme of obstruction has a strong smell of
('27', 219, 3, 15, 441295) 1 This typewritten document is evidently an elaboration of his “Thoughts on Council entry ” It carried the title “First Draft of Statement on the Councils Question’ and the words: “Very rough incomplete draft, unrevised.
('27', 219, 3, 16, 441516) Confidential not for publi cation.” Gandhiji forwarded this draft to Motilal Nehru on April 13; vide “Letter to Motilal Nehru”, 13 4 1924. The latter sent Gandhiji an elaborate note; vide Appendix “Motilal Nehru’s Note on Council Entry”, before 18 4 1924. In this, he critically analysed the contents of Gandhiji’s draft and offered his own suggestions.
('27', 219, 3, 17, 441870) Gandhiji then prepared a final draft which, with a few minor verbal changes, was issued as a statement to the Press on May 22.
('27', 220, 0, 1, 441997) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 221
('27', 220, 1, 2, 442041) violence about it and cannot generate an atmosphere of calmness which is so necessary for preparing the ground for civil disobedience, which the Congress has found to be the only sanction for which the people of India can be made ready and which is regarded as an effective substitute for armed rebellion.
('27', 220, 1, 3, 442347) (c) It has retarded the progress of the constructive programme, namely, the charkha, unity between the different communities, rem oval of untouchability, development of the Panchayat system, National Schools and the collection of subscriptions necessary for carrying on the programme.
('27', 220, 1, 4, 442632) (d) Assuming that the entry was desirable, it was premature.
('27', 220, 1, 5, 442693) It will be admitted that the discipline that the Swaraj Party has shown in the Legislative bodies is due to the intensive and methodical work that the Congress has carried on since 1920. But neither discipline nor methodical work in the face of disappointments has become a habit with Congress workers.
('27', 220, 1, 6, 442996) The experience of the past four years shows that the habit of discipline and application is likely to vanish under prolonged strain.
('27', 220, 1, 7, 443129) The present Legislative bodies do not contain an atmosphere disposing one to truthfulness and non violence.
('27', 220, 1, 8, 443237) On the contrary, there is in that atmosphere a constant, almost irresistible, temptation to depart from them.
('27', 220, 1, 9, 443347) (e) The entry is tantamount to abandoning the Khilafat and the Punjab causes.
('27', 220, 1, 10, 443425) I do not wish to enter into detailed argument in support of the objections above set forth.
('27', 220, 1, 11, 443517) I would say a word only on the funda mental objection, namely that the entry is tantamount to participation in violence.
('27', 220, 1, 12, 443638) It has been suggested that nobody takes the extreme view of non violence that I do and that most Congressmen confine the definition of non violence to mere abstention from causing physical hurt to the opponent.
('27', 220, 1, 13, 443849) I venture to doubt the accuracy of the statement, but if it is so, it is an argument, not against the fundamental difference I have started, but for revising the Congress creed and removing the adjective “non violent” wherever it occurs in the Congress reso lutions, for it must be plain to everybody that, if a non co operator, whilst he refrains from causing physical hurt to his opponent, may wound him with his tongue and in his thought wish him ill, the struggle must break down.
('27', 220, 1, 14, 444334) Non violence is a mere camouflage and the atmosphere for civil disobedience can never be created, for we will always be giving tacit approval to every violent demonstration against
('27', 221, 0, 1, 444515) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 222
('27', 221, 1, 2, 444557) the administrators and and co operators.
('27', 221, 1, 3, 444598) It was in vindication of the view that I have set forth that civil disobedience was suspended during the Rowlatt Act agitation after the incendiarism and murders in Amritsar, Viramgam and Ahmedabad, and during the non co operation campaign after the mob violence in Bombay and again in Chauri Chaura.
('27', 221, 1, 4, 444899) Each time the advice I tendered for suspension of civil disobedience was accepted by the nation and, if it was an honest acceptance, I was justified in thinking that non violence in its full sense, but restricted as to the cause for which it was taken, was understood and accepted by the nation.
('27', 221, 2, 5, 445195) Such being my view of the Council entry, it follows that, if I could persuade the Swarajists, I would have them retrace their steps and give up the Assembly and the Councils.
('27', 221, 2, 6, 445370) But if they have failed to convince me of the soundness of the step they have taken, I have fared no better with them.
('27', 221, 2, 7, 445489) On the contrary, they can show, and with justice, brilliant victories: my release, an ocular demonstration of khaddar in the highest places, almost complete success of obstruction, namely, forcing the Government to resort to certification, which success would have been complete if the Congress had given unstinted support to the Council entry at Gaya, thus enabling the Swaraj Party to organize so effectively as to prevent a single election from going in favour of non Swarajists.
('27', 221, 2, 8, 445972) Naturally, it is vain for me to argue that all such things could have been done even before non co operation.
('27', 221, 2, 9, 446082) If our aim was to get releases of prisoners, we could have got not merely a Gandhi released but many Hasrat Mohanis and all Punjab prisoners.
('27', 221, 2, 10, 446224) It is idle for me to argue that there is not much in the khaddar demonstration or in keeping so many Moderates out.
('27', 221, 2, 11, 446340) The machinery of the Govern ment goes unchecked with or without the Moderates and in spite of obstruction.
('27', 221, 2, 12, 446447) Nor is it much use arguing that all that the entry into the Councils is likely to achieve could have been achieved by fairly directed agitation even in 1920. It is highly likely that, whilst the Government may not make the admission, some pleasant 2 advance upon the Reforms will be made, but I have no doubt that everything that is likely to be granted will be far short of what the Congress programme was and is designed for.
('27', 221, 3, 13, 446875) 1 In the final draft of the statement, this examination of the issne of non violence dose not find a place.

('27', 222, 1, 2, 447184) It was not to be expected that the Swarajists could be convinced by any argument.
('27', 222, 1, 3, 447266) They are many of them amongst the ablest, most experienced and honest patriots.
('27', 222, 1, 4, 447346) They have not entered the Legislative bodies in the teeth of opposition without full deliberation, and they must not be expected to retire from the position until experience has convinced them of the futility of their programme.
('27', 222, 1, 5, 447575) The question, therefore, before the country is not an examination and distribution 1

('27', 222, 2, 7, 447705) The question is: regarding the Council entry as a settled fact, what is to be done now.
('27', 222, 2, 8, 447793) Are the No changers to keep up if only mental hostility against the Swarajists’ programme, or are they to remain neutral and even help wherever it is possible and consistent with their principles?
('27', 222, 2, 9, 447990) The Delhi and Cocanada resolutions have permitted those Congressmen who have no conscien tious scruples to enter the Councils and the Assembly if they wish to.
('27', 222, 2, 10, 448150) In my opinion, the Swarajists are, therefore, justified in entering the Legislative bodies and expecting perfect neutrality on the part of the No changers.
('27', 222, 2, 11, 448306) They were also justified in resorting to obstruction, because such was their policy and the Congress had laid down no conditions as to their entry.
('27', 222, 2, 12, 448454) So far as I am concerned, being an out and out believer in non violence, my position remains the same as at Amritsar in 1919. I do not believe in obstruction in any shape or form within the Councils.
('27', 222, 2, 13, 448654) It appears to me to be an utter waste of time.
('27', 222, 2, 14, 448701) I would enter the Councils only if I believed that I could make use of them for the advancement of the country.
('27', 222, 2, 15, 448813) I must, therefore, have faith of the machinery and those in charge of it.
('27', 222, 2, 16, 448887) I cannot be part of the machinery and till want to destroy it.
('27', 222, 2, 17, 448950) Taking the Council entry, therefore, as a necessary evil, if I were a member of any to these bodies, is should carry out the constructive programme of the Congress.
('27', 222, 2, 18, 449115) Two things can be immediately done: a resolution requiring the Central Government and the Provincial Gov ernments in future to buy only hand spun and hand woven khaddar for all the departments under them, and another resolution abolishing the whole of the revenue from drinks and drugs, the deficit to be covered by a corresponding reduction in the army expenditure.
('27', 222, 2, 19, 449482) The Government is likely even to disregard these resolutions.

('27', 226, 3, 4, 454538) MY DEAR RAJAGOPALACHARI, Here is a copy of my letter 1 to the Secretaries of the Kerala Provincial Conference.
('27', 226, 3, 5, 454649) In sent you yesterday a copy of the draft 2 about Council entry which I have prepared.

('27', 226, 8, 13, 455115) POST ANDHERI, April 12, 1924
('27', 226, 9, 14, 455144) DEAR FRIEND, It was good of you to have taken the trouble to write that long letter 3. I wish the problem was so simple as you state it.
('27', 226, 9, 15, 455281) It is terribly concrete for me.
('27', 226, 9, 16, 455313) If I have a duty at all towards fellow creatures, I must think what it is in the face of those who are simply skin and bone.
('27', 226, 9, 17, 455438) Is there such a thing as the quality of mercy and pity and love, and if there is, am I to say these men and women who are dying of slow starvation and who are almost naked, are, after all, reaping the fruit of their past karma and I have no duty by them?

('27', 227, 5, 15, 456707) 238. MY NOTES
('27', 227, 6, 16, 456721) ANOTHER MISUNDERSTANDING I have cleared in an editorial the misunderstanding about Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('27', 227, 6, 17, 456825) Another misunderstanding of the same type has occurred in Hakim Ajmal Khan’s Tibbia College.
('27', 227, 6, 18, 456918) When my release was being celebrated there, a Hindu student compared me with Jesus Christ.
('27', 227, 6, 19, 457009) When another student hinted that it was not proper to compare an ordinary man with great prophets, the former felt hurt as he took the hint to be an insult to me.
('27', 227, 6, 20, 457172) Thereupon, the student who had spoken against the comparison explained his standpoint and apolo gized.
('27', 227, 6, 21, 457275) Some journalist made a mountain out of this molehill.
('27', 227, 6, 22, 457329) I happened to read a news paragraph just when I started writing these notes.
('27', 227, 6, 23, 457406) Two persons were taking tea in Calcutta.
('27', 227, 6, 24, 457447) One of them praised me, the other criticized me.
('27', 227, 6, 25, 457496) My admirer did not like the criticism, so he fell out with the critic.
('27', 227, 6, 26, 457567) The two heroes then faced each other pugnaciously.
('27', 227, 6, 27, 457618) Finally, the police had to intervene and separate the violent contestants.
('27', 227, 6, 28, 457693) To whom shall I offer the bouquet?
('27', 227, 6, 29, 457728) To the admirer, to the detractor, to both or to neither of them?
('27', 227, 6, 30, 457793) It is easy to answer this.
('27', 227, 6, 31, 457820) The admirer really blackened me by hitting the critic.
('27', 227, 6, 32, 457875) It is me that he has
('27', 228, 0, 1, 457896) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 229
('27', 228, 1, 2, 457940) Had the critic given me two lashes of the whip, I would have immediately forgiven him in accordance with my religion of non violence.
('27', 228, 1, 3, 458074) Possibly, I would have even kissed his whip had I the strength to do so.
('27', 228, 1, 4, 458147) One who has read Chaurasi Vaishnavoni Varta 1
('27', 228, 2, 5, 458193) should not see anything surprising in this.
('27', 228, 2, 6, 458237) By striking the critic my admirer has dealt me a severer lash than that of the whip.
('27', 228, 2, 7, 458322) The non violence which I practice now cannot go, at least today, to the length of forgiving him.
('27', 228, 2, 8, 458419) If my admirer meets me, he will certainly have to bear my displeasure and anger.
('27', 228, 2, 9, 458500) The critic said what he believed.
('27', 228, 2, 10, 458534) But my admirer did not act up to his belief.
('27', 228, 2, 11, 458579) In the language of swamiji and the Maulana, my admirer can be said to have only censured the tenets of his won religion and, howsoever good may be the principle of his religion, his conduct was worse than his critic’s.
('27', 228, 2, 12, 458798) My bouquet will surely stay with me.
('27', 228, 2, 13, 458835) I shall certainly not hand it over to my admirer.
('27', 228, 2, 14, 458885) And since my critic belongs to the opposite camp, how can there be any bouquet for him in the present atmo sphere?
('27', 228, 2, 15, 459000) But if the atmosphere changes and if I must offer the bouquet to one of them, I shall offer it to my critic and go off to the Himalayas.
('27', 228, 2, 16, 459137) Tolerance is the prime quality of a Swarajist.
('27', 228, 2, 17, 459184) As long as this world endures, views are bound to differ from individual to individual.
('27', 228, 2, 18, 459272) Swaraj will be shared, in common, by men holding different views.
('27', 228, 2, 19, 459338) If we start cutting off the heads of all people who have necks too long or too short, not even two persons will be left with necks of equal length.
('27', 228, 2, 20, 459486) Hence we must respect the freedom of others as much as we value our own.
('27', 228, 2, 21, 459559) What is our quarrel with the Government about?
('27', 228, 2, 22, 459606) Is it not about freedom of thought?
('27', 228, 2, 23, 459642) The Government arrested me because it considered my ideas to be wrong.
('27', 228, 2, 24, 459713) That gentleman in the Tibbia College and the critic in Calcutta also followed the same path as the Government and so they co operated with it.
('27', 228, 2, 25, 459856) If the Hindus and the Muslims want unitedly to secure swaraj, they should learn this lesson by heart and act accordingly.
('27', 228, 2, 26, 459978) They should tolerate each other’s ideas and practices and each should refrain from interfering in the practices of the other.
('27', 228, 3, 27, 460104) Those who are the first to implement this principle will score a victory.
('27', 228, 3, 28, 460178) If one waits for another to give a lead, in the end both will remain where they are.
('27', 228, 3, 29, 460263) If everyone says “After you”, all will miss the bus.

('27', 229, 0, 1, 460387) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 230
('27', 229, 1, 2, 460429) NEW SUPPLEMENT TO “NAVAJIVAN” An ordinary supplement to Navajivan continues to appear from time to time.
('27', 229, 1, 3, 460534) The reader will find elsewhere in this number an announcement about a special supplement on education which is to be issued henceforward.
('27', 229, 1, 4, 460672) This special education supplement will appear on the third Saturday of every month, so that the first such issue will be out on the 19th instant.
('27', 229, 1, 5, 460818) From the announcement the reader will find that it was I who advised them that, instead of being issued indep endently, the education number should come out as a supplement to some journal.
('27', 229, 1, 6, 461008) Many newspapers are published in Gujarat, even books appear in very large numbers.
('27', 229, 1, 7, 461091) The growth of readership may be considered to be a good thing.
('27', 229, 1, 8, 461154) Where a thousand subscribers were regarded as satisfactory, even three or four thousand, are now looked upon as ordinary.
('27', 229, 1, 9, 461276) Thus we must welcome this increase in the love of reading among the Gujaratis.
('27', 229, 1, 10, 461355) But the responsibility of writers and those running newspapers has increased.
('27', 229, 1, 11, 461433) The two big problems are: the type of material to be published and the style in which it is to be presented.
('27', 229, 1, 12, 461542) The habits which the readers will contract today are likely to endure permanently.
('27', 229, 1, 13, 461625) What is true of children is also true of grown ups.
('27', 229, 1, 14, 461677) Even the grown ups are as good as children where new experiences are concerned.
('27', 229, 1, 15, 461757) If old people like some new thing and if they get used to it, they will take delight in it even like children.
('27', 229, 1, 16, 461868) And, if by chance, it turns out to be undesirable, even then they will find it hard to give it up.
('27', 229, 1, 17, 461967) Thus the increased love of reading among the Gujaratis may in the end prove to be harmful if it is not given a healthy turn.
('27', 229, 1, 18, 462092) Therefore, the knowledge that a writer has to exercise control over his pen is one of the reasons for my hesitation.
('27', 229, 1, 19, 462209) It may be doubted whether such a blemish will creep into an education supplement.
('27', 229, 1, 20, 462291) But is there a limit to methods of education?
('27', 229, 1, 21, 462337) I for one do not believe that all methods are good enough.
('27', 229, 1, 22, 462396) There are likely to be many drawbacks in a system devised without regard to time, place and class of students.
('27', 229, 1, 23, 462507) It cannot be laid down that one working in the education field should have unrestricted freedom.
('27', 229, 1, 24, 462604) The other cause of my hesitation is about the reader’s pocket.
('27', 229, 1, 25, 462667) Even the burden of a voluntary tax falling on the reader must not exceed a certain limit.
('27', 229, 1, 26, 462757) The circulation of all newspapers, books etc., will only be among the class of readers that has now come into being.
('27', 229, 1, 27, 462874) I am afraid if such a burden becomes heavy, it may kill the desire to read.
('27', 230, 0, 1, 462950) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 231
('27', 230, 1, 2, 462994) I had requested the Vidyapith 1 to consider both these reasons for my hesitation.
('27', 230, 1, 3, 463076) As a result, it has decided not to issue an indepen dent monthly but to have a special supplement to Navajivan every month.
('27', 230, 1, 4, 463200) Those in charge of the Vidyapith have found it necessary to have a special mouthpiece which will record the activities of the Vidyapith, express its ideas on education, and be of assistance to teachers, parents and students too.
('27', 230, 1, 5, 463429) Whether they are right in this view experience alone will show.
('27', 230, 1, 6, 463493) This much is clear that there is a lot for teachers, parents and even students to learn about the important activities of the Vidyapith.
('27', 230, 1, 7, 463630) Let us all hope that this need will be met by the proposed enterprise.
('27', 230, 1, 8, 463701) There is no doubt that, if the educated class lends a hand, this venture will succeed brilliantly.
('27', 230, 2, 9, 463800) SAVED For the present at least the Indians [in South Africa] appear to have been saved from the sword, hitherto hanging over their heads, in the form of confining their residence to the scavengers’ Location.
('27', 230, 2, 10, 464008) Sarojini’s efforts appear to have succeeded in an unexpected manner.
('27', 230, 2, 11, 464077) General Smuts 2 has announced his decision to dissolve Parliament and to hold fresh elections as he felt that public opinion did not back the Union Government of South Africa.
('27', 230, 2, 12, 464253) Hence the new bills which were to be passed by the present Parliament have been postponed, at least for the present.
('27', 230, 2, 13, 464370) But it is not at all likely that members of the now Parliament will be inclined to do justice to Indians.
('27', 230, 2, 14, 464476) It will not at all be suprising if their attitude towards the Indians in South Africa is harder even than that of the present members.
('27', 230, 2, 15, 464611) Still, we should rest satisfied, for the time being at least, as “he who survives a crisis may live up to the age of a hundred years.”
('27', 230, 3, 16, 464746) VALUE OF ALERT PUBLIC OPINION We have a lot to learn from what is happening in South Africa.
('27', 230, 3, 17, 464839) General Smuts has suspended the administrative work of the entire country because one representative of his party was defeated in only one city.
('27', 230, 3, 18, 464984) While dissolving Parliament, he declared: We cannot introduce new policies contemplated by us if the public opinion does not back us.
('27', 230, 3, 19, 465118) It is enough for us that the voters of one main city only gave their votes to the opposition party.

('27', 231, 1, 2, 465442) In this we see both General Smuts’s adroitness and his sub mission to public opinion.
('27', 231, 1, 3, 465528) Do we find such a thing in our country?

('27', 231, 2, 8, 465910) THIS PICTURE AND THAT While preparations were being made for the visit of the Prince of Wales to South Africa, General Smuts sent a message to the effect that, since the whites would be busy with the new elections, the royal visit should for the present be postponed.

('27', 233, 2, 5, 469906) 239. CHARGE AGAINST MAHOMED ALI
('27', 233, 3, 6, 469938) A gentleman writes to say that the Gujarati papers report Maulana Mahomed Ali as having said in a speech that Gandhi was lower than the most wretched Muslim.
('27', 233, 3, 7, 470096) The correspondent suggests that, though the Maulana would never have said such a thing, the true fact should be made known through Navajivan so that the misunder standing might be removed.
('27', 233, 3, 8, 470285) I must admit regretfully that this report has appeared in English as well as Gujarati newspapers.
('27', 233, 3, 9, 470383) There has been a lot of discussion on this matter.
('27', 233, 3, 10, 470434) God knows what has happened, but at present there is mis understanding between Hindus and Muslims all around.
('27', 233, 3, 11, 470544) They do not trust each other.
('27', 233, 3, 12, 470574) I know there are various reasons for this state of affairs, but I do not consider it necessary in regard to this episode to go into them.
('27', 233, 3, 13, 470712) The Hindi and Urdu newspapers in northern India have overdone the thing.
('27', 233, 3, 14, 470785) Dr. Ansari writes to say that those papers regard it as their duty to make allegations against each other, to spread false rumours, to calumniate each other’s religion and thereby to vilify each other.
('27', 233, 3, 15, 470987) It seems this has become a means of increasing the circulation of their papers.
('27', 233, 3, 16, 471067) How to stop this infection from spreading has become a big problem.
('27', 233, 3, 17, 471135) To solve it is, in my opinion, much more important than Council entry.
('27', 233, 3, 18, 471206) I am sure that our ability to run the administration will be seen in the course of solving it.
('27', 233, 3, 19, 471301) If we can solve some of the problems confronting the people, we shall have swaraj in our hands right today.
('27', 233, 3, 20, 471409) There can be no swaraj as long as we are not able to untie these knots.
('27', 233, 3, 21, 471481) The Councils will not be able to solve these difficulties.
('27', 233, 3, 22, 471540) But in this article I do not propose to examine these difficulties.
('27', 233, 3, 23, 471608) I wish to assess only the allegations against the Maulana.
('27', 233, 3, 24, 471667) The Maulana, who was asked in a meeting at Lucknow a question on his first speech, gave this reply: “I consider the religious principles of an adulterous Muslim to be better than Mahatma Gan dhi’s religious principles.” Here the Maulana has not instituted a comparison between “Mahatma” Gandhi and an adulterous Muslim,
('27', 234, 0, 1, 471987) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 235
('27', 234, 1, 2, 472031) but only between their religious principles.
('27', 234, 1, 3, 472076) Let us also consider for a while why this comparison was made.
('27', 234, 1, 4, 472139) The Muslims have charged the Maulana with having become a flatterer or worshipper of Gandhi.
('27', 234, 1, 5, 472232) To worship Gandhi is to deify Gandhi, that is, to believe that there is nothing higher than Gandhi in this world.
('27', 234, 1, 6, 472346) This amounts to professing Gandhi’s religion, and that was the charge against the Maulana.
('27', 234, 1, 7, 472437) The Maulana gave the reply quoted above to meet this allegation of some Muslims.
('27', 234, 1, 8, 472518) While trying to please the Muslims, did he annoy the Hindus?
('27', 234, 1, 9, 472579) If the Maulana had uttered the above quoted sentence on some other occasion, he would not have been criticized at all.
('27', 234, 1, 10, 472698) Hindu newspapers gave a distorted report of his speech.
('27', 234, 1, 11, 472754) They represented that the Maulana considered an adulterous Muslim better than “Mahatma” Gandhi.
('27', 234, 1, 12, 472850) We have seen that he did not say so.
('27', 234, 1, 13, 472887) Moreover, in his letter to Swami Sharddhanand, he has expressed his belief that “Mahatma” Gandhi is the best man in the whole world.
('27', 234, 1, 14, 473020) But he has assessed the religious principles of that “Mahatma” as lower than those of an adulterous Muslim.
('27', 234, 1, 15, 473128) There is no contradiction at all in this.
('27', 234, 1, 16, 473170) Moreover, almost the whole world recognizes the difference between persons and their principles.
('27', 234, 1, 17, 473267) Christian friends close to me regard me as a very good man and yet, because they consider their religion better than mine, pray to God that I may become a Christian.
('27', 234, 1, 18, 473433) I received a letter two or three weeks ago from one such friend in South Africa, in which he writes: I was glad to hear that you were released.
('27', 234, 1, 19, 473577) I always pray for you that God may give you good sense, so that you may start believing in Jesus Christ and His power to effect deliverance.
('27', 234, 1, 20, 473718) if you do so, your work would soon bear fruit.
('27', 234, 1, 21, 473765) Thus, many Christian friends desire me to become a Christian.
('27', 234, 1, 22, 473827) What do many Hindus do?
('27', 234, 1, 23, 473851) Do they not consider the principles of their own religion to be far superior to those of the noblest Christian on Muslim?
('27', 234, 1, 24, 473973) If they do not, will they give their daughter in marriage to the best Muslim or Christian?
('27', 234, 1, 25, 474064) Again, they would not give her even to the best among Hindus if he does not belong to their own denomination or sub caste.
('27', 234, 1, 26, 474187) What does that suggest?
('27', 234, 1, 27, 474211) They believe their own religion to be better than any other.
('27', 234, 1, 28, 474272) In my humble opinion, the Maulana has proved the purity of his heart and his faith in his own religion by expressing his view.
('27', 234, 1, 29, 474399) He has, in fact, honoured me in two ways first, as a friend, secondly as a man.
('27', 234, 1, 30, 474479) He has honoured me as a friend because he has taken it for granted
('27', 235, 0, 1, 474546) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 236
('27', 235, 1, 2, 474588) that I shall not take it ill at all if he says anything about me, that I shall never put a wrong construction on his words.
('27', 235, 1, 3, 474712) He has honoured me as a man because, despite the difference in our religions and despite his belief that his religion is better then mine, he regards me as the best among men.
('27', 235, 1, 4, 474888) What an implicit confidence in me!
('27', 235, 1, 5, 474923) I can understand people’s superstition which leads them to regard me as a good man, but how strange it is that a friend who has been in close association with me regards me as the best despite seeing the many defects in me!
('27', 235, 1, 6, 475147) I consider it very risky to regard any man as the best.
('27', 235, 1, 7, 475203) Who can know his heart except God?
('27', 235, 1, 8, 475238) How dirtier must they be who can hide their evil than those whose evil comes out in the open?
('27', 235, 1, 9, 475332) The latter has scope for deliverance because, when the evil comes out in the open, the path to get out of it is clear.
('27', 235, 1, 10, 475451) But in the other case, the evil within, kept concealed as in a box, will eat one up like poisonous germs.
('27', 235, 1, 11, 475557) Deliverance is impossible for such a one in this birth.
('27', 235, 1, 12, 475613) And, therefore, the Shastras have placed Truth above everything; for the same reason, they have forbidden us to hide our sins.
('27', 235, 1, 13, 475740) Even if it is possible to assess any man as the best among men, it can only be after his death.
('27', 235, 1, 14, 475836) I for one cannot be confident about myself.
('27', 235, 1, 15, 475880) I find it easier to be so about others.
('27', 235, 1, 16, 475920) In doing so if I get cheated, I may suffer some financial loss or the world may consider me gullible.
('27', 235, 1, 17, 476022) If I place too much confidence in myself and remain complacent, I shall be doomed.
('27', 235, 1, 18, 476105) Since I have this opportunity, let me tell my reader that, on one occasion, when I was about to be lost through placing too much confidence in my own self, I was saved only through God’s grace.
('27', 235, 1, 19, 476299) On another occasion, and adulterous friend of mine had saved me.
('27', 235, 1, 20, 476364) It was of course not possible for him to save himself; but because he regarded me as pure minded and wished that I should not allow myself to be defiled by evil, he shook me out of infatuation.
('27', 235, 1, 21, 476558) Instead of keeping a watch on others and sitting in judgment over them, we should keep a watch on our own selves.
('27', 235, 1, 22, 476672) If we become our own judges we shall save ourselves and save the world from our tyranny.
('27', 235, 1, 23, 476761) There fore, the true definition of swaraj is this: swaraj is control over one’s own self.
('27', 235, 1, 24, 476851) He who gains such control has gained everything.
('27', 235, 1, 25, 476900) The saying, “The world is good, if we are ourselves good” is very mean ingful.
('27', 235, 1, 26, 476979) I have not strayed from the subject and started discussion of any profound problem, but have only discussed issues arising from the subject.
('27', 235, 1, 27, 477120) I tremble because my friends regard me as the best man.
('27', 236, 0, 1, 477176) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 237
('27', 236, 1, 2, 477220) come to believe it, it will bring about my downfall, because I have yet far to climb.
('27', 236, 1, 3, 477306) My aspiration has no bounds.
('27', 236, 1, 4, 477335) Many are the inner enemies whom I have to conquer.
('27', 236, 1, 5, 477386) The deeper I ponder, the better I come to realize my drawbacks.
('27', 236, 1, 6, 477450) As I do so, I wonder what the truly best men will be like.

('27', 236, 1, 11, 477825) I give a translation of it in this very issue.
('27', 236, 2, 12, 477872) Swamiji has welcomed the Maulana’s letter; he has thanked him for his frankness; he regards the Maulana as a friend of the Hindus and has appealed to those who had sent a notice of a resolution making allegations against him and asking him to submit his resignation from the Congress to withdraw that notice.
('27', 236, 2, 13, 478181) But at the same time, he has also made it clear that in the case of his own religion mere principles did not count and that a man was judged by his character.

('27', 236, 2, 18, 478805) Hence what Maulana Mahomed Ali has said only comes to this, that to everyone his own religion appears good.

('27', 237, 1, 2, 479376) 240. SATYAGRAHA AND CASTE REFORM
('27', 237, 2, 3, 479409) As the principle of satyagraha comes to be better understood, it is being put to ever new applications.
('27', 237, 2, 4, 479513) It is used not merely in fighting the Government, but we find it being applied within the family and the caste as well.
('27', 237, 2, 5, 479633) In a certain community there prevails the inhuman practice of offering girls in marriage for a consideration and a youth has felt the urge to end it.
('27', 237, 2, 6, 479783) It has been asked what he should do.
('27', 237, 2, 7, 479820) An easy form of satyagraha is non cooperation.
('27', 237, 2, 8, 479867) The young man wishes to banish this custom from his community.
('27', 237, 2, 9, 479930) His intention is good.
('27', 237, 2, 10, 479953) But should he start non co operation and, if so, how and against whom?
('27', 237, 2, 11, 480024) It is difficult to give a definite opinion in this particular case.
('27', 237, 2, 12, 480092) But one can suggest some general rules for all situations of this type.
('27', 237, 2, 13, 480164) In the first place, one should never embark upon non co operation all of a sudden.
('27', 237, 2, 14, 480247) Evil customs which have prevailed for ages cannot be eradicated in a moment.
('27', 237, 2, 15, 480324) Reform is one legged, and so proceeds haltingly.
('27', 237, 2, 16, 480373) Anyone who loses patience can never become a pure satyagrahi.
('27', 237, 2, 17, 480435) The first step for a reformer is to educate public opinion.
('27', 237, 2, 18, 480495) He should meet the wise elders of the community and listen to their points of view.
('27', 237, 2, 19, 480579) Maybe the reformer is a poor man, no one knows him and the elders will not listen to him.
('27', 237, 2, 20, 480669) What should he do then?
('27', 237, 2, 21, 480693) A poor person like this should know that he is not destined to be an instrument of reform.
('27', 237, 2, 22, 480784) We may all wish that untruth may disappear from the world, but who will bring round the liars?
('27', 237, 2, 23, 480879) Here is an essential reform, and yet how patiently we mark time!
('27', 237, 2, 24, 480944) The thing is that a reformer should be free from egotism.
('27', 237, 2, 25, 481002) Why should we assume responsibility for ending all evils?
('27', 237, 2, 26, 481060) We should be content with speaking the truth ourselves and acting truthfully.
('27', 237, 2, 27, 481138) Likewise, in regard to the evil practices in the community, we should see that our own attitude and conduct are blameless and maintain a neutral attitude towards others.
('27', 237, 2, 28, 481308) To think “I do this, I do that” is ignorance, like that of the dog who thought that the cart was being drawn by him.
('27', 237, 2, 29, 481425) We should learn these lines by heart and, as they suggest, remain free from pride.
('27', 237, 2, 30, 481508) If, even then, we feel that the responsibility is ours, an especial duty devolves upon us.
('27', 237, 2, 31, 481599) For example, the elders of the community cannot, professing to be humble, condone the prevailing evils, for , by
('27', 238, 0, 1, 481712) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 239
('27', 238, 1, 2, 481756) accepting the position of elders, they have made themselves the guardians of its moral conduct.
('27', 238, 1, 3, 481852) Even if only one girl is given away in marriage for money, the curse of that innocent girl will fall upon them.
('27', 238, 1, 4, 481964) If, however, the leaders of the community do nothing to stop evil practices and themselves follow this one of accepting money for a daughter given in marriage, what should this poor member of the community do?
('27', 238, 1, 5, 482174) He has made his own life above reproach, and has met all the leading men of the community.
('27', 238, 1, 6, 482265) All of them have treated him insultingly and driven him away as they might a dog.
('27', 238, 1, 7, 482347) Abuse has been showered on him.
('27', 238, 1, 8, 482379) Dispirited, tired and sad, he has returned home.
('27', 238, 1, 9, 482428) He sees no shelter save the sky above and no support save the earth below.
('27', 238, 1, 10, 482503) Now, will God hear his prayer for help?
('27', 238, 1, 11, 482543) But this is only the first step.
('27', 238, 1, 12, 482576) He has been tested, as he had to be, before he could be fit for tapascharya 1. Now he can hear his inner voice.
('27', 238, 1, 13, 482688) He asks the God within him: “Though insulted, do I yet love my brethren?
('27', 238, 1, 14, 482761) Am I ready to serve them?
('27', 238, 1, 15, 482787) Shall I be able to submit even to blows and kicks with their shoes?” If the in dwelling God answers all these questions in the affirmative, then he is fit to take the second step.
('27', 238, 1, 16, 482967) Now he may start non co operation in the spirit of love.
('27', 238, 1, 17, 483024) Such non co operation means giving up all rights but not duties.
('27', 238, 1, 18, 483089) What are the rights of this poor servant as a member of his community?
('27', 238, 1, 19, 483160) To be invited to community dinners and to be eligible for marriage within its circle.
('27', 238, 1, 20, 483246) He should, with humility, give up both these rights, and then he will have done his duty.
('27', 238, 1, 21, 483336) If the elders of the community cast him off like a thorn saying in the arrogance of their authority, “One invitee less at dinners, one prospective bridegroom less,” strike his name off the register, the poor servant, instead of despairing, should have confidence that from the pure seed sown by him will grow a huge tree.
('27', 238, 1, 22, 483658) After fulfilling his dutynot beforemay he sing: To work I have the right, never to the fruit thereof.
('27', 238, 2, 23, 483762) This poor man of God is now a dweller in a forest.
('27', 238, 2, 24, 483813) If an unmarried man, he takes a stern pledge that he would remain so until the evil had disappeared from the community and, if married, that he would live with his wife as her friend and not as a husband.
('27', 238, 2, 25, 484018) If he has children, he would teach them also to observe brahmacharya.

('27', 239, 1, 19, 486291) In the letter that I have received, I have been asked whether, when our non co operating man of God lets go the privilege of attending community dinners, he should also refrain from attending such dinners arranged by his friends in the community.

('27', 240, 1, 2, 486867) with him.
('27', 240, 1, 3, 486877) That is to say, the question of his refraining from dinners given by particular individuals will not arise at all.
('27', 240, 1, 4, 486992) If he is thus declared to be an outcaste, it will be the special duty of our man of self restraint not to attend dinners given by his friends even if they invite him, openly or secretly.

('27', 242, 7, 14, 491723) [ANDHERI, April 13, 1924] Vaikom satyagrahis undoubtedly arrived at a delicate state, so many leaders having been picked up by the Travancore authorities.
('27', 242, 7, 15, 491878) Appeal has been made to all India leaders to lead the movement.
('27', 242, 7, 16, 491942) It is a question how far a local movement, on reaching a critical stage, can be turned into an all India movement.
('27', 242, 7, 17, 492057) All India sympathy I can understand and that Vaikom satyagrahis are having in abundance, but to concentrate active energies of leaders from different provinces on a single local movement seems to be a difficult, if not an impossible, task.
('27', 242, 7, 18, 492297) I am hoping, however, that leaders in the Madras Presidency will not allow the movement to die for want of proper lead.

('27', 244, 1, 2, 494380) 246. LETTER TO H. G. PERRY 1

('27', 245, 1, 2, 495854) 248. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('27', 245, 2, 3, 495884) BOMBAY, [April 15, 1924]
('27', 245, 3, 4, 495909) At four in the evening yesterday, when our representative was taken into his presence, Mahatmaji was engaged in reading an Urdu book.
('27', 245, 3, 5, 496043) There was Mr. Andrews writing in a front room.
('27', 245, 4, 6, 496090) Questioned by our representative: “What is your opinion on the untouch ability satyagraha organized in Travancore?
('27', 245, 4, 7, 496205) How can the country as a whole help it and what is the best form of rendering help?” Mahatmaji, replying at length, said: From what I know of the leaders of the movement I have no doubt that they have acted with great caution and deliberation and that they have embarked upon it after having taken preliminary steps.
('27', 245, 4, 8, 496522) From the reports I have been receiving, I believe that the Madras Presidency will supply the lead that will be required.
('27', 245, 4, 9, 496643) I do not think that the leaders from all the parts of India can spare themselves and concentrate their energy directly on the movement.
('27', 245, 4, 10, 496779) But the whole of the Indian Press can give due prominence to the movement and I am glad to notice that it is receiving such prominence.
('27', 245, 4, 11, 496915) Beyond this moral support, I hardly think all India efforts can go further and, if the movement retains its continuous purity and non violence, public support it must win in the end.
('27', 245, 5, 12, 497098) Q. “How would you solve the problem of the lack of leaders even after the few who will have gone there are arrested?” Mahatmaji replied: A letter that I have received shows that the movement has gone so far that volunteers will continue to offer satyagraha, even when all the leaders are arrested.
('27', 245, 5, 13, 497396) I would also advise that at least one leader keeps himself in reserve and directs the movement without courting arrest.
('27', 245, 6, 14, 497516) To a further question: “Supposing that even the leader who wants to reserve himself is also arrested or finds that he must offer himself for arrest, do you think it possible to conduct such a movement without leadership?” Mahatmaji answered: In my opinion, satyagraha is one such movement, in which after a certain stage it is the easiest to continue without leadership.
('27', 245, 6, 15, 497887) This is its inherent quality and strength.
('27', 245, 6, 16, 497930) In satyagraha there is no such thing as diplomacy and manoeuvering, as we understand the terms.
('27', 245, 6, 17, 498026) The road is narrow, I admit; but it is straight and, therefore, simple.
('27', 245, 6, 18, 498098) Only the will is required, but no cunning after all.
('27', 245, 6, 19, 498151) What have the volunteers to do but
('27', 246, 0, 1, 498186) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 247
('27', 246, 1, 2, 498230) simply to offer satyagraha till the right, for which it is offered, is vindicated?
('27', 246, 1, 3, 498313) If those who are opposing offer any settlement, they will secure the release of the leaders who are arrested.
('27', 246, 1, 4, 498423) That was exactly what happened in South Africa.
('27', 246, 1, 5, 498471) It was when almost all the leaders were arrested that Mr. Gokhale was frightened and sent Mr. Andrews and Mr. Pearson.
('27', 246, 1, 6, 498590) Whilst their help was invaluable, it was not necessary to keep the sacrificial fire going.
('27', 246, 1, 7, 498681) They were useful for conducting negotiations.
('27', 246, 1, 8, 498727) But the real suffering was the privilege of the rank and file.
('27', 246, 2, 9, 498790) “Does not the campaign location in an Indian State detract from its value as a part of the great Non co operation movement?” inquired our representative.
('27', 246, 2, 10, 498944) I do not regard this campaign as a part of the Non co operation movement, as such.
('27', 246, 2, 11, 499027) It is certainly a part of satyagraha.
('27', 246, 2, 12, 499065) But it has no direct connection with the Non co operation movement.
('27', 246, 2, 13, 499133) Satyagraha is an eternal principle.
('27', 246, 2, 14, 499169) I am sure that it has come to stay and we shall find, as time marches on, that it is applied in a variety of ways.
('27', 246, 2, 15, 499284) I have dealt with one such instance in the columns of the Navajivan.
('27', 246, 2, 16, 499353) 1 An enthusiastic reformer wishes to apply satyagraha to the solution of a corrupt practice in his caste, viz., the sale of daughters to the highest bidder.
('27', 246, 2, 17, 499510) He wants to stop this inhuman practice by courting suffering for the sake of his caste sisters.
('27', 246, 2, 18, 499606) If he does offer satyagraha in this case, we would not call it a part of the Non co operation movement.
('27', 246, 2, 19, 499710) I know that there is much difference between this instance and the Vaikom movement.
('27', 246, 2, 20, 499794) The latter is being conducted by congressmen and has reference to one plank in the Non co operation movement, that is, untouchability.
('27', 246, 2, 21, 499929) Nevertheless, it is clear to me that it cannot be called a part of the Non co operation movement.
('27', 246, 2, 22, 500027) Whether such a movement at the present stage should be initiated in an Indian State is a question which should be considered on its merits.
('27', 246, 2, 23, 500167) If the Vaikom movement was a part of the political movement, which is being conducted in Bri tish India, it is absolutely clear to me that it should be dropped.
('27', 246, 2, 24, 500328) I am personally averse to Congressmen creating directly or indirectly any complications in Indian States, who are themselves no better circums tanced than British Indian subjects.
('27', 246, 2, 25, 500508) A mere Resident or Political Agent is enough to frighten Rajas and Maharajas out of their wits.
('27', 246, 2, 26, 500604) They simply cannot resist any the slightest pressure from the British authorities.
('27', 246, 2, 27, 500687) This Vaikom movement is a socio religious movement.
('27', 246, 2, 28, 500739) It has no immediate or ulterior political motive behind it.
('27', 246, 2, 29, 500799) In its inception

('27', 247, 1, 2, 500908) it was not directed against the Travancore Durbar.
('27', 247, 1, 3, 500959) It was directed purely against an age long, intolerable sacerdotal prejudice.
('27', 247, 1, 4, 501037) So far as I know, the Durbar has intervened purely in the interests of peace, fearing, rightly or wrongly, that the presence of satyagrahis on these prohibited roads would result in a breach of peace.
('27', 247, 1, 5, 501238) If the Maharaja himself was a reformer and held strong views against untouchability, he might have thrown in his might in favour of the satyagrahis and protected them from molestation.

('27', 247, 2, 12, 502113) She has undoubtedly given them courage and hope and she has by her matchless gifts won over to our side many Europeans.

('27', 247, 2, 17, 502573) It did not reflect cultured European opinion.
('27', 247, 2, 18, 502619) In my opinion, she has acted with great tact and judgment.
('27', 247, 2, 19, 502678) It was not to be expected that she would produce any permanent effect upon the European opinion.
('27', 247, 2, 20, 502775) That can only be produced by the exemplary conduct of the resident Indians and their capacity for united action and suffering.

('27', 251, 1, 2, 509038) 253. TELEGRAM TO KALICHARAN 1
('27', 251, 2, 3, 509068) [On or after April 16, 1924]
('27', 251, 4, 4, 509097) From a photostat: S.N.8733
('27', 251, 5, 5, 509124) 254. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES I
('27', 251, 6, 6, 509151) The reader knows that I am a hardened criminal.
('27', 251, 6, 7, 509199) It was not for the first time that I found myself a prisoner in the March of 1922. I had three previous South African convictions to my credit, and as I was regarded at the time by the South African Government as a dan gerous criminal, I was moved from jail to jail and was able, therefore, to gather much experience of jail life.
('27', 251, 6, 8, 509530) 2 I had, before the Indian conviction, passed through six prisons and had come in touch with as many Superintendents and many more jailors.
('27', 251, 6, 9, 509670) When, therefore, during the beautiful night of the 10th of March I was taken to the Sabarmati Jail together with Mr. Banker, I did not feel any awkward ness which always attends upon a strange and new experience.
('27', 251, 6, 10, 509883) I almost felt I was going from one home to another in order to make more conquests of love.
('27', 251, 6, 11, 509975) The preliminaries were more like being taken to a pleasure trip than to jail.
('27', 251, 6, 12, 510053) The courteous Superintendent of Police, Mr. Healy, would not even enter the Ashram, but sent Anasuyabai with a message that he had a warrant for my arrest and that a car awaited me at the Ashram Gate.
('27', 251, 6, 13, 510254) I was to take whatever time I needed for getting ready.
('27', 251, 6, 14, 510310) Mr. Banker, who was on his way back to Ahmedabad, was met by Mr. Healy on the way and already arrested.
('27', 251, 6, 15, 510414) I was not at all unprepared for the news that Anasuyabai brought.
('27', 251, 6, 16, 510480) As a matter of fact, after having waited long enough for the coming of the warrant which everybody thought was imminent, I had given instructions that all should retire and I was myself about to lay myself to bed.
('27', 251, 7, 17, 510694) 1 This was in reply to Kalicharan’s telegram of April 16, 1924 which read: “Resolved to call All India Depressed Classes Round Table Conference on 31st May 1st June at Gondia through C.P. and Berar Depressed Classes Association’s and earnestly request you alone to preside and decide all questions concerning us once for all.” 2 For Gandhiji’s earlier jail experiences; a condensed version appeared in Young India, 29 6 1922, 20 7 1922 and 10 8 1922.
('27', 252, 0, 1, 511145) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 253
('27', 252, 1, 2, 511189) returned that evening from Ajmer after a fatiguing journey where most reliable information was given to me that a warrant had been sent to Ajmer, for my arrest, but the authorities would not execute the warrant, as the very day that the warrant reached Ajmer, I was going back to Ahmedabad.
('27', 252, 1, 3, 511480) The real news of the warrant, therefore, came as a welcome relief.
('27', 252, 1, 4, 511547) I took with me an extra kuchh (lion cloth), two blankets, and five books: Bhagavad Gita, Ashram Hymn Book, Ramayana, Rodwell’s translation of the Koran, a presentation copy of the Sermon on the Mount sent by schoolboys of a high school in California with the hope that I would always carry it with me.
('27', 252, 1, 5, 511849) The Superintendent, Khan Bahadur N.R. Wacha, received us kindly, and we were taken to a separate block of cells situated in a spacious, clean compound.
('27', 252, 1, 6, 512001) We were permitted to sleep on the verandah of the cells, a rare privilege for prisoners.
('27', 252, 1, 7, 512090) I enjoyed the quiet and the utter silence of the place.
('27', 252, 1, 8, 512146) The next morning we were taken to the Court for preli minary examination.
('27', 252, 1, 9, 512220) Both Mr. Banker and I had decided not only not to offer any defense but in no way to hamper the prosecution, but rather to help it.
('27', 252, 1, 10, 512352) The preliminary examination was, therefore, quickly over.
('27', 252, 1, 11, 512410) The case was committed to the Sessions, and as we were prepared to accept short service, the trial was to take place on the 18th of March.
('27', 252, 1, 12, 512549) The people of Ahmedabad had risen to the occasion.
('27', 252, 1, 13, 512600) Mr. Vallabhhai Patel had issued strict instructions that there should be no crowds gathering near the Court house and that there should be no demonstration of any kind whatsoever.
('27', 252, 1, 14, 512780) There were, therefore, in the Court house only a select body of visitors, and the police had an easy time of it, which I could see was duly appreciated by the authorities.
('27', 252, 1, 15, 512952) The week before the trial was passed in receiving visitors who were generally permitted to see us without restriction.
('27', 252, 1, 16, 513071) We were allowed to carry on correspondence so long as it was harmless and submitted to the Superintendent.
('27', 252, 1, 17, 513178) As we willingly carried out all the Jail regulations, our relations with the Jail officials were smooth and even cordial during the week that we were in Sabarmati.
('27', 252, 1, 18, 513342) Khan Bahadur Wacha was all attention and politeness, but it was impossible not to notice his timidity in everything he did.
('27', 252, 1, 19, 513466) He seemed to apologize for his Indian birth and unconsciously to convey that he would have done more for us had he been a European.
('27', 252, 1, 20, 513598) Being an Indian, even in allowing facilities which the regulations permitted, he was afraid of the Collector and the Inspector General of Prisons and every official who was at all superior to him.
('27', 252, 1, 21, 513795) He knew that, if it came to a struggle between himself and the Collector or the Inspector General of Prisons,
('27', 253, 0, 1, 513905) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 254
('27', 253, 1, 2, 513947) he had nobody to back him up at the Secretariat.
('27', 253, 1, 3, 513996) The notion of inferiority haunted him at every step.
('27', 253, 1, 4, 514049) What was true outside was equally true, if not truer, inside the Jail.
('27', 253, 1, 5, 514120) An Indian official would not assert himself, not because he could not, but because he lived in mortal fear of degradation, if not dismissal.
('27', 253, 1, 6, 514261) If he was to retain his post and obtain promotion, he must please his superiors even to the point of ringer and even at the sacrifice of principles.
('27', 253, 1, 7, 514410) The contrast became terrible when we were transferred to Yeravda.
('27', 253, 1, 8, 514476) The European Superin tendent had no fear of the Inspector General of Prisons.
('27', 253, 1, 9, 514554) He could claim just as much influence at the Secretariat as the latter.
('27', 253, 1, 10, 514626) The Collector for him was almost an interloper.
('27', 253, 1, 11, 514674) His Indian superiors he held cheap and, therefore, he was not afraid to do his duty when he wished and was equally unafraid to neglect it, when discharge of duty was an onerous task.
('27', 253, 1, 12, 514857) He knew that, as a rule, he was always safe.
('27', 253, 1, 13, 514902) This sense of safety enables young European officers often to do the right thing in spite of opposition either from the public or from the Government, and he has also often driven coach and six through all regulations, all instructions and defied public opinion.
('27', 253, 1, 14, 515165) Of the trial and the sentence I need say nothing as the reader knows all about it, except to acknowledge the courtesy which was extended to us by all the officials including the Judge and the Advocate General.
('27', 253, 1, 15, 515375) The wonderful l restraint that was observed by the small crowd of people that was seen in and about the Court, and the great affection showed by them can never be effaced from memory.
('27', 253, 1, 16, 515559) The sentence of six years’ simple imprisonment I regarded as light.

('27', 262, 2, 10, 537736) VYKOM SATYAGRAHA Vykom, of which till lately no one outside Travancore, at most the Madras Presidency, knew anything, has suddenly leapt to fame because it has become the seat of satyagraha.
('27', 262, 2, 11, 537927) The Press contains bulletins of the daily progress of the movement from day to day.
('27', 262, 2, 12, 538011) It has been undertaken in behalf of the untouchables of Travancore.

('27', 262, 2, 18, 538748) As most of the leaders have been imprisoned, an appeal has been made to the leaders all over India to come to the rescue.

('27', 267, 2, 3, 548042) NON VIOLENCE IN SILK A friend points out that, in the process of silk production, innumerable silk worms are destroyed, and asks how men and women who believe in non violence can use it.
('27', 267, 2, 4, 548229) If they cannot, he adds, the Gujarat Khadi Pracharak Mandal certainly should not undertake to popularize silk.
('27', 267, 2, 5, 548340) Here it is necessary to understand what is meant by having faith in non violence.
('27', 267, 2, 6, 548422) If a person’s acceptance of non violence is restricted to the sphere of Congress work, there can be no objection to his wearing silk, since his pledge of non violence has reference only to the Non co operation movement.
('27', 267, 2, 7, 548642) But those whose acceptance of non violence is absolute cannot be too careful in their efforts to refrain from all violence.
('27', 267, 2, 8, 548766) Since the world in which we live is full of violence and we see violence at every step, the believer in absolute non violence has necessarily to live with the utmost restraints.
('27', 267, 2, 9, 548944) Such a person should give up everything he can and also keep in mind that what we need to get rid of first are desire and anger.
('27', 267, 2, 10, 549073) There may be greater violence in making a caustic remark than in wearing silk.
('27', 267, 2, 11, 549152) Only he who has vowed to subdue his senses and has achieved some measure of success in his effort may concern himself with such subtle points.
('27', 267, 2, 12, 549295) Austerity in dress and food is of value only if it is a sign of inner discipline, otherwise it is likely to be insincere.
('27', 267, 2, 13, 549417) If my view is correct, there is no taint of violence in the sale of silk by the Gujarat Khadi Pracharak Mandal.
('27', 267, 2, 14, 549529) Considering the matter from the point of view of non co operation, we have no business to concern ourselves with selling silk.
('27', 267, 2, 15, 549656) If any organization connected with the Congress sells silk, its activity can perhaps be defended on the ground that it does so in order to popularize khadi.
('27', 267, 2, 16, 549813) I personally see no necessity for selling silk to make khadi popular.
('27', 267, 2, 17, 549883) One can, however, understand and condone the use of silk borders to beautify khadi.
('27', 267, 2, 18, 549967) SWADESHI SILK Besides, there is very little silk made in the country.
('27', 267, 2, 19, 550037) Silk thread is mostly imported.
('27', 267, 2, 20, 550069) It is true that some silk thread is produced in Bangalore and a few other places, but the quantity is so small as to be negligible.

('27', 268, 1, 2, 550293) popularized is not served by popularizing silk.
('27', 268, 1, 3, 550341) The spread of khadi is a moral duty because people in the country depend upon spinning for eking out a livelihood.
('27', 268, 1, 4, 550456) So long as we are unable to solve the problem of our daily bread, we cannot hope to follow dharma nor to win swaraj.
('27', 268, 1, 5, 550573) Where only a few thousand can earn their living by producing silk, crores can do so by spinning cotton and crores starve for want of opportunity to spin.
('27', 268, 1, 6, 550727) If the silk industry went out of existence, these crores or thousands would not starve.

('27', 268, 2, 8, 550877) His question is whether hand woven atlas 1 made from hand spun silk thread can be regarded as khadi.
('27', 268, 2, 9, 550978) Khadi can and should have only one meaning, viz., hand woven cloth made from hand spun thread.
('27', 268, 2, 10, 551073) Silk thread, jute fibre and wool woven in this manner may be called, if we like, silk, jute and woollen khadi, respectively.

('27', 270, 2, 4, 555258) MEANING OF ERADICATING UNTOUCHABILITY I observe that questions are still asked about issues which I thought had been made sufficiently plain.
('27', 270, 2, 5, 555400) According to the Congress resolution and my personal opinion as well, removal of untouchability can have only one meaning.
('27', 270, 2, 6, 555523) That is that, we Hindus, must rid ours elves of the sin of untouchability.
('27', 270, 2, 7, 555598) The four Varnas 1 do not regard one another’s touch as defiling or sinful.
('27', 270, 2, 8, 555673) We should treat Antyajas in the same way.
('27', 270, 2, 9, 555715) It has been repeatedly stressed that the resolution has no other implication.
('27', 270, 2, 10, 555793) As there is no inter dining or intermarriage among other communities, so also we are not required by the Resolution to have such relations with Antyajas.
('27', 270, 2, 11, 555947) There can be no compulsion in these matters.
('27', 270, 2, 12, 555992) But the conduct of the person who objects to physical contact as such with another person or looks upon someone as untouchable merely because he is born in a certain community, violates Nature’s law, is repugnant to he spirit of compassion and to shastra in the true sense of the word.
('27', 270, 2, 13, 556278) To mix up the efforts being made to end this sinful practice with inter dining and intermarriage is to obstruct the progress of the atonement which it is essential for us to go through.
('27', 270, 2, 14, 556464) The evil of untouchability has struck such deep roots among us that we do not recognize it as evil.
('27', 270, 2, 15, 556564) One would actually think that it was being carefully preserved as an ornament to the Hindu community.
('27', 270, 2, 16, 556666) When well wishers of the community find it difficult to end this evil, practical men would not introduce further difficulties and obstruct the progress of the reform.
('27', 270, 2, 17, 556833) Inter dining and intermarriage are issues relating to reform of the cast system.
('27', 270, 2, 18, 556914) Those who believe that caste should be abolished are working to bring about these reforms.
('27', 270, 2, 19, 557005) But it should be clearly realized that their efforts are entirely distinct from, and have nothing whatever to do with, the eradication of untouchability.
('27', 270, 2, 20, 557159) Those who wish to abolish caste also help in eradicating untouchability, and that is only right.
('27', 270, 2, 21, 557256) If they understand, however, that the reforms of inter dining and intermarriage are distinct from efforts to abolish untouchabliity, they will be able to judge their relative importance on merit.
('27', 270, 2, 22, 557452) What, then, is meant by the eradication of untouchability?
('27', 270, 2, 23, 557511) I thought this was already clear.
('27', 270, 2, 24, 557545) It means that the so called untou

('27', 271, 1, 3, 557910) The argument that the untouchables are dirty in their ways and follow some unclean occupation is, to my mind, the result of ignorance.
('27', 271, 1, 4, 558045) There are others dirtier than the untouchables, yet they draw water from the public wells.
('27', 271, 1, 5, 558136) A nursing mother does unclean work, and so does a doctor, but we honour both.
('27', 271, 1, 6, 558214) If it is said that they wash themselves after they have done their work, so do many untouchables before they go to a well to fetch water.
('27', 271, 1, 7, 558352) If, however, they do not keep themselves clean, the fault is ours.
('27', 271, 1, 8, 558419) To despise them, to compel them to live at a distance from the village, to make it impossible or difficult for them to gain access to the means of keeping themselves clean and then to reproach them for being unclean is the height of injustice.
