('27', 282, 5, 11, 584182) 269. NOTES
('27', 282, 6, 12, 584193) VYKOM SATYAGRAHA The anti untouchability campaign at Vykom is providing an interesting study in satyagraha and, as it is being conducted in a calm spirit, it must prove of great use for future workers along similar lines.
('27', 282, 6, 13, 584415) The Travancore authorities, whilst they still remain unbending regar ding the prohibition order, are carrying out their purpose in a court eous manner.
('27', 282, 6, 14, 584567) The public already know how quickly the authorities tried to check violence against satyagrahis.
('27', 282, 6, 15, 584664) The treatment in the jails too is in keeping with their conduct in the open.
('27', 282, 6, 16, 584741) Here is what Mr. Menon 2 writes from Trivandrum Jail:
('27', 282, 7, 17, 584795) The expected has happened.
('27', 282, 7, 18, 584822) I am now within the walls of the Trivandrum Central Jail along with my friend Mr. Madhavan.
('27', 282, 7, 19, 584914) We are treated as State prisoners.
('27', 282, 7, 20, 584949) A separate block is set apart for our use.
('27', 282, 7, 21, 584992) We are allowed our own clothes.
('27', 282, 7, 22, 585024) A convict cooks for us.
('27', 282, 7, 23, 585048) I am having the same food as I take at home.
('27', 282, 7, 24, 585093) so is my friend Mr. Madhavan.
('27', 282, 7, 25, 585123) Books and newspapers are also allowed.
('27', 282, 7, 26, 585162) Of course, in writing letters we are not allowed to say anything about the Vykom affair.
('27', 282, 7, 27, 585251) Friends can see us between 8 a.
('27', 282, 7, 28, 585283) and 4 p.m.
('27', 282, 7, 29, 585294) every day except Sunday.
('27', 282, 8, 30, 585319) 1 The remarks were scribbled by Gandhiji on a telegram dated April 23, 1924, received by Vallabhbhai Patel from Balwantrai Mehta, reading : “Devchandbhai wires postponement Committee.
('27', 282, 8, 31, 585503) Wire final instructions.” 2 Presumably, K.P. Kesava Menon, Secretary of the Kerala Congress Committee
('27', 283, 0, 1, 585605) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 284
('27', 283, 1, 2, 585647) I am sure that you would be glad to hear that the Superintendent and other authorities of the Jail are doing everything to make us comfortable.
('27', 283, 1, 3, 585791) we receive from them the same polite treatment as we received from the Police officers at Vykom.
('27', 283, 1, 4, 585888) The Travancore Jail authorities deserve to be congratulated upon their considerate treatment of the satyagrahi prisoners.
('27', 283, 1, 5, 586010) Let us hope on either side the present self restraint and courteous conduct will be continued to the end.
('27', 283, 2, 6, 586116) WHY PETITION ?
('27', 283, 2, 7, 586131) Surprise has been expressed over the advice I have tendered to the satyagrahis that, whilst satyagraha continues, the organizers should leave no stone unturned by way of petitions, public meetings, depu tations, etc., in order to engage the support of the State and public opinion on their side.
('27', 283, 2, 8, 586427) The critics argue that I am partial to the State authorities because they represent Indian rule, whereas I am hostile to the British authorities because they represent an alien rule.
('27', 283, 2, 9, 586610) For me every ruler is alien that defies public opinion.
('27', 283, 2, 10, 586666) In South Africa, Indians continued to negotiate with the authorities up to the last moment event though satyagraha was going on.
('27', 283, 2, 11, 586795) In British India, we are non co operating and we are doing so because we are bent on mending or ending the whole system of Government and, therefore, the method of petition is a hopeless effort.
('27', 283, 2, 12, 586990) In Travancore, the satyagrahis are not attacking a whole system.
('27', 283, 2, 13, 587055) They are not attacking it at any point at all.
('27', 283, 2, 14, 587102) They are fighting sacerdotal prejudice.
('27', 283, 2, 15, 587142) The Travancore State comes in by a side door as it were.
('27', 283, 2, 16, 587199) Satyagrahis would, therefore, be deviating from their path if they did not try to court junction with the authorities and cultivate public support by means of deputations, meetings, etc.
('27', 283, 2, 17, 587386) Direct action does not always preclude other consistent methods.
('27', 283, 2, 18, 587451) Nor is petitioning, etc., in every case a sign of weakness on the part of a satyagrahi.
('27', 283, 2, 19, 587539) Indeed, he is no satyagrahi who is not humble.
('27', 283, 3, 20, 587586) SOME IMPLICATIONS I have been also asked to develop the argument against sending aid apart from public sympathy from outside Travancore.
('27', 283, 3, 21, 587723) I have already stated the utilitarian argument in an interview.
('27', 283, 3, 22, 587787) 1 But there is a root objection too to getting, indeed even accepting, such support.
('27', 283, 3, 23, 587872) Satyagraha is either offered by a few self sacrificing persons in the
('27', 283, 4, 24, 587942) 1 Vide “Interview to The Hindu”, 15 4 1924
('27', 284, 0, 1, 587985) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 285
('27', 284, 1, 2, 588029) name of the many weak, or by very few in the face of enormous odds.
('27', 284, 1, 3, 588097) In the former case, which is the case in Vykom, many are willing but weak, and a few are willing and capable of sacrificing their all for the cause of the untouchables.
('27', 284, 1, 4, 588266) In such a case, it is obvious they need no aid whatsoever.
('27', 284, 1, 5, 588325) But suppose that they took outside aid, how would it serve the untouchable countrymen?
('27', 284, 1, 6, 588412) The weak Hindus, in the absence of strong ones rising in their midst, will not prevail against the strong opponents.
('27', 284, 1, 7, 588529) The sacrifice of helpers from other parts of India will not convert the opponents and it is highly likely that the last state of the untouchables will be worse than the first.
('27', 284, 1, 8, 588705) Let it be remembered that satyagraha is a most powerful process of conversion.
('27', 284, 1, 9, 588784) It is an appeal to the heart.
('27', 284, 1, 10, 588814) Such an appeal cannot be successfully made by people from other parts of India flocking to Vykom.
('27', 284, 1, 11, 588912) Nor should a campaign conducted from within need outside monetary support.
('27', 284, 1, 12, 588987) All the weak but sympathetic Hindus of Travancore may not court arrest and other suffering, but they can and should render such pecuniary assistance as may be needed.
('27', 284, 1, 13, 589154) I could not understand their sympathy without such support.
('27', 284, 1, 14, 589214) In the case, too of a very few offering satyagraha against heavy odds, outside support is not permissible.
('27', 284, 1, 15, 589321) Public satyagraha is an extension of private or domestic satyagraha.
('27', 284, 1, 16, 589390) Every instance of public satyagraha should be tested by imagining a parallel domestic case.
('27', 284, 1, 17, 589482) Thus, suppose in my family I wish to remove the curse of untouch ability.
('27', 284, 1, 18, 589556) Suppose further that my parents oppose the view, that I have the fire of the conviction of Prahlad, that my father threatens penalties, calls in even the assistance of the State to punish me.
('27', 284, 1, 19, 589748) What should I do?
('27', 284, 1, 20, 589766) May I invite my friends to suffer with me the penalties my father has devised for me?
('27', 284, 1, 21, 589852) Or is it not up to me meekly to bear all the penalties my father inflicts on me and absolutely rely on the law of suffering and love to melt his heart and open his eyes to the evil of untouchability?
('27', 284, 1, 22, 590052) It is open to me to bring in the assistance of learned men, the friends of the family, to explain to my father what he may not understand from me, his child.
('27', 284, 1, 23, 590210) But I may allow no one to share with me the privilege and the duty of suffering.
('27', 284, 1, 24, 590291) What is true of this supposed case of domestic satyagraha is equally true and no less of the case we have imagined of public satyagraha.
('27', 284, 1, 25, 590428) Whether, therefore, the Vykom satyagrahis represent a hopeless minority or, as I have been informed, a majority of the Hindus concerned, it is clear that they should avoid aid from outside save that of public sympathy.
('27', 285, 0, 1, 590647) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 286
('27', 285, 1, 2, 590689) That, in every such case, we may not be able to conform to the law, that in the present case too, we may not be able to do so may be true .
('27', 285, 1, 3, 590829) Let us not , however, forget the law and let us conform to it as far as ever we can.
('27', 285, 1, 4, 590914) CASE OF CHIRALA PERALA Let me quote one case in which I had the honour of advising.
('27', 285, 1, 5, 590998) I refer to the case of Chirala Perala.
('27', 285, 1, 6, 591037) 1 The citizens’ claim was that they were a united body and prepared to suffer.
('27', 285, 1, 7, 591116) What I witnessed was a wonderful exhibition of cohesion, courage and extremely able and daring leadership.
('27', 285, 1, 8, 591223) I said that I could not advise the Congress or the public to give pecuniary support.
('27', 285, 1, 9, 591308) I could not advise the Congress even to encourage them by passing resolutions.
('27', 285, 1, 10, 591387) If they won, the Congress would claim credit for the success of the means adopted by it.
('27', 285, 1, 11, 591476) If they failed, the Congress will share no discredit.
('27', 285, 1, 12, 591530) The people understood and accepted the advice.
('27', 285, 1, 13, 591577) Even after three years’ careful consideration, I have no reason to revise the advice then tendered.
('27', 285, 1, 14, 591677) On the contrary, I feel sure that, if we are to grow to our full height, we shall do so only by punctiliously observing the laws of the game.
('27', 285, 2, 15, 591819) THE WORK The Karnatak Provincial Congress Committee has met and amicably settled its differences about the venue.

('27', 285, 2, 26, 592719) I know that one party at least must surrender all to win all.
('27', 285, 2, 27, 592781) If each wants to bargain with the other, it becomes a miniature edition of the Hindu Muslim problem.
('27', 285, 2, 28, 592882) The only way to solve these knotty problems is for each party to regard the interest of the other as its own.
('27', 285, 2, 29, 592992) Then the knot is unloosed without effort.
('27', 285, 2, 30, 593034) The unresisting will solve the knot even as in undoing a material knot we

('27', 286, 1, 3, 593228) If the volunteers and workers vie with one another in serving, if the Brahmin bends to the non Brahmin and vice versa, they will clothe the whole of Karnatak in khadi, they will show national schools teaching under one roof Brahmin, non Brahmin, untouchable, Mussalman and all other creeds, boys and girls.

('27', 286, 2, 6, 593774) A STUDY IN PHILANTHROPY We have been accustomed so much to the charge against the Indian settlers in Kenya that, as they do not care for the native interest, their immigration should be restricted in the interest of the natives.

('27', 286, 2, 10, 594422) But the question naturally arises: is the presence of the European detractors of Indians beneficial to the natives?

('27', 286, 2, 14, 594888) His White Man’s Trust’ is more full of facts and figures than his previous article.

('27', 286, 2, 16, 595006) He is a student of history.
('27', 286, 2, 17, 595034) He is the readiest man I know to admit mistakes if he finds he has made any.

('27', 287, 2, 6, 596079) MR. PENNINGTON ON THE WAR PATH Mr. Pennington sent the following letter to my predecessor from France:
('27', 287, 3, 7, 596182) As a very old official of the Indian Government, I read Young India very carefully to see how you propose to govern the country when you have succeeded in making British Rule impossible.
('27', 287, 3, 8, 596369) You will perhaps admit that we British think we have a duty to perform in India, by way of keeping the peace both internally and externally, and that we should not be justified in handing it over, except to something like a possible Government.
('27', 287, 3, 9, 596614) I have the greatest respect for Mr. Gandhi and many other “Swarajists”, but do you honestly think that any Government he could form could govern that enormous country without a backing of British bayonets?
('27', 287, 4, 10, 596820) If the Swarajists could have shown that they could manage affairs even tolerably under.
('27', 287, 4, 11, 596908) Mr. Montagu’s scheme for the short period of 10 years, it might have been possible to frame some sort of Colonial scheme that would work; but, so far, they have only shown how to make anything like representative Government quite impossible, and so proved the greater fitness of the old system in the present state of the country.
('27', 287, 4, 12, 597239) It may be necessary therefore to try some other plan perhaps by further Indianization of the old system, as suggested many years ago by Mr. Donald Smeaton.
('27', 287, 4, 13, 597395) The King’s Government must be carried on even if Diarchy has to be scrapped.
('27', 287, 4, 14, 597472) I am glad to be able to renew acquaintance with Mr. J. B. Pen nington.
('27', 287, 4, 15, 597543) The answer to his query is incredibly simple.
('27', 287, 4, 16, 597589) If India succeeds in making British Rule impossible without matching the British bayonet with another bayonet, she will rule herself too with the same means.
('27', 287, 4, 17, 597747) But if it is an unalterable law that the rule of one bayonet can only be displaced by another of equal or greater strength, then I see no present prospect of making British Rule impossible.
('27', 287, 4, 18, 597937) I must admit, as my correspondent will have me to, that British people think that they have a duty to perform in India, but I may be permitted to add that we Indians think that their duty is not to impose peace upon us when we are longing to war against one another, but to lift their oppressive weight from over our heads.
('27', 287, 4, 19, 598261) We think that we are sinking beneath that weight.

('27', 288, 1, 2, 598378) 270. FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION
('27', 288, 2, 3, 598405) TO THE EDITOR, Young India
('27', 288, 4, 4, 598432) While commenting on the Tibbya College incident in the Young India
('27', 288, 5, 5, 598499) on the 10th April you write 1: “The Muslim student who took exception to the comparison was after all justified in so doing.” I do not know what exactly happened in the Tibbya College on the day of the celebration of Mr. Gandhi’s birthday, but accepting what Dr. Ansari writes as the true version of the incident, I feel it is difficult to agree with you in your comment.
('27', 288, 5, 6, 598871) No harm seems to have been meant or done to anyone when.
('27', 288, 5, 7, 598928) Mr. Gandhi was compared to Jesus Christ.
('27', 288, 5, 8, 598969) It may not be necessary for the purpose of honouring a man, as you write, to compare him with revered prophets, but at times to bring home to the audience or the public the greatness of an individual, comparison with other honoured men or revered prophets is neither unnatural nor unbecoming.
('27', 288, 5, 9, 599262) Mr. Andrews has on many occasions declared Mr. Gandhi to be a true picture of Jesus Christ.
('27', 288, 5, 10, 599354) It is quite possible that the person compared may not be worthy of a place of equality with revered prophets.
('27', 288, 5, 11, 599464) That is quite a different matter.
('27', 288, 5, 12, 599498) But how can one justifiably take exception to the principle of comparison itself?
('27', 288, 5, 13, 599580) The Muslim student in the Tibbya College might be considering Mr. Gandhi to be unworthy of comparison with Jesus Christ; if so, he was quiet welcome to hold his view and to declare it before the audience, as the Hindu student should have been welcome to hold his.
('27', 288, 5, 14, 599844) We can understand such a difference of opinion.
('27', 288, 5, 15, 599892) No one has a quarrel with it.
('27', 288, 5, 16, 599922) But here the case was quite different.
('27', 288, 5, 17, 599961) It was not that the Muslim student disagreed with the Hindu student in the latter’s estimate of Mr. Gandhi’s worth when he compared him with Jesus Christ, but that be objected to such a comparison itself, observing that no living person, however eminent in all respects, should be compared to
('27', 288, 6, 18, 600254) prophets.
('27', 288, 6, 19, 600264) One fails to understand how such an objection can be held to be justifiable.
('27', 288, 6, 20, 600341) Previous prophets were human beings and the like of them may now be amongst us and are sure to come hereafter.
('27', 288, 6, 21, 600452) What harm is there if comparisons are made of living saints or great men whom some may consider to be prophets with those that have gone before?
('27', 288, 6, 22, 600597) Intellectually, ethically or spiritually, there is nothing wrong in doing so.
('27', 288, 7, 23, 600675) A person compared to previous prophets may out of modesty disclaim such a comparison, but that is beside the issue.

('27', 289, 5, 21, 602952) 271. WHAT IS HINDUISM?
('27', 289, 6, 22, 602975) A dear friend send me a letter 1 (published elsewhere) gently criticizing the manner of my defence of Maulana Mahomed Ali’s now famous speech regarding his comparison of creeds.
('27', 289, 6, 23, 603153) The friend
('27', 289, 7, 24, 603164) 1 This was published under the title “The Ambiguous Middle”.
('27', 290, 0, 1, 603225) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 291
('27', 290, 1, 2, 603269) says that I have not been fair to Hindusim in that I have said a Hindu will fare no better than the Maulana.
('27', 290, 1, 3, 603378) He quarrels with my illustration about marriage and then goes on it show the beauties of Hinduism.
('27', 290, 1, 4, 603477) Another friend, too, has made a similar remonstrance and added that many others share his opinion.
('27', 290, 1, 5, 603576) These friends have, in my opinion, mixed up the question of propriety of comparing creeds with that of the allocation of their respective merits.
('27', 290, 1, 6, 603722) Indeed, in arguing that Hinduism is not like Islam and that a Hindu could not think like the Maulana, the friends themselves have subscribed to the Maulana’s argument that it is not only perfectly correct, but it is the logical outcome of one’s preferring a particular belief to every other, that for oneself that particular belief, though held by a bad man, is superior to that of another howsoever saintly.
('27', 290, 1, 7, 604131) I adhere to the marriage illustration chosen by me, though I now see that it would have been better for me to have avoided it.
('27', 290, 1, 8, 604258) It is not a conclusive illustration.
('27', 290, 1, 9, 604295) There are, I admit with my critics, many reasons for confining the choice of a husband to a particular class.
('27', 290, 1, 10, 604405) But I do claim that the predominant reason for excluding the best man if he happens to belong, as he often does, to another class or caste is his creed.
('27', 290, 1, 11, 604558) A Brahmin parent chooses a Brahmin as a husband for his daughter because he prefers the general body of opinion, which may be called creed, held by his clan.
('27', 290, 1, 12, 604716) Underlying the preference is no doubt the belief that acceptance of a creed ultimately involves practice in accordance with it.
('27', 290, 1, 13, 604844) A narrow creed, if it is honestly believed, has necessarily a limited field for practice.
('27', 290, 1, 14, 604934) A creed, for instance, that makes it obligatory to offer human sacrifice will never free the believer from the taint of religious murder unless he gives up the creed.
('27', 290, 1, 15, 605101) Thus it is that we find people otherwise most moral disappointing us when they fall short of the highest because of their narrow creed.
('27', 290, 1, 16, 605237) Many sincere and otherwise noble minded Hindus consider untouchability as a part of the Hindu creed and would, therefore, regard the reformers as outcastes.
('27', 290, 1, 17, 605394) If untouch ability was a part of the Hindu creed, I should decline to call myself a Hindu and most decidedly embrace some other faith if it satisfied my highest aspirations.
('27', 290, 1, 18, 605568) Fortunately for me, I hold that untouchability is no part of Hinduism.
('27', 290, 1, 19, 605639) On the contrary, it is a serious blot upon it, which every lover of it must sacrifice himself to remove.
('27', 290, 1, 20, 605744) Suppose, however, I discover that untouchability was really an integral part of Hinduism, I should have to wander in the wilderness because the other creeds, as I know them through their accepted interpreters, would not
('27', 291, 0, 1, 605964) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 292
('27', 291, 1, 2, 606006) satisfy my highest aspirations.
('27', 291, 1, 3, 606038) My correspondent accuses me of the crime of using the ambiguous middle in that I have confused Truth and non violence with the Hindu creed.
('27', 291, 1, 4, 606178) The crime is deliberate.
('27', 291, 1, 5, 606203) It is the good fortune or the misfortune of Hinduism that it has no official creed.

('27', 292, 1, 2, 608268) 272. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES II
('27', 292, 2, 3, 608296) SOME OFFICIALS It was on Saturday the 18th March that the trial was finished.
('27', 292, 2, 4, 608374) We were looking forward to a quiet time in the Sabarmati Jail at least for some weeks.
('27', 292, 2, 5, 608461) We had expected that the Government would not let us remain in that jail for any length of time.
('27', 292, 2, 6, 608558) We were, however, not prepared for the very sudden removal that actually did take place.
('27', 292, 2, 7, 608647) For, the reader may recall that we were removed on Monday the 20th March to a special train which was to take us to the Yeravda Central Jail.
('27', 292, 2, 8, 608789) We were made aware of the proposed removal only about an hour before departure.
('27', 292, 2, 9, 608869) The officer in charge was all politeness and we were enabled to feel perfectly comfortable on the journey.
('27', 292, 2, 10, 608976) But, imme diately on alighting at Kirkee, we observed the difference and were made to feel that we were prisoners after all.
('27', 292, 2, 11, 609101) The Collector and two others were awaiting the train.
('27', 292, 2, 12, 609155) We were put in a motor prison van which had perforations for ventilators.
('27', 292, 2, 13, 609229) But for its hideous appearance, it could well be a pardah motor.
('27', 292, 2, 14, 609294) Certainly, we could see nothing of the outside world.
('27', 292, 2, 15, 609348) For the story of our reception at the Jail, the tearing away of Mr. Banker from me, his restoration, the first interview, and kindred interesting details, I must refer the reader to my letter 1 to Hakimji Ajmal Khan Saheb, already published in these columns.
('27', 292, 2, 16, 609607) After the first unpleasantness, the relations between the then Superintendent, col.
('27', 292, 2, 17, 609691) Dalziel, and ourselves rapidly improved.
('27', 292, 2, 18, 609732) He was most considerate regarding our creature comforts.
('27', 292, 2, 19, 609789) But there was a certain something about him which always jarred.
('27', 292, 2, 20, 609854) He would never forget that he was Superintendent and we were prisoners.
('27', 292, 2, 21, 609926) He would not let it be granted that we were fully aware that we were prisoners and he was Superin tendent.
('27', 292, 2, 22, 610033) I made bold to say that we never once forgot that we were prisoners.
('27', 292, 2, 23, 610102) We showed him all the deference due to his rank.
('27', 292, 2, 24, 610151) The reminders were so unnecessary.
('27', 292, 2, 25, 610186) But he had the needlessly haughty demeanour which one often regretfully notices about so many British officials.
('27', 292, 2, 26, 610299) This weakness of his made him distrustful of the prisoners.
('27', 292, 2, 27, 610359) Let me give a pleasant illustration of what I mean.
('27', 292, 2, 28, 610411) He was most anxious that I should eat more than I was taking.

('27', 292, 2, 32, 610610) Well, it came.

('27', 298, 3, 4, 622336) 277. ACTIONS AS AGAINST BELIEFS
('27', 298, 4, 5, 622368) The discussion on Maulana Mahomed Ali’s speech on Islam still goes on in the newspapers.
('27', 298, 4, 6, 622457) I see that many persons who are otherwise intelligent and can understand things have also not understood the distinction drawn by him or, if they have, they lose sight of it while speaking and writing about the matter.
('27', 298, 4, 7, 622676) This means that the distinction has not penetrated deep enough in their minds.
('27', 298, 4, 8, 622755) It is, therefore, necessary to refresh, time and again, our understanding of the distinction drawn by the Maulana.
('27', 298, 4, 9, 622870) He believes that 1. There is a distinction between a man’s actions and his ideas.
('27', 298, 4, 10, 622953) 2 A man whose ideas are of the best may yet be unworthy in his conduct.

('27', 298, 4, 13, 623300) Hind uism, according to me, acknowledges the supremacy of truth and non violence.
('27', 298, 4, 14, 623382) There is no dharma greater than truth.
('27', 298, 4, 15, 623421) Ahimsa is the supreme dharma.
('27', 298, 4, 16, 623451) In conformity with these principles, the Maulana said: “As a Muslim, I regard the beliefs of an adulterous Muslim as superior to the beliefs of Gandhi whose conduct is the noblest.” The reader will see that here the Maulana has not instituted a comparison between me and an adulterous Muslim; he has just compared my beliefs with those of an adulterous Muslim.
('27', 298, 4, 17, 623812) Moreover, out of his liberality and his regard for me the Maulana says that, if one man may at all be compared with another, I would stand higher in point of virtue or conduct than even his revered mother or spiritual teacher.
('27', 298, 4, 18, 624039) This is an insult neither to me nor to the Hindu religion.

('27', 299, 1, 2, 624213) Suppose a European who is the greatest of saints believes that there is nothing wrong in experimenting on animals even by torturing them or by killing them for saving human life, nay, that it is wrong not to do so.

('27', 305, 1, 2, 639020) 280. MY NOTES
('27', 305, 2, 3, 639034) MILL SLIVERS We still find mill silvers being used in many places.
('27', 305, 2, 4, 639101) The use of such slivers did not matter when the spinning wheel was just coming into use and no one knew how to make slivers.
('27', 305, 2, 5, 639226) But today their use ought to be considered intolerable.
('27', 305, 2, 6, 639282) Only a person who does not understand the real principle behind the spinning wheel will use mill slivers.
('27', 305, 2, 7, 639388) We desire to see the spinning wheel installed in every home and in every village in the country.
('27', 305, 2, 8, 639485) There are seven lakh villages in India.
('27', 305, 2, 9, 639525) Many of them are very far from the railway line.
('27', 305, 2, 10, 639574) It is impossible to supply mill slivers to those villages.
('27', 305, 2, 11, 639633) Cotton which grows in one village is ginned at another place and then it is sent to a mill for being carded and ultimately it goes back to the same village in the form of slivers for being spun into yarn!
('27', 305, 2, 12, 639838) This is like getting flour kneaded in Bombay bread therefrom baked in Pethapur 1. Cotton should be carded where it is spun and it should be ginned where it grown.
('27', 305, 2, 13, 640001) The present unnatural system should be totally abolished.
('27', 305, 2, 14, 640059) The programme of the spinning wheel basically includes all the processes preliminary to spinning.
('27', 305, 3, 15, 640157) SISTERS OF KARNATAK Last week , about 50 Karnatak sisters living in Bombay came to see me.
('27', 305, 3, 16, 640248) They had brought with them yarn spun by them.
('27', 305, 3, 17, 640294) Along with it, they had brought Rs. 500. One of them had written a play called Samaj Seva.
('27', 305, 3, 18, 640385) The others staged it.
('27', 305, 3, 19, 640407) Admission was by tickets.
('27', 305, 3, 20, 640433) The sum of Rs. 500 was saved out of the money received from the sale of tickets for the performance.
('27', 305, 3, 21, 640534) They spent only Rs. 50 on staging the play.
('27', 305, 3, 22, 640578) Would not other sisters follow their example?
('27', 305, 3, 23, 640624) Not many sisters can write plays which are readable and fit for the stage and not many can stage plays either, but all can surely spin.
('27', 305, 3, 24, 640760) One sister told me that Maharashtrian women were active and indus trious, but Gujarati women were easy going.
('27', 305, 3, 25, 640870) How can Gujarati sisters tolerate such a charge?
('27', 305, 3, 26, 640919) Of course, I must admit that I do not know of Gujarati sisters having spun as much yarn as Smt.
('27', 305, 3, 27, 641015) Avantikabehn 2
('27', 305, 4, 28, 641030) succeeded getting Maharashtrian sisters in her circle to spin.
('27', 305, 4, 29, 641093) We shall certainly find other proofs of the superiority of Maharashtrian sisters
('27', 305, 5, 30, 641174) 1 A village in North Gujarat 2 Avantikabai Gokhale, a leading Congress worker of Maharashtra
('27', 306, 0, 1, 641267) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 307
('27', 306, 1, 2, 641311) if we look for them objectively.
('27', 306, 1, 3, 641344) Yet, being myself a Gujarati, how can I, writing about Gujarati sisters, be objective?
('27', 306, 1, 4, 641431) I accept the principle of being objective.
('27', 306, 1, 5, 641474) Still I must be partial to Gujarati sisters and request them in this article to prove themselves as active and industrious as their sisters in Maharashtra.
('27', 306, 1, 6, 641630) If they do not heed my humble entreaty, I shall have to believe that the change levelled by that Gujarati sister against them is true.
('27', 306, 1, 7, 641765) Both men and women may spin, but it is the special duty of the latter to do so.

('27', 307, 2, 6, 644277) MAJORITY OPINION But there is in that open letter one point which merits consi deration: Can questions relating to religion be decided by majority opinion in a municipality of any other public body?

('27', 312, 1, 2, 654305) 285. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES III
('27', 312, 2, 3, 654334) SOME TERRIBLE RESULTS In this chapter, I propose to discuss the results of the officials thinking that their duty ends with caring for the health of the prisoners, preventing fights among them or absconding.
('27', 312, 2, 4, 654542) I do not think I am exaggerating when I say that jails may be described as well or ill managed cattle farms.
('27', 312, 2, 5, 654651) A superintendent who ensures good food for the prisoners and does not punish without cause is considered both by the Government and the prisoners as a model superintendent.
('27', 312, 2, 6, 654824) Neither party expects more.
('27', 312, 2, 7, 654852) If a superintendent were to introduce the real human touch in his relations with the prisoners, he is highly likely to be misunderstood by the prisoners and will very probably be distrusted by the Government as being unpractical, if not worse.
('27', 312, 2, 8, 655096) The jails have, therefore, become hot beds of vice and degra dation.
('27', 312, 2, 9, 655165) The prisoners do not become better for their life in them.
('27', 312, 2, 10, 655224) In most cases they become worse than before.
('27', 312, 2, 11, 655269) Perhaps all the world over, the jails are an institution the most neglected by the public.
('27', 312, 2, 12, 655360) The result is that there is little or no public check on their administration.
('27', 312, 2, 13, 655439) It is only when a political prisoner of some fame finds himself within the walls of a prison that there is any public curiosity about the hap penings therein.
('27', 312, 2, 14, 655598) What classification there is of prisoners is regulated more in the interest of the administration than those of the prisoners.
('27', 312, 2, 15, 655725) Thus, for instance, one would find habitual criminals and persons who have committed not a moral but a merely statutory offence are put together in the same yard, in the same block and even in the same cell.
('27', 312, 2, 16, 655933) Fancy forty or fifty persons of varying types being locked in the same cell for night after night!
('27', 312, 2, 17, 656032) An educated man, who had been convicted under the Stamp Act for having used an officially defaced stamp, was put in the same block as habitual offenders regarded as dangerous characters.
('27', 312, 2, 18, 656219) It is no unusual thing to see murderers, abductors, thieves and mere statutory offenders huddled together.
('27', 312, 2, 19, 656326) There are some tasks which can only be done jointly by several men, such as working the pump.
('27', 312, 2, 20, 656420) Able bodied men alone can be put onto such tasks.
('27', 312, 2, 21, 656470) Some highly sensitive men were included in one such gang.
('27', 312, 2, 22, 656528) Now the ordinary prisoners in such a gang will use language which no decent
('27', 313, 0, 1, 656604) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 314
('27', 313, 1, 2, 656646) man would care to hear.
('27', 313, 1, 3, 656670) The men who use indecent language have no sense of indecency in the language they use.
('27', 313, 1, 4, 656757) But a sensitive man will feel most uncomfortable when such language is used in his presence.
('27', 313, 1, 5, 656850) Convict warders are in immediate charge of such gangs.
('27', 313, 1, 6, 656905) In the discharge of their duty, it is customary for them to swear at prisoners in the choicest billingsgate.
('27', 313, 1, 7, 657014) And when they are sufficiently worked up, they do not spare the rod either.
('27', 313, 1, 8, 657090) Needles to say, both the punishments are not only unauthorised, but they are unlawful.
('27', 313, 1, 9, 657177) I could however, present quite a decent catalogue of things unlawful that happen in jails to the knowledge of, and sometimes even with the connivance of, officials.
('27', 313, 1, 10, 657342) In the case mentioned by me, the sensitive prisoner could not put up with the foul language.
('27', 313, 1, 11, 657435) He, therefore, refused to work in the gang unless it was stopped.
('27', 313, 1, 12, 657501) It was due to the prompt intervention of Major Jones that a most awkward situation was averted.
('27', 313, 1, 13, 657597) But the relief was momentary.
('27', 313, 1, 14, 657627) He had no power to stop a recurrence of the trouble; for it must continue to recur so long as prisoners are not classified in accordance with a moral standard and with regard to their human requirements rather than administrative convenience.
('27', 313, 1, 15, 657870) One would have thought that, in a jail where every prisoner is under surveillance night and day and can never be out of the sight of a warder, crimes will not be possible.
('27', 313, 1, 16, 658042) But, unfortunately, every conceivable crime against morality is not only possible, but is committed almost with impunity.
('27', 313, 1, 17, 658164) I need not mention small pilferings, deceptions, petty and even serious assaults, but I wish to refer to unnatural crimes.
('27', 313, 1, 18, 658287) I will not shock the reader with any details.
('27', 313, 1, 19, 658333) In spite of my many jail experiences, I did not think that such crimes were possible in jails.
('27', 313, 1, 20, 658428) But the Yeravda experience gave me more than one painful shock.
('27', 313, 1, 21, 658492) The discovery of the existence of unnatural crimes produced one of the greatest of the shocks.
('27', 313, 1, 22, 658587) All the officials who spoke to me about them said that, under the existing system, it was impossible to prevent them.
('27', 313, 1, 23, 658705) Let the reader understand that, in a majority of cases, the consent of the victim is lacking.
('27', 313, 1, 24, 658799) It is my deliberate opinion that it is possible to prevent such crimes if the administration of jails is humanized and can be made a matter of public concern.
('27', 313, 1, 25, 658958) The number of prisoners in the jails of India must be several hundred thousand.
('27', 313, 1, 26, 659038) It should be the concern of public workers to know what happens to them.
('27', 313, 1, 27, 659111) After all, the motive behind punish ment is reformation.
('27', 313, 1, 28, 659168) The legislature, the judge and the jailor are believed to expect that the punishments would act as deterrents, not merely for the physical and mental hurt they cause, but for the
('27', 314, 0, 1, 659347) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 315
('27', 314, 1, 2, 659391) repentance that prolonged isolation must bring about.
('27', 314, 1, 3, 659445) But the fact is that punishments only brutalize the prisoners.
('27', 314, 1, 4, 659508) In the jails they are never given an opportunity for repentance and reform.
('27', 314, 1, 5, 659584) The human touch is lacking.
('27', 314, 1, 6, 659612) True, there is a weekly visit from religious preachers.
('27', 314, 1, 7, 659668) I was not permitted to attend any of these meetings, but I know that they are mostly shams.
('27', 314, 1, 8, 659760) I do not wish to suggest that the preachers are shams.
('27', 314, 1, 9, 659815) But a religious service once a week for a few minutes can produce no impression on those who ordinarily see nothing wrong in crimes.
('27', 314, 1, 10, 659948) It is necessary to provide a responsive atmosphere in which a prisoner unconsciously sheds bad and cultivates good habits.
('27', 314, 1, 11, 660071) But such atmosphere is impossible so long as the system of entrusting convicts with most responsible work is continued.
('27', 314, 1, 12, 660191) By far the worst part of the system is the appointment of convict officers.
('27', 314, 1, 13, 660267) These men are necessarily long term prisoners.
('27', 314, 1, 14, 660314) They are, therefore, men who have committed the most serious crimes.
('27', 314, 1, 15, 660383) Generally the bullies are chosen as warders.
('27', 314, 1, 16, 660428) They are the most forward.
('27', 314, 1, 17, 660455) They succeed in pushing themselves to the front.
('27', 314, 1, 18, 660504) They are the instruments for the commission of almost all the crimes that take place in the jails.
('27', 314, 1, 19, 660603) A free fight resulting in one death once took place because two such warders were concerned in the same prisoner who was a victim of their unnatural lust.
('27', 314, 1, 20, 660758) Everyone knew what was happening in the jail.
('27', 314, 1, 21, 660804) But the authorities intervened only to prevent further fighting and further bloodshed.
('27', 314, 1, 22, 660891) These convict officers recommend tasks for the other prisoners.
('27', 314, 1, 23, 660955) They supervise the tasks.
('27', 314, 1, 24, 660981) They are responsible for the good behaviour of the prisoners under their charge.
('27', 314, 1, 25, 661062) In fact, the will of the permanent officers is expressed and carried out through these convicts who are dignified as “officers”.
('27', 314, 1, 26, 661191) The marvel to me was that under such a system, things were not much worse than they actually were.
('27', 314, 1, 27, 661290) It once more demonstrated to me how superior men were to a wicked system as they were inferior to a good one.
('27', 314, 1, 28, 661400) Human beings seem naturally to seek the middle path.
('27', 314, 1, 29, 661453) The whole of the cooking, too, is entrusted to prisoners.
('27', 314, 1, 30, 661511) The result is indifferent cooking and organized favouritism.
('27', 314, 1, 31, 661572) It is the prisoners who grind corn, shred vegetables, cook food and serve.
('27', 314, 1, 32, 661647) When complaints as to short and badly cooked rations were recur ringly made, the invariable answer was that the remedy was in their own hands as they cooked their own food, as if they were related to one another and understood mutual responsibility!
('27', 314, 1, 33, 661897) Once when I pushed the argument to its logical extent, I was told that no admi nistration could afford the cost.
('27', 314, 1, 34, 662010) I differed from the view at the time of
('27', 315, 0, 1, 662050) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 316
('27', 315, 1, 2, 662092) argument.
('27', 315, 1, 3, 662102) Further observation has confirmed me in my contention that, under a well devised system, jail administration can be made self supporting.
('27', 315, 1, 4, 662240) I hope to devote a chapter to an examination of jail economics.
('27', 315, 1, 5, 662304) For the present, I must satisfy myself with saying that no question of cost can possibly be admitted as relevant in a consi deration of moral abuses.

('27', 315, 2, 7, 662476) 286. NOTES
('27', 315, 3, 8, 662487) A CATALOGUE OF CRIMES 1. Contributing to Tilak Swaraj Fund; 2. Association with Non co operators; 3. Subscribing to N.C.O. papers; 4. Standing for Non co operation; 5. Wearing khaddar.
('27', 315, 3, 9, 662672) These were actually regarded as crimes by the Post Master General of Madras in April 1922 and were the only grounds for dismissal of Mr. Subba Rao, a servant in the Postal Department, after 17 years’ service.
('27', 315, 3, 10, 662881) Let not the reader imagine that now Mr. Subba Rao has been reinstated.
('27', 315, 3, 11, 662952) Nothing of the kind has happened.
('27', 315, 3, 12, 662986) The poor dismissed servant of the Government petitioned the Viceroy and on the 3rd October 1923 he received a reply saying that His Excellency had ‘decided to reject your (his) memorial.’ The order of dismissal contains the counts as I have given them.
('27', 315, 3, 13, 663239) The recital of each count is followed by a description.
('27', 315, 3, 14, 663295) The contribution to the Tilak Swaraj Fund, for instance, is stated to have been given in the name of the minor daughter and amounted to Rs. 5. Venom could not go any further.
('27', 315, 3, 15, 663470) The logical result of such dismissals should be a regulation making it penal for a member of the legislature to wear khaddar.

('27', 316, 1, 2, 664207) WHAT IS VIOLENCE ?
('27', 316, 1, 3, 664226) Apropos of my article in Young India (April 10, 1924) entitled, ‘What It Is Not’, a correspondent examining the ingredients of viol ence says:
('27', 316, 2, 4, 664369) The real issue is not about just or unjust grounds.
('27', 316, 2, 5, 664421) Whether an act is an act of violence or not can be determined, not by reference to the grounds on which it is undertaken, but by reference to the manner in which it affects the party against whom it is directed and the effects which it produces generally.
('27', 316, 2, 6, 664677) Bothacts of violence and acts that are not acts of violencemay have a just or an unjust cause.
('27', 316, 2, 7, 664774) If a just cause can vindicate the adoption of a remedy, why should it justify a passive remedy only and not an active remedy?
('27', 316, 2, 8, 664900) If it can vindicate N.C.O., it can equally justify the use of a sword.
('27', 316, 2, 9, 664971) What moral delicacy should induce us to adopt N.C.O. and discard the sword?
('27', 316, 2, 10, 665047) We are answered that the use of the sword is a way of violence.
('27', 316, 2, 11, 665111) Way is that so?
('27', 316, 2, 12, 665127) The reason is clear that it causes pain and suffering to our adversary.
('27', 316, 2, 13, 665199) Does not N.C.O. do the same?
('27', 316, 2, 14, 665228) Is there any difference between the two?
('27', 316, 2, 15, 665269) The only difference is this.
('27', 316, 2, 16, 665298) Whilst a thrust from the sword would cause a feeling of pain and suffering due to a disturbance caused thereby to the natural processes inside the body, which result in and preserve life, the practising of N.C.O.
('27', 316, 3, 17, 665511) would cause pain and suffering by a disturbance to the processes working outside the body in the economic, social and political spheresprocesses
('27', 316, 4, 18, 665657) which are as much responsible for the preservation of life as those working inside the body.
('27', 316, 4, 19, 665750) The argument is clever, but it does not take us very far.
('27', 316, 4, 20, 665808) The writer confuses two words, pain and violence, and regards them as synonymous.
('27', 316, 4, 21, 665890) A physician who administers a bitter drug or cuts open an artery causes pain, but does no violence.
('27', 316, 4, 22, 665990) The patient thanks him for it.
('27', 316, 4, 23, 666021) If I do not serve my employer because he ill treats me, my resignation, i.e., non co operation, may cause pain, but I have used no violence.
('27', 316, 4, 24, 666162) But if I hammer him so as to make him do justice, I have extorted justice by violence.
('27', 316, 5, 25, 666249) HINDU MUSLIM TENSION IN SIND Dr. Choithram has sent me newspaper cuttings which give a fair idea of the trouble that seems to be brewing in Sind.
('27', 316, 5, 26, 666395) I have no desire to go into the facts of the case.
('27', 316, 5, 27, 666446) There was an attempt to settle the Hindu Muslim dispute by arbitration.
('27', 316, 5, 28, 666518) Dr. Choithram and Seth Haji Abdulla Haroon have had their say in the Press.
('27', 316, 5, 29, 666594) Seth Haji Abdulla Haroon says that there could be no arbitration before change of hearts.
('27', 316, 5, 30, 666684) Whatever the cause, the failure of arbitration is unfortunate.
('27', 317, 0, 1, 666747) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 318
('27', 317, 1, 2, 666789) But the painful part of the whole affair is that the Hindus do not feel that they are safe and that the police guard the route in the affected area.
('27', 317, 1, 3, 666938) If this is true, there is something radically wrong.
('27', 317, 1, 4, 666991) Whoever is to blame, there should be an understanding between the parties that no one can take the law into his own hands.
('27', 317, 1, 5, 667114) The parties may go to court if they cannot arbitrate, but overawing of one party by another can only end in bloodshed eventually.

('27', 317, 2, 12, 667769) 287. THE STARVING MOPLAH
('27', 317, 3, 13, 667794) I gladly print the following from Mr. Yakub Hasan :
('27', 317, 4, 14, 667846) I enclose a copy of the statement I have lately issued to the Press about Moplah Relief.
('27', 317, 4, 15, 667935) You will no doubt be grieved to learn that thousands of women and children belonging to the Moplahs, who were killed in the rebellion or were shot or hanged afterwards or are undergoing long imprisonment, are almost starving.
('27', 317, 5, 16, 668161) Moplahs as a class have always been poor.
('27', 317, 5, 17, 668203) Most of them cultivating lands under the petty landlords called Jenmies, who are almost all Hindus.
('27', 317, 5, 18, 668303) The oppression of the Jenmies is a matter of notoriety and a long standing grievance of the Moplahs that has never been redressed though unsuccessful attempts were made several times to ease the situation by means of legis lation.
('27', 317, 5, 19, 668534) The rebellion has reduced the poverty stricken Moplah community to still lower depth of destitution.
('27', 317, 5, 20, 668635) The forcible conversions have placed the community in bad odour with the Hindus in general and the Jenmies in particular, and the Government has also no love for the people who have not long ago fought pitched battles with it.
('27', 317, 5, 21, 668862) Hindus have had their vengeance through the military who burnt the Moplah houses and their mosques wholesale.
('27', 317, 5, 22, 668972) Thousands of Moplahs have been killed, shot, hanged or imprisoned for life and thousands are now languishing in jail.
('27', 317, 5, 23, 669090) Of those who are left behind, several thousand are paying fines in monthly instalments in lieu of imprisonment for two years.
('27', 317, 5, 24, 669216) These people are always under the thumb
('27', 318, 0, 1, 669256) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 319
('27', 318, 1, 2, 669300) of the police.
('27', 318, 1, 3, 669315) The few who have escaped death, jail or fine are not in any happier condition.
('27', 318, 1, 4, 669394) They are frightened out of their wits and are constantly living in terror.
('27', 318, 1, 5, 669469) Some of the people I talked to in the out of way places were trembling with fear in spite of the assurance given to them that I was their friend and the object of my visit was only to help them if I can.
('27', 318, 2, 6, 669673) This is the general condition of the Moplahs in South Malabar.
('27', 318, 2, 7, 669736) The condition of the women who have lost husbands and fathers by death or imprisonment is still worse.
('27', 318, 2, 8, 669839) Unlike their sisters in other parts of India, Moplah women do not observe purdah.
('27', 318, 2, 9, 669921) They are intelligent and industrious
('27', 318, 3, 10, 669958) and always work with their male relations in fields and elsewhere.
('27', 318, 3, 11, 670025) They are now very much handicapped; for just when the burden of supporting the family is thrown on their shoulders and they are called upon by the untoward circumstances to be the sole bread earners for their families, they find no work that would give them a living wage.
('27', 318, 3, 12, 670298) Though Moplahs have always been poor, still there were no beggars among them.
('27', 318, 3, 13, 670376) But now it is a common sight to see Moplah women and children in tatters begging in the streets.
('27', 318, 3, 14, 670473) Among the poor Muslim women who beg in this alms giving month of Ramzan, I find almost half are Moplah women in Madras, and I am told this is the case in all large cities in this Presidency.
('27', 318, 4, 15, 670664) As for children, their neglected condition can be more imagined than described.
('27', 318, 5, 16, 670744) Something has to be done and done immediately if the Moplah community is to be saved from moral, even physical, destruction.
('27', 318, 5, 17, 670869) In spite of all his faults and shortcomings, the Moplah is a fine man.
('27', 318, 5, 18, 670940) He has the bravery, the pluck and the grit of his Arab father, and the gentleness and the industry of his Nair mother.
('27', 318, 5, 19, 671059) His religious zeal is more misunderstood than appreciated.
('27', 318, 5, 20, 671118) He is as a rule peaceful, but he brooks no affront to his honour or religion.
('27', 318, 6, 21, 671196) Unfortunate circumstances, the causes of which I need not enter into on this occasion, forced him into the position of a rebel.
('27', 318, 6, 22, 671324) He has done what anyone, Hindu, Muslim or Christian, under the same circumstances and in the same emergency, would have done in self defence and self interest.
('27', 318, 6, 23, 671484) He has suffered the consequence of his deeds.
('27', 318, 6, 24, 671530) Should the society also visit his sins on his wife and children?
('27', 318, 7, 25, 671595) I place this matter before you Mahatmaji, because you are the head of the Indian nation, and both Hindus and Mussalmans jointly and severally look upon you as their leader.
('27', 318, 7, 26, 671768) It is not for me to say how this great problem should be tackled.
('27', 318, 7, 27, 671834) In your wisdom and goodness of heart, you will, God willing, find ways and means to carry life giving succour to the suffering Moplah women and children.
('27', 318, 7, 28, 671988) Your appeal will make the Hindus forgive and forget and show that magnanimity of the heart without which no nation can aspire to be great, and your appeal will make Mussalmans realize more fully their duty to themselves.
('27', 318, 7, 29, 672209) I am sure all the leading men
('27', 319, 0, 1, 672239) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 320
('27', 319, 1, 2, 672281) irrespective of cast or creed or political thoughts, will join hands with you in bringing this humanitarian cause home to the people at large.
('27', 319, 1, 3, 672424) My appeal must necessarily be to the Hindus.
('27', 319, 1, 4, 672469) I do not know how far it will be successful in the present tension between the two communities.
('27', 319, 1, 5, 672565) But I must not think of the result.
('27', 319, 1, 6, 672601) I should be guilty of cowardice if did not publish Mr. Yakub Hasan’s letter which comm ands my sympathy.
('27', 319, 1, 7, 672706) I know that the Hindus feel sore over what the Moplahs in 1921 did to their Hindu neighbours in Malabar.
('27', 319, 1, 8, 672811) I know that thousands of Hindus think that the Moplah atrocities were not as strongly condemned by the general body of the Mussalmans as they might have been.

('27', 319, 1, 13, 673827) We may not remember against posterity the sins of its forefathers.
('27', 319, 1, 14, 673894) The Moplahs sinned against God and have suffered grievously for it.
('27', 319, 1, 15, 673962) Let the Hindus also remember that they have not allowed the opportunity of revenge to pass by.

('27', 319, 1, 17, 674136) My point is simple.
('27', 319, 1, 18, 674156) In face of the awful fact of starvation and homelessness, all argument and all opposition must be hushed.
('27', 319, 1, 19, 674262) Generations hence, when all our evil acts will have been forgotten, posterity will cherish the treasured memory of every simple act of love shown by the one to the other.
('27', 319, 1, 20, 674433) I therefore ask every Hindu reader who will extend the hand of love and fellowship to his starving Moplah brother and sister and their children, to send his or her mite, and I shall endeavour to see that it is properly distributed among the most deserving among the Moplahs.

('27', 320, 1, 2, 674773) 288. VAIKOM SATYAGRAHA
('27', 320, 2, 3, 674796) Vaikom Satyagraha has attracted such wide public attention and, though restricted to a small area, presents so many problems for solution that I offer no apology to the reader for constantly engaging his attention for it.
('27', 320, 2, 4, 675018) I have received several important and well thought out letters protesting against my countenancing it in any way whatsoever.

('27', 320, 2, 6, 675238) I am sorry that I am unable to publish all these letters.
('27', 320, 2, 7, 675296) But I hope to cover all the points raised in these letters or otherwise brought to my notice.
('27', 320, 2, 8, 675390) The first may be cleared at once.
('27', 320, 2, 9, 675424) Exception has been taken to Mr. George Josepha Christianhaving been allowed to replace Mr. Menon as leader and organiser.
('27', 320, 2, 10, 675548) In my humble opinion the exception is perfectly valid.

('27', 323, 2, 23, 684103) 2. If it is general, then what is the special reason for selecting Vaikom in preference to places within the British territory in Kerala?
('27', 323, 2, 24, 684241) 3. Did the satyagrahis petition the Maharaja, the local As sembly, etc.?
('27', 323, 2, 25, 684314) 4. Did they consult the orthodox sections ?
('27', 323, 2, 26, 684358) 5. Is not the use of the road the thin end of the wedge, is it not a step towards the abolition of caste altogether?
('27', 323, 2, 27, 684475) 6. Is not the road a private road?
('27', 323, 2, 28, 684510) The first two questions are irrelevant.
('27', 323, 2, 29, 684550) Unapproachability and untouchability have to be tackled wherever they exist.
('27', 323, 2, 30, 684627) Wherever the workers consider a place or time suitable, it is their duty to start work,
('27', 324, 0, 1, 684715) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 325
('27', 324, 1, 2, 684759) whether by satyagraha or other legitimate means.
('27', 324, 1, 3, 684808) My information goes to show that the method of petition, etc.
('27', 324, 1, 4, 684870) was tried not once but often.
('27', 324, 1, 5, 684900) They did consult the orthodox people and thought that they had the latter’s support.
('27', 324, 1, 6, 684985) I am assured that the use of the road is the final goal of the satyagrahis.
('27', 324, 1, 7, 685061) It is, however, not to be denied that the present movement throughout India is to throw open to the suppressed classes all the public roads, public schools, public wells and public temples which are accessible to non Brahmins.
('27', 324, 1, 8, 685288) It is, in fact, a movement to purify caste by ridding it of its most pernicious result.
('27', 324, 1, 9, 685376) I personally believe in Varnashrama, though it is true that I have my own meaning for it.
('27', 324, 1, 10, 685466) Anyway, anti untouchability movement does not aim at inter dining or inter marrying.
('27', 324, 1, 11, 685551) Those who mix up the touch and the last two things together are doing harm to the cause of the suppressed classes as also to that of inter dining and intermarriage.
('27', 324, 1, 12, 685716) I have letters which protest that the road in question is a public road.
('27', 324, 1, 13, 685789) In fact, my informants tell me, it was some years ago even accessible to the unapproachables as to other non Brahmins.
('27', 324, 1, 14, 685908) In my opinion, therefore, there is a just cause for the Vaikom satyagraha and so far as it is kept within proper limits and conducted with the strictest regard to non violence and truth, it deserves full public sympathy.

('27', 324, 2, 16, 686151) 289. CHARKHA IN SOUTH KANARA
('27', 324, 3, 17, 686180) Writing about the work of the volunteers in relieving distress caused by the floods in South Kanara, Mr. Sadashiv Rao 1 writes :
('27', 324, 4, 18, 686309) About Rs. 50,000 were collected by the Floods Relief Committee of which I happen to be the Joint Secretary; and most of this money has been distributed among the poor, first for affording food and c lothing and latterly by way of money doles for building huts or small dwelling places for the poor.
('27', 324, 4, 19, 686608) In accordance with the undertaking given by the Committee to the public, the whole amount thus collected has practically been spent.
('27', 324, 4, 20, 686741) But the amount of Rs. 5,000 timely sanctioned by the All India Working Committee of the Indian National Congress and earmarked for advancing the constru 
('27', 324, 5, 21, 686895) 1 Karnad Sadashiv Rao, Karnatak Congress leader
('27', 325, 0, 1, 686943) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 326
('27', 325, 1, 2, 686985) ctive programme in the flood stricken areas has proved, like the flood itself, to be a blessing in disguise.
('27', 325, 1, 3, 687094) Under the auspices of the Rashtriya Jilla Khadi Board working under our District Congress Committee, we have opened twelve model depots in the affected parts wherein weaving and carpentry have been arranged to be taught according to the aptitudes of the people; and a great impetus has been given to the progress of spinning in the affected parts among all classes of people.
('27', 325, 1, 4, 687470) A convenient central village has been singled out for working the depot; and every morning our workers go into the neighbouring villages with cotton and charkhas to teach carding and spinning to the people in their homes.
('27', 325, 1, 5, 687692) Nurseries of cotton plants have also been made on the plots attached to these depots and arrangements have been made to distribute the plants gratis or at nominal prices among the people for being planted in their own places.
('27', 325, 1, 6, 687918) Last year the Congress Committee made a humble attempt to popularize cotton growing by a free distribution of seeds suited to the soil at this time of the year.
('27', 325, 1, 7, 688079) But barring a handful of them, most of the people did not take kindly to it.
('27', 325, 1, 8, 688156) It is for this reason that a departure has been made this year.
('27', 325, 1, 9, 688220) Already more than five hundred families have taken enthusiastically to spinning and we expect a thousand pounds of yarn in this month.
('27', 325, 1, 10, 688355) Last month we received through these twelve depots 735 Ibs.
('27', 325, 1, 11, 688415) of yarn of counts ranging from 8 to 20. We are obliged to give charkhas on the instalment system as the people are poor.
('27', 325, 1, 12, 688536) It is a most encouraging feature that the majority of these families who have begun to spin are Mahomedans and Christians.
('27', 325, 1, 13, 688659) The monsoon is almost upon us as it is expected to break out earlier this year, and already we have had showers with thunder and lightning.
('27', 325, 1, 14, 688799) It is well known that within a few weeks after the rains set in, most of the people in village parts are without occupation.
('27', 325, 1, 15, 688924) The money in hand set apart for the constructive programme has been exhausted.
('27', 325, 1, 16, 689003) And, if the charitable public do not come to our rescue at this juncture, the humble work begun by our struggling volunteers for relieving the distress of the poor by supplying supplementary occupations at their very doors will come to grief.
('27', 325, 1, 17, 689246) Having regard to the fact that 90 p.c.
('27', 325, 1, 18, 689285) of the people that have thus taken to spinning are women, I feel that I can confidently look up to all who love nation building work to contribute their mite for helping us to continue this glorious work of serving the poor.
('27', 325, 1, 19, 689510) There are thousands of women who are hankering to have the charkhas; but, for want of funds, the work cannot progress.
('27', 325, 2, 20, 689629) We have also made another departure in accordance with your advice.
('27', 325, 3, 21, 689697) There are twenty national schools in our district with a thousand pupils.
('27', 325, 4, 22, 689771) of these are high schools.
('27', 325, 4, 23, 689798) Boys coming out of these schools are taken as
('27', 325, 5, 24, 689844) apprentices in these depots; and they are asked to go back to their respective
('27', 325, 6, 25, 689923) villages for starting national elementary schools or panchayat courts or any
('27', 325, 7, 26, 690000) other handicrafts like weaving, carpentry, iron smithy, dyeing, printing,
('27', 325, 8, 27, 690074) etc., arrangements for teaching all of which are being made in these depots.

('27', 327, 8, 14, 692629) I also understand that the Working Committee, which met at Porbandar, had got to consult Pattani Saheb before it made recommendation to the Reception Committee to hold the Conference in Bhavnagar, and in failing to do this it has acted indiscriminately.
('27', 327, 8, 15, 692883) Pattani Saheb desires that the Parishad should not be held in Bhavnagar this Year.

('27', 327, 8, 18, 693119) He is prepared to encourage the people of Bhavnagar to attend it and, above all these, he is prepared to give all necessary help for making it possible for the

('27', 328, 2, 15, 694775) 294. RENUNCIATION PERSONIFIED 1
('27', 328, 3, 16, 694807) God created nothing finer than the Hindu widow.
('27', 328, 3, 17, 694855) Whenever I hear men recounting their misfortunes, the picture of the widow comes vividly before my eyes and I laugh at the man who bewails his misfortunes.
('27', 328, 3, 18, 695011) Self control has been carried by Hinduism to the greatest height and, in a widow’s life, it reaches perfection.
('27', 328, 3, 19, 695123) Man can find a remedy for his misfortunes, which are usually the consequence of his own folly.
('27', 328, 3, 20, 695218) Much of his misery is due merely to greed.
('27', 328, 3, 21, 695261) But what of the widow?
('27', 328, 3, 22, 695284) She, poor woman, is in no way responsible for her misfortune.
('27', 328, 3, 23, 695346) Nor is the remedy for it open to her, for custom has barred that door.
('27', 328, 3, 24, 695417) A great many widows do not even look on their suffering as suffering.
('27', 328, 3, 25, 695487) Renunciation has become second nature to them, and to renounce it would be painful to them.
('27', 328, 3, 26, 695579) They find happiness in their self denial.
('27', 328, 3, 27, 695621) This is not an undesirable state.
('27', 328, 3, 28, 695655) On the contrary, it is good.
('27', 328, 3, 29, 695684) It is Hinduism at its best.
('27', 328, 3, 30, 695712) I regard the widow’s life as an ornament to Hinduism.
('27', 328, 3, 31, 695766) When I see a widow, I instinctively bow my head in
('27', 328, 4, 32, 695817) 1 Vide also “Curse of Widowhood”, 9 5 1920 & “More thoughts about Widows”, 16 5 1920.
('27', 329, 0, 1, 695903) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 330
('27', 329, 1, 2, 695945) reverence.
('27', 329, 1, 3, 695956) I never regard the sight of a widow as an ill omen.
('27', 329, 1, 4, 696008) I feel blessed if I see the face of one in the morning.
('27', 329, 1, 5, 696064) A widow’s blessing is to me a gift which I prize.
('27', 329, 1, 6, 696114) Seeing her, I forget all my sorrows.
('27', 329, 1, 7, 696151) Man is but a clod before her.
('27', 329, 1, 8, 696181) A widow’s patient suffering is impossible to rival.
('27', 329, 1, 9, 696233) Compared to her inheritance of ages, of what worth is a man’s self acquired wealth of brief renunciation ?
('27', 329, 1, 10, 696340) If a widow suffers, before whom can she pour out her grief?
('27', 329, 1, 11, 696400) If there is anyone in this world before whom she can do so, it is her mother.
('27', 329, 1, 12, 696478) But what is the use ?
('27', 329, 1, 13, 696500) What help can the mother give ?
('27', 329, 1, 14, 696532) All she can do is to ask her to be patient and go and attend to her work.
('27', 329, 1, 15, 696606) For a widow, her mother’s house is no longer her home.
('27', 329, 1, 16, 696661) She must live with her father in law’s family.
('27', 329, 1, 17, 696708) Only a daughter in law knows what it is to be harassed by a mother in law.
('27', 329, 1, 18, 696783) A widow’s duty is to serve others.
('27', 329, 1, 19, 696818) The brother in law, the mother in law, the father in law and every chance visitorshe must serve them all.
('27', 329, 1, 20, 696925) She is never weary.
('27', 329, 1, 21, 696945) She only prays for strength to enable her to serve better.
('27', 329, 1, 22, 697004) If this holy life lived by widows becomes a thing of the past, if this living image of service is destroyed through ignorance or pride, incalculable harm will be done to Hinduism.
('27', 329, 1, 23, 697184) How can this way of life for widows be kept alive?
('27', 329, 1, 24, 697235) What share of the virtues of following it can be claimed by parents who marry off a daughter only ten years old?
('27', 329, 1, 25, 697348) Can the girl who becomes a widow on the very day she is married be regarded as a widow?
('27', 329, 1, 26, 697436) Are we not committing an unforgivable sin by regarding as dharma the extreme length to which the rules about a widow’s life are carried?
('27', 329, 1, 27, 697573) If this way of life is to be kept alive, is it not essential that the men give thought to their own duty?
('27', 329, 1, 28, 697679) Can a woman, who is innocent of what widowhood means, possess a body that can follow the widow’s life?
('27', 329, 1, 29, 697782) Who can imagine how a girl married today feels?
('27', 329, 1, 30, 697830) What is her father’s duty towards her?
('27', 329, 1, 31, 697869) Or, was it over when he put a knife to her throat?
('27', 329, 1, 32, 697920) It is my humble opinion that the following rules are necessary for preserving the sanctity of the widow’s life, for preserving Hinduism and for order in Hindu society.
('27', 329, 1, 33, 698088) 1. No father should get a daughter under the age of 15 married.
('27', 329, 1, 34, 698152) 2. If a girl below this age has already been married and has become a widow, it is the father’s duty to get her married again.
('27', 329, 1, 35, 698279) 3. If a fifteen year old girl becomes a widow within a year of her marriage, her parents should encourage her to marry again.
('27', 329, 1, 36, 698405) 4. Every member of the family should look upon the widow with
('27', 330, 0, 1, 698467) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 331
('27', 330, 1, 2, 698511) the utmost respect.
('27', 330, 1, 3, 698531) Parents or parents in law must provide her with the means of improving her knowledge.
('27', 330, 1, 4, 698617) I have not suggested these rules to be generally followed.
('27', 330, 1, 5, 698676) They are to serve only as a guide.
('27', 330, 1, 6, 698711) I am convinced that our duty towards widows is along the lines indicated in them.
('27', 330, 1, 7, 698793) Who should ensure that these rules are followed?
('27', 330, 1, 8, 698842) In Hindu society, castes are the natural agencies for this purpose.
('27', 330, 1, 9, 698910) But till such time as they are reformed, what should those parents do who are ready to follow these rules?
('27', 330, 1, 10, 699017) They should make efforts to persuade their community to introduce reforms and, if they do not succeed, free themselves from the shackles of the caste and search for a suitable bridegroom for the widow.
('27', 330, 1, 11, 699219) Both the parties should be ready to live outside the cast and appeal to its members from outside.
('27', 330, 1, 12, 699317) They should do nothing which would shock the leaders, nor should they think of resorting to satyagraha; if at all they want to offer satyagraha; they should understand that staying humbly outside the caste is in itself satyagraha.
('27', 330, 1, 13, 699548) If the marriage had been thought of as the only possible course in the circumstances, if the motive behind it was to live a life of self control and if the ostracized family’s life is blameless in every way, then the elders will not only take them back into the caste, but will also accept this reform and other poor widows will be spared the torture which would have been theirs otherwise.
('27', 330, 1, 14, 699939) Such reforms cannot be brought about immediately, but it is enough if their seeds are sown.
('27', 330, 1, 15, 700031) In time, the seeds will surely grow into trees.
('27', 330, 1, 16, 700079) I have suggested only a minor reform.
('27', 330, 1, 17, 700117) I have done this because a really big reform may seem impossible.
('27', 330, 1, 18, 700183) This reform would be that, man too, like woman, should not remarry after the death of his partner.
('27', 330, 1, 19, 700282) If we understand the true meaning of Hinduism, we would not reduce the rigour of a restraint which is difficult to practise, but would on the contrary introduce in our lives other similar restraints and thus practise the former more rigidly.
('27', 330, 1, 20, 700524) If widowers do not marry again, widows would not feel life to be a burden, and marriages of ill matched pairs and of children which are so common today would stop.
('27', 330, 1, 21, 700688) There is in all this one danger which we should guard against.
('27', 330, 1, 22, 700751) I have heard the following argument: “The widow’s customary life is a great ideal in every way.
('27', 330, 1, 23, 700847) Why, then, to get a few child widows remarried?
('27', 330, 1, 24, 700895) We want even widowers to refrain from marrying again.
('27', 331, 0, 1, 700949) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 332
('27', 331, 1, 2, 700991) Besides, we want the custom of child marriage also to end.
('27', 331, 1, 3, 701050) It is not necessary, therefore, to encourage widows to remarry under any circumstances.” This is a dangerous argument, for it is mere sophis try.
('27', 331, 1, 4, 701196) It resembles an argument put forward by some British friends: “You believe in non violence and want us also to practise non violence.
('27', 331, 1, 5, 701330) Hence, no matter what force we use, you ought not to ask your people to resist us with force.” This is what some of them tell me.
('27', 331, 1, 6, 701460) The fallacy in this reasoning is plain enough.
('27', 331, 1, 7, 701507) All of us commit similar fallacies knowingly or unknowingly.
('27', 331, 1, 8, 701568) The British friends who argue in this way forget that I wish to teach non violence to both parties.
('27', 331, 1, 9, 701668) But how can I advocate non violence to those who are incapable of the understanding it, who are, in other words, cowardly?
('27', 331, 1, 10, 701791) I could not convince my son of the duty of remaining non violent.
('27', 331, 1, 11, 701857) Nor could I get it accepted by the poor and harassed villagers of Bettiah.
('27', 331, 1, 12, 701932) 1 I had to tell them: “If your choice lies between running away and leaving a woman to her fate or defending her by force against a mis creant, if you cannot, resolutely, remain where you are and, looking upon him as your brother and using no force against him, oppose him with satyagraha unto death, then by all means attack him with force and defend the woman.” The path of satyagraha is not for cowards.
('27', 331, 1, 13, 702339) It is only when a person has shed his cowardice and become a that he is fit for the method of non violence.
('27', 331, 1, 14, 702447) If we now examine the sophistic argument in regard to widows, we shall see that only widowers who are ready to remain unmarried have a right to advance it.
('27', 331, 1, 15, 702603) Others who do not appreciate the idea of a widower remaining unmarried or who, though they appreciate the idea itself, are not ready to act upon it, have no right to use that as an argument for defending the custom of compelling widows to remain unmarried.
('27', 331, 1, 16, 702860) Imagine a sixty year old man, who had remarried, cheerfully contemplating the possibility of his nine year old wife, so called, becoming a widow, writing admiringly in his will about her state, saluting his poor child wife doomed to be a widow and saying: “If, through misfortune, I die before my most virtuous wife, my partner in dharma, I know that she will remain a widow and shed glory on me, on my and her parents’ families and on the Hindu way of life.
('27', 331, 1, 17, 703319) Having married this girl, I have realized that a widower should remain unmarried.
('27', 331, 1, 18, 703401) I would have done better if I had done so.
('27', 331, 1, 19, 703444) I admit my weakness.
('27', 331, 1, 20, 703465) But a man’s weakness adds to the lustre of a widow’s life.
('27', 331, 2, 21, 703524) 1 Vide “Speech at Bettiah”, 8 12 1920.
('27', 332, 0, 1, 703563) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 333
('27', 332, 1, 2, 703607) Concerning my child wife, therefore, I desire that, after my death, she should remain a widow and illustrate the glory of self control.” What effect will this argument have on that child widow or on those who read the will?
('27', 332, 1, 3, 703831) It was necessary to examine this argument, since, under cover or in the name of loyalty to a noble ideal, many unholy practices which have the appearance of being holy are defended.
('27', 332, 1, 4, 704013) The definition of a widow can have no reference to child marriages.
('27', 332, 1, 5, 704081) A widow means a woman who, at the proper age, married a person of her choice or was married to him with her consent, who has had relations with her husband, and who has then lost her husband.
('27', 332, 1, 6, 704273) A wife who has not known consummation of marriage or a girl of tender age sacrificed by her parents cannot and must not be included in this definition.
('27', 332, 1, 7, 704425) It is, therefore, perversity to defend the custom forcing girls to submit to their so called widowhood.

('27', 338, 3, 17, 719788) THE MEANING OF “BHAIYA” Like men, words too cannot but suffer from association.

('27', 340, 1, 24, 725422) It will be enough if there is a change of heart in them.
('27', 340, 1, 25, 725479) Their love of money will then go with more of compassion than at present.
('27', 340, 1, 26, 725553) Today, concern with morality is subordinate to wealth, instead of which wealth will become subordinate to such concern.

('27', 340, 1, 28, 725768) As long as khadi has not been adopted universally, this happy state of affairs will not be achieved and, if khadi is to be so adopted, it
('27', 341, 0, 1, 725906) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 342
('27', 341, 1, 2, 725948) should be recognized beyond dispute that those who are working in this movement can have no use for cloth other than khadi.
('27', 341, 1, 3, 726072) It is because this is not plain to all that the spread of khadi is slow, people take up the spinning wheel for a time and stop, start again and stop.

('27', 341, 1, 6, 726503) THE LATE RAMABAI RANADE The name of Ramabai Ranade is not as well known in Gujarat as it is in Maharashtra.
('27', 341, 1, 7, 726611) This lady brought lustre to the name of the late Justice Ranade.
('27', 341, 1, 8, 726676) Her death is a great loss to the country.
('27', 341, 1, 9, 726718) Few women have lived their lives as widows as worthily as Ramabai did.
('27', 341, 1, 10, 726789) Search where we will in the country, we shall not find an institution the equal of the Seva Sadan of poona.
('27', 341, 1, 11, 726897) Here a thousand women and girls receive education in various fields.
('27', 341, 1, 12, 726966) The Seva Sadan could never have acquired such prestige but for the single minded devotion of Ramabai.
('27', 341, 1, 13, 727068) She gave her whole life to this one task.
('27', 341, 1, 14, 727110) A widow’s life in itself means a life of single minded devotion.
('27', 341, 1, 15, 727175) The wife’s constancy connotes the purest loyalty.
('27', 341, 1, 16, 727225) Ordinary loyalty relates to the body and dies with it.
('27', 341, 1, 17, 727280) The loyalty of the woman living as a widow is to the husband’s spirit.
('27', 341, 1, 18, 727351) By giving a religious significance to the state of widowhood, Hinduism has shown that marriage is not a physical but a spiritual union.
('27', 341, 1, 19, 727487) Ramabai had married Ranade’s soul and she kept this union of souls unbroken.
('27', 341, 1, 20, 727564) For this reason she took up from among the causes which were dear to him (her husband) a task which was within her capacity.
('27', 341, 1, 21, 727689) Dedicating herself wholly to it, she taught people the full meaning of widowhood.
('27', 341, 1, 22, 727771) In this way, Ramabai, through her work, rendered priceless service to women.
('27', 341, 1, 23, 727848) When I was in the Sassoon Hospital, Col.
('27', 341, 1, 24, 727889) Maddock told me that good Indian nurses were trained in that hospital, that the trainees came from the Seva Sadan and were in great demand all over the country.
('27', 341, 1, 25, 728050) If widows wish to take up work, there are many fields open to them.
('27', 341, 1, 26, 728118) Spinning alone can fill the leisure of hundreds of rich widows.
('27', 341, 1, 27, 728182) Is there any widow who does not know from experience that the spinning wheel is the support of the poor?
('27', 341, 1, 28, 728287) I have here suggested one beneficent activity which can be universally adopted.
