('27', 342, 2, 3, 728550) CULTIVATORS OF SUPA 1
('27', 342, 3, 4, 728572) A gentleman from Kaliawari 2 writes as follows.
('27', 342, 4, 5, 728620) This letter is worth reading and pondering over.
('27', 342, 4, 6, 728669) It shows that the country is a land of gold.
('27', 342, 4, 7, 728714) That the agriculturists should not understand the value of an activity which is of profit to themselves is a painful, but not surprising, state of affairs.
('27', 342, 4, 8, 728870) They have followed their methods for a long time and so cannot grasp elementary economic facts.
('27', 342, 4, 9, 728966) The higher the price for cotton which they get, the more will they have to spend for their cloth.
('27', 342, 4, 10, 729064) This is simple and straightforward arithmetic, but how can we expect them to understand it?
('27', 342, 4, 11, 729156) If a child has been taught by some teacher a wrong method of doing a sum, he will always get wrong answer.
('27', 342, 4, 12, 729263) If, now another teacher tries to correct the error, he will be laughed at.
('27', 342, 4, 13, 729338) Such is our pitiful condition today.
('27', 342, 4, 14, 729375) We have been taught a wrong method, with the result that to us the right method seems wrong and the wrong seems right.
('27', 342, 4, 15, 729494) It was such phenomena that Shankaracharya described as maya.
('27', 342, 4, 16, 729555) In these circumstances, the only thing for voluntary workers is to have patience.
('27', 342, 4, 17, 729637) They must never be angry with cultivators.
('27', 342, 4, 18, 729680) What their condition is today, ours was yesterday.
('27', 342, 4, 19, 729731) They will certainly understand their interest.
('27', 342, 4, 20, 729778) Just as they keep back enough grain for their own use, why should they not store cotton too?
('27', 342, 4, 21, 729871) If they are too well off to spin or weave, they may get others to do the work for them.
('27', 342, 4, 22, 729959) Even the wealthy do not follow such an absurd rule where grain is concerned.
('27', 342, 4, 23, 730036) They get it cooked in their own homes and do not buy food from the bazaar.
('27', 342, 4, 24, 730111) In fact, buying food from the bazaar is considered improper for a respectable man.
('27', 342, 4, 25, 730194) This used to be the feeling in regard to cloth also.
('27', 342, 4, 26, 730247) Why should it not be so again?

('27', 343, 1, 2, 730594) 298. NEGLECT OF THE CHARKHA
('27', 343, 2, 3, 730622) A gentleman writes from Kashi that our going into the local boards, etc., has done us no good whatever; in fact, it has put a stop to constructive work.
('27', 343, 2, 4, 730775) He also says that these people are apathetic towards the charkha.
('27', 343, 2, 5, 730841) Many people do not also have faith in the charkha.
('27', 343, 2, 6, 730892) When one says anything to these people, they answer: “We have got on the board on Gandhiji’s advice.” First I do not want that anyone should do anything on my advice.
('27', 343, 2, 7, 731059) Whatever people do, they should do according to their own judgement.
('27', 343, 2, 8, 731128) We wish to be free.
('27', 343, 2, 9, 731148) We do not wish to be slaves of anyone, however influential he may be.
('27', 343, 2, 10, 731218) My own opinion is that it is not so very necessary to go to the local boards, etc.
('27', 343, 2, 11, 731301) If we do go there, we should do so solely with the intention of furthering constructive work.
('27', 343, 2, 12, 731395) If, however, it is not possible to carry on constructive work properly there, we should keep away from these institutions.
('27', 343, 2, 13, 731518) I know that many non co operators have no faith in the power of the charkha.
('27', 343, 2, 14, 731595) There is only one way of convincing them: that those who have faith in the charkha should ply it with the greatest zest and encourage others.
('27', 343, 2, 15, 731737) It is my firm belief that without the charkha it is impossible to secure or retain swaraj.
('27', 343, 2, 16, 731828) True, it may be that all of us do not mean the same thing by swaraj.
('27', 343, 2, 17, 731897) To me it has but one meaning : the eradication of the poverty of India and freedom for every man and woman.
('27', 343, 2, 18, 732005) Ask the starving men and women of India.
('27', 343, 2, 19, 732046) They say that their swaraj is their bread.
('27', 343, 2, 20, 732089) Agriculture alone cannot feed the tens of millions of Indian peasants.
('27', 343, 2, 21, 732160) They need additional help from some industry or other.
('27', 343, 2, 22, 732215) The charkha alone can provide such a universal industry.
('27', 343, 2, 23, 732272) “A starving man cannot think of God.” Another gentleman writes to say that something should be done to provide livelihood to those who have given up their trades on account of the non co operation movement.
('27', 343, 2, 24, 732479) It is and it is not a difficult question to solve at once.
('27', 343, 2, 25, 732538) If everyone comes to understand the secret of constructive work, the question of starving does not arise at all.
('27', 343, 2, 26, 732651) But if faith in constructive work is lacking, starvation will remain a perpetual problem.
('27', 343, 2, 27, 732741) It is my firm belief that he who has faith in the charkha and the handloom can easily find a livelihood.
('27', 343, 2, 28, 732846) The dif ficulties of the middle classes in the country can only be solved through industry.
('27', 343, 2, 29, 732938) We have a number of bad customs.
('27', 343, 2, 30, 732971) We shall have to
('27', 344, 0, 1, 732988) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 345
('27', 344, 1, 2, 733032) give them up.
('27', 344, 1, 3, 733046) If only one man labours and there are ten who do nothing, we cannot get a living out of weaving.
('27', 344, 1, 4, 733143) Also, we should not keep looking up to the Congress all the time.
('27', 344, 1, 5, 733209) Swaraj should mean this, too, that we become self supporting.
('27', 344, 1, 6, 733271) This is what one may call faith in oneself.
('27', 344, 1, 7, 733315) Lord Krishna, the lover of his devotes, has laid down in the Bhagavad Gita one condition for the livelihood of every man.
('27', 344, 1, 8, 733437) He who wants to appease his hunger should fulfil this condition.
('27', 344, 1, 9, 733502) Yajna means a number of things.
('27', 344, 1, 10, 733534) One important thing it means is labour.
('27', 344, 1, 11, 733574) He who eats but performs no labour is a thief, in the words of the Lord.

('27', 348, 1, 2, 739226) 305. LETTER TO QUMAR AHMED
('27', 348, 2, 3, 739253) POST ANDHERI, May 6, 1924
('27', 348, 3, 4, 739279) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter undated, but I know it was received some time ago.
('27', 348, 3, 5, 739362) I am sorry I have not been able to read it earlier.
('27', 348, 3, 6, 739414) I am not indifferent towards lawyers and schoolmasters.
('27', 348, 3, 7, 739470) It is because my whole heart is with them that I find it difficult to advise them.
('27', 348, 3, 8, 739553) No disgrace can possibly be attached to a man who changes his attitude regarding a particular thing from conviction.
('27', 348, 3, 9, 739670) A lawyer or a schoolmaster who gave [up] his calling at my bidding would be still less blameworthy if, finding me a broken reed, [he] has gone back to his profession.
('27', 348, 3, 10, 739837) I should be extremely sorry to discover, however, that lawyers and schoolmasters, instead of thinking for themselves, simply did what I said, although I vehemently argued that no one should non co operate unless he was convinced of the necessity and the propriety of it.
('27', 348, 3, 11, 740108) How shall I say to a man, who conscientiously feels that it is wrong to practise before the British Law Courts or serve in British schools, that he should rejoin his profession; and how and why should I prevent those who have no conscientious scruple from rejoining it ?
('27', 348, 3, 12, 740379) I am quite aware that many pleaders were doing useful public work whilst they were practising.
('27', 348, 3, 13, 740474) The work that we are now called upon to do is, in my opinion, far superior to what we were doing before, and requires much greater sacrifice.
('27', 348, 3, 14, 740616) A mofussil pleader, who was just earning his maintenance whilst in practice, can do so now if he will qualify himself as a good weaver, and he can at the same time do public work.
('27', 348, 3, 15, 740796) I wonder if I have now made myself clear.
('27', 348, 4, 16, 740838) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI Q. AHMED, ESQ.

('27', 349, 1, 2, 741020) 306. LETTER TO K. MADHAVAN NAIR
('27', 349, 2, 3, 741052) POST ANDHERI, May 6, 1924
('27', 349, 3, 4, 741078) MY DEAR MADHAVAN NAIR, I have your letter 1 enclosing your thoughts on the Vaikom struggle.
('27', 349, 3, 5, 741170) There cannot be any question for displeasure over an honest difference of opinion.
('27', 349, 3, 6, 741253) In the midst of blind assent, which is being given to all, I say your difference of opinion comes to me as a ray of sunshine.
('27', 349, 3, 7, 741379) I congratulate you upon it, and I would ask you to adhere to your view until you are convinced to the contrary.
('27', 349, 3, 8, 741491) Now for your manuscript.
('27', 349, 3, 9, 741516) You will be surprised to learn that I have not yet read the Social Reformer 2 to which you have referred.
('27', 349, 3, 10, 741622) I always love to read Mr. Natarajan’s writings.
('27', 349, 3, 11, 741670) I have kept even a copy of that number in my file, but I have not been able to read it.
('27', 349, 3, 12, 741758) It is my misfortune that I read newspapers the least when I am editing the most.
('27', 349, 3, 13, 741839) Now let us consider the merits.
('27', 349, 3, 14, 741871) Do you know that, when Kesav Menon started the movement, he told me that the general body of the Hindus was with the movement?
('27', 349, 3, 15, 741998) Letters received by me after, from other workers, gave me the same impression.
('27', 349, 3, 16, 742077) Satyagraha is taken up by one who feels that truth is being trampled under foot.
('27', 349, 3, 17, 742158) He fights against error with only God as his support.
('27', 349, 3, 18, 742212) He is never in search for any other support.
('27', 349, 3, 19, 742257) It comes in time, and if it is legitimate, he accepts it.
('27', 349, 3, 20, 742315) A satyagrahi is pledged to fight single handed in the face of starvation and worse.
('27', 349, 3, 21, 742399) Pray read my article again, and you will probably understand my meaning more clearly than you have done.
('27', 349, 3, 22, 742504) There is no such thing as a settled fact in satyagraha.
('27', 349, 3, 23, 742560) If you find that you have erred at any stage, it is never too late to retrace your step.
('27', 349, 3, 24, 742649) If, in Travancore, public opinion is not in favour, you may not overawe the public by a demonstration from outside.
('27', 349, 3, 25, 742765) You must patiently wait and suffer.
('27', 349, 3, 26, 742801) Reduce yourselves to the position of the suppressed classes.
('27', 349, 3, 27, 742862) Live with them and suffer their humiliation.

('27', 354, 5, 11, 749654) 313. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES IV 2
('27', 354, 6, 12, 749684) ‘POLITICAL’ PRISONERS
('27', 354, 7, 13, 749706) “We do not make any distinction between political and other prisoners.
('27', 354, 7, 14, 749777) Surely you do not want any such distinction to be made in your favour?” Thus said Sir George Lloyd 3 when he visited the Yeravda Jail about the end of the last year.
('27', 354, 7, 15, 749943) He said that in reply to an inadvertent use made by me of the adjective ‘political’.
('27', 354, 7, 16, 750028) I ought to have known better.
('27', 354, 7, 17, 750058) For I was fully aware of the Governor’s distaste for that word.
('27', 354, 7, 18, 750122) And yet, strange to say, the history tickets of most of us were marked ‘political’.
('27', 354, 7, 19, 750206) When I remarked upon the anomaly, I was told by the then Superintendent that the distinction was private and was intended only for the guidance of the authorities.
('27', 354, 7, 20, 750370) We, the prisoners, were to ignore it, for we could not base any claim upon it.
('27', 354, 8, 21, 750449) I have reproduced Sir George Lloyd’s language word for word so far as I can remember.
('27', 354, 8, 22, 750535) There is a sting about what Sir George
('27', 354, 9, 23, 750574) 1 The message, given by Gandhiji before leaving the Sessions Court, Ahmedabad, on being sentenced, should be read with “Message to the Country”; vide 18 3 1922. 2 For the first three articles of this series.
('27', 354, 9, 24, 750782) 3 Governor of Bombay; for Gandhiji’s letter to him regarding prisoner classification, vide “Letter to Governor of Bombay”, 15 8 1923.
('27', 355, 0, 1, 750916) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 356
('27', 355, 1, 2, 750958) Lloyd said.
('27', 355, 1, 3, 750970) And it was so gratuitous.
('27', 355, 1, 4, 750996) For he knew that I was asking for no favours and no distinction.
('27', 355, 1, 5, 751061) Circumstances had 1 brought about a general discussion.
('27', 355, 1, 6, 751117) But the idea was to tell me, “You are no better than the rest in the eye of the law and the administration.” And yet the painful inconsistency was that the very time that the distinction was, without any occasion for it, combated in theory, it was made in practice.
('27', 355, 1, 7, 751383) Only, in the majority of Gases, it was made against the political prisoners.
('27', 355, 1, 8, 751460) As a matter of fact, it is impossible to avoid making distinctions.
('27', 355, 1, 9, 751528) If the human factor were not ignored, it would be necessary to understand a prisoner’s habits of life, and model his life accordingly in the prisons.
('27', 355, 1, 10, 751678) It is not a question of distinguishing between rich men and poor men or educated and uneducated, but between modes of life these antecedents have developed in them.
('27', 355, 1, 11, 751843) As against the inevitable recognition of the existing fact, it has been urged that the men who commit crimes should know that the law is no respecter of persons, and that it is the same to the law whether a rich man or a graduate or a labourer commits theft.
('27', 355, 1, 12, 752102) This is a perversion of a sound law.
('27', 355, 1, 13, 752139) If it is really the same to the law as it should be,each will get the treatment according to his capacity for suffering.
('27', 355, 1, 14, 752260) To give thirty stripes to a delicately built thief and as many to an able bodied one would be not impartiality but vindictiveness towards the delicate one and probably indulgence to the able bodied.
('27', 355, 1, 15, 752459) Similarly to expect, say, Pandit Motilalji 2 to sleep on a rough coirmat spread on hard floor is additional punishment, not equality of treatment.
('27', 355, 1, 16, 752606) If the human factor was introduced into the administration of the jails, the ceremony on admission would be different from what it is today.
('27', 355, 1, 17, 752747) Finger impressions would undoubtedly be taken, a record of past offences would find its place in the register.
('27', 355, 1, 18, 752858) But there will be, in addition, particulars about the prisoner’s habits and mode of life.
('27', 355, 1, 19, 752948) Not distinction but classification is perhaps the word that better describes the necessary method which the authorities, if they would treat priso ners as human beings, must recognize.
('27', 355, 1, 20, 753133) Some kind of classification there already is.
('27', 355, 1, 21, 753179) For instance, there are circles wherein prisoners are
('27', 355, 2, 22, 753233) 1 The source has “has”.
('27', 355, 2, 23, 753257) 2 Motilal Nehru (1861 1331), prominent lawyer and Swarajist leader; President, Indian National Congress, 1919 and 1928
('27', 356, 0, 1, 753376) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 357
('27', 356, 1, 2, 753420) housed in batches in long cells.
('27', 356, 1, 3, 753453) Then there are the separate single cells intended for dangerous criminals.
('27', 356, 1, 4, 753528) There are solitary cells where prisoners undergoing solitary confinement are locked.
('27', 356, 1, 5, 753613) There are, again, the condemned cells in which are locked prisoners awaiting the gallows.
('27', 356, 1, 6, 753703) Lastly, there are cells for under trial prisoners.
('27', 356, 1, 7, 753754) The reader will be surprised to find that political prisoners were mostly confined in the separate division or the solitary.
('27', 356, 1, 8, 753879) In some cases, they were confined in condemned cells.
('27', 356, 1, 9, 753933) Let me not do an injustice to the authorities.
('27', 356, 1, 10, 753980) Those who do not know these divisions and cells may form the impression that the condemned cells, for instance, must be specially bad.
('27', 356, 1, 11, 754115) Such, however, is not the case.
('27', 356, 1, 12, 754147) The cells are all well constructed and airy so far as Yeravda Jail is concerned.
('27', 356, 1, 13, 754228) What is, however, open to strong objection is the association about these cells.
('27', 356, 2, 14, 754309) The classification being, as I have shown, inevitable and in existence, there is no reason why it should not be scientific and human.
('27', 356, 2, 15, 754443) I know that revision of classification according to my suggestion means a revolution in the whole system.
('27', 356, 2, 16, 754549) It undoubtedly means more expense and a different type of men to work the new system.
('27', 356, 2, 17, 754635) But additional expense will mean economy in the long run.
('27', 356, 2, 18, 754693) The greatest advantage of the proposed revolution would no doubt be a reduction in the crimes and reformation of the prisoners.
('27', 356, 2, 19, 754821) The jails would then be reformatories representing to society sinners as its reformed and respectable members.
('27', 356, 2, 20, 754932) This may be a far off event.
('27', 356, 2, 21, 754961) If we were not under the spell of a long lived custom, we should not find it a difficult task to turn our prisons into reformatories.
('27', 356, 2, 22, 755095) Let me quote here a pregnant remark made by one of the jailors.
('27', 356, 2, 23, 755159) He once said:
('27', 356, 3, 24, 755173) When I admit search or report prisoners, I often ask myself whether I am
('27', 356, 4, 25, 755246) a better man than most of them.
('27', 356, 4, 26, 755278) God knows I have been guilty of worse crimes
('27', 356, 5, 27, 755323) than what some have come here for.
('27', 356, 5, 28, 755358) The difference is that these poor men have
('27', 356, 6, 29, 755401) been detected whereas I am not.
('27', 356, 6, 30, 755433) Is not what the good jailor confessed true of many of us?
('27', 356, 6, 31, 755491) Is it not true that there are more undetected than detected crimes?
('27', 356, 6, 32, 755559) Society does not point the finger of scorn at them.
('27', 356, 6, 33, 755611) But habit has made us look askance at those who are not smart enough to escape detection.
('27', 356, 6, 34, 755701) Imprisonment often makes them hardened criminals.
('27', 357, 0, 1, 755751) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 358
('27', 357, 1, 2, 755793) The animal treatment commences on arrest.
('27', 357, 1, 3, 755835) The accused are in theory assumed to be innocent unless they are found guilty.
('27', 357, 1, 4, 755914) In practice the demeanour of those in charge of them is one of haughtiness and contempt.
('27', 357, 1, 5, 756003) A convicted man is lost to society.
('27', 357, 1, 6, 756039) The atmosphere in the prison inures him to the position of inferiority.
('27', 357, 1, 7, 756111) The political prisoners do not as a rule succumb to this debilitating atmosphere, because they, instead of responding to the depressing atmosphere, act against it and, therefore, even refine it to a certain extent.
('27', 357, 1, 8, 756326) Society, too, refuses to regard them as criminals.
('27', 357, 1, 9, 756377) On the contrary, they become heroes and martyrs.
('27', 357, 1, 10, 756426) Their sufferings in the jail are exaggerated by the public.
('27', 357, 1, 11, 756486) And such indulgence in many cases even demoralizes the political prisoners.
('27', 357, 1, 12, 756562) But unfortunately, exactly in proportion to the indulgence of the public, is the strictness, mostly unwarranted, of the officials.
('27', 357, 1, 13, 756693) The Government regard the political prisoners as more dangerous to society than the ordinary prisoner.
('27', 357, 1, 14, 756796) An official seriously contended that a political prisoner’s crime placed the whole society in danger whereas an ordinary crime harmed only the criminal.
('27', 357, 1, 15, 756949) Another official told me that the reason why the political pri soners were isolated and denied newspapers, magazines, etc., was to bring the guilt home to them.
('27', 357, 1, 16, 757110) Political prisoners, he said, seemed to glory in ‘imprisonment’.
('27', 357, 1, 17, 757175) The deprivation of the liberty, while it afflicted the ordinary criminal, left the political prisoner unmoved.
('27', 357, 1, 18, 757286) It was, therefore, he added, but natural that the Government should devise some other method of punishment.
('27', 357, 1, 19, 757394) hence, he said, the denial of facilities which otherwise such prisoners should undoubtedly have.

('27', 357, 1, 21, 757661) Let the reader not regard this deprivation as a light penalty for those who regard the newspaper as a necessity in no way inferior to breakfast.

('27', 358, 0, 1, 758138) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 359
('27', 358, 1, 2, 758182) no light thing to be in the company of those who never speak but to utter foul language or whose conversation is as a rule indecent.
('27', 358, 1, 3, 758315) I could understand political prisoners being put in such surroundings, if the Government sanely took them in their confidence and used them to exercise a wholesome influence on the ordinary criminal.
('27', 358, 1, 4, 758515) This however is, I admit, not a practical proposition.

('27', 358, 5, 17, 759318) She was a true friend and helpmate to her illustrious husband in his lifetime.
('27', 358, 5, 18, 759397) After his death she chose as her life work one of her husband’s activities.

('27', 358, 5, 21, 759625) She concentrated her whole energy upon it.
('27', 358, 5, 22, 759668) The result is that the Sevasadan has become an institutionwithout a second of its kind throughout all India.
('27', 358, 5, 23, 759777) It educates nearly one thousand girls and women.
('27', 358, 5, 24, 759826) Maddock 3 told me that it was his hospital that turned out the best and the largest number of Indian nurses.
('27', 358, 5, 25, 759935) All these sisters

('27', 368, 1, 2, 780898) 317. IS IT NON CO OPERATION?
('27', 368, 2, 3, 780927) The argument has been advanced that with the failure (in my opinion wrongly assumed) of the boycott of titles, schools, law courts, and Councils, Non co operation is dead.
('27', 368, 2, 4, 781099) The critics see nothing of Non co operation in the slow and unexciting khaddar programme.
('27', 368, 2, 5, 781189) They forget that the fourfold boycott is like a scaffolding which is absolutely necessary till the whole structure is ready.
('27', 368, 2, 6, 781314) It does not matter that the institutions, which are the symbols of the authority we seek to destroy, continue to exist so long as we do not make use of them.
('27', 368, 2, 7, 781472) The fact is that we cannot erect our structure without the scaffolding of the fourfold boycott.
('27', 368, 2, 8, 781568) And we must succeed if we can work the Congress organization without the aid of these institutions and even in spite of them.
('27', 368, 2, 9, 781694) Moreover, let us not forget that our boycott is not fourfold, but fivefold.
('27', 368, 2, 10, 781770) The fifth is by far the most important, i.e., boycott of foreign (not merely British) cloth.
('27', 368, 2, 11, 781863) The boycott is the negative, though on that account none the less useful, part of our programme.
('27', 368, 2, 12, 781960) Khaddar, national schools, panchayats, Hindu Muslim unity, and uplift of the untouchable, the drunkard and the opium eater, are the positive part of our programme.
('27', 368, 2, 13, 782124) The greater our progress in it, the greater will be the progress towards the boycott and, therefore, towards swaraj.
('27', 368, 2, 14, 782241) Nature abhors a vacuum.
('27', 368, 2, 15, 782265) Therefore, construction must keep pace with destruction.
('27', 368, 2, 16, 782322) Even if all the titled friends gave up their titles, and if schools, courts and Councils were entirely deserted, and being thus embarrassed the Government abdicated in our favour, and if we had no constructive work to our credit, we could not conduct swaraj.
('27', 368, 2, 17, 782581) We should be entirely helpless.
('27', 368, 2, 18, 782613) I often wonder whether it is sufficiently realized that our movement is not one for mere change of personnel but for change of the system and the methods.
('27', 368, 2, 19, 782768) Full khaddar programme is, therefore, to me full swaraj.
('27', 368, 2, 20, 782825) The English interest in India is selfish and in conflict with the national interest.
('27', 368, 2, 21, 782910) It is anti national, because of the illegitimate cotton interest.
('27', 368, 2, 22, 782976) To boycott, therefore, foreign cloth is to sterilize the English and all other foreign interests.
('27', 368, 2, 23, 783074) Boycott merely of British cloth may harm the British, but can lead to no construction in India.
('27', 368, 2, 24, 783170) Boycott of British cloth will be a
('27', 369, 0, 1, 783205) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 370
('27', 369, 1, 2, 783247) jump out of frying pan into fire.
('27', 369, 1, 3, 783281) Not before the foreign piece goods trade is entirely replaced by homespun will the bleeding process cease.
('27', 369, 1, 4, 783388) Boycott of foreign cloth, therefore, is the centre of our boycott programme.
('27', 369, 1, 5, 783465) The central boycott cannot succeed until we universalize khaddar.
('27', 369, 1, 6, 783531) In order to achieve the desirable end, we will need to employ all our resources to the fullest extent.
('27', 369, 1, 7, 783634) We shall need men, money and machinery, i.e., organization.
('27', 369, 1, 8, 783694) We cannot universalize khaddar without Hindu Muslim unity, without removing untouchability.
('27', 369, 1, 9, 783786) To make khaddar successful is to demonstrate our capacity forself government.
('27', 369, 1, 10, 783864) Khaddar is a people’s programme, for success in which all, high and low, rich and poor, Hindu and non Hindu must take part.
('27', 369, 1, 11, 783988) But say the sceptics, ‘How can khaddar bring swaraj?
('27', 369, 1, 12, 784041) Will Englishmen then retire in our favour?’ My answer is—yes and no.
('27', 369, 1, 13, 784110) Yes, because Englishmen will then find that their interest must be coincident with that of India.
('27', 369, 1, 14, 784208) They will then be content to remain in India as her servants, for they will have then found that they cannot impose their custom upon us.
('27', 369, 1, 15, 784346) When, therefore, khaddar becomes successful, Englishmen’s hearts will have been changed.
('27', 369, 1, 16, 784435) They will regard it, then, as an honour to be our allies instead of regarding it, as they do now, their right to be our masters.
('27', 369, 1, 17, 784564) My answer is no, if we intend to drive out Englishmen and ruin every English interest, legiti mate or otherwise.
('27', 369, 1, 18, 784677) Such is not the goal of the non violent movement.
('27', 369, 1, 19, 784727) Non violence has its limits.
('27', 369, 1, 20, 784756) It refuses to hate or generate hatred.
('27', 369, 1, 21, 784795) Indeed, by its very nature, it is incapable of so doing.
('27', 369, 1, 22, 784852) ‘But’ the scep tics further argue, ‘suppose the English refuse to revise their system and insist upon holding India by the sword, what can universal use of khaddar do?’ In thus doubting the efficacy of khaddar, they forget that khaddar is an indispensable preparation for civil diso bedience.
('27', 369, 1, 23, 785145) And this, everyone admits, is an irresistible force.
('27', 369, 1, 24, 785198) Without the univer sal adoption of khaddar, I see no chance whatsoever of universal civil, i.e., non violent, disobedience.
('27', 369, 1, 25, 785322) Any single district that can be fully organized for khaddar is, if it is also trained for suffering, ready for civil disobedience.
('27', 369, 1, 26, 785453) And I have not a shadow of doubt that even one district thus organized can make itself irresistible even though the whole might of the Government may be matched against it.
('27', 369, 1, 27, 785626) ‘Who shall bell the cat?’ is the last question.
('27', 369, 1, 28, 785674) That question is, however, irrelevant to the present inquiry.
('27', 369, 1, 29, 785736) The question I set out to
('27', 370, 0, 1, 785762) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 371
('27', 370, 1, 2, 785806) answer was whether constructive programme, i.e., khaddar, could be considered part of Non co operation.
('27', 370, 1, 3, 785910) I have attempted to prove that it is an integral part of Non co operation in its positive aspect.

('27', 370, 3, 5, 786030) 318. NOTE ON BHAGWANDAS’S LETTER
('27', 370, 4, 6, 786063) I gladly publish Babu Bhagwandas’s 1 letter 2. The Congress scheme of swaraj can only be formulated when the Congress is ready to take swaraj.
('27', 370, 4, 7, 786206) What it will do then, one can say now.
('27', 370, 4, 8, 786245) But I have promised Babu Bhagwandas that I would certainly publish my own scheme.
('27', 370, 4, 9, 786327) I am aware that all sorts of ideas are entertained about my conception of swaraj.
('27', 370, 4, 10, 786409) I simply ask for breathing time.
('27', 370, 4, 11, 786442) Meanwhile, I assure our respected countrymen that I have absolutely no design on capitalists.
('27', 370, 4, 12, 786536) I can have none as I don’t believe in violence.
('27', 370, 4, 13, 786584) But I do want cleanliness in capitalism as well as in labour.
('27', 370, 4, 14, 786646) And I would certainly resist capitalism being used to exploit the resources of the country for the use of the few, be they foreigners or home born.
('27', 370, 4, 15, 786794) But let me not anticipate my scheme.

('27', 375, 5, 13, 794411) 326. IMPATIENT KATHIAWAR
('27', 375, 6, 14, 794436) Friends tell me that the views which I expressed about the Kathiawar Political Conference 1 have caused some resentment.
('27', 375, 6, 15, 794557) Since I took up the editorship of the three journals 2, I have almost stopped reading newspapers.
('27', 375, 6, 16, 794655) But friends look after me and keep me informed about what I ought to know.
('27', 375, 7, 17, 794730) I have also heard it said: “That self exiled Gandhi succumbed to the wiles of Pattani Saheb 3 and brought to nothing the awakening in Kathiawar.
('27', 375, 7, 18, 794875) It is not surprising that Pattani Saheb who has risenthrough scheming and diplomacy, should have tricked a half naked tramp mixing with Bhangis and weavers.” As I have given elsewhere in this issue the substance of a letter from Abbas Saheb 4, so this also is the substance of what people say.
('27', 375, 7, 19, 795169) No one has reported these actual words to me.
('27', 375, 7, 20, 795215) But readers may trust that I have given correctly the substance of what has come to my ears.
('27', 375, 7, 21, 795308) Kathiawaris living in Bombay say,
('27', 375, 8, 22, 795342) 1 This was to be held at Bhavnagar in January 1925. 2 Navajivan in Gujarati and Hindi, and Young India

('27', 376, 1, 2, 795663) “Gandhi has brought us ruin.”
('27', 376, 2, 3, 795693) The truth is this: Pattani Saheb is not so full of knavery as is imagined.
('27', 376, 2, 4, 795768) To defeat a satyagrahi by trickery, even a shrewd Kathiawari like Pattani Saheb will have to wait till he is born again as a satyagrahi.
('27', 376, 2, 5, 795905) There is no word like “defeat” in the vocabulary of a satyagrahi.
('27', 376, 2, 6, 795971) One satyagrahi, it can be stated, may defeat another, but this is doing violence to the meaning of the word “defeat”.
('27', 376, 2, 7, 796089) A satyagrahi gives in when he sees his mistake and rises higher as a result.
('27', 376, 2, 8, 796166) This cannot be called defeat.
('27', 376, 3, 9, 796196) I am convinced that the part played by Pattani Saheb in my presence regarding the decision about the Conference was such as enhances his own and Kathiawar’s prestige.
('27', 376, 3, 10, 796363) There was no need for him to employ diplomacy.
('27', 376, 3, 11, 796410) I stated the reasons which weighed with me and I am aware of no other reason besides these.
('27', 376, 4, 12, 796502) I know that I would be of no further service when, yielding to somebody’s influence or my love for him, I deviate from the path of truth.
('27', 376, 4, 13, 796640) I dislike suicide and am not likely, therefore, to commit the folly of deviating from that path.
('27', 376, 5, 14, 796737) A satyagrahi’s objective must be absolutely pure.
('27', 376, 5, 15, 796787) There was certainly some impropriety in recommending that the Bhavnagar Conference should be held in Porbandar.
('27', 376, 5, 16, 796899) I am using the mildest term to describe what happened.
('27', 376, 5, 17, 796954) It is an unalterable rule for a satyagrahi that his case must be unsullied—like milk in its whiteness.
('27', 376, 5, 18, 797057) Just as even a speck of dirt renders milk unfit for use, so even a slight flaw in a case makes it unworthy of a satyagrahi.
('27', 376, 5, 19, 797181) I, therefore, do not need to use a stronger term than “impropriety”.
('27', 376, 6, 20, 797250) The second reason is equally sound.
('27', 376, 6, 21, 797286) I did not know that the organizers had decided to hold the Conference even subject to conditions.
('27', 376, 6, 22, 797384) I have often made it clear that I am against agreeing to conditions.
('27', 376, 6, 23, 797453) That in certain circumstances it may be necessary to accept conditions is beside the point.
('27', 376, 6, 24, 797545) Once the principle of conditions has been accepted, the matter no longer remains within the scope of satyagraha.
('27', 376, 6, 25, 797658) If the Conference is to be held on certain conditions, then why not agree as well to hold it in Songadh?
('27', 376, 6, 26, 797763) The reason for accepting conditions was that in the present circumstances there was no other way of creating an awakening among the people.
('27', 377, 0, 1, 797903) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 378
('27', 377, 1, 2, 797945) motive is not irrelevant or unworthy.
('27', 377, 1, 3, 797983) The purpose would have been the same even if it had been decided to hold the Conference at some other place.
('27', 377, 1, 4, 798092) It is by no means as certain that, if we resorted to satyagraha, we would be able to hold the Conference.
('27', 377, 1, 5, 798198) A satyagrahi fights unto death.
('27', 377, 1, 6, 798230) If he dies fighting, then, according to the philosophy of satyagraha, he will have won.
('27', 377, 1, 7, 798318) The satyagrahis did their duty when they went to jail.
('27', 377, 1, 8, 798373) But the Conference has not yet been held.
('27', 377, 1, 9, 798415) The aim just now is to hold the Conference somehow.
('27', 377, 1, 10, 798467) “We wish to hold the Conference if we can do so on our terms, not otherwise”— this is the satyagrahi’s attitude.
('27', 377, 1, 11, 798580) “We wish to hold the Conference somehow”—this cannot be the satyagrahi’s way.
('27', 377, 1, 12, 798658) The people are not preparing themselves for satyagraha to accept whatever kind of swaraj the Government may offer.
('27', 377, 1, 13, 798773) They are cultivating this irresistible strength in order to win the kind of swaraj they want.
('27', 377, 1, 14, 798867) It is only when Kathiawar decides to hold the Conference without agreeing to any conditions that it will be faced with the duty of offering satyagraha.
('27', 377, 1, 15, 799019) It is not the duty of a satyagrahi to insist on holding a Conference which is subject to conditions.
('27', 377, 1, 16, 799120) To do so would be to exchange a copper piece for a cowrie.
('27', 377, 2, 17, 799179) This does not mean that, if there are no conditions, the satyagrahi is free to indulge in abuse.
('27', 377, 2, 18, 799276) How can anyone who forsakes humility and civility be called a satyagrahi?
('27', 377, 2, 19, 799350) It is because he can restrain himself that he declines to let another restrain him.
('27', 377, 2, 20, 799434) But his self imposed limits are the strictest possible.
('27', 377, 3, 21, 799490) If the Conference does its work this year with perfect civility and compels admiration even from its opponents, but is even then required next year to submit to conditions or has to face similar obstacles, then the satyagrahis’ case will be clear and strong and no one will have any ground to criticize them.

('27', 396, 2, 3, 838505) JUHU, Vaisakha Sud 9 [May 13, 1924] 1
('27', 396, 3, 4, 838543) BHAISHRI GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your letter.
('27', 396, 3, 5, 838586) I am quite sure an attitude of tolerance towards opposition by members of your community will bear fruit in the end.
('27', 396, 3, 6, 838703) All of us have both divine and dark forces working within us.
('27', 396, 3, 7, 838765) Some amount of agitation is, therefore, bound to persist.
('27', 396, 3, 8, 838823) But we need not be afraid of it.
('27', 396, 3, 9, 838856) The dark forces can be overcome by sustained effort to control them, but we must be fully convinced in our heart that it is our duty to help the forces of light.
('27', 396, 3, 10, 839018) I am anxious about your father and brother.
('27', 396, 3, 11, 839062) If they are thinking of organizing those in your favour and fighting it out and if you cannot persuade them to keep to the path of peace, there will he the danger of people in your own family adopting two opposite courses.
('27', 396, 3, 12, 839285) At such a time, one is in a fix what to do.
('27', 396, 3, 13, 839329) I would beg your father and brother, too, not to be responsible for creating two hostile camps in your community.
('27', 396, 3, 14, 839443) I would certainly not consider it proper for you to apologize for what you did because you thought it right to do and about the worthiness of which even today you have no doubt.
('27', 396, 3, 15, 839621) I have received Rs. 5,000 sent on your behalf.
('27', 396, 3, 16, 839668) You can send whatever amount you consider proper for Young India and Navajivan.
('27', 396, 3, 17, 839748) About fifty copies are to be given free.
('27', 396, 4, 18, 839789) Yours sincerely,

('27', 397, 8, 8, 840257) 334. MESSAGE TO “ ANTYAJA” CONFERENCE, BORSAD 3
('27', 397, 9, 9, 840305) May 14, 1924 The problem of untouchability is becoming more and more important day by day, and this is but right.
('27', 397, 9, 10, 840419) You and I both know that we have not taken up work among Antyajas in order to make political capital out of it.
('27', 397, 9, 11, 840531) The eradication of untouchability is primarily a religious problem, though it is also true that it holds the key to swaraj.
('27', 397, 9, 12, 840655) I am getting more and more convinced every day that Hinduism cannot survive if it clings to the practice of untouchability.
('27', 397, 9, 13, 840779) By trying to abolish it, we purify ourselves and not the untouchables.
('27', 397, 9, 14, 840850) In doing our duty in this matter, I would leave out the consideration of self interest, namely, its importance for swaraj.
('27', 397, 9, 15, 840973) True, I have had a hand in getting it included in the Congress programme; I did so, however, with no political motive but from a purely religious point of view.
('27', 397, 9, 16, 841134) It was included in the Congress programme in order to impress on the minds of the people the simple truth that, without its abolition, swaraj cannot be won.
('27', 397, 9, 17, 841291) Even if, however, we could get swaraj today, we would still have this problem with us.
('27', 397, 9, 18, 841378) If anyone promised to give us swaraj on condition that I gave up working for the abolition of untouchability, I would reply without a moment’s hesitation that I did not want such swaraj.
('27', 397, 9, 19, 841565) To let the people cling to this practice means, for me, renouncing my Hinduism.
('27', 397, 9, 20, 841645) Though physically I shall be at Juhu at the time of the Conference, you may rest assured that in spirit

('27', 399, 7, 16, 844293) 338. NOTES
('27', 399, 8, 17, 844304) FREE TRADE V. PROTECTION
('27', 399, 9, 18, 844329) Apropos of the contemplated protection for Tata Steel Works, I have been asked to state my own views on protection.
('27', 399, 9, 19, 844445) Of what use they can possibly be, at the present moment, I do not know; nor do I know the merits of the proposal regarding the Steel Works.
('27', 399, 9, 20, 844585) But I take the opportunity of dispelling the illusion that I am inimical to capital and that I would destroy machinery and its products if I had the power.
('27', 399, 9, 21, 844741) The fact is that I am a confirmed protectionist.
('27', 399, 9, 22, 844790) Free trade may be good for England which dumps down her manufactures among
('27', 399, 10, 23, 844865) 1 The postmark carries this date.
('27', 399, 10, 24, 844899) 2 In a figurative sense
('27', 400, 0, 1, 844923) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 401
('27', 400, 1, 2, 844967) helpless people and wishes her wants to be supplied from outside at the cheapest rate.
('27', 400, 1, 3, 845054) But free trade has ruined India’s peasantry in that it has all but destroyed her cottage industry.
('27', 400, 1, 4, 845153) Moreover, no new trade can compete with foreign trade without protection.
('27', 400, 1, 5, 845227) Natal nursed her sugar industry by both bounty and import duty.
('27', 400, 1, 6, 845291) Germany developed beet sugar by a system of bounties.
('27', 400, 1, 7, 845345) I would any day welcome protection for mill industry, although I give and would always give preference to hand spun khaddar.
('27', 400, 1, 8, 845470) Indeed, I would give protection to all useful industries.
('27', 400, 1, 9, 845528) Much of my opposition to the Government would abate if I found that it was truly solicitous for India’s economic and moral welfare.
('27', 400, 1, 10, 845660) Let the Government protect the cloth industry to the point of prohibition of all foreign cloth, let it popularize the charkha by making all its purchases of cloth in khaddar, let it abolish without regard to revenue the drink and the drug traffic, and cut down the army expenditure to the extent of the loss of that revenue.
('27', 400, 1, 11, 845985) When such a happy event takes place, my opposition will lose its point.
('27', 400, 1, 12, 846057) It will pave the way for a real discussion of Reforms.
('27', 400, 1, 13, 846112) To me the two steps will be a striking sign of change of heart which must precede any honourable settlement.
('27', 400, 2, 14, 846221) A FULL STOP
('27', 400, 3, 15, 846233) I have received several ably argued letters on Maulana Mohamed Ali’s 1 comparison between the creed of a Mussalman and that of a Hindu.
('27', 400, 3, 16, 846369) For 2, in spite of my correspondents, I must adhere to the proposition that the Maulana has done nothing more than comparing the two creeds and preferring his own to mine.
('27', 400, 3, 17, 846541) Able, instructive and interesting though some of the letters before me are, I must resist the temptation of publishing them.
('27', 400, 3, 18, 846666) The country has much more important work before it than following a clever theological or even philosophical discussion.
('27', 400, 3, 19, 846787) The only reason for my devoting the space of Young India to a defence of the Maulana Sahib’s position was, if possible, to avoid an unnecessary increase in the prevailing bitterness between Hindus and Mussalman.
('27', 400, 3, 20, 846999) 3 I would not have cared,
('27', 400, 4, 21, 847025) 1 1871 1931; journalist and politician; led the Khilafat delegation to England in 1920; President, Indian National Congress, at Cocanada, 1923 2 Presumbly, a slip for ‘But’.

('27', 401, 1, 2, 847280) merely out of regard for a friend, to devote the space of a public journal to a defence of the Maulana.

('27', 401, 1, 4, 847470) And I do not share the opinion expressed by one of the correspondents that the Maulana has betrayed ill will against Hindus and that there is no chance now of Hindu Muslim union.
('27', 401, 1, 5, 847649) That union is coming in spite of the present ferment and in spite of us all.

('27', 401, 2, 14, 848271) LEARNING URDU AND SPINNING Mr. George Joseph writes from Trivandrum Central Jail:

('27', 404, 8, 9, 854176) BOMBAY I gladly publish the foregoing.
('27', 404, 8, 10, 854215) I do not propose to worry Mr. Majli in his present state of health.
('27', 404, 8, 11, 854283) Nor, as I said in my note, did I wish to make the treatment a matter of complaint.
('27', 404, 8, 12, 854366) But I must say that on two points at least Mr. Majli is substantially correct.
('27', 404, 8, 13, 854445) Mr. Majli does not deny that he was given ‘twist spinning’.
('27', 404, 8, 14, 854505) But ‘twist spinning’ means ‘twisting yarn’.
('27', 404, 8, 15, 854549) Perhaps the acting Director of Information does not know that there is no process known as ‘twist spinning’.
('27', 404, 8, 16, 854658) You spin or twist yarn on the wheel.
('27', 404, 8, 17, 854695) Mr. Majli wanted spinning which was a matter of duty and pleasure with him.
('27', 404, 8, 18, 854771) But he was given twisting which was no matter of pleasure and which was much harder than spinning.
('27', 404, 8, 19, 854870) That he was locked up is also evidently true.
('27', 404, 8, 20, 854916) That there were two companions with him does not alter the fact of the lock up.
('27', 404, 8, 21, 854996) Only a prisoner knows what lock up, especially in the day time, means, whether with or without company.

('27', 411, 1, 2, 869520) 339. EMPIRE GOODS BOYCOTT
('27', 411, 2, 3, 869546) It is curious how the question of the Empire goods boycott continues to challenge public attention from time to time.
('27', 411, 2, 4, 869664) From the standpoint of non violent non co operation, it seems to me to be wholly indefensible.
('27', 411, 2, 5, 869759) It is retaliation pure and simple and, as such, punitive.
('27', 411, 2, 6, 869817) So long, therefore, as the Congress holds to non violent non co operation, so long must boycott of British, as distinguished from other foreign goods, be ruled out.
('27', 411, 2, 7, 869982) And if I am the only Congressman holding the view, I must move a resolution at the next Congress repealing the resolution in the matter carried at the last Special Session.
('27', 411, 2, 8, 870155) But, for the moment, I propose to discuss not the ethics but the utility of the retaliatory boycott.
('27', 411, 2, 9, 870256) The knowledge that even the Liberals joined the Boycott campaign cannot make one shrink from the inquiry.
('27', 411, 2, 10, 870362) On the contrary, if they come to believe with me that the retaliatory boycott that they and the Congress took up was not only ineffective, but was one more demonstration of our impotent rage and waste of precious energy, I would appeal to them to take up with zeal and determination the boycott of all foreign cloth and replacing same not with Indian mill cloth but with hand spun khaddar.
('27', 411, 2, 11, 870752) I have had the pleasure of reading the report of the Boycott Committee.
('27', 411, 2, 12, 870824) It must be, has remained, the last word on the utmost that can be done in the shape of boycott of British or Empire goods.
('27', 411, 2, 13, 870947) The Report, in my opinion, presents a formidable case, not for but against such boycott.
('27', 411, 2, 14, 871036) It frankly states that the bulk of the Empire goods, such, for instance, as railway material, is imported by the Government or English firms; that the trifles such as scents, soaps, boots imported are mostly consumed by those easy going, luxury loving Indians who are never likely to take to the boycott.
('27', 411, 2, 15, 871341) It will be found on a calm consideration of the figures that even if the boycott of the trifles was scrupulously carried out by every Congress man and every Liberal, the amount would not be, at the outside, more than one crore of rupees per year.
('27', 411, 2, 16, 871588) He must be a brave optimist who could believe that the Kenya Englishman or English men in general, would be made to change their policy by reason of such boycott.
('27', 412, 0, 1, 871751) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 413
('27', 412, 1, 2, 871795) ‘But,’ says the critic, ‘see what a flutter was created in Cheap side when the Empire goods boycott resolution of the Bombay Municipal Corporation was cabled free of charge by Reuter.’ Surely we know enough of the British trade methods not to be unduly elated by such flutters.
('27', 412, 1, 3, 872073) They are often put on in order to inflame the gullible public against ‘the unscrupulous Indian agitators who are bent upon injuring England’.
('27', 412, 1, 4, 872215) When the excitement is not put on, it is a symptom of the British mercantile sensitiveness to every commercial fluctuation or movement.
('27', 412, 1, 5, 872351) It is by such sensitiveness that it ever remains prepared for emergencies of every conceivable type.
('27', 412, 1, 6, 872452) I would ask the public, therefore, never to rely upon the excitements or approbations from England, or, for that matter, from any foreign State.
('27', 412, 1, 7, 872597) Their fear or praise of our action can never secure us in our position if our action which is either feared or praised is not, in itself, substantially effective.
('27', 412, 1, 8, 872760) If our rage did not blind us, we should be ashamed of the boycott resolution when we realized that we depended upon British goods for some of our national requirements.
('27', 412, 1, 9, 872929) When we may not do without English books and English medicines, should we boycott English watches because we can procure Geneva watches?
('27', 412, 1, 10, 873066) And if we will not do without English books because we need them, how shall we expect the importer of British watches or perfumes to sacrifice his trade?
('27', 412, 1, 11, 873220) My very efficient English nurse, whom I loved to call ‘tyrant’ because she insisted in all loving ways on my taking more food and more sleep than I did, with a smile curling round her lips and insidious twinkle in her eyes, gently remarked after I was safely removed to a private ward, escorted by the house surgeon and herself: “As I was shading you with my umbrella I could not help smiling that you, a fierce boycotter of everything British, probably owed your life to the skill of a British surgeon, handling British surgical instruments, administering British drugs, at d to the ministrations of a British nurse.

('27', 413, 1, 2, 874340) the dumping down of foreign cloth in India has reduced millions of mypeople to pauperism.” I was even able to interest her in the khaddar movement.
('27', 413, 1, 3, 874488) Probably she became a convert to it.

('27', 413, 3, 12, 875490) 340. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES V
('27', 413, 4, 13, 875517) POSSIBILITIES OF REFORM
('27', 413, 5, 14, 875541) It has been my invariable experience that good evokes good, evil—evil; and that therefore, if the evil does not receive the corresponding response, it ceases to act, dies of want of nutrition.
('27', 413, 5, 15, 875734) Evil can only live upon itself.
('27', 413, 5, 16, 875766) Sages of old, knowing this law, instead of returning evil for evil, deliberately returned good for evil and killed it.
('27', 413, 5, 17, 875885) Evil lives nevertheless, because many have not taken advantage of the discovery, though the law underlying it acts with scientific precision.
('27', 413, 5, 18, 876027) We arc too lazy to work out in terms of the law the problems that face us and, therefore, fancy that we are too weak to act up to it.
('27', 413, 5, 19, 876161) The fact is, that the moment the truth of the law is realized, nothing is so easy as to return good for evil.
('27', 413, 5, 20, 876271) It is the one quality that distinguishes man from the brute.
('27', 413, 5, 21, 876332) It is man’s natural law not to retaliate.
('27', 413, 5, 22, 876374) Though we have the human form, we are not truly human till we have fully
('27', 414, 0, 1, 876447) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 415
('27', 414, 1, 2, 876491) realized the truth of the law and acted up to it.
('27', 414, 1, 3, 876541) The law admits of no escape.
('27', 414, 2, 4, 876570) I cannot recall a single instance in which it has not answered.
('27', 414, 2, 5, 876634) Utter strangers have within my experience irresistibly responded to it.
('27', 414, 2, 6, 876706) In all the South African jails through which I passed, the officials who were at first most unfriendly to me became uniformly friendly because I did not retaliate.
('27', 414, 2, 7, 876870) I answered their bitterness with sweetness.
('27', 414, 2, 8, 876914) This does not mean that I did not fight injustice.
('27', 414, 2, 9, 876965) On the contrary, my South African jail experiences were a continuous fight against it, and in most cases it was successful.
('27', 414, 2, 10, 877089) The longer Indian experience has but emphasized the truth and the beauty of non violent conduct.
('27', 414, 2, 11, 877186) It was the easiest thing for me to acerbate the authorities at Yeravda.
('27', 414, 2, 12, 877258) For instance, I could have answered the Superintendent in his own coin when he made the insulting remarks described in my letter to Hakim Saheb.
('27', 414, 2, 13, 877403) 1 I would have in that case lowered myself in my own estimation and confirmed the Superintendent in his suspicion that I was a cantankerous and mischievous politician.
('27', 414, 2, 14, 877571) But the experiences related in that letter were trivialities compared to what was to follow.
('27', 414, 2, 15, 877664) Let me recall a few of them.
('27', 414, 3, 16, 877693) A European warder I knew suspected me.
('27', 414, 3, 17, 877732) He thought it was his business to suspect every prisoner.
('27', 414, 3, 18, 877790) As I did not want to do any the slightest thing without the knowledge of the Superintendent, I had told him that, if a prisoner passing by salaamed, I would return the salaam and that I was giving to the convict warder in charge of me all the food that I could not eat.
('27', 414, 3, 19, 878060) The European warder knew nothing of the conversation with the Superintendent.
('27', 414, 3, 20, 878138) He once saw a prisoner salaam me.
('27', 414, 3, 21, 878172) I returned the salaam.
('27', 414, 3, 22, 878195) He saw us both in the act, but only took from the prisoner his ticket.
('27', 414, 3, 23, 878266) It meant that the poor man would be reported.
('27', 414, 3, 24, 878312) I at once told the warder to report me too, as I was equally guilty with the poor man.
('27', 414, 3, 25, 878399) He simply told me he had to do his duty.
('27', 414, 3, 26, 878440) Instead of reporting the warder for his officiousness, but in order to protect a fellow prisoner, I merely mentioned to the Superintendent the incident of salaaming without the conversation I had with the warder.
('27', 414, 3, 27, 878653) The latter recognized that I meant no ill whatsoever to him, and from that time forward ceased to suspect me.
('27', 414, 3, 28, 878763) On the contrary, he

('27', 415, 1, 2, 878873) became very friendly.
('27', 415, 2, 3, 878895) I was subject to search like the other prisoners.
('27', 415, 2, 4, 878945) I never objected.
('27', 415, 2, 5, 878963) And so, daily before the lock up, a regular search took place for many months.

('27', 415, 2, 15, 879568) This happened a fairly long time after my admission to Yeravda.
('27', 415, 2, 16, 879632) The Superintendent was, therefore, likely to take severe notice of the jailor’s conduct if I reported him.

('27', 415, 2, 18, 879766) I felt that I must pocket these personal rudenesses.
('27', 415, 2, 19, 879819) If I reported him, the jailor was likely to lose his job.

('27', 415, 2, 22, 880074) He took my conversation in good part and felt grateful.

('27', 415, 3, 27, 880506) The first hunger strike was that of the Sikh life sentence prisoners..
('27', 415, 3, 28, 880577) They would not eat food without the restoration of their sacred loin cloth and without the permission to them to cook their own food.

('27', 415, 3, 31, 880832) It was a question of prestige and jail discipline.

('27', 416, 1, 2, 881241) prisoners the painful, prolonged fast But, I was told, if I could not see them, I could send them ‘wireless messages’!
('27', 416, 1, 3, 881360) I must explain this special expression.
('27', 416, 1, 4, 881400) Wireless messages in prison parlance means unauthorized messages sent by one prisoner to another with or without the knowledge of the officials.
('27', 416, 1, 5, 881545) Every official knows and must connive at such interchange of messages.
('27', 416, 1, 6, 881616) Experience has shown them that it is impossible to guard against or to detect such breaches of prison regulations.
('27', 416, 1, 7, 881731) I may say that I was scrupulously exact about such messages.
('27', 416, 1, 8, 881792) I cannot recall a single occasion when I sent a ‘wireless’ for my own purpose.
('27', 416, 1, 9, 881871) In every case it was in the interest of prison discipline.
('27', 416, 1, 10, 881930) The result was, I think, that the officials had ceased to distrust me and, if they had it in their power, they would have availed themselves of my offer of intervention in such cases.
('27', 416, 1, 11, 882114) But the superior authority, so jealous of its prestige, would not hear of it.
('27', 416, 2, 12, 882192) In the above instance, I did set in motion the wireless apparatus, but it was hardly effective.
('27', 416, 2, 13, 882288) The fast was broken after many days, but I am unable to say whether it was at all due to my messages.
('27', 416, 3, 14, 882390) This was the first occasion when I felt that I should intervene in the interest of humanity.
('27', 416, 4, 15, 882483) The next occasion was when certain Mulshi Peta prisoners were flogged for short task.
('27', 416, 4, 16, 882569) 1 I need not go into the painful story at length.
('27', 416, 4, 17, 882619) Some of these prisoners were youngsters.
('27', 416, 4, 18, 882660) It is likely that they had wilfully done much less task than they could have.
('27', 416, 4, 19, 882738) They were put on grinding.
('27', 416, 4, 20, 882765) Somehow or other these prisoners were not classed political as the swaraj prisoners were.
('27', 416, 4, 21, 882855) Whatever the cause, they were mostly given grinding as their task.
('27', 416, 4, 22, 882922) Grinding has an unnecessary bad odour about it.
('27', 416, 4, 23, 882970) I am aware that all labour is irksome when it has to be done as a task and under supervision not always gentle.
('27', 416, 4, 24, 883082) But a prisoner who courts imprisonment for conscience sake should look upon his task as a matter of pride and pleasure.

('27', 417, 2, 18, 884437) In spite of his sterling good nature, love of justice and even partiality for prisoners as against officials, he was hasty in action.

('27', 419, 2, 3, 888122) May 15, 1924
('27', 419, 3, 4, 888135) I have still not forgotten what you told me about your first fruitful meeting with the robbers.
('27', 419, 3, 5, 888231) Today, you have advanced far beyond that.
('27', 419, 3, 6, 888273) You have bound the Dharala brothers and sisters to you with bonds of love.

('27', 419, 4, 8, 888518) I am certain that a community which throws up robbers and wicked men has only itself to blame.
('27', 419, 4, 9, 888613) It is not as if robbers like being what they are.
('27', 419, 4, 10, 888663) They take to robbing under pressure of circumstances.
('27', 419, 4, 11, 888717) A robber becomes confirmed in his ways when the community punishes him and in this way the disease spreads.
('27', 419, 4, 12, 888825) If we cultivate friendly relations with robbers and others like them, they realize their error and reform themselves.
('27', 419, 5, 13, 888943) You are engaged in this invaluable work.
('27', 419, 5, 14, 888984) I know that all Dharalas are not robbers.
('27', 419, 5, 15, 889026) Many of them are upright men, but, in our ignorance, we have kept them away from us.
('27', 419, 5, 16, 889111) I regard your work as of supreme importance.
('27', 419, 5, 17, 889156) One may say that it holds the key to India’s regeneration.
('27', 419, 6, 18, 889215) Let your love not become blind.
('27', 419, 6, 19, 889247) Persuade the Dharala brothers and sisters to take up some [honest] work.
('27', 419, 6, 20, 889320) I am sure you are exerting yourself to see that they wear khadi woven by themselves from yarn which they themselves have spun, that they give up drinking and addiction to opium and other vices, that their children get education and the grown ups learn bhajans 2 and kirtans 3; even so, you should work harder still.

('27', 426, 1, 2, 898853) 350. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('27', 426, 2, 3, 898883) BOMBAY, Saturday, May 17, 1924
('27', 426, 3, 4, 898914) Our representative asked: Are you in a position to make any statement about
('27', 426, 4, 5, 898990) your discussions with the deputation that has come to you from Vykom?
('27', 426, 5, 6, 899060) Mahatmaji replied in slow accents: I think that our discussions are now practically closed and I am satisfied that the movement has been carried on by the organizers in an orderly and non violent manner.
('27', 426, 5, 7, 899264) The steadiness with which they have conducted it has drawn the attention of the whole of the Indian public.
('27', 426, 5, 8, 899372) All this is certainly to the good, but after having fully discussed with the friends from Vykom the position, I still entertain the opinion that Satyagraha should be confined to the Hindus only and that, too, as far as possible to the volunteers drawn from Kerala, and, at the most, from the Madras Presidency.
('27', 426, 5, 9, 899683) Satya graha in its intensest form goes deeper and therefore necessarily covers a very small surface.
('27', 426, 5, 10, 899784) Let me make my meaning clear.
('27', 426, 5, 11, 899814) The purer the organizers, the stronger and more effective is their Satya graha and, therefore, when the organizers of Satyagraha extend the boundary line, it is really an admission of one’s weakness, not of the cause, but of the persons organized.
('27', 426, 5, 12, 900062) I think I have said sufficiently in the pages of Young India to show why non Hindus cannot possibly offer Satyagraha in respect of a religious question which is exclusively Hindu.
('27', 426, 5, 13, 900242) I believe that my friends have seen the force of my argument.
('27', 426, 5, 14, 900304) If I could possibly persuade the Christian and Mohammedan sympa thizers who had gone to jail as Satyagrahis, I will ask them to tell the authorities that they offered Satyagraha in error and that, therefore, if the authorities intended to discharge them they might do so because they would not court arrest in the cause of the untouchable Hindus.
('27', 426, 5, 15, 900651) I am deliberately using the term untouchable Hindus, because I understand that among the Syrian Christians of Malabar there are untouchable Christians also.
('27', 426, 5, 16, 900808) But as the present satyagraha is not being offered on behalf of the untouchable Christians, the sacrifice of Messrs Joseph, Sebastian and Abdul Rahim carries no merit with it.
('27', 426, 5, 17, 900984) So far as the Sikh kitchen is concerned, it is not only out of place but it is harmful to the cause and to the self respect of the
('27', 427, 0, 1, 901115) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('27', 427, 1, 2, 901157) people of Kerala.
('27', 427, 1, 3, 901175) Harmful to the cause because it weakens the strength of the sacrifice of the volunteers and it must unnecessarily irritate that portion of the orthodox Hindus who are hostile to the reform.
('27', 427, 1, 4, 901365) It is harmful to the self respect of the Kerala people because unthinkingly they partake of the food distributed by the Sikh friends.
('27', 427, 1, 5, 901499) It can only be regarded as charity.
('27', 427, 1, 6, 901535) I cannot but regard it as charity that a large number of people, who are well able to feed themselves, should feed themselves at the kitchen and unwillingly be partakers of charity of which they do not stand in needs and this I say irrespective of the fact whether Sikhs be regarded as a part of the Hindu society or not.
('27', 427, 1, 7, 901857) I would expect the Kerala friends to have self respect and courage enough courteously to decline such assistance even if Sanatani Hindus offered to establish a kitchen.
('27', 427, 1, 8, 902026) I can conceive the possibility and necessity of such a kitchen in a famine stricken area where people are starving.
('27', 427, 1, 9, 902142) As to the pecuniary help from outside, I do retain the opinion that the Kerala friends should neither seek nor receive, even if it is offered unsought, pecuniary assistance from Hindus or others outside the Madras Presidency.
('27', 427, 1, 10, 902368) They may, if they so need it, seek the pecuniary assistance only of the Hindus of the Madras Presidency.
('27', 427, 1, 11, 902473) Of course, the Kerala people distributed all over India are bound, if they approve of the struggle, to send all the financial assistance that they can to the organizers of the movement.
('27', 427, 1, 12, 902659) My friends asked me whether I had expressed an opinion to the effect that the Kerala Congress Committee should not have taken up the question.
('27', 427, 1, 13, 902802) My answer to them was that, if the question should have been taken up at all, the Congress Committee should have been the first body to take it up because it is pledged to bring about the removal of untouchability by all peaceful and legitimate means.
('27', 427, 1, 14, 903054) But the Congress taking it up cannot and does not mean that non Hindus can or ought to participate in satyagraha.
('27', 427, 1, 15, 903168) They can only give their moral support.
('27', 427, 2, 16, 903208) I have no doubt whatsoever that, if the organizers continue the struggle in the same peaceful manner as they have done, accept the restrictions which I have suggested, and if they are thinking of sustaining the struggle for an indefinite period, their efforts must be
('27', 428, 0, 1, 903476) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 429
('27', 428, 1, 2, 903520) crowned with success.
('27', 428, 1, 3, 903542) I cannot, however, lay too much stress upon the fact that satyagraha is a process of conversion and, therefore, the organizers must ever aim at changing the heart of their opponents.
('27', 428, 2, 4, 903725) Q. Have you seen a cable sent by the Daily Telegraph’s correspondent in India to the
('27', 428, 3, 5, 903810) effect that you have decided to take the lead at the next Congress, on the platform for
('27', 428, 4, 6, 903898) securing a majority in the Assembly and Councils, replacing futile rejection of the
('27', 428, 5, 7, 903982) budget by a programme combining co operation in carrying on essential services
('27', 428, 6, 8, 904061) with persistent demands backed by consistent and substantial majorities for speedy
('27', 428, 7, 9, 904144) extension and recasting of reforms and speeding up of Indianization including the
('27', 428, 8, 10, 904226) In view of such deliberate misrepresentation, prompted by a desire to discredit
('27', 428, 9, 11, 904306) the Swarajists in particular and the Indian National movement in general and in view
('27', 428, 10, 12, 904391) of the thick ignorance which prevails in England regarding the real aims of the
('27', 428, 11, 13, 904471) movement, don’t you think that an Indian Bureau should be established in England for
('27', 428, 12, 14, 904556) the dissemination of the truth regarding India?
('27', 428, 12, 15, 904604) Have you revised your views since
('27', 428, 13, 16, 904638) Nagpur?
('27', 428, 13, 17, 904646) If the expense of maintaining such a bureau will be too heavy, should not a
('27', 428, 14, 18, 904722) small subsidy be paid from Congress funds to some individual who is willing to
('27', 428, 15, 19, 904801) undertake the work?
('27', 428, 16, 20, 904821) A. I did see the cablegram, but I thought that nobody would attach the slightest importance to it or credit me with the views about co operation such as are imputed to me in the cable.
('27', 428, 16, 21, 905006) As I have said so often, I am personally eager and anxious to offer co operation, but I am more eager and more anxious to strengthen the forces of non co operation till there is the slightest possible indication of a change of heart, of which hitherto I have seen no sign whatsoever.
('27', 428, 16, 22, 905290) I retain the same views about a publicity bureau to be maintained or subsidized in London for the purpose of contradicting mis statements that may appear in the British Press.
('27', 428, 16, 23, 905466) I am still of opinion that no misrepresentation or mis statement can possibly do us any harm if we are ourselves strong and sound.
('27', 428, 16, 24, 905597) Conversely no patronizing or favourable notice of our demands in the British or the foreign Press can be of any avail to us if we are ourselves weak, disorganized and not prepared to give battle to the Government.
('27', 428, 16, 25, 905811) Therefore, every rupee that we can spare I would utilize for the khaddar propaganda, for national schools and for other parts of the constructive programme.
('27', 428, 17, 26, 905968) Q. You must have seen that resort to so called Satyagraha is becoming
('27', 428, 18, 27, 906038) frequent in the country not only in connection with political grievances but purely
('27', 429, 0, 1, 906122) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('27', 429, 1, 2, 906164) religious or social.
('27', 429, 1, 3, 906185) Don’t you think that there is danger of the abuse of this weapon and duragaha instead of Satyagraha being practised for illegitimate ends?
('27', 429, 1, 4, 906324) Can you
('27', 429, 2, 5, 906332) lay down any rules for Satyagrahis—at least those who follow the Congress lead?
('27', 429, 2, 6, 906412) Yes, I agree that there is some danger of Satyagraha degenerating into an evil force and therefore becoming harmful.
('27', 429, 2, 7, 906529) Abuse of a good thing is always possible, especially of a force so powerful and subtle as Satyagraha.
('27', 429, 2, 8, 906631) I think, in my discussion of Satyagraha at Vykom, I have discussed in a cursory manner its fundamentals, but I accept your suggestion and, as soon as I have a little leisure, I hope to draw the rules which in my opinion are binding upon every satyagrahi.
('27', 429, 3, 9, 906886) In the course of a conversation with Messrs K. Madhavan Nair and Kurur
('27', 429, 4, 10, 906957) Neelakantan Nambudripad, who constitute the Vykom Deputation, they gave me to
('27', 429, 5, 11, 907035) understand that they had three to four long interviews with Mahatmaji and had
('27', 429, 6, 12, 907113) discussed the question threadbare.
('27', 429, 6, 13, 907148) They represented the whole case as well as they
('27', 429, 7, 14, 907196) could, which Mahatmaji listened to with his characteristic patience and politeness.
('27', 429, 8, 15, 907280) They said to me that they were satisfied with Mahatmaji’s statement and were
('27', 429, 9, 16, 907357) confident that it would satisfy workers and sympathizers in Kerala and the Madras
('27', 429, 10, 17, 907439) Presidency.
('27', 429, 10, 18, 907451) Mahatmaji emphasized self reliance and self sufficiency involved in a
('27', 429, 11, 19, 907521) movement.
('27', 429, 11, 20, 907531) They were afraid, they said, that Mahatmaji might find objection to the
('27', 429, 12, 21, 907603) Congress Committee undertaking the [anti ]untouchability movement as it was
('27', 429, 13, 22, 907679) represented in some quarters.
('27', 429, 13, 23, 907709) They were, however, satisfied that there was nothing of
('27', 429, 14, 24, 907765) the kind.
('27', 429, 14, 25, 907775) Mahatmaji’s very emphatic assertion raises no apprehensions in that
('27', 429, 15, 26, 907843) direction.
('27', 429, 15, 27, 907854) The Deputation is returning to Vykom in a day or two.
('27', 429, 16, 28, 907908) With regard to the Council question, Mahatmaji gave our representative to
('27', 429, 17, 29, 907982) understand that a full statement would be issued to the Press in the course of this week.
('27', 429, 18, 30, 908072) Our representative understands that Mahatmaji and Swarajist leaders had had long and
('27', 429, 19, 31, 908157) repeated conferences and the decision is practically arrived at.
