('27', 430, 1, 2, 908287) 351. MY NOTES
('27', 430, 2, 3, 908301) SHASTRAS ON CHILD MARRIAGE A friend, commenting on the article on “Renunciation Person ified” 1, has written to me to the following effect: “You are against the marriage of girls under fifteen, but the Shastras enjoin us to get girls married before they attain puberty.
('27', 430, 2, 4, 908571) Even those who are against child marriage follow this injunction of the Shastras.
('27', 430, 2, 5, 908653) How does one solve this dilemma?” I see no dilemma here.
('27', 430, 2, 6, 908710) Anyone who claims or believes that whatever is found in the books known as the Shastras is true and that no departure from it is permissible will find himself in such dilemmas at every step.
('27', 430, 2, 7, 908901) A given verse may be interpreted in many ways, and these meanings may even be mutually contradictory.
('27', 430, 2, 8, 909003) Moreover, the Shastras lay down some principles which are immutable, while some others related to conditions at a particular time and place and applied only to those circumstances.
('27', 430, 2, 9, 909184) If anyone could live in the Arctic region where the sun does not set for six months, at what time should he perform sandhya 2?
('27', 430, 2, 10, 909311) What would he do about bathing, etc.?
('27', 430, 2, 11, 909349) The Manusmriti 3 lays down many rules about what should and what should not be eaten, not one of which is observed today.
('27', 430, 2, 12, 909471) Nor were all the verses written by the same person or at the same time.
('27', 430, 2, 13, 909543) Hence, anyone who lives in fear of God and does not wish to violate moral laws has no choice but to reject everything which seems to be immoral.
('27', 430, 2, 14, 909688) Self indulgence cannot possibly be dharma.
('27', 430, 2, 15, 909731) Hinduism places no restrictions on a life of self control.
('27', 430, 2, 16, 909790) What about the girl who has come to feel aversion to worldly pleasures?
('27', 430, 2, 17, 909862) What does attaining puberty signify?
('27', 430, 2, 18, 909899) Why should we insist that a girl should necessarily be married immediately after or before she arrives at a state which is normal for women.
('27', 430, 2, 19, 910040) One can well understand a restriction to the effect that a girl can marry only after she has arrived at this state.
('27', 430, 2, 20, 910156) Quarrelling over the meaning of the Shastras, we should never perpetrate cruelties.
('27', 430, 2, 21, 910240) A Shastra is what leads us towards moksha 4
('27', 430, 3, 22, 910284) 1 Vide “Renunciation Personified”, 4 5 1924.
('27', 430, 4, 23, 910329) 2 Worship, especially morning and evening 3 Manu’s code of laws 4 Deliverance from phenomenal existence as the supreme end of life
('27', 431, 0, 1, 910460) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('27', 431, 1, 2, 910502) and dharma what teaches us self restraint.
('27', 431, 1, 3, 910545) Anyone who jumps into a well and drowns himself merely because it is his ancestral well is a misguided fool.
('27', 431, 1, 4, 910654) Akha Bhagat 1 described the Shastras as a dark well.
('27', 431, 1, 5, 910707) Jhaneshwar 2 regarded even the Vedas as much too narrow in scope.
('27', 431, 1, 6, 910773) Narasinh Mehta 3 regarded experience alone as true knowledge.
('27', 431, 1, 7, 910835) If we turn our eyes to the world, we can see that what this gentleman regards as dharma is in truth adharma 4 and should be completely rejected.
('27', 431, 1, 8, 910980) It is because of this adharma that today we sacrifice innumerable young girls.
('27', 431, 1, 9, 911059) History will condemn Hindu men for this custom.
('27', 431, 1, 10, 911107) We need not, however, worry over what history will say.
('27', 431, 1, 11, 911163) We ourselves are tasting the bitter fruit of the custom of child marriage.
('27', 431, 1, 12, 911238) It cannot be denied that this custom is one main reason why many Hindu young men have no spirit in them, behave like cripples and are all fear.
('27', 431, 1, 13, 911382) It should not be forgotten that children of parents who are not fully grown men and women cannot develop a strong physique, do what you will.
('27', 431, 1, 14, 911524) Fortunately, all Hindus do not follow the rule mentioned by the gentleman and the race has not totally lost its physical vitality.
('27', 431, 1, 15, 911655) If, however, it were literally followed in practice, Hindu society would have no men at all.
('27', 431, 2, 16, 911748) A LEGITIMATE COMPLAINT
('27', 431, 3, 17, 911771) Perhaps most readers of Navajivan have not heard of Shri Harihar Sharma.
('27', 431, 3, 18, 911844) He may be described as a relative of Kaka’s.
('27', 431, 3, 19, 911889) Let me introduce the reader to that family.
('27', 431, 3, 20, 911933) When Barrister Shri Keshavrao Deshpande founded the Ganganath Vidyalaya in Baroda, he gathered round him a group of teachers and, with the idea of creating a family feeling among them, gave them titles indicative of family relationships.
('27', 431, 3, 21, 912171) The school as an institution housed in a particular building has ceased to exist, but as a sentiment it survives even today.
('27', 431, 3, 22, 912296) This family circle still maintains its old ties.
('27', 431, 3, 23, 912345) Like blood relationship, spiritual relationship too cannot cease.
('27', 431, 3, 24, 912411) Inspired by this idea, those who were given these titles of family relationships regard them as sacred and have retained them.
('27', 431, 3, 25, 912538) Keshavrao Deshpande’s followers still know
('27', 431, 4, 26, 912581) 1 Gujarati saint poet of the 17th century 2 Maharashtrian saint of the 13th century 3 1414 1479; saint poet of Gujarat 4 The opposite of dharma
('27', 432, 0, 1, 912725) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 433
('27', 432, 1, 2, 912769) and respect him by the name of “Saheb”.
('27', 432, 1, 3, 912809) Our Kalelkar likes always to be addressed as “Kaka”.
('27', 432, 1, 4, 912862) Very few Gujaratis know Phadke by that name.
('27', 432, 1, 5, 912907) We know him as “Mama”.
('27', 432, 1, 6, 912930) Similarly, Harihar Sharma is “Anna”.
('27', 432, 1, 7, 912967) This is one of the titles in use in Maharashtrian families.
('27', 432, 1, 8, 913027) In Tamil, too, it is used in much the same sense.
('27', 432, 1, 9, 913077) “Anna” means brother.
('27', 432, 1, 10, 913099) Another person is known as “Bhai”.
('27', 432, 1, 11, 913134) Though he is still alive, he is as good as lost.
('27', 432, 1, 12, 913183) I do not know the names of all the members of this well known family.
('27', 432, 1, 13, 913253) I have given these few facts while introducing Shri Harihar Sharma, hoping that Kaka himself will tell us in detail about the family when he has an occasion to do so.
('27', 432, 2, 14, 913420) Through this preface, I have also removed one misconception.
('27', 432, 2, 15, 913481) Some persons, or rather quite a few, believe that Kaka and other work ers like him are my gift to Gujarat; in fact, they are gifts by Saheb.
('27', 432, 2, 16, 913622) He has given them on loan to me and, thereby, has put a responsibility on me as well.
('27', 432, 2, 17, 913708) My only duty towards the members of this family is to help them in the work and increase their devotion to Saheb as much as possible.
('27', 432, 2, 18, 913842) Other birds, too, have come for shelter into the nest which I have built.
('27', 432, 2, 19, 913916) If we examine the reasons for this, we shall see that they have all come because people find comfort for their spirit in this nest.
('27', 432, 2, 20, 914048) The birds feel their wings strengthened here, not clipped, so that they can fly as they wish.
('27', 432, 2, 21, 914142) I am their debtor so long as they stay.
('27', 432, 2, 22, 914182) As I am not responsible for collecting them, I cannot keep them either.
('27', 432, 2, 23, 914254) Everyone is free to follow his own way.
('27', 432, 2, 24, 914294) Since, however, they believe in self restraint, I cannot describe them as men who accept no law.
('27', 432, 3, 25, 914391) This Anna has taken up the work of propagating Hindi in the Dravida region and, for that purpose, he and his wife studied Hindi in Prayag.
('27', 432, 3, 26, 914530) Both of them passed the Hindi examination there and they started the work of spreading Hindi in Madras.
('27', 432, 3, 27, 914634) Anyone who wants to get more information about this can do so by writing to him.
('27', 432, 4, 28, 914715) Shri Anna also brings out a fortnightly magazine called Hindi Prachar.
('27', 432, 4, 29, 914786) The chairman of the Reception Committee of the Provincial Conference 1 at Borsad sent him an invitation which was wholly in English !
('27', 432, 4, 30, 914920) How could Anna tolerate this?
('27', 432, 4, 31, 914950) He has written me a strongly

('27', 452, 3, 4, 954418) Q. Mahatmaji, you have stated that fasting as a weapon cannot be resorted to
('27', 452, 4, 5, 954495) by a satyagrahi except against friends.
('27', 452, 4, 6, 954535) The Travancore Government is either a friend
('27', 452, 5, 7, 954580) or a foe that opposes the wishes of its subjects.
('27', 452, 5, 8, 954630) If it is a friend, the sufferings
('27', 452, 6, 9, 954664) undergone by the Satyagrahis evidencing the intensity of their feelings in this matter
('27', 452, 7, 10, 954751) are sure ultimately to melt the heart of the Government and induce it to grant the
('27', 452, 8, 11, 954834) demands of the satyagrahis.
('27', 452, 8, 12, 954862) The Maharaja of Travancore, though orthodox to the
('27', 452, 9, 13, 954913) core, is a kind ruler and loves his subjects and he will not be able to look with
('27', 452, 10, 14, 954995) equanimity on the sufferings undergone by the Satyagrahis.
('27', 452, 10, 15, 955054) He is not a tyrant who
('27', 452, 11, 16, 955077) does not feel for his people.
('27', 452, 11, 17, 955107) Under these circumstances, why cannot the satyagrahis
('27', 452, 12, 18, 955161) adopt fasting to melt the Maharaja’s heart and to conquer him through their
('27', 452, 13, 19, 955237) sufferings?
('27', 452, 13, 20, 955249) A. Satyagraha implies absolute love and non violence.
('27', 452, 13, 21, 955303) Fasting as a weapon can only be used against a lover, a friend, a follower or co worker who, on account of his love for you and the sufferings you undergo actually, realizes his mistake and corrects himself.
('27', 452, 13, 22, 955511) He purifies himself of an evil which he knows and acknowledges to be an evil.
('27', 452, 13, 23, 955589) You recall him from his evil ways to the correct path.
('27', 452, 13, 24, 955644) A son can fast against a father addicted to drink to cure him of his evil.
('27', 452, 13, 25, 955719) The father knows it to be an evil and realizes the enormity of it by the sufferings of the son and he corrects himself.
('27', 452, 13, 26, 955839) My followers and co workers who resorted to violence in Bombay knew that violence was against the principle of non co operation.
('27', 452, 13, 27, 955968) Only they deviated from that funda mental principle.
('27', 452, 13, 28, 956021) My fasting brought home to them their mistake and they corrected it.
('27', 452, 13, 29, 956090) But you cannot fast even against a friend when other consi derations than actual realization of his evil ways are likely to make him yield.
('27', 452, 13, 30, 956230) For example, when I proposed to introduce an untouchable as a member of my household, my wife objected.
('27', 452, 13, 31, 956334) My fasting against her under such circumstances might have obliged her to give in, but it would be the fear that my fasting would lead to my death and the loss of her husband that would influence her to surrender her opinion and
('27', 452, 14, 32, 956563) 1 This consisted of K. Madhavan Nair and Kurur Nilakantan Nambudripad.

('27', 453, 1, 2, 956676) not the consciousness that she was committing a wrong in regarding a human being as untouchable.
('27', 453, 1, 3, 956773) I succeeded in the case not by converting her to my opinion but by tyrannizing over her and doing violence to her feelings.
('27', 453, 1, 4, 956897) In the same way, the Maharaja of Travancore may be a kind man who may not bear to witness with equanimity the death of a satyagrahi.
('27', 453, 1, 5, 957030) Your fasting may compel him to yield, but he yields not because he sees the error of his ways and believes untouch ability to be evil, but because he cannot bear to see the death of a person who, in his opinion, perversely chooses to die: This is the worst form of compulsion which militates against the fundamental princi ples of satyagraha.

('27', 458, 2, 3, 968472) APPENDIX I
('27', 458, 3, 4, 968483) ANDREW’S STATEMENT ON GANDHIJI’S RELEASE
('27', 458, 4, 5, 968524) Mr. C. F. Andrews has communicated the following statement to the Associated Press concerning Mr. Gandhi :
('27', 458, 5, 6, 968631) I was present at the Sassoon Hospital this morning at about 7.30 a.m.
('27', 458, 5, 7, 968701) and found Mahatma Gandhi very bright and cheerful after a good night’s rest.
('27', 458, 5, 8, 968778) While we were talking, Col.
('27', 458, 5, 9, 968806) Maddock who has been in charge of the patient in hospital came in and announced to Mahatmaji news of his unconditional release and congratulated him upon it most heartily.
('27', 458, 5, 10, 968978) He then read out to him words of the official message and said that it had come on Monday night by a special messenger.
('27', 458, 5, 11, 969098) Therefore he had taken earliest opportunity of coming to him as he wished [him] to be the first man to hear news that he was now free.
('27', 458, 5, 12, 969233) Mahatma Gandhi remained quiet for a few moments and then said to Col.
('27', 458, 5, 13, 969303) Maddock with a smile, “I hope you will allow me to remain your patient and also your guest a little longer.” Doctor laughed and told him that he trusted that his patient would go on obeying his orders as a doctor and that he himself might have very great pleasure and satisfaction of seeing him thoroughly restored to health.
('27', 458, 5, 14, 969629) Later on in the morning, after dressing the wound, Col.
('27', 458, 5, 15, 969685) Maddock gave warning that recovery of the patient which was going on so well might be seriously thrown back if any unnecessary excitement or tiredness was caused in the next few days by visits of those who wished to see him.
('27', 458, 5, 16, 969910) Kindest thing in the world would be for everyone, except those who were nursing him, to give him all the rest possible at this critical time in his recovery.
('27', 458, 5, 17, 970068) It had to be remembered that the wound which had to be made while performing the operation was not fully healed and a little over taxing of strength of the patient might throw recovery back.
('27', 458, 5, 18, 970259) Next fortnight would be the time when every reserve of strength would be needed in order that the wound might be fully healed.
('27', 458, 5, 19, 970386) Everything had gone well up to the present, but it was imperative that no unnecessary risks shall be incurred.
('27', 458, 6, 20, 970497) Mahatma Gandhi was removed by doctor’s orders into another room with an outside verandah where he would be able to get the full benefit of the sunshine and open air.
('27', 458, 6, 21, 970663) Telegrams began to pour in upon him from an early hour.
('27', 458, 6, 22, 970719) The first telegram reached hospital very soon after Col.
('27', 458, 6, 23, 970776) Maddock had left.
('27', 458, 7, 24, 970794) I would wish, if I may be permitted to do so, after all I have seen in the hospital concerning Mahatma Gandhi’s health, to add my own urgent request to the warning given by the doctor, for while undoubtedly Mahatma Gandhi has recovered wonderfully hitherto, he is still in a very weak condition and it must be remembered that healing of the wound has still to go on and anything that in the slightest degree might bring about a relapse must be avoided.
('27', 458, 7, 25, 971247) Every day of complete rest which he can
('27', 459, 0, 1, 971287) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 460
('27', 459, 1, 2, 971329) now obtain, especially during the next fortnight, will mean an immense difference for the future.
('27', 459, 1, 3, 971427) It would be the greatest kindness possible if those to whom his health is most precious would strictly observe doctor’s instructions until the recovery has been fulfilled.
('27', 459, 1, 4, 971599) It will also be quite impossible for Mahatmaji to grant interviews to Press correspondents.
('27', 459, 1, 5, 971691) After writing out this statement, I read it over to Mahatma Gandhi himself at his own request, and he has passed it for the Press.

('27', 460, 2, 3, 973175) EXTRACT FROM K. P. KESAVA MENON’S LETTER
('27', 460, 3, 4, 973216) Kerala Provincial Congress Committee at its last meeting chalked out a definite programme of work with regard to untouchability this year.
('27', 460, 3, 5, 973355) As you know, the conditions in Kerala are peculiar.
('27', 460, 3, 6, 973407) Here the question is not only untouchability but unapproachability.
('27', 460, 3, 7, 973475) We are now taking steps to see that public roads are also open to the unapproachables.
('27', 460, 3, 8, 973562) There are ever so many roads in Kerala now used by Mahomedans, Christians and high caste Hindus but are not allowed to be used by the unapproachables such as Ezuvas, Thiyyas and Pulayas.
('27', 460, 3, 9, 973749) Two weeks ago when I went to
('27', 460, 4, 10, 973778) Vykom, a place of some importance in north Travancore, I appealed to the caste Hindus to allow members of the Ezuva and Pulaya communities to use the public road
('27', 460, 5, 11, 973940) round the temple.
('27', 460, 5, 12, 973958) I may mention that this road is maintained by public funds and is now being freely used by Christians, Mahomedans and caste Hindus.
('27', 460, 5, 13, 974090) Though we arranged a procession consisting of Pulayas to pass this road on the morning of the
('27', 460, 6, 14, 974184) 1st instant, we had to postpone it at the request of several local friends who wanted some time more to educate public opinion on the question.
('27', 460, 6, 15, 974328) You may remember Mr. T. K. Madhavan, a leading member of Thiyya community who interviewed you some
('27', 460, 7, 16, 974427) three years ago while you were at Tinnevelly.
('27', 460, 7, 17, 974473) 1 He has now joined the Congress and is whole heartedly working with us for the removal of untouchability.
('27', 460, 7, 18, 974580) We have fixed the 30th instant to take the procession along these roads.
('27', 460, 7, 19, 974653) I need not assure you that it would be our endeavour to conduct it in the most orderly way possible.
('27', 460, 7, 20, 974754) In the meanwhile, attempts are being made by lectures, distribution of leaflets, and personal interviews to bring the orthodox people to our side.
('27', 460, 7, 21, 974901) A message from you would instil fresh courage in us.
('27', 460, 8, 22, 974954) The Hindu, 25 3 1924
('27', 460, 9, 23, 974975) APPENDIX IV
('27', 460, 10, 24, 974987) LETTER FROM C. VIJAYARAGHAVACHARIAR
('27', 460, 11, 25, 975023) THE “ARAMA”, SALEM, (SOUTHERN INDIA), March 23, 1924
('27', 460, 12, 26, 975076) MY DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('27', 460, 13, 27, 975095) I am so glad to receive your letter 2 today and I tender you my special thanks for reading the long statement during your present state of health.
('27', 460, 13, 28, 975242) I fear that I have not
('27', 460, 14, 29, 975265) 1 Vide “Interview to Deshabhimani”, 23 9 1921.
('27', 460, 15, 30, 975312) 2 This was dated March 19, 1924.
('27', 461, 0, 1, 975345) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 462
('27', 461, 1, 2, 975387) expressed myself crisply and clearly in my statement.
('27', 461, 1, 3, 975441) With your refreshing frankness, you must permit me to say that you have misunderstood it in vital parts.
('27', 461, 1, 4, 975546) To show this clearly to you would require more space and time than I can well command now I am not quite well and mostly in bed and on fluid diet under medical adviceor desirable to trouble you with, during your rest so necessary; but I shall take one or two instances.
('27', 461, 2, 5, 975818) You say, “It will also follow from your reasoning that swaraj will only have to be a grant from the British Parliament.” This sentence has taken me by surprise.
('27', 461, 2, 6, 975979) The whole tone and drift of my argument in this statement, as it had been previously throughout my life, is quit the contrary.
('27', 461, 2, 7, 976106) I never was a party and could never be a party to the debasing view that we could secure our freedom only as a gift from any nation.
('27', 461, 2, 8, 976239) In this very statement, I have clearly emphasized my strong difference from this view.
('27', 461, 2, 9, 976326) I am sorry I did not number the paragraphs; but you can easily locate in it what I have said on this subject.
('27', 461, 2, 10, 976436) You will note that I distinguish both our Moderates and Nationalists from those who have adopted your gospel of swaraj.
('27', 461, 2, 11, 976556) I say there that the former have no ‘sanction’ for winning our freedom.
('27', 461, 2, 12, 976628) You know what this word means in legal and political language.
('27', 461, 2, 13, 976691) I also allude to the only two methods proclaimed authoritatively as means to gain our freedom, namely, a gift from England or by the employment of the sword and I afterwards said that we have invented a third method in the place of these two and that I call a sanction; namely moral coercion of such a kind that England will not and dare not resist.
('27', 461, 2, 14, 977041) Surely, in the face of this, it pains me to see you attribute to me the idea of a spontaneous grant of swaraj from England.
('27', 461, 2, 15, 977165) I can expand this argument, but I think it unnecessary.
('27', 461, 2, 16, 977221) I shall console myself with an earnest appeal to you to read my statement again and also the cuttings which have been sent to Rev.
('27', 461, 2, 17, 977352) Mr. C. F. Andrews a few days ago.
('27', 461, 2, 18, 977386) You must ever remember that I am not a scholar and you must kindly gather my full meaning from scattered ideas not very logically arranged.
('27', 461, 2, 19, 977526) As regards your statement that my swaraj is not consistent with our freedom to quit the British Empire when we choose, I can only refer you to the general tone and drift of these arguments as well as to my address at Nagpore, from all of which you can easily gather that my idea of swaraj implies freedom and ability to say England “Get thee gone”.
('27', 461, 2, 20, 977875) You know well that the late French Prime Minister, Sir Wilfred Laurier, the leader of the Canadian Liberals, said that if Canada declared herself independent, England dared not fire a single gun.
('27', 461, 2, 21, 978071) This view that the domi nions of the British Empire are free to detach themselves at any time they liked is no longer a controversial policy but an accepted one.
('27', 461, 3, 22, 978233) On the subject of untouchablity, you don’t thoroughly understand me either.
('27', 461, 3, 23, 978309) I merely wish to correct the erroneous and mischievous impression generally prevai ling, especially abroad, that the doctrine of untouchability of Hindu outcastes and low castes was invented by the higher castes.
('27', 461, 3, 24, 978522) I should like to know authority to the contrary if you disagree with me.
('27', 461, 3, 25, 978595) On the other hand, this doctrine of untouchability,
('27', 462, 0, 1, 978647) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 463
('27', 462, 1, 2, 978691) applied again to those unfortunate classes, is clearly and logically an expansion and even an exaggeration in a most uncharitable form of the doctrine of untouchability within caste and within family.
('27', 462, 1, 3, 978892) In either case, the doctrine is based upon the idea that touch meant pollution and impurity.
('27', 462, 1, 4, 978985) That’s all I meant.
('27', 462, 1, 5, 979005) I meant that both the ideas are the same in kind but different in degree.
('27', 462, 1, 6, 979079) You perhaps are not aware that, in Southern India, we cannot go near a woman when she is unwell (periodically) be that woman our mother, sister, or daughter and , if inadvertently we did, we have to bathe and even change the sacred thread, exactly as the most orthodox do when they touch or go too near a Pariah.
('27', 462, 1, 7, 979392) This aspect was not thoroughly endorsed by Sri Shankaracharya.
('27', 462, 1, 8, 979455) He said that bathing and changing thread would do if there was actual touch of the woman in such condition, but there was no pollution if one goes near her.
('27', 462, 1, 9, 979612) You will thus see from all these that I never meant more than that a grievance, which really exists and which it is our sacred duty to, remove should not be exaggerated in nature or needlessly even in scope so that unnecessary bitterness of feeling is caused to the sufferers from a delusion that the doctrine was specially invented by the higher order of the Hindu society to degrade them on purpose.
('27', 462, 1, 10, 980014) I hope you will agree with me that reform in this vital particular in our national corporate life is the more easy if there are no misconceptions on the part of either side and no exhibition of unseemly gesture on the part of the sufferers due to bitterness of feeling rising from erroneous diagnosis of the cause and exaggerated view of the grievance.
('27', 462, 1, 11, 980367) When we meet again and when I shall have the good fortune to make you the more clearly and exactly see me as I am and as I have been, I hope to convince you that my views touching our duties no less than of our rights in order that we might take our proper place among the great families in this world are saner and sounder and more charitable than you appear to think, judging from your present letter.
('27', 462, 2, 12, 980771) My respects to Mrs. Gandhi, as well as my regards to Rev.
('27', 462, 2, 13, 980829) Mr. C. F. Andrews and my kind remembrances to your children.
('27', 462, 2, 14, 980890) Trusting that you are every day making good progress towards complete recovery of your health and with very kind regards, I am, Yours sincerely,
('27', 462, 3, 15, 981035) C. VIJAYARAGHAVACHARIAR PS.
('27', 462, 3, 16, 981063) As regards the melancholy meanness of the business of the Congress at Cocanada in treating the so called Compromise Resolution as a Non co operation Resolution, I would call your attention to the attitude of “Janmabhumi” of Masuli patam edited by Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya.
('27', 462, 3, 17, 981336) This paper attacks it more than I do, and Sitaramayya is a genuine Congressman.
('27', 462, 3, 18, 981416) You have not a purer and more loyal follower than he.

('27', 463, 2, 3, 981551) (A) LETTER FROM RAMANAND SANYASI
('27', 463, 3, 4, 981584) BALDEV ASHRAM, KHURJA (U. P.), April 1, 1924
('27', 463, 4, 5, 981629) SHRIMAN MAHATMAJI,
('27', 463, 5, 6, 981648) I am in receipt of your letter dated the 28th instant.
('27', 463, 5, 7, 981703) I regret I did not give you any particulars in my first letter.
('27', 463, 6, 8, 981767) (1) After 1921 episode the recruiting absolutely stopped.
('27', 463, 6, 9, 981825) The trade was dull and there were huge stocks of Indian tea.
('27', 463, 6, 10, 981886) both in England and in India.
('27', 463, 6, 11, 981916) With the present rise in the market and clearance of stocks, the planters began to feel need of more labour to recultivate the plantations which had been abandoned since 1921. The present recruiting started in last November.
('27', 463, 6, 12, 982141) The information which I received was from a friend who is the District Engineer of Gurgaon District (Punjab).
('27', 463, 6, 13, 982251) Then later on I received information from nearly six districts in U. P. and two districts of Punjab.
('27', 463, 6, 14, 982352) It was in January that I issued a statement to the Press warning the people against consequences.
('27', 463, 6, 15, 982450) The Anglo Indian agents who were in charge carefully avoided the districts from which they used to draw their labour before 1921 episode.
('27', 463, 7, 16, 982588) (2) The above covers your questions No.
('27', 463, 7, 17, 982628) 2 and 3 also.
('27', 463, 8, 18, 982642) (3) The enquiry I want to make in the plantations is what are actual conditions prevailing there at present.
('27', 463, 8, 19, 982751) Has their moral or otherwise their economic position increased than hitherto, and whether it will not be in the general interest of the country to check the flow of the labour to those districts if no improvement in any direction has taken place so that the morals and characters of further number may not become lax.
('27', 463, 9, 20, 983069) (4) No written conditions were offered to the would be recruit as far as I have ascertained, but mainly they were as follows:
('27', 463, 10, 21, 983195) (i) Rs. thirty per mensem as wages both to the husband and wife, (ii) free quarters, wood for fuel and medical attendance.
('27', 463, 10, 22, 983318) (iii) Free railway passage in case the recruit does not like the place.
('27', 463, 10, 23, 983390) But you can yourself guess how difficult it is to return from tea garden districts if you are once there as a labourer.
('27', 463, 10, 24, 983510) I quite accept your suggestion that enquiries should be made first through Assam Congress Committee before proceeding there.
('27', 463, 10, 25, 983635) Accordingly I am writing a letter to the Committee the copy of which I am enclosing herewith.
('27', 463, 10, 26, 983729) I am also enclosing herewith a letter in original which I only few days ago received from the Congress committee, Biswan.
('27', 463, 11, 27, 983851) Sincerely yours,

('27', 464, 1, 2, 983959) (B) RAMANAND SANYASI’S LETTER TO CONGRESS COMMITTEE
('27', 464, 2, 3, 984011) BALDEV ASHRAM, KHURJA (U. P.), April 1, 1924
('27', 464, 3, 4, 984056) TO THE SECRETARY ASSAM PROVINCIAL CONGRESS COMMITTEE GAUHATI
('27', 464, 4, 5, 984117) DEAR SIR, In last November I received news from the Gurgaon District of Punjab that a certain Anglo Indian gentleman was employing retired militarymen for recruiting labour for tea gardens, and that he was offering (i) Free railway passage to the gardens (ii) Rs. thirty monthly as wages both for husband and wife, (iii) together with free quarters and fuel wood.
('27', 464, 4, 6, 984481) He was also willing to provide passage back and journey expenses should the recruit when at reaching there does not like to stay.
('27', 464, 4, 7, 984611) Immediately after that I received news to the same effect from Karnal, Ambala, Rohtak and Hissar districts of Punjab and from nearly every district of U. P. except Fezabad, Bellia, Gorakhpore and some other two or three districts which they perhaps avoided because these contained their ex labourers.
('27', 464, 4, 8, 984912) As I am quit familiar with the conditions prevailing in tea gardens and episode of 1921 came vividly before my eyes, I issued a statement to the Bengal, Punjab and U.P. Press in January last which you must have noticed and also I wrote to Bengal, U.P. and Punjab committees to take such action as conditions permit.
('27', 464, 4, 9, 985228) At that time I did not write to you not because it was not necessary but because Assam had slipped from my memory.
('27', 464, 4, 10, 985343) Now I wrote to Mahatma Gandhiji telling him of the thing and consulting him regarding the advisability or otherwise of proceeding to the tea gardens and looking at the thing.
('27', 464, 4, 11, 985518) He has written to me to first make enquiries through you and then to consider what action should be taken in light of the same.
('27', 464, 4, 12, 985646) Therefore I shall be obliged if you will kindly supply me the following information: (1) What are the actual conditions prevailing in plantations at present and has any improvement taken place regarding wages or morals since 1921 happenings.
('27', 464, 4, 13, 985888) (2) Is fresh labour coming there, if so, from which districts mainly, and how they are being treated.
('27', 464, 4, 14, 985990) (3) Do you think in the light of enquiries which you will make it is advisable to take measures against recruiting or should any body be deputed there to look after them.
('27', 464, 4, 15, 986161) Kindly forward a copy of reply to my this letter to Mahatmaji at Andheri, Bombay.
('27', 464, 4, 16, 986243) Sincerely yours,
('27', 464, 5, 17, 986260) RAMANAND SANYASI (Note) I am forwarding a copy of this letter to Mahatmaji as per his orders.

('27', 465, 1, 2, 986425) APPENDIX VI
('27', 465, 2, 3, 986437) C. F. ANDREWS’ INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('27', 465, 3, 4, 986482) Mr. C. F. Andrews interviewed on the same subject stated that he had been
('27', 465, 4, 5, 986556) present with Mr. Gandhi through the preliminary negotiations with General Smuts,
('27', 465, 5, 6, 986637) which had led up to the Smuts Gandhi Settlement of July 1914. He had himself
('27', 465, 6, 7, 986714) actually witnessed the signing of the original draft agreement.
('27', 465, 6, 8, 986778) Every word had been
('27', 465, 7, 9, 986798) carefully discussed and fully explained on both sides.
('27', 465, 7, 10, 986853) General Smuts had said, “This
('27', 465, 8, 11, 986883) time let there be no misunderstanding or mental reservation.
('27', 465, 8, 12, 986944) Let all the cards be laid
('27', 465, 9, 13, 986970) on the table.” Mr. Gandhi had acted exactly in accordance with that spirit.
('27', 465, 10, 14, 987046) made three points as plain as possible :
('27', 465, 11, 15, 987087) (1) That the Settlement should contain no racial taint.
('27', 465, 12, 16, 987143) (2) That all existing rights vested in the community, small as they were, should be secured.
('27', 465, 13, 17, 987236) (3) That any remaining disabilities might be brought forward for settle ment in the future.
('27', 465, 14, 18, 987328) This third point was established in a letter to the Secretary of the Minister of
('27', 465, 15, 19, 987409) the Interior, dated June 16, 1914. The first point was emphasized again and again in
('27', 465, 16, 20, 987494) Mr. Gandhi’s farewell speeches which were cabled all over the world.
('27', 465, 16, 21, 987563) He said, for
('27', 465, 17, 22, 987576) instance, at Johannesburg: “The Settlement reached establishes the principle that the
('27', 465, 18, 23, 987662) legislation can never contain a racial taint.
('27', 465, 18, 24, 987708) It is a vindication of this principle of the
('27', 465, 19, 25, 987753) British constitution.
('27', 465, 19, 26, 987775) I do not think there is any room left for misunderstanding.
('27', 465, 20, 27, 987835) While the Settlement is final in the sense that it close the great struggle, it is not
('27', 465, 21, 28, 987922) final in the sense that it gives the Indians all they are entitled to.
('27', 465, 21, 29, 987993) These further
('27', 465, 22, 30, 988007) restrictions will have to be removed.” 1
('27', 465, 23, 31, 988048) The most important statement which may be regarded the final word on the
('27', 465, 24, 32, 988121) subject from Mr. Gandhi was his message to Reuter on the eve of his departure from
('27', 465, 25, 33, 988204) South Africa.
('27', 465, 25, 34, 988218) It contained the following significant passage: “The promise made by
('27', 465, 26, 35, 988287) General Smuts to administer the existing law justly with due regard to vested rights
('27', 465, 27, 36, 988372) gives the Indian community breathing time.
('27', 465, 27, 37, 988415) But these laws are in themselves
('27', 465, 28, 38, 988448) defective, and can be, as they have been, turned into engines of oppression and
('27', 465, 29, 39, 988528) instruments by indirect means to drive the Indian population out of South Africa.
('27', 465, 30, 40, 988610) concession to popular prejudice, by which we have reconciled ourselves to the almost
('27', 465, 31, 41, 988695) 1 Vide “Speech at Farewell Banquet”, 14 7 1914. 2 ibid
('27', 466, 0, 1, 988750) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 467
('27', 466, 1, 2, 988794) total prohibition of fresh Indian Immigration and the deprivation of all political
('27', 466, 2, 3, 988877) power, is the utmost that could be expected from us.
('27', 466, 2, 4, 988930) These two things being assured, I
('27', 466, 3, 5, 988964) submit we are entitled to full rights of trade, inter provincial migration and
('27', 466, 4, 6, 989043) ownership of landed property being restored to us in the not distant future.” 2
('27', 466, 5, 7, 989123) These passages, Mr. Andrews stated, made perfectly evident that Mr. Gandhi went away from South Africa with a Settlement that was precisely defined.
('27', 466, 5, 8, 989272) On the understanding that immigration would be prohibited, General Smuts had agreed that no racial bar should be raised and that all existing vested rights should be secured.
('27', 466, 5, 9, 989447) He also agreed that the Indian community would be free in the future to seek to remove further disabilities such as the restriction of inter provincial migration.
('27', 466, 6, 10, 989610) Mr. Andrews concluded by stating that he could not at all understand Mr. Duncan’s interpretation, and that Mr. Gandhi’s prophetic words appeared to be coming true; for the Union Government appeared to be now engaged in turning its laws into “engines of oppression and instruments by indirect means to drive the Indian population out of South Africa.”
('27', 466, 7, 11, 989961) The Hindu, 7 4 1924
('27', 466, 8, 12, 989981) APPENDIX VII
('27', 466, 9, 13, 989994) (A) MAHOMED ALI’S LETTER TO SWAMI SHRADDHANAND
('27', 466, 10, 14, 990041) RESPECTED SWAMI MAHARAJ,
('27', 466, 11, 15, 990066) I am sorry I could not write to you yesterday regarding the matter referred to by you, as per promise, as I had gone out to pay a visit to H.H. the Nawab Sahib of Rampur and had to remain there from 11 a.m.
('27', 466, 11, 16, 990273) to 8 p.m.
('27', 466, 11, 17, 990283) I have just now seen in the Tej
('27', 466, 12, 18, 990315) a requisition by four of your Arya friends that I should resign from the Congress.
('27', 466, 12, 19, 990398) I could not help feeling amused at it, although I confess it grieved me also.
('27', 466, 12, 20, 990476) I am aware that some persons of this type have been engaged in this sort of activity for some time past, but I was led to think that, after the reply that I had given to a question addressed to me at a public meeting in Lucknow, which appealed so much to a Hindu gentleman present that he shouted out in his enthusiasm that 22 crores of Hindus were ready to stand or fall by me, these gentlemen would not venture to pursue their line of activity any further.
('27', 466, 12, 21, 990935) I now realize how vain this expectation was.
('27', 466, 12, 22, 990980) Although the manner in which the controversy is conducted at present is such as to render it absolutely unnecessary on my part to give a single word in reply, still as I have already promised to explain the matter fully, I beg to make the following statement as desired by you:
('27', 466, 13, 23, 991258) The fact is as I had stated verbally to you.
('27', 466, 13, 24, 991303) Even then, some Mussalman friends have been constantly flinging at me the charge of being a worshipper of Hindus and a Gandhi worshipper.
('27', 466, 13, 25, 991441) The real object of these gentlemen was to alienate from me the Mussalman community, the Khilafat Committee and the Congress, by representing
('27', 467, 0, 1, 991582) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 468
('27', 467, 1, 2, 991624) that I had become a follower of Mahatma Gandhi in my religious principles.
('27', 467, 1, 3, 991699) I had, therefore, on several occasions plainly declared that in the matter of religion, I professed the same belief as any other true Mussalman, and as such I claimed to be a follower of the Prophet Mahomed (on him be peace) and not of Gandhiji.
('27', 467, 1, 4, 991945) And further that since I hold Islam to be the highest gift of God, therefore, I was impelled by the love I bear towards Mahatmaji to pray to God that He might illumine his soul with the true light of Islam.
('27', 467, 1, 5, 992152) I wish, however, to emphatically declare that I hold that today neither the representatives of Islam nor of the Hindu, Jewish, Nazarene or Parsi faith can present another instance of such high character and moral worth as Gandhiji and that is the reason why I hold him in such high reverence and affection.
('27', 467, 1, 6, 992459) I deeply revere my own mother, and if contentment and gratefulness under all circumstances be the true meaning of Islam, I claim there is no person, howsoever well versed in religion, who has understood it better than she.
('27', 467, 1, 7, 992682) Similarly, I regard Maulana Abdul Bari as my religious guide.
('27', 467, 1, 8, 992744) His loving kindness holds me in bondage.
('27', 467, 1, 9, 992785) I deeply admire his sincerity of heart.
('27', 467, 1, 10, 992825) But in spite of all this I make bold to say that I have not yet found any person who in actual character is entitled to a higher place than Mahatma Gandhi.
('27', 467, 2, 11, 992981) But between belief and actual character there is a wide difference.
('27', 467, 2, 12, 993049) As a follower of Islam I am bound to regard the creed of Islam as superior to that professed by the followers of any non Islamic religion.
('27', 467, 2, 13, 993188) And in this sense the creed of even a fallen and degraded Mussalman is entitled to a higher place than that of any other non Muslim irrespective of his high character, even though the person in question be Mahatma Gandhi himself.
('27', 467, 3, 14, 993418) At Lucknow, when just before the commencement of my speech, some one placed a printed copy of the question in reference in my hand for reply (copies of which had also been freely distributed among the audience) I had stated that I did not want to answer any such questions, as I did not consider that anyone, unless he could prove that he bore a greater affection towards Mahatmaji than I did, was entitled to charge me with having reviled him.
('27', 467, 3, 15, 993863) It was only when I was told that the point at issue was not that I had reviled Mahatmaji, but that I had reviled the Hindu religion, that I gave the above stated reply.
('27', 467, 3, 16, 994032) A report of my speech had appeared in the Hamdam at
('27', 467, 4, 17, 994084) that time, i.e., about one month back.
('27', 467, 4, 18, 994123) I had said further therein that every Christian believed that a Christian, however degraded or fallen, was entitled to a higher place in regard to the matter of belief as contra distinguished from actual character than any Mussalman or Jew, irrespective of his high character and the same was the case with Hindus or followers of any other religion.
('27', 467, 4, 19, 994473) My reply proved so satisfactory that, as I have already mentioned, a Hindu friend shouted out that 22 crores of Hindus were prepared to stand by me and several Hindu members of the audience acclaimed it with cries of Bande Mataram, Allah o Akbar, while the persons who had brought the
('27', 467, 5, 20, 994758) printed copies of the question were completely silenced.
('27', 467, 5, 21, 994815) The beauty is that one of the friends who have now come forward with a requisition demanding my resignation had
('27', 468, 0, 1, 994927) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 469
('27', 468, 1, 2, 994971) quite recently sent a warm invitation to attend a public meeting at Dehra Dun.
('27', 468, 2, 3, 995050) I cannot under these circumstances possibly retire from any of my activities as a result of what these gentlemen might say or think.
('27', 468, 2, 4, 995183) Besides, the matter is well within the jurisdiction of the Congress.
('27', 468, 2, 5, 995252) I wish, however, to state here, and I hope you will bear me out in my statement, that if I, although I am the meanest and the most insignificant among the followers of Islam, am to be regarded by these gentlemen as an enemy of Hindu Muslim unity and a reviler of Mahatmaji and the religious principles which he professes, then I am afraid they will not find a single Mussalman who will completely satisfy them.
('27', 468, 3, 6, 995663) I beg to state once more that were I not bound by my promise to you, this letter might not have been written at all as I am most unwilling to add one more to the numberless controversies that are raging in the country at present.
('27', 468, 3, 7, 995893) As for the friends who have thought fit to raise such an unpleasant controversy at a time when the death of my daughter and the dangerous illness of a brother and mother have rendered me physically unfit to engage in any such controversy, I think it best to leave them to be judged by their own conscience.
('27', 468, 3, 8, 996200) I again beg to record my thanks to you for your condolence and with these words take my leave.
('27', 468, 3, 9, 996295) If you write anything to the Press in this connection, you may publish this letter as it is.
('27', 468, 4, 10, 996388) Yours, etc.,
('27', 468, 5, 11, 996401) MAHOMED ALI
('27', 468, 6, 12, 996413) Young India, 10 4 1924
('27', 468, 7, 13, 996436) (B) MAHOMED ALI’S LETTER TO THE EDITOR, “TEJ”
('27', 468, 8, 14, 996482) DEAR SIR, There was one sentence in Swamiji Maharaj’s letter which is liable to give the impression that I do not consider right action as essential for salvation.
('27', 468, 8, 15, 996646) That is not at all my belief nor that of any other Mussalman.
('27', 468, 8, 16, 996708) The essential conditions for salvation are faith, purity of action, persuading others to do good and to warn them against evil and to submit to all consequences of your actions with patience.
('27', 468, 8, 17, 996900) I hold that a non Moslem is perfectly entitled to reward for his good actions even as a Mussalman is liable to be punished for his evil deeds.
('27', 468, 8, 18, 997043) The point at issue was not at all as to the essential conditions for salvation, but only regarding the distinction between Belief and Conduct.
('27', 468, 8, 19, 997186) That is the reason why I gave to Mahatmaji the highest place among all the Mussalmans that I know of so far as actual character was concerned.
('27', 468, 8, 20, 997329) But to consider one’s creed as superior to that of every non Muslim is the duty of a Mussalman.
('27', 468, 8, 21, 997425) By stating this I refuted the charge of Gandhi worship levelled against me and that was precisely my object and not to hurt the feelings of my Hindu brethren or to revile Mahatma Gandhi.
('27', 468, 8, 22, 997612) If any one can have reason to complain, it is my own co religionists, none of whom I considered to be worthy of being ranked with Mahatma Gandhi in excellence of character.
('27', 468, 9, 23, 997785) MAHOMED ALI
('27', 468, 10, 24, 997797) Young India, 10 4 1924
('27', 469, 0, 1, 997820) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 470
('27', 469, 1, 2, 997862) APPENDIX VIII
('27', 469, 2, 3, 997876) (A) MOTILAL NEHRU’S NOTE ON COUNCIL ENTRY
('27', 469, 3, 4, 997918) I have read and re read Mahatmaji’s draft with all the attention I am capable of
('27', 469, 4, 5, 997999) and have allowed a whole week to elapse since it was handed to me.
('27', 469, 4, 6, 998066) I have also had the
('27', 469, 5, 7, 998086) advantage in this interval of discussing the draft with Mahatmaji for which he was
('27', 469, 6, 8, 998169) good enough to give me a long sitting of over three hours.
('27', 469, 6, 9, 998228) I have considered the
('27', 469, 7, 10, 998250) observations made by Mahatmaji in the course of that discussion with anxious care.
('27', 469, 8, 11, 998333) This long deliberation has, I am sorry to say, resulted only in confirming the opinion
('27', 469, 9, 12, 998420) I formed 18 months ago.
('27', 469, 10, 13, 998444) I agree that the difference between Mahatmaji and me is in some respects one of principle and not of mere detail.
('27', 469, 10, 14, 998558) Indeed, on closer examination, I have come to think that it goes deeper and lies more in the theory on which the principle is based than in the principle itself.
('27', 469, 10, 15, 998720) But with all that I am persuaded to believe that it does not and ought not to be allowed to affect the application of the principle in practice.
('27', 469, 10, 16, 998865) Let us take “non violence” and “non co operation” separately.
('27', 469, 11, 17, 998927) (1) “Non violence” Mahatmaji’s “non violence” is conceived on a very much higher plane than what I have agreed to adopt owing to the compelling necessity of the case.
('27', 469, 11, 18, 999095) The doctrine of ahimsa with all its implications and logical deductions has not been and cannot be adopted by the Congress which professes to include men of all religions and creeds in the world within its fold.
('27', 469, 11, 19, 999307) Islam does not recognize it as an invariable and inflexible rule of life and there are many Hindu castes and sects with which the judicious use of violence is an accepted article of faith.
('27', 469, 11, 20, 999496) Whilst Mahatmaji would not resort to violence under any circumstances whatever in thought, word or deed, many true Congressmen would, under certain conditions, consider it their highest duty to resort to actual physical violence.
('27', 469, 11, 21, 999726) In fact, I hold that it would be doing violence to the highest and noblest feelings implanted in man if we ruled out violence in any shape or form under all conceivable circumstances.
('27', 469, 11, 22, 999910) If I see a bully ill treating or assaulting a person weaker than himself, I would not merely interpose my body between the assailant and the victim and thus enable him to have two victims instead of one, but try to knock him down and thus save both his victim and myself.
('27', 469, 11, 23, 1000182) Again if I were assaulted, I would defend myself, if necessary, by inflicting violence on my assailant and that violence may under certain circumstances extend even to the causing of the assailants’s death.
('27', 469, 11, 24, 1000389) I need not give other illus trations of a similar nature which can easily be conceived.
('27', 469, 11, 25, 1000477) As for non violence in thought, it is obvious that one who is prepared to resort to actual violence on certain occasions cannot be entirely free from the thought of it.
('27', 469, 11, 26, 1000646) By joining the movement of non violent non co operation all I have undertaken to do is, to refrain from inflicting or even contemplating violence of any kind in carrying out the programme of non 
('27', 470, 0, 1, 1000842) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 471
('27', 470, 1, 2, 1000886) co operation against the Government.
('27', 470, 1, 3, 1000923) This is what I take Mahatmaji to mean, when he speaks of “non violence in its full sense, but restricted as the cause for which it was taken”.
('27', 470, 1, 4, 1001066) If a government official chooses to behave to me like the bully of my illustration in matters wholly unconnected with the Congress programme, he shall receive exactly the same treatment as I would give to the bully.
('27', 470, 1, 5, 1001282) The doctrine of non violence has, so far as I am concerned, a limited application for the very special purpose for which I have adopted it.
('27', 470, 2, 6, 1001422) Mahatmaji says entry into the Councils is “tantamount to participation in
('27', 470, 3, 7, 1001496) violence”.
('27', 470, 3, 8, 1001507) I understand this to refer to the fact that the Councils are established by a
('27', 470, 4, 9, 1001585) Government which is based on violence.
('27', 470, 4, 10, 1001624) I maintain that no one living under such a
('27', 470, 5, 11, 1001667) Government can help participating in violence in that sense.
('27', 470, 5, 12, 1001728) The very act of living
('27', 470, 6, 13, 1001751) and adopting the most essential means of sustaining life under such a government
('27', 470, 7, 14, 1001832) would be “tantamount to participation in violence”.
('27', 470, 7, 15, 1001884) Whether or not going into the
('27', 470, 8, 16, 1001914) Councils is a more direct participation in violence than merely living under a
('27', 470, 9, 17, 1001993) Government based on violence is only a question of degree and depends on the object
('27', 470, 10, 18, 1002077) with which one goes into the Councils.
('27', 470, 11, 19, 1002116) Mahatmaji has been pleased to doubt the accuracy of the statement that “nobody takes the extreme view of non violence that I do and that most Congressmen confine the definition of non violence to mere abstention from causing physical hurt to the opponent”.
('27', 470, 11, 20, 1002373) There may be some who take the extreme view in theory, but I do not know a single follower of Mahatmaji who acts upon it.
('27', 470, 11, 21, 1002495) It is true that non violence even in the limited sense that I give to it must relate both to word and deed and cannot be confined to abstention from causing physical hurt only.
('27', 470, 11, 22, 1002672) But non violence in thought must be ruled out entirely as impracticable.
('27', 470, 11, 23, 1002745) Otherwise, we shall be weaving a cobweb of casuistry around us from which it would be impossible to extricate ourselves.
('27', 470, 12, 24, 1002866) (2) Non co operation I confess my inability to see any trace of non co operation in the present day activities of the Congress.
('27', 470, 12, 25, 1002995) They may possibly lead to non co operation at some future date, but can by no stretch of imagination be taken to constitute non co operation.
('27', 470, 12, 26, 1003137) We have only the Bardoli programme before us, but there is nothing in it which can in any sense amount to actual non co operation with the Government.
('27', 470, 12, 27, 1003288) Mahatmaji says that the triple boycott has not failed because the lawyers have lost their prestige, the parents have lost faith in Government school education, and the Councils have lost their glamour.
('27', 470, 12, 28, 1003490) I admit all that and more for, in my opinion, the number of things lost can easily be multiplied.
('27', 470, 12, 29, 1003588) But the question is whether this has been due to the practice of the boycott or is the result of Mahatmaji’s teachings.
('27', 470, 12, 30, 1003708) And does it not show a far sadder state of things than that which existed before these boycotts were conceived?
('27', 470, 12, 31, 1003820) The number of lawyers and of the school going population has considerably increased and that of the Councillors remains the
('27', 471, 0, 1, 1003944) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 472
('27', 471, 1, 2, 1003986) The only difference is that, while before 1920 people took to the profession of law, sent their children to Government schools and entered the Councils honestly believing that they were doing the right thing, they did the same in 1921 23 with the knowledge and belief that they were doing a great wrong not only to themselves but to the whole nation.
('27', 471, 1, 3, 1004337) Has this improved the standard of public morality?
('27', 471, 1, 4, 1004388) The triple boycott has in my humble judgment only shown that the preaching of high ideals which the people are not ready to follow can only result in positive harm.
('27', 471, 1, 5, 1004553) The honest thing to do is to admit failure and frankly give up the triple boycott.
('27', 471, 1, 6, 1004636) The Swarajists would have done it had it not been for their belief that they had no chance of success with the masses against Mahatmaji’s teachings.
('27', 471, 1, 7, 1004785) The next best thing they could do was to introduce a real element of non co operation in the Councils.
('27', 471, 1, 8, 1004888) In this there can be no question that they have eminently succeeded.
('27', 471, 2, 9, 1004957) I shall now take the liberty to examine the case made out by Mahatmaji
('27', 471, 3, 10, 1005028) against Council entry.
('27', 471, 3, 11, 1005051) He makes a grave and serious charge against Swarajists by
('27', 471, 4, 12, 1005109) saying that “the entry into the Legislative bodies has retarded the progress towards
('27', 471, 5, 13, 1005194) swaraj”.
('27', 471, 5, 14, 1005203) I respectfully but emphatically join issue and maintain that exactly the
('27', 471, 6, 15, 1005276) contrary has been the case.
('27', 471, 6, 16, 1005304) What has actually happened is that the Assembly has laid
('27', 471, 7, 17, 1005361) a foundation for the people’s swaraj broad based on their free will and choice.
('27', 471, 8, 18, 1005441) Whether the demand made by the Assembly will be conceded or not is immaterial.
('27', 471, 9, 19, 1005520) Whether any actual progress towards swaraj through the Councils is possible or not is
('27', 471, 10, 20, 1005606) equally beside the point.
('27', 471, 10, 21, 1005632) But how any action taken in the Assembly or the Provincial
('27', 471, 11, 22, 1005691) Councils has actually “retarded the progress towards swaraj” simply beats my
('27', 471, 12, 23, 1005768) comprehension.
('27', 471, 12, 24, 1005783) I should have thought that the Swarajists have at least shown to a
('27', 471, 13, 25, 1005850) doubting world that they are a determined set of men who will have nothing short of
('27', 471, 14, 26, 1005934) swaraj.
('27', 471, 14, 27, 1005942) The positive value of this demonstration may perhaps be doubted, but it is
('27', 471, 15, 28, 1006017) hardly fair to attribute a negative value to it.
('27', 471, 16, 29, 1006066) I will now deal with the reasons given by Mahatmaji categorically.
('27', 471, 17, 30, 1006133) (a) Council entry is “tantamount to taking part directly or indirectly in the
('27', 471, 18, 31, 1006211) present system of Government”.
('27', 471, 18, 32, 1006242) There are innumerable things we do every day of our
('27', 471, 19, 33, 1006294) lives by which we take part directly or indirectly in the present system of
('27', 471, 20, 34, 1006370) Government.
('27', 471, 20, 35, 1006382) The objection, however, seems to be based on the assumption that the Legislative bodies are “a chief part of the machinery designed to sustain that
('27', 471, 21, 36, 1006530) system.” It would be more accurate to say that the Legislative bodies are merely an ornamental part of the machinery designed to justify the existing system.
('27', 471, 21, 37, 1006688) The truth is
('27', 471, 22, 38, 1006701) that the Government is absolutely independent of the Legislative bodies, which do
('27', 471, 23, 39, 1006783) not really sustain the system but are designed to conceal the fraud which the
('27', 471, 24, 40, 1006861) Government is practising on the world.
('27', 471, 24, 41, 1006900) The Swarajists have entered the Councils to
('27', 471, 25, 42, 1006944) expose this fraud not by taking part in it, but by refusing to take such part.
('27', 471, 25, 43, 1007023) I am at a
('27', 472, 0, 1, 1007033) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 473
('27', 472, 1, 2, 1007077) loss to reconcile this dictum of Mahatmaji with his acquiescence in Congressmen
('27', 472, 2, 3, 1007157) taking part in the Municipal Councils.
('27', 472, 2, 4, 1007196) A cursory perusal of the various Municipal
('27', 472, 3, 5, 1007239) Acts in force in this country will show that these bodies are a most essential part of
('27', 472, 4, 6, 1007326) the administration and can only be carried on by complete co operation with the
('27', 472, 5, 7, 1007406) Government in all important matters.
('27', 472, 5, 8, 1007443) They nullify the boycott of schools, for almost
('27', 472, 6, 9, 1007491) every Municipality applies for and obtains handsome grants from the public revenues
('27', 472, 7, 10, 1007575) to run the schools.
('27', 472, 7, 11, 1007595) They bring about the anomaly of Congressmen having to carry
('27', 472, 8, 12, 1007655) out policy of the Ministry appointed under the Government of India Act and
('27', 472, 9, 13, 1007730) submitting the former to the control the latter.
('27', 472, 9, 14, 1007779) There are many other things which do
('27', 472, 10, 15, 1007816) not merely smell of co operation but amount to direct participation in the system of
('27', 472, 11, 16, 1007901) Government.
('27', 472, 12, 17, 1007913) (b) “Obstruction” This is a very much misused and misapplied word, but I admit that our Swarajist nostrils are not trained enough to smell violence in it, and fail to see how the Swarajist programme can possibly have a stronger smell of violence than the breaking of the Criminal Law Amendment Act and the various forms of picketing and hartals authorized by the Congress.
('27', 472, 12, 18, 1008286) I take Civil Disobedience itself to be the highest form of obstruction.
('27', 472, 12, 19, 1008358) But let us not lay undue stress on words and consider what the Swarajists have actually done.
('27', 472, 12, 20, 1008452) They have carried out the programme to the full in C.P. Let us see what has been done there.
('27', 472, 12, 21, 1008545) The first step taken was to pass a vote of “No confidence” in the Ministers.
('27', 472, 12, 22, 1008622) That really meant no confidence in the system which brought Ministers into existence and that was made perfectly clear in the speeches made in support of the motion.
('27', 472, 12, 23, 1008788) The Government did not dismiss the Ministers as it should have done after this vote.
('27', 472, 12, 24, 1008873) The next step taken was to refuse the salaries of the Ministers, but they continued to stick to their offices and introduce measures relating to their departments.
('27', 472, 12, 25, 1009037) These measures were all rejected, because the Council refused to recognize the Ministers after the vote of “No Confidence” and the refusal of their salaries.
('27', 472, 12, 26, 1009195) Then came the budget on which the Council had no effective control.
('27', 472, 12, 27, 1009263) It was thrown out on the express ground that the Council would be no party to the expenditure of public revenues in the raising of which it had no voice and in the spending of which it had no control.
('27', 472, 12, 28, 1009464) Some other Bills were thrown out on similar grounds.
('27', 472, 12, 29, 1009517) This is all that has happened.
('27', 472, 12, 30, 1009548) I invite an examination of each of these acts of the Swarajists on its own merit and ask if any objection can be taken to any one of them on the highest moral and ethical grounds.
('27', 472, 12, 31, 1009728) The same acts can be and have been described as acts of obstruction, acts of destruction, and acts of wrecking from various points of view.
('27', 472, 12, 32, 1009868) But nothing turns upon mere phrases.
('27', 472, 12, 33, 1009905) What you have to look to is the substance and I claim that what was done in the C.P. in substance was non co operation with a Government which paid no heed to the popular will.
('27', 472, 12, 34, 1010082) The same applies to the acts of the Swarajists in the Assembly and the Bengal Council.
('27', 472, 13, 35, 1010169) (c) “Constructive Programme.” I could not understand what this objection
('27', 473, 0, 1, 1010242) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 474
('27', 473, 1, 2, 1010284) meant; but Mahatmaji has since explained to me that all that it meant was that the time and energy given to the question of Council entry was so much time and energy taken away from the constructive programme.
('27', 473, 1, 3, 1010494) So far as that goes it applies only to the No changers, for the Swarajists were practically expelled from the Congress Executive and had no control on the organizations of the various department of the constructive programme.
('27', 473, 1, 4, 1010720) The only alternatives to Council entry open to them were either to go into retirement or start independent organizations to carry on the constructive programme, neither of which would have helped the cause.
('27', 473, 2, 5, 1010927) (d) “Entry is premature” I am afraid I do not quite grasp this objection.
('27', 473, 2, 6, 1011001) If it means that we should have waited till we got swaraj it begs the whole question.
('27', 473, 2, 7, 1011087) As for a “constant, almost irresistible temptation to depart from truthfulness and non violence in the atmosphere of the Councils”, all I can say is that I have perceived no difference in the Council atmosphere from that outside the Councils.
('27', 473, 2, 8, 1011330) The “strain” on discipline will certainly not be more prolonged in the Councils than it is sure to be in the long expectation of Civil Disobedience.
('27', 473, 3, 9, 1011479) (e) “Khilafat and Punjab causes” Apart from the fact that these causes are practically dead, I do not see what special connection there is between them and the question of entry into the Councils.
('27', 473, 4, 10, 1011676) The above are the principal reasons given by Mahatmaji against the entry of Congressmen into the Councils.
('27', 473, 4, 11, 1011783) A few other points are mentioned in the passing in the course of the general remarks that follow the main reasons.
('27', 473, 4, 12, 1011898) After acknowledging the “brilliant victories of the Swarajists”, Mahatmaji proceeds to point out that all that the Swarajists have done could be achieved “before non co operation”, that we could, “not merely get a Gandhi released, but many Hasrat Mohanis and all Punjab prisoners” by “fairly directed agitation” and that there is not “much in the khaddar demonstration, or in keeping so many Moderates out”.
('27', 473, 4, 13, 1012306) “The machinery of the Government goes on unchecked with or without the Moderates and in spite of obstruction.” In adopting this line of argument, Mahatmaji has done less than justice to himself.
('27', 473, 4, 14, 1012501) The Swarajists have never taken any credit for the release of Mahatmaji or the demonstration of khaddar, but they have certainly succeeded in keeping the Moderates out which the boycott of Councils under Mahatmaji’s programme could not achieve.
('27', 473, 4, 15, 1012746) I agree that the real machinery of the Government goes on unchecked, but we claim that we have taken out the false and ornamental parts of the machinery and exposed its true character to the world.
('27', 473, 4, 16, 1012944) If it was right to send thirty thousand of our workers to gaol simply to establish the fact that the visit of the Prince of Wales was forced upon a discontented people, it was certainly worth something to expose the continuing fraud practised day to day in the name of the representatives of the people.
('27', 473, 5, 17, 1013248) The unkindest cut of all is contained in the sentence: “It was not to be expected that the Swarajists could be convinced by any argument.” All I can say is that the
('27', 474, 0, 1, 1013413) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 475
('27', 474, 1, 2, 1013457) Swarajists in all humility claim to exercise their own judgment and have not yet heard anything that could carry conviction to them.
('27', 474, 2, 3, 1013590) After this Mahatmaji makes one or two more observations which must be noticed.
('27', 474, 2, 4, 1013669) He says, “I would enter the Councils only if I could believe that I could make use of them for the advanceement of the country.
('27', 474, 2, 5, 1013797) I must therefore have faith in the machinery and those in charge of it.
('27', 474, 2, 6, 1013869) I cannot be part of the machinery and still want to destroy it.” I venture to submit that this argument suffers from the weakness of all arguments based on analogies and metaphors.
('27', 474, 2, 7, 1014050) I do not see why one must have faith in those whom one finds in charge of machinery, if it can be worked better by others.
('27', 474, 2, 8, 1014173) I should have thought that the most perfect machinery could be so hopelessly mismanaged by those in charge as to require their immediate removal.
('27', 474, 2, 9, 1014319) There can be no harm in taking over a rickety old machine from the hands of mechanics bent on evil, and try to run it after proper repairs for the benefit of those in whose interest it ought to be worked.
('27', 474, 2, 10, 1014524) We have not become parts of the machinery in order to destroy it.
('27', 474, 2, 11, 1014590) There are certain imported parts of the machine which destroy the goods in the process of manufacture.
('27', 474, 2, 12, 1014693) We are for the present taking out those parts and substituting ourselves for them, hoping eventually to have an entirely new machine of pure swadeshi make to be run by the people for the people.
('27', 474, 3, 13, 1014888) I now come to that part of the draft note where Mahatmaji, looking upon Council entry as a settled fact, answers the question: “What is to be done now ?” As was to be expected, he has given the only answer which the resolutions of the Delhi and Cocanda Congress could admit of.
('27', 474, 3, 14, 1015166) But I venture to think that something more than a mere interpretation of those resolution is necessary.
('27', 474, 3, 15, 1015270) The most important point to be considered is what is to be the position of the Swarajists in the general Congress movement.
('27', 474, 3, 16, 1015394) Is it to be somewhat similar to that assigned by Mahatmaji to practising lawyers who were compared to cobblers and declared debarred from taking an active part in the Counsels of the Congress and from being appointed on its Executive?
('27', 474, 3, 17, 1015629) If that is the idea, Swarajists must deprive themselves of the honour of remaining under the distinguished leadership of Mahatmaji and, either retire from public life or look for “fresh fields and pastures new”.
('27', 474, 3, 18, 1015841) But if that is not the idea, I believe it is yet possible to work together for the common cause.
('27', 474, 3, 19, 1015938) Certain proposals have occurred to me in this connection and I put them in the order in which they appeal to me.
('27', 474, 4, 20, 1016051) 1. A new programme of work in the Councils may be framed by the Congress with the object of helping the outside activities of the Congress in the direction of “construction” and “non co operation”.
('27', 474, 4, 21, 1016249) The programme so framed will then stand in place of a mandate from the country which every Swarajist would be bound to carry out and all Congressmen bound to support.
('27', 474, 4, 22, 1016416) In this case, all distinction between Swarajists and Non Swarajists or Pro changers and No changers will disappear, but while all will act together, generally such Congressmen will only go into the Councils as have no objection to do so.
('27', 474, 4, 23, 1016654) Funds required for Council propaganda will be granted by the vote of the Working Committee subject to the control of the All India
('27', 475, 0, 1, 1016785) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 476
('27', 475, 1, 2, 1016827) Committee exactly in the same manner as for other Congress purposes, and with due regard to the relative importance of the various heads of Congress expenditure.
('27', 475, 1, 3, 1016989) It will be permissible to donors to the Tilak Swaraj Fund to earmark their contribution for Councils if they choose.
('27', 475, 2, 4, 1017106) 2. A separate section or department of the Congress called the Councils Section or department may be opened and placed in sole charge and direction of the Swarajists.
('27', 475, 2, 5, 1017273) The latter will take part in the general activities of the Congress outside the Councils and help those activities in the Councils as desired by the Congress.
('27', 475, 2, 6, 1017432) In this case also, there will be some Swarajists on the General Executive but no financial help will be given from Tilak Swaraj Fund not earmarked for the Councils.
('27', 475, 3, 7, 1017597) difference between the first proposal and this is that, while in the former case the Congress will lay down the whole programme for the Councils in the latter case it will only call upon the Swarajists to take particular steps such as those referred to by Mahatmaji at the end of his draft, viz., the propagation of khaddar and the abolition of drink revenue.
('27', 475, 4, 8, 1017957) 3. To carry on as now under the Delhi and Cocanada resolutions without any disqualification attaching to Swarajists as such.
('27', 475, 4, 9, 1018082) In this case Swarajists will frame and carry out their own policy without reference to the Congres and will collect their own funds and the Congress will not in any way interfere with them.
('27', 475, 4, 10, 1018272) The Swarajya Party will do all it can to carry out the constructive programme of the Congress and the Congress will help and support that action.

('27', 475, 6, 12, 1018452) (B) EXTRACT FROM C. R. DAS’S LETTER
('27', 475, 7, 13, 1018488) CALCUTTA, April 18, 1924
('27', 475, 8, 14, 1018513) Motilal has sent me a draft containing your views in the Council entry question.
('27', 475, 8, 15, 1018594) I am very anxious to discuss one or two points raised in it by you.
('27', 475, 8, 16, 1018662) You may be right in your view on the question of non co operation if non co operation is construed very strictly.
('27', 475, 8, 17, 1018776) But as it is I do not see eye to eye with you on the question of non violence.
('27', 475, 8, 18, 1018855) I believe in non violence as a principle and it is very unfortunate that doctors will not allow me to go and discuss the whole matter with you.
('27', 475, 8, 19, 1018999) I am dictating this letter under very great difficulty.
('27', 475, 8, 20, 1019055) Will it be very inconvenient if you postpone the publication of your views till I am well enough to see you?
('27', 475, 8, 21, 1019164) It may sound presumptuous but I feel that, if the Delhi compromise is suddenly upset, the whole country will be engaged again in philosophical discussions which will materially interfere with the larger work.
('27', 475, 8, 22, 1019373) I have to be here till the 23rd for medical treatment and after that the proposal is that I should go to Darjeeling and remain there at least a month.
