('27', 476, 0, 1, 1019552) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 477
('27', 476, 1, 2, 1019596) APPENDIX IX
('27', 476, 2, 3, 1019608) LETTER FROM BHAGWAN DAS
('27', 476, 3, 4, 1019632) TO, THE EDITOR,
('27', 476, 4, 5, 1019648) YOUNG INDIA
('27', 476, 6, 6, 1019660) In Young India for 17 4 1924, in the course of your article headed
('27', 476, 7, 7, 1019727) “Schoolmasters and Lawyers”, the following sentences occur at p.
('27', 476, 8, 8, 1019792) “But it is a difficulty which we have to face boldly, even heroically, if our desire is to establish swaraj for the people, not substitute one class rule by another, which may be even worse.” And again: “If under swaraj we shall have to make the town life correspond to the village life, we shall be bound to simplify the town mode of life.”
('27', 476, 9, 9, 1020134) I most earnestly invite your attention and the attention of all readers of Young India to the implication of these two ifs, and to their vitally important bearing on the
('27', 476, 10, 10, 1020304) whole N.C.O. movement and the struggles for swaraj, along various tines, by various methods of the various parties which accept the new creed of the Congress wherein ‘swaraj’ is used without any definition or specification of any kind.
('27', 476, 11, 11, 1020540) Some of us are convinced that it is just these unsolved and unsettled ifs which
('27', 476, 12, 12, 1020620) are the root cause of all the many defects which are hampering and marring the N.C.O. movement.
('27', 476, 12, 13, 1020716) So long as these ifs remain unsettled, there will never be mutual trust
('27', 476, 13, 14, 1020788) between any two classes, any two creeds, any two castes, it might almost be said, any two workers, oat of all those who all want swaraj and who all disagree as to what it should be.
('27', 476, 14, 15, 1020970) Because the unity secured by a mere word, an understood, ill understood, mis understood word, is a very false unity, therefore is it breaking down perpetually—into violence of thought and language in political controversies and of deed also in Hindu Muslim riots; therefore is the movement failing in so many respects—in respect of even minded perseverance, Of discipline, of organization, of systematic work, whether destructive or constructive.
('27', 476, 15, 16, 1021417) Shortly after the first sentence quoted above, you say, “Hitherto the villagers
('27', 476, 16, 17, 1021497) have died in their thousands so that we might live, now we might have to die so that
('27', 476, 17, 18, 1021582) they may live.” But “we” (i.e., townsfolk) are also included in “the people” for whom
('27', 476, 18, 19, 1021668) swaraj is to be established; are “we” not?
('27', 476, 18, 20, 1021711) and a large proportion of the townsfolk are
('27', 476, 19, 21, 1021755) as ill off as the country folk, are they not?
('27', 476, 20, 22, 1021801) Because townsmen have been vaguely feeling that the swaraj of the N.C.O. movement, unknown as it is, is yet likely to destroy towns (witness the cries of
('27', 477, 0, 1, 1021955) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 478
('27', 477, 1, 2, 1021997) “Bolshevism” raised against it), therefore, they are naturally not enthusiastic about it in their hearts.
('27', 477, 1, 3, 1022103) For, the larger bulk of Tilak Swaraj Fund has come from towns; Bombay first and foremost.
('27', 477, 1, 4, 1022193) It has come from the people whose trade and means of livelihood the constructive and destructive programme of the N.C O. movement tends to undermine, directly or indirectly.
('27', 477, 1, 5, 1022367) That it has so come is due partly to the affectionate respect in which your personality is held by Indians of ail classes, and partly to the hope that, after all, the wished for swaraj will not run utterly amuck against the towns, but will only try to mend the evils in them.
('27', 477, 2, 6, 1022643) The disappearance of towns will mean the disappearance of Lakshmi and of Saraswati.
('27', 477, 2, 7, 1022727) And Gauri Annapurna, disporting by herself in the corn fields, however ‘full of grain’, will fail to make human life richly artistic, scientifically intelligent, and.
('27', 477, 2, 8, 1022894) therefore interesting.
('27', 477, 2, 9, 1022917) What is needed is a balancing of the three great goddesses,
('27', 477, 3, 10, 1022977) universally worshipped by human beings of all creeds, all times, all climes; and not a sacrificing of any one of them.
('27', 477, 3, 11, 1023096) Ayodhya flourished in Ramarajya, though Lanka was
('27', 477, 4, 12, 1023146) partly destroyed.
('27', 477, 5, 13, 1023164) You, fortunately for our peace of mind, yourself say in a later para, “We shall
('27', 477, 6, 14, 1023244) be bound to simplify the town mode of life.” This is likely to relieve somewhat the
('27', 477, 7, 15, 1023328) terrors caused by the earlier sentences, though it may not bring complete reassurance.
('27', 477, 8, 16, 1023415) “Moderation”, “the golden mean”, “the middle course”, temperance” —this is what the bulk of humanity instinctively craves for and strives after.
('27', 477, 8, 17, 1023560) Unless you, as the leader of our leaders, place before India, some outline scheme of swaraj which will bring to all sections of the people the hope that none of them will be destroyed entirely, though the excesses of all or any will be duly curtailed—unless and until this is done, no section of the people will be able to give its whole heart to the struggle, and true unity in the striving for swaraj will never be achieved and therefore swaraj, true swaraj will never never be achieved.
('27', 477, 9, 18, 1024050) The space in Young India is limited and precious, and I must not ask for too
('27', 477, 10, 19, 1024127) much of it—though I sincerely believe that no topic that has ever yet been written about in its columns is of deeper importance or farther reaching consequences than this, viz., of the kind of swaraj that India needs.
('27', 477, 11, 20, 1024345) I have been pressing the matter on the attention of the general public,
('27', 477, 12, 21, 1024417) on that of the Congress Committees of all grades (from the Banaras local
('27', 477, 13, 22, 1024490) to the all lndia) and on that of the individual leaders, for the last three wears, in
('27', 477, 14, 23, 1024576) season and out of season.
('27', 477, 14, 24, 1024602) I have been pursuing you with letters and printed papers
('27', 477, 15, 25, 1024659) on the subject practically up to the moment of your arrest, and, again since you
('27', 477, 16, 26, 1024740) came out.
('27', 477, 16, 27, 1024750) I must not repeat here what 1 have said over and over again elsewhere.
('27', 477, 17, 28, 1024821) My hopes were greatly aroused, for a brief while, in the beginning of 1923,
('27', 477, 18, 29, 1024897) that the subject would meet with the consideration it deserved, when a leader of
('27', 478, 0, 1, 1024978) VOL. 27 : 12 JANUARY, 1924 21 MAY, 1924 479
('27', 478, 1, 2, 1025022) such note as Deshbandhu Das interested himself in it, for some time.
('27', 478, 1, 3, 1025091) But that
('27', 478, 2, 4, 1025100) ‘brief while’ was over, very soon.
('27', 478, 2, 5, 1025135) And I have been gradually settling down to the
('27', 478, 3, 6, 1025182) belief that “the time is not ripe” for the discussion of the subject.
('27', 478, 4, 7, 1025252) But my eyes happened to light upon the two very significant ifs in your
('27', 478, 5, 8, 1025324) article, and I was galvanized into this present further effort.
('27', 478, 6, 9, 1025388) Some of us will feel profoundly grateful if you will very kindly say something, in Young India, on this subject—so near to the heart of these “some of us”—
('27', 478, 7, 10, 1025544) something which may shoot a gleam of light through the gloom of our despair.
('27', 478, 8, 11, 1025621) I am, etc.,
('27', 478, 9, 12, 1025633) BHAGWAN DAS
('27', 478, 10, 13, 1025645) Young India, 8 5 1924
